HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Bill Clinton's Center

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
With apologies to Art Buchwald, who had a similar dream in 1965 . . .
I awoke with a shudder the other morning from a terrible dream. I dreamt that George Bush had been re-elected last fall, and the country still had a President who was paralyzed by fear of the political right. 
 In the dream Bush caved in to right-wing opponents of civil rights laws. Under attack from them he withdrew his nomination of a personal friend, a law professor, to enforce those laws.
Bush tried to do something for the budget and the environment by setting realistic fees for grazing cattle on Federal lands. But ranchers objected, and Bush caved in again.
The wimp factor: That's what the dream brought back, memories of a President who did not have the courage of his convictions. Or did not have convictions.
Bosnia was the most painful part of the dream. President Bush went on wringing his hands and doing nothing. And the Serbs went on raping and killing and terrorizing the Bosnian Muslims to force them out.
Bush gave China most-favored-nation treatment for another year despite new accounts of Chinese cruelty toward political prisoners. He made only a dubious promise to impose human rights conditions next year.
Humanitarian pleas for Haitian political refugees got nowhere either. Bush kept turning the refugees back without giving them a chance to prove they were entitled to political asylum. He continued to hold H.I.V.-positive refugees in a Guantanamo prison camp.
The right won another victory in my dream, small but especially sweet for Jesse Helms. The Justice Department asked for reversal of a Federal judge's decision that the "decency clause" added to the standard for Federal arts grants violated the First Amendment.
If Bill Clinton had been elected, I thought, those things could not have happened. The censors and the opponents of civil rights enforcement would have lost their clout. Strong American leadership in the world would have supported human rights. The country would have seen change, vigor, courage . . .
Of course it is unfair to Bill Clinton to suggest by irony that George Bush might as well be President. Some things have changed. Mr. Clinton signed the voter registration and family leave bills that Mr. Bush vetoed. He did away with the infamous abortion gag rule.
Moreover, real choices are harder than campaign promises. China has economic power. Admitting Haitians, even victims of persecution, has political costs.
But there is something profoundly wrong with Bill Clinton's Presidency. No one knows that more than those of us who thought the country needed real change.
The Lani Guinier episode represented failure both political and moral. The bungling ended in an outright misrepresentation -- that Mr. Clinton's decision to withdraw her nomination had no political basis.
The result will embolden right-wing obstructionists. In the civil rights field, it will make more difficult reasoned discussion, long overdue, of the gerrymandered "minority districts" that trouble Professor Guinier.
And the Guinier affair was only the latest example of capitulation and chaos in this White House. The record is full of jobs dangled and then withdrawn. Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago was asked to be Secretary of Transportation; he said yes, but then the job wasn't there.
To show he is moving to the center, Mr. Clinton has hired David Gergen. Mr. Gergen is a fine man, but he is not a substantive political figure -- a representative Republican, say. He is an opinion-shaper.
With 43 percent of the vote, Mr. Clinton should be near the center. But the way to have done that, to broaden his base, was to include moderate Republicans in his Administration at the start.
Mistakes can be corrected. What is worrying about Bill Clinton is the possibility that something fundamental is lacking in this very smart man. He may inadvertently have said it in his comment on dropping Lani Guinier: "This is about my center, not about the political center."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Essay;
Cheer Up, Europe

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Europe is entering the third millennium the same way it entered the second -- with the Christians kicking the Muslims out.
Many civilized Europeans are troubled by their New Barbarism. They are embarrassed at the way Turkish workers, denied citizenship, are being harassed in a Germany still arrogant about ethnic purity. 
 They are ashamed of their craven solution to the Balkan war -- with Bosnian Muslims being herded into refugee camps, where hatreds will fester and vengeance will be vowed.
That's one reason for the gloom pervading this continent. A more plebeian reason is that business is lousy. The unexpected price of German unity led to the albatross of high interest rates, which has aborted recovery.
On top of all that, the utopian promise of 1993 -- political as well as economic integration, creating global competition for the Asian and American markets -- has been dashed by the reality of nationalism.
No wonder Europeans are savaging their leaders. In France, Mitterrand is on his last legs, his Socialists swept from power; in Britain, Major has sunk lower in the polls than any Prime Minister since polling began; in Germany, Kohl ducks Muslim funerals to appeal to his resentful right; Italian politicians by the score have been charged with being in the pockets of the Mafia. By the 1995 G-7 meeting, Bill Clinton may be the veteran among rookies.
At such a low point, the poet Milton come to mind: "Hence, loathed Melancholy!" (Modern poets would render that as "Gedoutahere, Gloom!")
Consider all that Europe's nations have going for them.
Hard times are doing what hard times are supposed to do: force an end to business inefficiency long encouraged by government-protected featherbedding. In post-Socialist France, 20 of the biggest companies -- including Air France and Renault -- will be privatized, and despite the anguish of managers being fired, the slimmed-down companies will be competitive. Complacent German automakers, too, have been awakened to the real world.
On Europe's ideological front, there's little left of the left. The discredited notions of redistribution of wealth, reward for doing nothing, penalties for enterprise and success -- the ideas that undermined the profit motive and hold down standards of living -- are being abandoned even in Sweden. The complaining is heavy from the entitlement brigades, but the direction is right.
While concentrating on the ethnic problems caused by the cold war's end, too many of what Mr. Clinton at home calls "the preachers of pessimism" overlook the benefits: Spending on armaments, which are essentially unproductive, will continue to be cut. Fear of the Russians may have been a unifier, but the absence of the fear of a loss of freedom is an undeniable value.
Even the integration of Europe is now being approached with less messianic zeal. Monetary union hasn't worked. The good sense of the Danes resulted in a loosening of the bonds of political union; only because of new "reservations" of sovereignty did Denmark's referendum approve the flawed Maastricht treaty. As the Brits and others demand the same flexibility, the result should help the European Community without giving Brusselscrats the power to crush national diversity.
The business cycle will do its turn; animal spirits will revive; dejection will lift and prosperity will again be taken for granted. What then?
Then the nations of western Europe will have no ready excuse for denying opportunity to the former Soviet bloc; or for refusing to share their rights of full citizenship with longtime residents; or for unconscionably turning their backs on the victims of invasion, repression and genocide.
Today, in the grip of gloom, the tired leaders of Europe's nations have failed their first post-cold-war test in the Balkans and imperiled the continuance of the American presence here.
Tomorrow, on the rebound, Europe's new leaders will be called on to decide whether Europe will be the cradle or the grave of the "right to intervene" to defend human rights.
If so, they will find the American President as their ally in the advancement of freedom. If not -- if they let the coming prosperity's vain deluding joys bedazzle them -- they will justify the doubts of today's prophets of doom.

HEADLINE: Guatemala's New Chief Ousts Some Top Officers

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, June 7

 BODY:
The former human rights ombudsman who is Guatemala's new President, Ramiro de Leon Carpio, moved quickly today against the military high command, sweeping out some officers who played leading roles in the political turmoil of the last two weeks.
On his first full day as Commander in Chief of the armed forces, Mr. de Leon Carpio ordered the retirement of the Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Domingo Garcia Samayoa, and the transfer of several other commanders. 
The new orders also promoted some officers who were said by diplomats to have challenged the seizure of almost dictatorial powers by former President Jorge Serrano Elias on May 25 and to have pushed successfully for Mr. Serrano's overthrow.
But as his new Defense Minister, Mr. de Leon Carpio named Gen. Roberto Perussina, a senior officer viewed by some diplomats and Guatemalan military analysts as a leader of the harder-line faction within the army.
In making the changes, Mr. de Leon Carpio seemed to try to capitalize on both the wide popularity with which he took office early Sunday and the sudden weakness of military leaders who intervened and reversed themselves several times in the political crisis.
As the so-called Attorney General of Human Rights, Mr. de Leon Carpio forged a reputation as the Guatemalan official most willing to challenge the power of the armed forces, accusing soldiers and officers in cases of serious abuses. But analysts said it was unlikely that the military would strike back against the new President now because the former high command had drawn significant opposition from within the officer corps by supporting Mr. Serrano.
"There's no doubt that this situation is not only difficult but strange," Mr. de Leon Carpio said in an interview today.
"Now, taking the position of President of the republic and the responsibility of Commander in Chief of the army, there is no doubt that the army will have to accept it," he added.
General Garcia Samayoa and other members of the military command initially supported Mr. Serrano when he dissolved the Congress and suspended the Constitution two weeks ago. But under strong internal and international pressure, they forced him from power on June 1 in a move that was praised by political and business leaders and others, including Mr. de Leon Carpio.
The next day, General Garcia Samayoa reversed himself again, backing the attempted succession of Mr. Serrano's Vice President, Gustavo Espina Salguero. But late Friday, the military command once again bowed to public pressure, turning against Mr. Espina, and ultimately allowing the inauguration of Mr. de Leon Carpio.
The new Government was warmly welcomed today by Latin American and European countries and by the United States, which promised to renew the economic and military aid it suspended after Mr. Serrano's moves two weeks ago.
Meanwhile, officials in Panama announced that Mr. Serrano had taken refuge there. Although there were unconfirmed reports that he had been granted political asylum, Guatemalan prosecutors said they would continue to seek his extradition to face charges that include corruption and violating the Constitution.
Guatemala news reports this morning had predicted that the Defense Ministry would go to Gen. Mario Rene Enriquez, the military's Deputy Chief of Staff and an officer with a reputation for being relatively open and democratic.
General Enriquez was promoted to Chief of Staff. But the more powerful Defense Minister's job went to General Perussina, a more senior officer who had been the Chief of Staff. Despite his reputation as a hard-liner, some military analysts said that General Perussina was also an opponent of heavy military involvement in political affairs and that his promotion might have been a concession to the military hierarchy.
Perhaps more important than General Garcia Samayoa's retirement, the analysts said, was the transfer of the powerful head of the presidential military staff, Gen. Francisco Ortega Menaldo, to a remote army garrison. General Ortega was said by many observers of the military to have been a crucial supporter of Mr. Serrano's seizure of power and of the brief move to seat Mr. Espina as President.
General Ortega was replaced by Col. Otto Perez, who was widely said to have been removed from his post as chief of military intelligence because of his strong opposition to the actions of Mr. Serrano.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ramiro de Leon Carpio with his mother after he was elected President of Guatemala on Saturday. (Reuters)

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1285 words

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Answer: Cut Entitlements. Question: But How?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Like a weed run rampant, entitlement programs are taking over the Federal budget, and unless they are brought under control, politicians and economists agree, no hope exists for lowering the deficit in the long run.
The issue dominated the House debate on President Clinton's budget last month and is sure to be a main element of the debate in the Senate later this month. 
 But controlling entitlements -- Government programs like Social Security and welfare that make automatic payments to everyone who is eligible -- is no easier than stopping the spread of kudzu in the Carolinas, since it involves choices no politician wants to make.
 
Why It's So Hard
 "Cutting entitlements sounds painless," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist. "But when you examine the specifics, you realize this is the third rail of American politics."
Here is why it is so hard: The only politically realistic way to slow the growth in entitlement spending is to reduce the costs of Medicare and Medicaid, the main Government health programs. The only way to do that is to rein in the overall cost of health care. The only practical way to do that is to overhaul the whole health-care system.
And, as the deliberations of the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform have shown, changing the health-care system entails raising taxes, which is exactly what the lawmakers who say they want to lower the deficit by reducing entitlements want to avoid.
But that has not stopped politicians from advocating cutting or freezing entitlements, the political equivalent of a Potemkin village. It was a central feature of the Presidential campaign of George Bush last year and of the economic views of his budget director, Richard G. Darman. Prominent senators of both parties favor such steps in principle.
 
'Suggesting Big Savings'
 Last month, as the price of support for his economic plan from some recalcitrant Democrats in the House, President Clinton agreed to new budget rules that would force the White House and Congress to respond if spending for entitlement programs rose beyond official projections.
Most of this, say economists and budget analysts on both the left and the right, is simply political hot air.
"It's a way of suggesting big savings that will never be delivered," said Stuart M. Butler, the director of domestic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization.
The only responsible way to advocate reducing entitlement spending, Mr. Butler said, is to say precisely which programs would be cut and by how much -- something politicians rarely do.
There are dozens of entitlement programs, including prominent ones like Social Security, food stamps and farm price supports and obscure ones like money for witnesses in Federal trials and subsidies to farmers who agree not to cultivate environmentally sensitive land.
What they have in common is that the money is spent each year without the annual review accorded programs that need new appropriations from Congress. Altogether, they will cost $770 billion this year, more than half the Federal budget and four-fifths of all the spending, not counting what goes for the military or interest on the debt.
 
Running Rampant
 More than two-thirds of all this entitlement money, $528 billion, will be spent on only three programs: Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid. And only two entitlement programs are actually running rampant: Medicare, which covers the medical costs for the elderly and the disabled, and Medicaid, the state-Federal health program for the poor.
Social Security is growing no faster than the general growth in the economy, and the increases in the taxes that support it in the 1980's more than made up for rising benefits being paid out to retirees.
Many of the other entitlement programs, including food stamps and Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare programs, have failed for years to keep pace with inflation and the growth in the eligible population.
In fact, even if the Government abolishes food stamps, welfare, farm price supports, child nutrition programs and veterans' pensions -- an extreme step that no one is advocating -- entitlement spending would still be a higher percentage of the Federal budget in 1998 than it is now, unless Medicare and Medicaid costs are reduced.
Spending on Medicare and Medicaid rose from $48 billion in 1980, or 8 percent of the budget, to $196 billion last year, or 14 percent of the budget. If nothing is done to change the law, the cost of the two programs will more than double by 1988, to $405 billion, or 22 percent of total spending, according to Congressional Budget Office projections.
 
'Sea of Red Ink'
 And by 2003, the Federal budget deficit, now about $300 billion, will have grown to nearly $700 billion, "making the current sea of red ink look more like a puddle," Mr. Reischauer said.
Letitia Chambers, a public policy consultant here who specializes in budget matters, said that all the political talk about limiting entitlement spending masked the true problem. "The real issue," she said in an interview last week, "is that Medicare and Medicaid have gone through the roof."
Actually, those programs have grown less than health-care costs generally in recent years, although Medicaid spending doubled from 1989 to 1992 largely because the recession caused so many more people to become eligible.
President Clinton has proposed cutting Medicare by about $50 billion over the next five years, and the Senate Finance Committee is prepared to cut an additional $31 billion, said the panel's chairman, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York. But the cuts will not come cheaply.
Many cost-cutting measures in the Government's health programs alone have been counterproductive. For example, when the Government has put limits on Medicare payments to hospitals, doctors and laboratories, they have generally responded by charging patients more when the patients are covered by private insurance. The effect has amounted to a hidden tax on the general public in the form of higher insurance premiums.
"The way health care works these days," said Stanley E. Collender, a budget specialist at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, "if you cut Medicare and Medicaid, you and I are going to pay for it, pure and simple."
This does not mean entitlements cannot be cut. For example, Social Security payments to the wealthy could be withheld, or cost-of-living increases in retirement benefits could be abolished. Medicare premiums for outpatient care could be increased substantially, or upper-income retirees could be asked to pay more of their hospital bills out of pocket.
But such steps would be so unpopular that they would amount to political suicide for many who voted for them.
So rather than talking about the specifics, politicians embrace the word "entitlement."
The word used to be a euphemism for welfare, but now it mostly refers to benefits enjoyed by the general public. Eighty percent of entitlement payments do not take account of the recipient's income.
By making benign-sounding proposals like freezes or caps, politicians avoid the risk that voters will tally up what the proposals would cost them personally.
Mr. Bush advocated such proposals. And that is the stand taken by Representative Charles W. Stenholm, a Texas Democrat, and most Republicans in the House and by Senators Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, a Republican, and Sam Nunn of Georgia, a Democrat, among others.
"It's as if they're proposing holding back the tide," said Mr. Butler of the Heritage Foundation.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Rises

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
American consumers increased their borrowing for the ninth consecutive month in April, bringing their total debt to a record high, the Government reported today.
Consumer installment credit outstanding rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.6 percent, to $754 billion, the Federal Reserve said. 
 April's gain followed a 4.7 percent rate advance in March and a 7.4 percent rate increase in February. The last decline in consumer credit came last July, which marked the 14th drop in 20 months.
During the recession, consumers reduced their borrowing and sought to pay down debts, but since last summer they seem to have been less leery of taking on added debt.
But economists say consumers could turn cautious again without continued improvement in the job market. The nation's unemployment rate in May was 6.9 percent, down from 7 percent from February through April and an eight-year high of 7.7 percent last June.
In April, the biggest gain in credit outstanding came in the revolving credit category, which includes credit cards. It rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.5 percent, following an identical increase in March.
Auto borrowing increased at a 1.9 percent annual rate after a 2.3 percent increase a month earlier. Other kinds of consumer loans rose at a 1.2 percent annual rate. This category includes loans for mobile homes, education, boats, trailers and vacations.
The Fed's consumer credit report includes all household debt not secured by real estate. It does not include home-equity loans or real estate.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Consumer Borrowing" tracks monthly net change in total consumer installment credit outstanding since December 1991. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: U.S. Gives Trade Plan To Japan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration presented the Japanese Government a broad proposal today to open Japan's markets by setting specific targets for imports of goods and services from the United States and other countries.
But while the proposal calls for the two countries to work out numerical benchmarks for opening the Japanese market for everything from cars to computer chips, senior Administration officials said at a briefing today that the proposal explicitly ruled out any automatic retaliation if the targets were not met. 
 In recent weeks, Administration officials have left the impression through their tough anti-Japan oratory that they would aggressively enforce any numerical targets agreed to by Japan. But Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown have steered clear of actually calling for the targets to be legally enforceable.
 
 
Kantor Cites 'Commitments'

Still, Mr. Kantor has gone out of his way to label as "commitments" the various benchmarks agreed to by the Japanese Government during the Bush Administration. In one case, Tokyo officially acknowledged in 1991 the expectation of the American semiconductor industry that foreign computer chips would capture 20 percent of the Japanese market by the end of last year. Japanese auto makers also said when President George Bush visited Tokyo last year that by 1994 they would increase their purchases of American auto parts to $19 billion from $9 billion in 1990.
The Semiconductor Industry Association said this evening in San Jose, Calif., where it is based, that it continued to support the position of Mr. Kantor that the foreign market share for computer chips in Japan should average 20 percent for all of 1993. Daryl Hatano, the association's trade specialist, said that the American industry lacked confidence in the durability of recent American inroads in the Japanese market. "At this stage in the game, we still need the Government's attention," he said.
The foreign market share in Japan rose to 20.2 percent in the 1992 fourth quarter from 15.9 percent in the 1992 third quarter, he said. "There's not a lot of confidence yet that that is sustainable," Mr. Hatano said. The chipagreement is in place until 1996 but the only numerical target was for the 20 percent level by the end of 1992.
 Sensitive to recent Japanese accusations that American officials are trying to manage trade, the plan offered today, which was worked out in four months of interagency wrangling, represented a victory for proponents of a less confrontational approach to trade disputes.
At a briefing today, senior Administration officials went out of their way to avoid any suggestion that they would restrict Japanese exports to the United States or try to force Tokyo's hand to open its markets. "This is not put in the spirit of making any kind of threat," said one of the officials, all of whom spoke on condition of anonymity.
But Administration officials were also sensitive to any suggestion that they were backing down from their previous tough talk. While no automatic retaliation is envisioned, the new plan would not restrict the Government's ability to use existing American law, which does provide for trade restrictions against countries that violate past agreements. For example, the Government has restricted imports of Italian wine coolers because it says Europe restricts various food products from the United States.
 
Not Legally Binding
 The benchmarks the Clinton Administration is proposing for Japan would, however, not be legally binding commitments by the Japanese and therefore would not be subject to automatic retaliation by the United States.
But in referring to the retaliatory power that the American Government can use under its existing laws to punish Japan for violating previous trade agreements, a senior Administration official said, "Of course, if we have to use it, we will use it."
The proposal has a few similarities to Bush Administration policies in that it seeks broad changes in the structure of the Japanese economy, ranging from opening it up for more foreign investment to streamlining its convoluted retail system, which tends to exclude foreign goods. The new approach differs by proposing numerical benchmarks for measuring progress in a wide range of disputes, and in setting a succession of deadlines for progress.
 
Combining Issues
 It also differs by combining structural issues with industry issues in a way that the Bush and Reagan Administrations did not try. For example, the proposal calls for negotiations on foreign car sales in Japan that would include structural issues like the Japanese car dealer system. That system is heavily influenced by Japan's car makers, who have been accused of using it to keep American cars out.
According to people with a detailed knowledge of the American proposal, it calls for Japan's trade surplus with the rest of the world to be reduced within three years to a range of 1.5 percent to 2 percent of Japan's economic output. Japan's current surplus, using a broad measurement that includes services and foreign aid, is about 3 percent of its economic output.
If the Japanese agree to adopt the benchmarks, the United States said it would keep its market as open to international goods and services as it is now. It is also promising to follow President Clinton's five-year plan for cutting the budget deficit in half, measured as a percentage of the nation's economic output, the Administration officials said.
The Japanese Embassy had no immediate reaction.
 
Facing a Deadline
 The mild American oratory at today's briefing was consistent with a softening of American and European criticisms of Japan in the last two weeks. The world's industrial powers are racing against a self-imposed deadline of early July to strike a broad compromise on lowering import tariffs and other trade barriers, as part of world trade talks involving 114 nations. Japanese trade negotiators have taken an increasingly conciliatory stance in these talks, which are under the auspices of GATT, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The heads of state from the world's seven leading economies are scheduled to meet on July 7 in Tokyo. The senior Administration officials said today that they hoped that President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan would announce there that they had agreed on a framework for the coming trade negotiations between the two countries.
A meeting between Japanese and American trade officials to outline the framework for the talks between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Miyazawa is scheduled for Friday in Washington.
The Tokyo meeting is also the target for a likely compromise on market access in the GATT talks. By deferring a bilateral confrontation with Japan while seeking the global trade deal, the Clinton Administration is closely following the example of the Bush Administration.
The Bush Administration started a very similar framework of American-Japanese trade talks in 1989 while emphasizing a global deal. But the world trade talks broke down in December 1990, leaving the Bush Administration with neither the global deal nor much progress on bilateral trade frictions.
The approach presented today does not represent all of the Administration's demands on trade but is its proposal for how to go about resolving trade disputes. Besides the targets for the size of Japan's surplus with the rest of the world, today's proposals would set goals on foreign access in a handful of specific industries.
At today's briefing, the senior Administration officials spoke on condition of anonymity because the White House has scheduled a much larger briefing on Tuesday, when a few more details of the plan will be officially released.
The senior Administration officials said today that the United States was calling for trans-Pacific trade negotiations to be divided into five categories, which they refused to identify. They will not do so on Tuesday either, a senior Administration official said, because the Administration does not want to negotiate with the Japanese in the newspapers.
 
Several Areas Covered
 But people familiar with the American proposal said today that the first category would cover compliance with existing trade agreements, while the second would cover trade in autos and auto parts. The third would cover regulated industries like banking and insurance, and the fourth would consist of government procurement issues, like the persistently low purchases of American-made supercomputers and construction engineering by the Japanese Government.
The last category, vaguely named economic integration, would cover issues like patent protection. American companies have long complained that it is more difficult for them to receive patents for new inventions in Japan than it is for Japanese companies to get patents here. It would also cover Japanese support for new technologies. The Japanese Government would be asked to identify all new industries that it is assisting, allowing the United States to insist that these industries not be protected from international competition until they were strong.
The Administration briefed a few members of Congress on Friday about the new plan. Representative Sander Levin, a Michigan Democrat who advocates more confrontational trade policies, said he was satisfied with the approach. "For the first time it has more than talking in it, for the first time it talks about specifics, like cutting in half" the overall Japanese trade surplus, he said today.

LENGTH: 1536 words

HEADLINE: Striking Coal Miners Fight To Protect Shrinking Power

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W.Va., June 3

 BODY:
It was just before midnight, an hour very dark and still in the mountains south of Charleston, and a dozen men were gathered around a fire on the picket line at the Hobet 21 Mine.
The strike by the United Mine Workers of America was in its third week, and a certain domesticity had settled in: The men had built a sturdy picket shack and stocked it with food and drink. They had adopted a stray dog and named it Striker. They had become enough of a fixture along U.S. 119 that motorists honked their horns, and many stopped with firewood and food. 
 Still, it was a lonely outpost, and it was manned mostly by miners in their 40's and 50's. In their camouflage fatigues, the semiofficial uniform of U.M.W. members on strike, they resembled nothing else so much as aging, weary soldiers. And they talked like men in a long, grim war -- a war against layoffs and mine shutdowns, against the growing tide of nonunion coal, against the hard economic trends of the Appalachian coal fields.
There have been many strikes and mine wars in this region, but no one underestimates the United Mine Workers' current struggle. The union's "selective strike," which began May 10 and has steadily expanded, now covers about 9,000 miners in five states and is widely expected to grow.
 
Memories of John L.
 But the days of John L. Lewis, when miners could lay down their tools, let the stockpiles dwindle and threaten to paralyze the American economy, are gone. While coal still generates about 55 percent of the nation's electricity, the union controls only about 30 percent of coal production. In the current strike, the union is battling to hold on to its remaining power, and the miners are fighting for the remaining jobs. Getting a share of the jobs in new, nonunion mines is a central issue.
The U.M.W. now claims about 70,000 working members nationwide, down from 120,000 a decade ago. "Our forefathers toughed it out for the benefits we've got today," said Danny Hoover, a third-generation miner who is 45. "We don't intend to lose them."
Voices chimed in from the dark. "We're not dumb hillbillies," one miner called out. "You can't raise a family on a McDonald's salary," said Jerry Selbe, sitting solemnly by the fire.
U.M.W. members, who long prided themselves on their image as the shock troops of American labor, are squeezed by several trends. Employment in the union's traditional strongholds, like southern West Virginia, has eroded in recent years with the steady increase in mechanization and productivity. Here in West Virginia, coal-mining employment has dropped by more than 50 percent in a decade, which helps account for an unemployment rate of 11.7 percent, highest in the nation.
Coal-mining employment has always been cyclical, but this time the factories of Detroit, Akron and Cleveland no longer provide the escape that they offered thousands of Appalachian men in the past.
Some miners do head South for construction work during layoffs. "I've spent my lifetime leaving here," said Doug Samson, a miner on the picket line at Sharples, W.Va.
But roots run deep in the coal fields, and many miners keep coming back. "Look around you," Kenny Smith, a 44-year-old miner who is a son and grandson of southern West Virginia miners, said on a gentle spring afternoon in the mountains. "To me it's hard not to understand. This is home."
 
The Precious Jobs
 This makes the remaining jobs in the mining industry all the more precious. According to the U.M.W., the average union miner is 44 years old and working in a mine with only seven years of production remaining. The stakes for the union as an institution are equally high, as it seeks to at least stabilize its membership.
Richard L. Trumka, the union president, asserts that the coal operators are trying to "box in" the U.M.W. and shift new production to nonunion subsidiaries. He also says the companies reneged on a 1988 agreement to give U.M.W. members three of every five newly created jobs; Mr. Trumka asserts that this pledge should apply to the companies' nonunion affiliates.
Trying to adjust to the times, the union has hired Frank Greer, President Clinton's media consultant, and mounted an advertising campaign in newspapers and on radio to plead its case: "You work hard. You raise productivity 200 percent, cut costs and increase profits. You lose your job. Something is wrong."
Spokesmen for the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, the principal bargaining group for the coal companies, dismiss the notion that there is some master plan to box in the union. In modern, complex corporations, they say, some affiliated companies will inevitably be union, and some will not. They say they have gone the extra mile in the current talks by offering the U.M.W. three out of five new jobs in nonunion affiliates, after the first 40 percent of the workers are hired.
 
A Form of Suicide?
 "What we haven't done is agree that every job be given to the union," said Tom Hoffman, a vice president of Consol, an energy company, and spokesman for the operators' negotiating committee. "I think it boils down to the company wanting to take the best people, and I don't know that you want to be locked into an antiquated system of seniority and job classification that restricts your ability to hire the best people."
Mr. Hoffman also argues that the U.M.W. may be practicing a form of "suicide" by its "selective strike" against unionized operations. "In 1993, customers have numerous ways to get coal from numerous sources not controlled by the U.M.W.A.," he said.
The union's five-year contract with the coal operators association expired in February. After negotiations broke down last month, Mr. Trumka called the strike and made targets of additional companies each week.
"We have to give them credit for being relatively innovative in the way they're pursuing this negotiation," said Rafael Villagran, a coal industry analyst with Lehman Brothers. "The U.M.W.A. can't shut down a country the way they used to be able to do, but they can still invoke a creative strike mechanism to try to hit bottlenecks in the industry and have a selective impact on regions."
 
Poker and Horseshoes
 While the positioning takes place in Washington and Pittsburgh, the miners walk the picket line; they play poker and horseshoes, they whittle and brood.
"Everything you ever worked for is at stake," Ray Goodman, a retired miner, told Jerry Perry on the picket line at a mine on Buffalo Creek one recent afternoon. Mr. Perry, a third-generation miner with 24 years in the industry, seemed well aware of the stakes.
"Over all these years, it's been the miners that's made the companies what they are," said Mr. Perry, who is 53. "We've been faithful to the mines. We've worked and produced."
What if his mine is worked out in seven years? he asked. "I'll be 60, 61 years old; too early for early Social Security, too old to be hired on a new job. This is what we're fighting for right now: for job security, that when I get up to this position here, that I ought not just be thrown out to the dogs."
Most of the miners on the picket line these days boast of their productivity; they are sensitive to the image that unionized miners acquired in the late 1970's, when a young work force engaged in a wave of wildcat strikes over issues like local grievances and gasoline rationing.
Mr. Trumka asserts that the huge productivity gains feed the miners' sense of injustice. "The question they always ask, and the question that echoes in my head, is, 'What did I do wrong?' " the union president said.
But Ralph Barbaro of Energy Ventures Analysis, a consultant for the coal and natural-gas industries, said that nonunion mines typically retained a competitive edge, both in wage and benefit costs and in productivity. "I think their membership will continue to shrink," Mr. Barbaro said of the union.
According to the coal operator's association, the average annual employment cost for a U.M.W. miner in 1991 was about $67,800 -- $41,800 in wages, and the rest in medical, pension and other benefit costs.
On the picket lines, the miners talk about the forces they see arrayed against them. They grumble that 12 years of Republican Presidents have rigged the game against them, made it harder and harder for unions to organize and strike. They talk of their hopes for a more sympathetic hearing from a Democrat in the White House, although they say they have yet to sense it.
But in almost every conversation during a reporter's three days of traveling the picket lines, the miners offered an affirmation of faith. "The union was in our fathers, and I would say it'll be in all of us until we die," said Patrick Browning, who works in a surface mine on Buffalo Creek.
Still, the changes are coming so rapidly, and so deep. At the headquarters of U.M.W. District 17, the district's president, Bob Phalen, said: "People ask me all the time, 'When is the coal industry coming back?' The coal industry hasn't gone anywhere. They're setting production records every day."
He added: "I've always said modern technology is great. But sooner or later, someone has to figure out what do you do with people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: United Mine Workers pickets relaxing outside the entrance to a mine in Buffalo Creek, W. Va. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

CITY: CHARLESTON, WV, USA (93%);

HEADLINE: Senate Repeals No-Fault Insurance Law

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 7

 BODY:
The state Senate gave final legislative approval tonight to a repeal of Connecticut's 20-year-old no-fault automobile insurance law, which critics say has led, despite the statute's intent, to higher premiums and clogged courts.
The repeal measure -- which still requires approval from Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who has not said whether he will sign it -- would replace no-fault insurance with a modified tort system that proponents said could cut premiums on a basic automobile insurance policy by more than 19 percent. 
 It would also, they conceded, put more disputes over car accidents back into the courts, by requiring that responsibility be established before claims are paid. But the bill also creates a new fast-track adjudication system aimed at settling those additional cases through arbitration and nonjury trials for claims of $75,000 or less.
 
Eliminates 'Stacking'
 It also eliminates the practice known as "stacking," under which a person who owns more than one car can combine the insurance benefits for each car for a higher payout. Insurance companies have argued for years that stacking policies has artificially fueled insurance costs.
Currently 14 states, including New York and New Jersey, have no-fault insurance systems. Connecticut's bill, if it becomes law, would mark only the fourth time that a no-fault insurance state has repealed its statute, according to the American Insurance Association, a trade group. One of those states, Pennsylvania, repealed no-fault, then went back.
"No-fault hasn't worked," said Senator George C. Jepsen, a Democrat from Stamford who sponsored the bill. Mr. Jepsen said he had no illusions that car insurance premiums in a state with high incomes, expensive cars and expensive health care could ever be made cheap. "But what we have before us today takes a reasonable, intelligent step," he said.
The 28-to-8 vote in the Senate sends the bill on to Governor Weicker. Before signing it, he said he would analyze it to make sure the bill meets a series of tests, including whether the savings are passed onto consumers in a "real and measurable" way, whether it leaves people better insured, and how it could affect highway safety.
The House of Representatives passed the bill last week by a 142-to-7 majority. Overriding a veto by the Governor requires 24 votes in the Senate and 101 votes in the House.
 
Shifting Costs
 Proponents of the bill contend that the heart of the no-fault system -- a $5,000 basic medical coverage provision that every motorist in Connecticut is now required to buy -- is not effectively managed to control costs. Under the Legislature's bill, those medical costs will instead be paid through drivers' health insurance policies -- in other words, in most cases by their employers, who generally have already moved to curb costs through health-maintenance organizations and other approaches.
Opponents said that shifting those costs to employers' medical plans would provide little savings, and that many more people who are unemployed or who have no health insurance at their job could be left vulnerable if injured. The bill allows people otherwise not covered by health insurance to continue to buy the basic coverage through their automobile policies for an extra charge. It would not require that coverage, however, as the current law does.
"The estimated savings in this bill are balanced on the backs of those who can afford it least," said Senator Donald E. Williams Jr., a Democrat from Thompson.
 
Refinements Are Likely
 The local insurance industry, including giants like Aetna Life and Casualty and the Travelers, both based here in Hartford, has reluctantly accepted the bill as the best compromise available. But the insurers say that it is a stopgap measure at best and that a complete overhaul similar to what New Jersey did three years ago -- a choice system that allows policy holders a menu of no-fault and tort options -- will likely be the next step.
"This is not the last act," said David F. Snyder, counsel to the American Insurance Association, a Washington-based trade group. "Costs in Connecticut will continue to rise -- the origin of high costs is litigation and you will have more of it, not less."

HEADLINE: Latest Version of Supreme Court List: Babbitt in Lead, 2 Judges Close Behind

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
President Clinton continued today to wrestle with his first Supreme Court appointment. The latest version of the President's short list has Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt as the top contender to fill the seat of Justice Byron R. White, who is retiring, with two Federal appeals court judges, Stephen G. Breyer and Gilbert S. Merritt, also in the running.
"Stay tuned," Mr. Clinton told reporters in the Rose Garden. "I have not made a decision yet, but I'm working on it." 
 Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Clinton had not yet interviewed any candidates and was not expected to make his choice until the end of the week at the earliest.
"The search has been narrowed," Ms. Myers said. "The President is reviewing the results of the vetting process. There is more than one candidate at play here."
For nearly three weeks, White House spokesmen and the President have said that the nomination was imminent, but each time it has been delayed for various reasons: some candidates high on Mr. Clinton's list dropped out, unexpected political crises arose and some names that were floated generated quick opposition.
Mr. Clinton has apparently become gun-shy after so many mishaps with appointees, and he now seems determined to find the perfect Supreme Court candidate, one who will be easily confirmed, reflect well upon him and not bring any surprises.
With this in mind, the White House has recently been floating names of possible nominees. Over the weekend, for instance, several news organizations reported that the President had settled on Mr. Babbitt for the Court seat, and the Interior Secretary's spokesman, Kevin Sweeney, told reporters this morning, "I think it's going to happen."
But only hours later, the White House made it clear that Mr. Babbitt's was not the only name on the President's list, although several officials said he probably had a definite edge over the other candidates. Now if Mr. Babbitt is not chosen, it could raise awkward questions about why.
In fact, that has already happened. Today the President was asked in the Rose Garden, "Why are you backing off Babbitt?"
"I'm not backing off on anybody," he snapped. "I haven't made a decision yet."
 
Losing a Good Thing
 While the President admires the 54-year-old Mr. Babbitt, Mr. Clinton has still not given him the nod yet for several reasons. For one, Mr. Babbitt has emerged as a star of Mr. Clinton's Cabinet, and the President is not eager to lose him without having a clear idea who might take his place.
Mr. Babbitt's political handling of environmental issues, which has won praise from environmentalists and business groups alike, is politically important for Mr. Clinton's standing in the West, where the President won one-third of his electoral votes.
Some environmental groups even have started lobbying the White House against the Babbitt appointment -- because they are so fond of him.
"Babbitt is uniquely suited to be Secretary of the Interior," said Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, a leading environmentalist group. "He has the political skills to pursue both economic growth and environmental protection, and while there is no doubt that he might make a great Supreme Court Justice, there are other alternatives for the court. But there are not other people with his stature and leadership skills who would be appropriate for Interior."
Mr. Babbitt, a former Governor of Arizona who also served as the state's attorney general, fits Mr. Clinton's desire to have a moderate-to-liberal nominee with a record of being able to build coalitions with conservatives, who now dominate the Court. That is a reputation Mr. Babbitt earned in Arizona, where he had to govern in cooperation with a Republican-dominated Legislature.
 
The Other Contenders
 Judge Breyer of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, is a stranger to the President but is well regarded as a legal thinker. Althought he was nominated for the court by President Jimmy Carter, Judge Breyer has a great deal of support among Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, has spoken out in support of his nomination, as has the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas.
Judge Merritt, chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, was appointed to the bench by Mr. Carter. He is considered a moderate who would generate some Republican support. But reports of his possible nomination two weeks ago drew the ire of one Jewish organization.
The Simon Wiesenthal Center, which monitors issues involving the Holocaust, criticized Judge Merritt for ordering an inquiry into the Justice Department's handling of the extradition of John Demjanjuk, who was convicted of Nazi war crimes by an Israeli court.
As for a possible Babbitt nomination, Senator Dole put Mr. Clinton on notice today that it might not be clear sailing. Asked about the ease with which Mr. Babbitt might be confirmed, he said: "I don't know enough about Bruce Babbitt's legal qualifications. I know he's a nice person. We've got some of our staff checking to see what he's done, to see what he's written."
He added: "I prefer to have somebody who has circuit court experience. I was sort of supporting Stephen Breyer. Is he still in the mix?"

HEADLINE: Stock Prices End Lower Across the Board

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed lower across the board yesterday, despite a late afternoon comeback that briefly took the Dow Jones industrial average into positive territory.
Among the weakest sectors were banking, technology and gambling. 
 Financial stocks, despite a firm bond market, continue to show weakness amid worries about higher interest rates and their impact on earnings.
Citicorp fell 1 3/8, to 26 3/8, while Bankers Trust fell 1 3/4, to 69 7/8; Chemical Bankdeclined 1 5/8, to 35 1/2.
Among technology stocks, Advanced Micro Devices fell 4 1/4, to 23 3/4, after a court reversed an arbitrator's earlier award giving it permanent royalty-free rights to clone Intel's popular 386 computer chip. Intel, the apparent victor, was up 1 3/4, to 58 1/8.
 
 
Andrea Electronics Soars
 Investors in Andrea Electronics were easily identifiable, They were the ones smiling. The stock soared 16 1/4, to 53 3/4, with trading halted for an order imbalance because raders could not keep up with large volume of buy orders.
Andrea Electronics said Friday that it "was right on track" in bringing to market by the third quarter a line of machines, including one to suppress street noise on pay phones.
The Dow fell 13.01 points, to 3,532.13, with volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaling 236.9 million shares. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by 11 to 7.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 7.40 points, to 694.61, while the American Stock Exchange composite was off five-hundredths of a point, to 440.90.
Some traders thought investors were approaching the market with extra caution ahead of Friday's release the May Producer Price Index, the next inflation indicator. Caught off guard last week with strong employment numbers, investors do not appear to be committing themselves to any strong moves and may be content picking individual stocks for now, analysts said.
"I still suspect a rally in the market could come as early as Tuesday," said Ricky Harrington, senior vice president and technical analyst at Interstate/Johnson Lane, Charlotte, N.C. "It may be a little early to suggest that investor money is on the sidelines, and of course interest rates are still reasonably stable."
A.T.& T., which is raising evening long-distance charges, rose 3/8, to 62 1/8.
Advanced Technology Labs and Acuson, which make ultrasonic medical equipment that could become more popular under cost-conscious health-care changes, were up 3/4, to 17 1/4, and 1 3/4, to 12 1/2, respectively.
 
 
Snapple Advances
 Snapple Beverage rose 5 3/4, to 62 1/4. The stock had fallen 5 percent since Emanuel Goldman, the Paine Webber analyst, reduced his rating to neutral on May 28, calling the stock overpriced. Yesterday, Mr. Goldman changed his rating to attractive after seeing April supermarket data last week that indicated continuing growth for Snapple.
Traders said Apple Computer was not as fortunate, falling 4 1/8, to 50 3/4, after Eugene Glazer of Dean Witter lowered his third-quarter estimates and reduced numbers for the 1993 and 1994 fiscal years. Bear, Stearns also said its estimates for the computer company were under review.

HEADLINE: Protection of Region's Open Spaces Urged by Planning Group

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
The planning group that more than half a century ago proposed the system of parkways that today unites the New York region has concluded that it is now critically important to identify and protect broad corridors of woods, open space and sparse development that still survive 40 to 100 miles from New York City.
The group, the Regional Plan Association, said that vast expanses of open space, previously considered invulnerable, are now threatened. A decade of frenetic development has claimed farmland, forests and verdant private estates from northern Connecticut to southern New Jersey, it said. 
 The Regional Plan Association is a private body without governmental authority or other means to carry out its proposals. But for 65 years its ideas for shaping the region have been embraced, at least in part, by Federal, state, city and county governments.
The association is to present its recommendations at a meeting of planners, environmentalists and government officials in Manhattan today. Its report consists largely of a map, identifying corridors of land, reservoirs and watershed areas that it says should be treated by the states, counties and municipalities as "regional reserves."
 
Threat of 'Urban Sprawl'
 These unspoiled areas "encompass the region's most important scenic, biological and water resources which are now being threatened by urban sprawl," the Regional Plan Association said.
The most critical open space corridors it identified are an area extending from the Litchfield Hills of northern Connecticut to the Delaware River in central New Jersey, New York's Catskill Mountains, the Pine Barrens of Long Island and the Pinelands of southern New Jersey.
 
Effect of Weak Economy
 The group maintained that its proposal for open-space planning had gained urgency even as the recession slowed the development trends that encroached on the rural and exurban landscape in the 1980's.
"For the moment, development pressures have lifted," said Claude Shostal, president of the association. "But developers are still speculating in land investments, and the pressure on our open space will certainly be there."
But the group said the weak economy in the New York region and elsewhere had made the goal of open-space preservation more difficult, because Federal money for land acquisition, which flowed into the region during most of the last 30 years, is sure to dwindle.
It said government agencies, environmentalists and developers must coordinate more closely to assure that new construction in the most sensitive open-space corridors is limited.
The Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit group financed by foundations and corporations, is offering no method of buying land. Nor does the group offer any assurance that long-running disputes between the states, counties and municipalities over land use and planning can be resolved.
But as the only large planning organization that seeks to coordinate land use across the region, the association has a long record of influence over public policy. Its professional staff, based in Manhattan, includes planners and land-use experts.
One critical source of support for open-space advocates that seems certain to dwindle is Federal financing for land acquisition. The group said the amount of park land in the region doubled between 1960 and 1990, mainly because of huge outlays from Washington.
More than $300 million flowed into the region for land acquisition during that period. Now, because of the recession, and longer term constraints on Congress to reduce the budget deficit, "I see little the Clinton Administration can do," Mr. Shostal said.
 
Role for Private Groups?
 Where land acquisition is required, the group said, non-government land trusts and other private groups may be asked to play a larger role. But it added that most of the open-space corridors it is seeking to protect are already interspersed with state or Federal park land, and the challenge facing the region now is to coordinate development plans so it leaves as much open space as possible intact.
One critical area, the group said, is the Long Island Pine Barrens, the wide expanse of low-lying undeveloped dwarf pine plains along the spine of Suffolk County. Faced with proposals for more than 200 development projects, environmentalists on Long Island have waged a bitter series of lawsuits, which culminated in May with a tentative agreement in which the developers said they would not build on half of the 100,000-acre corridor.
 
Sterling Forest on List
 Another area that ranks high on the list of threatened tracts, the group said, is Sterling Forest, a heavily wooded 17,500-acre tract in Rockland County where a Swedish Insurance Company wants to build a small new city of 35,000 residents. The tract lies at the center of the Hudson Highlands, one of the "regional reserves" that are identified by the Regional Plan Association as most critical to the region.
New York State officials say a deal is being negotiated in which the state would buy -- for an undisclosed figure under $50 million -- three quarters of Sterling Forest, allowing the Swedish company to build on the rest.
At the Regional Plan Association, analysts said both areas provided examples of the approach that might be necessary to preserve as much open space as possible for the region.
"We are not suggesting that there be no development," said Robert Pirani, the association's director of environmental projects. "But we need to identify what areas are most critical for the region, and see that development goes around these resources instead of destroying them."

HEADLINE: Attacks in Los Angeles Fly on Eve of Election

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 7

 BODY:
On the eve of what many people say could be a watershed election Tuesday, the two candidates for mayor of Los Angeles called each other liars and racists today, keeping up their personal attacks to the end in a close race.
The volley of accusations by the two candidates, City Councilman Michael Woo, 41, and Richard Riordan, 62, a millionaire businessman, have come in two televised debates and a joint television interview since Sunday. 
 Their continuing mutual attacks and failure to articulate a broad vision for the city have wearied many voters, who are hoping for strong leadership at a time of crisis in the economy, race relations and public safety.
The election has aroused little enthusiasm, and the strongest emotion voiced by a number of voters today was disappointment at the candidates and the tone of the campaign.
"We watched exactly 30 seconds of the debate last night, and we are avid political activists," said Sydney Weisman, a public relations executive. "The minute the attacks started, we said, 'Never mind.' "

HEADLINE: Judge Allows Dredging To Continue

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 7

 BODY:
A Federal judge held today that a permit for ocean disposal of dioxin-tainted silt from Newark Bay was flawed, but he rejected pleas from environmentalists that the dredging and dumping be halted.
The judge, Dickinson R. Debevoise of United States District Court here, said that the Army Corps of Engineers, which granted the permit to port officials, had failed to show that the dioxin existed only in trace amounts, less than 1 part per trillion. Federal law permits ocean disposal of dioxin only in trace amounts. 
 But a permit can be issued under an exception for economic hardship, and the judge strongly suggested that such an argument could prevail because failure to dredge the port's container-ship berths in Newark and Elizabeth would imperil waterfront commerce by forcing huge cargo ships to call elsewhere. It was the real and potential impact of such losses, the judge said, that persuaded him to rebuff attempts to halt the dredging, which began last Wednesday and will continue for a month.
 
Conditions Imposed
 Judge Debevoise ordered the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to take steps within 15 days either to establish that only trace amounts are being dumped or to seek a hardship waiver from the Secretary of the Army. He also barred the Corps from issuing any similar permits until it could apply the court's directives uniformly.
Hugh H. Welsh, a lawyer for the Port Authority, said that the agency would probably be able to prevail on either point raised by the judge but that "we'll have to study our alternatives." Under the permit, the port may dredge up to 460,000 cubic yards of sediment, dump it at sea and cap the material with three feet of fresh sand.
But Gordon L. Litwin, a lawyer for the environmental groups, said that up to 5 percent of the dredged material would escape the cap and, as a result, dioxin contamination would be measurably more than a trace.
 
Conservationists Disappointed
 The ruling was a disappointment for the coalition of conservationists and fishermen's groups that has been fighting the permit for three years. They contend that dioxin, a highly toxic industrial byproduct, should not be deposited at the Corps' 80-year-old Mud Dump, six miles east of Sandy Hook, N.J., amid some of the East Coast's richest fishing grounds.
Although they acknowledge that the port needs to be dredged to remain competitive, they say that dioxin, even in small amounts, could imperil the health of humans as well as of fish and wildlife and ruin New Jersey's commercial and sport fishing industry.
Although conservationists have called for alternatives to ocean dumping, including the construction of artificial containment islands or storage on land or in empty freighters, port and Government officials say that these are still too expensive and that decontamination techniques have yet to be perfected.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rebound for Treasury Bond Prices

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday in a rebound from the sharp decline that occurred Friday after the Government reported a suprisingly large increase in nonfarm payroll jobs in May.
But trading yesterday was very light, which means the rise in prices could have been exaggerated. When trading is thin, action by a few speculators and traders can move prices much further than would occur with normal trading volume. 
 "There was not much volume behind this, so the bounce is a little suspect," said Peter McTeague, a fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston.
 
Prices Edge Higher
 In late trading, the price of the 30-year bond due in Feburary 2023 was up 13/32 as the yield dropped to 6.87 percent, from 6.91 percent Friday. Prices and yields move in opposite directions. The prices of intermediate Treasury notes also rose, but not as much.
The major concern in the market right now is inflation and whether the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates to signal that it will not allow the pace of price increases to pick up.
There may be an answer to that question by the middle of next week because the Labor Department releases the Producer Price Index on Friday and the Consumer Price Index next Tuesday. If the increases are small, the Fed may not take action. But if they continue at the 4.3 percent annual rate that the Consumer Price Index showed in April, the Fed may be forced to respond quickly. Based on current forecasts, the May price increases are expected to be smaller than the average for the first four months of the year.
 
Bill Rates Rise
 The fear of Fed action was reflected in the weekly auction of Treasury bills yesterday, where the average discount rate rose for the fifth week in a row. The average rate on three-month bills rose to 3.14 percent, the highest since the 3.15 percent at the Jan. 4 auction and up from 3.08 percent last week. The rate on the six-month bill was 3.30 percent, the highest since the 3.38 percent on Dec. 26 and up from 3.22 percent last week.
Traders are not sure yet how much support prices of long-term securities are getting from the weekend's indications that the Clinton Administration is amenable to a deficit-reduction compromise with Senate Democrats that would mean more spending cuts and fewer tax increases.
Bond investors generally favor spending cuts over tax increases because they are a more reliable way to reduce the Federal budget deficit. But it is possible that such a revision, while passing the Senate, might run into trouble in the House, where some members may oppose the deeper spending cuts.
The House gave initial approval to the President's program by a narrow vote of 219 to 213 at the end of last month. If a compromise plan is approved in the Senate, the House and Senate would work out the differences in a conference committee and both houses would then vote on the revised proposal, adding to the uncertainity of the outlook for the program.
 
Other Markets
 Both the municipal and corporate market should be active this week. In the municipal market, $5 billion to $7 billion of issues are expected to be sold this week, according to Bloomberg Business News.
Prices of actively traded municipal bonds were little changed yesterday. There was a new wrinkle for the tax-exempt market in the budget talk over the weekend. The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said that he did not think that a proposed 36 percent top tax rate should be retroactive to Jan. 1, which is the case in the plan approved by the House.
In the corporate market, the International Business Machines Corporation, with Morgan Stanley & Company as the lead underwriter, is planning to sell $1.5 billion in bonds, one of the largest corporate offerings ever.
The bonds are part of the company's effort to raise about $3 billion. A third of that sum was obtained in the recent sale of preferred stock.
Some of the money raised could be used to pay the severance costs for the thousands of employees that are leaving the company as I.B.M. seeks to cut costs. The company already expects that more than 25,000 employees will leave voluntarily or involuntarily.
Following are the results of yesterday's action of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Slightly Lower After Traders Take Profits

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower in lethargic trading on world currency markets yesterday, under pressure from profit taking.
Gold prices declined worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold contract for August delivery settled at $375.70 an ounce, off $2.80 from Friday. The Republic National Bank quoted spot gold at a late bid price of $373.50, down $2.80. 
 Analysts said the dollar was poised for a technical correction following its sharp rise on Friday, when the currency got a boost from an unexpected surge in May employment.
When trading began in Europe, the currency was hit by profit taking, which continued as activity shifted to domestic markets, Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said.
 
Waiting for Monthly Reports
 But he described trading as "very apathetic," since there was no fresh news to move the market. Mr. Donney predicted activity would remain relatively light until Friday, when the Government is scheduled to issue reports on producer prices and retail sales, both for May.
"These are the pivotal events the market is looking at right now," he said. Investors will be looking for additional evidence that shows a firming economy to back the employment report. A strengthening economy gives the Federal Reserve more room to raise interest rates, which typically bolsters the dollar by enhancing the value of dollar-denominated securities.
Mr. Donney said that trading in the dollar had "good underlying tone." He said many traders expected the dollar to perform better "once we get through this sleepy little correction we're having."
In New York trading, the dollar settled at 107.25 yen, down from 107.75 yen on Friday. The dollar also slipped to 1.6205 German marks, down from 1.6260 marks. Meanwhile, the British pound rose in New York to $1.5220, from $1.5090 on Friday.
Silver prices also declined. On the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.405 an ounce, down from $4.434 on Friday.
