HEADLINE: Big Banks' Goal: Higher Ratings

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Over the last few months, the Chase Manhattan Corporation has presented its 34,000 employees with a four-page pamphlet detailing the bank's mission for the turn of the century: to be world class, balanced, financially strong and big. Amid those broad goals, however, there was one strikingly concrete objective: By 1995, Chase wants to raise its credit rating to the pristine double-A. Now it is triple-B, the level just above junk bonds.
Chase is not alone in this ambitious goal. After waves of bad loans starting with the developing-country debt crisis in the mid-1980's to the real estate collapse of 1990, America's largest banks are trying to recover their financial strength. And like Chase, several other large banks have publicly set goals for raising their credit ratings. 
 When it merged with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation in 1991, for example, the Chemical Banking Corporation said it wanted to raise its rating from triple-B to double-A by 1994. And at Citicorp's annual meeting last April, John S. Reed, the chairman, said the bank also wants to be rated double-A by 1995. Now Citicorp is rated triple-B by some credit rating agencies and single-A by others.
 
 
Pragmatic Reasons
 There are pragmatic reasons for these goals: higher-rated companies borrow money at lower interest rates. And more important for large banks like Chase, many corporations will not buy the most profitable bank services, such as interest rate swaps, from any but the highest-rated banks.
But for the large New York banks, which have been forced to cede leadership in the industry to stronger and more aggressive regional competitors, such as Nationsbank, regaining a double-A rating has important symbolic value as well.
A double-A rating "is one more measure that this place is back to good health," Thomas Jones, chief financial officer of Citicorp, said.
This sterling report card will be harder for the banks to get than they think. Over the last year, the leading rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service Inc., the Standard & Poor's Corporation and a handful of smaller competitors, have already started to upgrade the banks to single-A because they have raised capital and showed that the worst of their loan problems are behind them.
But the standard for a double-A is higher and more qualitative. "To get a single-A, an institution needs a good franchise, a clean balance sheet and to be well run." said Christopher T. Mahoney, associate director of financial institution ratings at Moody's. "To get a double-A is more difficult."
Moody's only rates four banks double-A -- the Republic New York Corporation, the Wachovia Corporation, NBD Bancorp and America's most creditworthy bank, J. P Morgan & Company. "Those are exceptional institutions that have gone through the worst banking crisis in history substantially unhurt," Mr. Mahoney said. "They are not only clean, they never got dirty."
In recognition of these difficulties, Chemical has partly backed off its initial goal of a double-A rating by next year. Now it says it wants its lead bank subsidiary, Chemical Bank, to be rated double-A and it would be content for the holding company to be rated single-A. In the United States, holding companies have lower ratings than their subsidiary banks, which are protected by Government deposit insurance.
Indeed, some banks shy away from the cost of earning a higher rating. To raise more capital, for example, a bank may have to sell so much stock that it will dilute its existing shares.
 
 
Bondholder Perspective
 "For the rating agencies, more equity capital is always better because they have the perspective of what gives the best protection to the bond holders," E. Michel Kruse, the chief financial officer of Chase, said. "For us, capital is better up to a certain point. Then it eats into shareholder return."
Because of this the big banks do not aspire to be triple-A, and many large regional banks, including BankAmerica and Nationsbank, are content with their single-A ratings.
Citibank, Chase and Chemical are more interested in a double-A rating than these other institutions because they are trying to attract business from the largest corporations and investors who are more sensitive to credit ratings than local customers. (Since bank deposits are federally insured up to $100,000, most consumers have no need to be concerned with credit ratings.)
"The nature of wholesale banking has changed radically over the last 10 years," Tanya S. Azarchs, financial institutions director with S.& P., said. Banks don't lend much money to large corporations, she said. "The money is in trading and cash management and for that you need a double-A." Cash management is a service that helps companies move their money between operations around the world and may involve very large uninsured deposits.
 
 
Derivative Products
 The most lucrative new business is the rapidly growing market for derivative products, such as swaps. These are custom-made financial contracts that help companies and investors manage their risk from financial markets. But since since banks sell derivative contracts that offer protection for as long as five years, their customers want to make sure the bank won't fail.
"Most big companies have written policies as to what banks they are allowed to enter transactions with, and a lot of them cut off at double-A," Mr. Kruse of Chase said. This has given the banks meeting this criteria, including J. P. Morgan, Bankers Trust and Credit Suisse, a substantial advantage.
In fact, before it merged with Chemical, Manufacturers Hanover calculated that it lost $100 million in pretax income from higher funding costs and lost business when it was downgraded to triple-B. And the new Chemical figures it can raise earnings by at least $150 million as a result of the upgrade to double-A, according to Peter Tobin, the company's chief financial officer.
In the late 1970's, Citicorp and Chase were both rated triple-A, but they were lowered to double-A in the early 1980's in recognition of the new competition from Wall Street and foreign banks. Along with Chemical, they fell to single-A in 1987 when they began to recognize their losses on loans to Latin American countries. And they fell to double-B in 1990, as the collapsing real estate market caused their bad loans to skyrocket. (S.& P., which was less worried about the effect of the real estate crisis on banks than Moody's, kept Citicorp at A-.)
 
 
Rate Cut Cited
 The picture began to brighten at the dawn of the Persian Gulf war in January 1991, when the Federal Reserve sharply cut short-term interest rates, which substantially increased the banks' profit margins. Since then, the banks have raised their capital ratios through retained earnings and by selling new stock. Moreover, the real estate market, while still low, has stopped its free fall, allowing the banks to begin selling off their bad loans and foreclosed properties.
Curiously, Citicorp's rating did not fall as low as that of Chemical and Chase, but rating agency analysts say it will not be upgraded as fast as the others either. While Citicorp had far more troubled real estate loans than any other bank, its credit rating was a notch higher because it had a greater diversity of earnings sources, including highly profitable foreign currency trading and retail banking in developing countries. Now the bank has not been as active raising capital as the other banks.
"Citi needs to establish some credibility" in its commitment to improving its financial position, said Robin Monro-Davies, the managing director of IBCA Ltd., a London-based bank rating agency. "Their capital is still 1.5 percentage points lower than anybody else and they are still not paying a dividend."
As the condition of the banks improves, their meetings with the rating agencies are becoming more confrontational. Some bankers openly complain that the agencies were much quicker with the downgrades than they are with upgrades.
But the agencies are unapologetic. "Most institutions think, 'If we get our financial ratios back to where they were when we were double-A, we will be double-A again,' " Mr. Mahoney of Moody's said. "That is not going to happen. The bar is getting higher."
 
 
Not All Business Is Equal
 One reason is that the large New York banks that increasingly rely on trading and other nontraditional services that are inherently less stable and thus less creditworthy than large regional banks, according to the agencies. "If you have 15 percent of the California retail banking market, no one can take that away from you," Mr. Mahoney of Moody's said. "If you have 15 percent of the foreign exchange business, anyone can take that away from you." As a result, "We see an institution such as Citi or Chase or Chemical as a natural single-A holding company," he added.
Moreover, the analysts worry that the current good times for the entire banking industry will not continue when the present wide gap between short- and long-term interest rates narrows. The traditional business of taking deposits to make loans will continue its long-term decline, as more corporations borrow money by selling securities and individuals save through mutual funds. Banks are trying to compensate by getting into these and other new businesses, and by buying other banks to cut costs and further reduce competition.
While some of these moves may make the surviving banks stronger, credit rating agencies worry that banks will make mistakes as they try to expand. "The good news is that the institutions are more diversified," Deborah J. Perry, associate director for financial institutions at Moody's, said. "And the bad news is that since this is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, the banks may be tempted to take extra risk."


GRAPHIC: Three money center bank holding companies that fell from grace with credit rating agencies during the 1980's are striving to boost their ratings back to safer, sounder levels where borrowing costs are lower and profits are higher. But compared to a double-A-rated bank like Wachovia Corp., their vital statistics are still weak.

HEADLINE: World Health Official Says AIDS Spread Could Be Controlled

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 7

 BODY:
The AIDS epidemic that is galloping through much of the world could be curtailed if known preventions measures were more widely applied and if an additional $1.5 billion to $2.9 billion a year were spent in developing countries on AIDS prevention, a World Health Organization official said here today at the ninth international AIDS meeting.
The extra money would represent an increase of about 1.5 percent over current health-care budgets in developing countries and would translate into the cost of one soft drink for every person in the world, said Dr. Michael H. Merson, who heads the W.H.O. program on AIDS. 
 The greater efforts would "save millions of lives, billions of dollars and immeasurable pain and suffering," Dr. Merson said. By the year 2000 it would be possible to cut in half the number of people who otherwise would be infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, he said.
W.H.O. says 14 million people are now infected with H.I.V. Unless more drastic action is taken, the number is expected to rise to 30 million to 40 million people by the year 2000, Dr. Merson said. With the suggested increase in spending for AIDS prevention, Dr. Merson said, the number of new adult infections during the remainder of this decade would drop from 20 million to 10 million.
"Either we pay now or we pay later," Dr. Merson said.
 
Seeking Early Intervention
 Dr. Dean T. Jamison, an economist at the University of California at Los Angeles and the World Bank in Washington, said the W.H.O. figures were reasonable cost estimates.
Developing countries now spend about $170 billion each year on health care. The World Bank will soon argue in its annual report for substantial increases in international aid to health, with a large share going to AIDS, Dr. Jamison said.
One main conclusion of the report is that "intervention early in an epidemic is vastly more cost effective than waiting until the epidemic is more established," Dr. Jamison said.
The World Bank concluded, however, that "the sheer magnitude of the epidemic in terms of the number of people infected or dying, either today or even a decade from now," did not give AIDS a greater claim on the health dollar than the many other diseases affecting the developing world, like heart disease and cancer.
 
Criticism of W.H.O.
 The call for increased efforts comes as the World Health Organization, an agency of the United Nations, has been under intense pressure to improve its AIDS program. Hiroshi Nakajima, a Japanese doctor, was re-elected head of W.H.O. last month despite opposition from the organization's major donors over what they say is Dr. Nakajima's poor management style in AIDS and other fields.
Dr. Merson's predecessor, Dr. Jonathan Mann, resigned in 1990 as head of W.H.O.'s global AIDS program, citing differences with Dr. Nakajima, and is now a professor at the Harvard School of Public Health in Boston. He and others have urged W.H.O. to apply what has been learned from pilot projects worldwide. Dr. Merson seemed to agree today, saying, "We must waste no time in scaling up the interventions that we know work."
Because the AIDS epidemic is a series of smaller epidemics, each driven by different factors and forces, there can be no single blueprint for preventing H.I.V. infection, Dr. Merson said.
He said there was a consensus about six key steps, including these:
*Promoting condom use in the general population through advertising and the involvement of pharmacists and other local merchants.
*Promoting condom use by prostitutes and their clients.
*Treating standard sexually transmitted diseases, because they can increase risk of H.I.V. infection.
*Increasing AIDS information and education in schools and through the media.
*Maintaining a safe blood supply.
*Operating needle exchange programs for people who inject drugs.
Dr. Merson cited a report by Dr. Don Des Jarlais of Beth Israel Hospital in New York City, who said at the meeting that controlling the spread of H.I.V. among intravenous drug users, once called impossible, was a realistic goal. Early intervention has prevented H.I.V. epidemics among drug users in four cities -- Glasgow, Scotland; Lund, Sweden; Sydney, Australia, and Tacoma, Wash. In those cities, H.I.V. rates among drug users have stayed below 5 percent for at least four years, Dr. Des Jarlais said.
W.H.O. estimates that investing $2.5 billion a year would save nearly $90 billion in direct and indirect costs by the year 2000 and additional savings for the 21st century, Dr. Merson said, "a return any company would be happy to achieve."
The money could come from several sources, he said, including the developing countries themselves and increased donations from the developed countries and the private sector.
 
Research on Immune System
 In another talk, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, who heads the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md., said today that scientists do not know whether an immune system damaged by H.I.V. can regenerate.
"We can't assume it will occur spontaneously," Dr. Fauci said.
Newer research has shown that there are many and overlapping phases of H.I.V. infection and that the search for therapies must take the complexities into account.
"We must dissect the various phases of H.I.V. disease to determine the feasibility of using agents that might block certain aspects of activation of H.I.V. without compounding immunosuppression" resulting from the disease, Dr. Fauci said.
One drug that deserves further study as a blocking agent at certain stages of H.I.V. is cyclosporin, which is widely used to prevent rejection of transplanted organs, Dr. Fauci said. French researchers tried cyclosporin for AIDS patients in 1985 but ran into difficulties with the French health ministry, which publicized the research before trials were conducted.
Recently, German researchers studied the results of transplant patients who were infected with H.I.V. through contaminated blood transfusions or organs. In those who had not received cyclosporin, Dr. Fauci told the conference, the development of AIDS was "significantly" greater than in the group of H.I.V. infected patients who had received it.
In laboratory experiments, cyclosporin and AZT blocked H.I.V. infection for much longer periods than either drug alone.
The evidence is not there to recommend treating H.I.V.-infected people with cyclosporin, but, Dr. Fauci said, "strategies should be developed to at least determine the feasibility" of using cyclosporin and similar drugs to inhibit activation of H.I.V. without aggravating the immune suppression.

HEADLINE: Ghost Town Where Byzantines Mined Gold

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
ARCHEOLOGISTS exploring a ghost town in the remote eastern desert of Egypt have discovered the remains of what almost certainly was a major gold-mining operation for the Byzantine Empire. The stark granite cliffs surrounding the town were the source of a rich supply of the metal that gilded the icons and lavish art of early Christianity.
The site, called Bir Umm Fawakhir, should give scholars a rare look at the conditions of ordinary people in Byzantine Egypt, a poorly understood period from A.D. 330, when control of the Roman Empire shifted to Constantinople, until the Muslim conquest in A.D. 642. 
 Archeologists have generally neglected the period, concentrating instead on the temples, tombs and other splendors of the ancient Pharaohs. Historians studying Byzantine Egypt have had to rely on tax rolls, legal and religious documents, textiles, art and churches, which give a limited view of most individuals' lives.
In announcing the discovery, Dr. Carol Meyer, an archeologist at the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, said that Bir Umm Fawakhir was one of only two Byzantine villages known in Egypt, and by far the better-preserved one. The partial walls of granite cobbles are still standing, and they outline the ruins of more than 200 houses in the central village. There remain wells, streets and quarries, as well as outlying settlements, some with more than 40 structures.
Pottery fragments show that the site, about 60 miles east of Luxor, near a road between the Nile River and the Red Sea, was an active settlement of miners and other workers in the fifth and sixth centuries. Some of the designs included Christian crosses. Labels painted in red on wine jars were in Greek. One of the first words the archeologists deciphered was the Greek word for sweet, presumably referring to the quality of the wine.
The ruins lie on the hot, sandy floor of a narrow, isolated valley, a bleak and arid moonscape surrounded by steep granite cliffs. The sides of the cliffs are pitted with gold mines, usually shallow shafts or trenches following a vein of quartz containing gold.
 
Desert Settlements Full of Surprises
 Among the artifacts found in explorations last January was a granite pounding stone that had been used to crush gold-bearing quartz. Written accounts of mining practices at the time describe workers using mills to grind stone into a powder from which gold was then washed.
"It was a wonderful find," Dr. Meyer said. "The pounding stone was surrounded by chunks of white quartz that a worker had crushed and then just walked away from. It was sitting there just as it had been left more than 1,000 years ago."
The site had not been entirely unknown. The archeologists noted that looters had gone through a cemetery. Earlier travelers had left brief descriptions of the ruins, which were thought to be from the Roman period. There are remains of a Roman watch tower still standing, and some old accounts mention a Roman-period temple, which the archeologists have not identified. But scholars were surprised to find flourishing Byzantine settlements, because they had assumed, based on Byzantine accounts, that there were no large post-Roman settlements in the eastern desert, only some nomadic tribes.
The wonder is that there was any town at all in this desert, where there is no vegetation, save for some thorn bushes, and summer temperatures regularly reach 120 degrees. The Romans had dug wells that still provide water. But everything else needed to keep a community going had to be hauled in from the Nile Valley.
The implications of such a large gold-mining community are not yet clear to Egyptologists. It could be, Dr. Meyer said, that Bir Umm Fawakhir shows that the economy of Byzantine Egypt was stronger than previously thought.
"Scholars have thought that people's lives at this time were pretty miserable, because of a declining economy and an increasing tax burden," she explained. "This community shows that there must have been more economic strength, because the leaders were able to arrange for the support of a fairly large town in the desert."
 
Enormous Need for Gold
 Terence Wilfong, an Egyptologist at the Oriental Institute who accompanied the expedition, said the effort to exploit the desert gold "implies there must have been an enormous need occurring at this time." One possible reason was that insurrections and other upheavals were apparently interfering with gold mining in Nubia, the more usual and accessible source for the Egyptians.
Another reason, Mr. Wilfong suggested, was that with the rise of Constantinople as the center of Christendom came a flourishing of religious art. Egypt was one of the major sources of gold to embellish this art.
It is not yet certain, Mr. Wilfong said, whether the laborers at Bir Umm Fawakhir were slaves, prisoners, military personnel or paid workers. Documents of that time make no mention of slaves working in the mines, and the lack of enclosing walls and other preserved security artifacts would seem to indicate that no slaves or prisoners lived there.
From the preliminary survey, Dr. Meyer said, most of the houses in the settlement were two- and three-room dwellings, with some clustered to form complexes with as many as 19 rooms. Many rooms had stone benches. In future excavations, the archeologists want to sample discarded material buried beneath the floors of these houses or in the mounds of trash outside, searching for coins, bones, fabrics and other evidence of what it was like to live and toil in a gold-mining village of Byzantine Egypt.

HEADLINE: Settle Down -- and Toughen Up

 BODY:
Well, it was quite a weekend, wasn't it? The talking heads, the pollsters, the Democrats in Congress all unloaded. Call it The Weekend Everyone Gave Up on Bill Clinton.
It's worth remembering that there have been other watershed moments in the annals of Presidential haplessness. There was the time people realized that George Bush was not going to perform the Presidency that Peggy Noonan had written for him. There was the moment when we realized that all the Reagan jokes were true. "It's true hard work never killed anyone," quoth the Gipper when teased about his naps, "but I figure, why take the chance?" 
 But even if the experience of White House wobbles is not entirely new, this business with Mr. Clinton has a spooky feeling all its own. So perhaps it is time for everyone to put heads on desks and give the classroom time to settle down. Clearly, things have gotten badly out of hand. But in the respirant hush of nap time, it may also be possible to assess what's happening to the Clinton Presidency and how it might be put back on track.
First and foremost, a moment of silence might give Mr. Clinton a chance to commune with the fact that if he is going to be principal of this rowdy school, he's got to quit acting like a substitute teacher. The growing doubts about his Presidency have less to do with ideology than with leadership. It's true that the polls show that people increasingly see him as a "liberal" and not the "new Democrat" he pledged to be. But what really seems to be troubling people is that Mr. Clinton is not projecting strength. He ran as the guy who could take a little of this and a dash of that and figure out how to make things work. But instead of he being the one who makes things happen, things keep happening to him.
Whether his troubles are those he could never have predicted (the wacko stuff in Waco) or problems that are going to be there regardless (Bosnia) or campaign promises he finds difficult to keep (the middle-class tax cut) or things he might have avoided by paying more attention (the savaging of his stimulus package), there has been a pattern of random accident that is scaring people.
Sometimes complex Washington situations yield best to simple solutions. The first counsel here is to be patient, to sit among the wreckage for a while. At first, people will feel sorry. Then they will begin to suspect Mr. Clinton knows something. Then a hopeful nation will see in some modest bit of good luck the plottings of a renascent political genius.
But Mr. Clinton has to slow the accident rate enough for this to happen. Toward that end, in all seriousness, it is time to get a staff that is more gifted at damage control than damage creation.
It may be that everyone around Mr. Clinton is full of wit and virtue. The point is that the nation does not think they know what they're doing. It is time to bring on the gray eminences, and it would not hurt for them to be Democrats -- new ones, old ones, whatever -- but Democrats, just to indulge the voters who thought they were kicking out the Republicans for good cause.
Once that happens, Mr. Clinton could listen to the Congressional Democrats who say the town meeting has become a quagmire. The format projects Mr. Clinton as a man with a channel-surfing mentality, who can talk knowingly about a hundred things when he ought to be talking powerfully about one or two things.
One thing to talk about is getting the economic program through the Senate. Then it would be about time to show the country what his health care reform looks like. If the Task Force is not ready -- well, Washington is a big town. It is full of experts who could probably turn out something pretty credible on a crash basis.
All this assumes Mr. Clinton realizes that while he may prefer conciliation to conflict, Congress does not. Deep in their hearts, senators and representatives believe in threats, bullying and revenge. The question is whether the President is going to do it to them or they to him.
Bill Clinton is smart enough to know that this crisis is more about him than his policies. "This is about my center, not about the political center," he said the other day. The question is whether he is tough enough to act on what he knows. Only a month or so ago, for example, Mr. Clinton, struggling even then, conceded publicly that his problem was a lack of "focus." But this honest self-analysis did not produce focus.
How urgent is it that Mr. Clinton settle down and toughen up? He has lots of time to accomplish a transformation, but probably very little to get one started. What is now an aura of disorganization will begin condensing soon into immutable political reality. From Mr. Clinton's point of view, it is not exactly time to panic. But no reasonable person would want it to get any worse.

HEADLINE: What Makes Energy Tax Scary

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Bipartisan Disservice" (editorial, May 21), on the proposals by Senators David Boren, Oklahoma Democrat, and John Danforth, Missouri Republican, to cut taxes and spending from President Clinton's proposed budget, was not clearly thought out where you touch on the Administration's plan to tax energy by British Thermal Units used.
You maintain that the Clinton-backed energy tax hurts oil-producing states like Oklahoma and Louisiana, and that the Boren-Danforth approach would shift the burden from South to North. 
 The reduction of Federal welfare outlays proposed by Southern oil-state senators would harm large urban areas, as you point out, but these are not all in the North. And how do you explain that senators from Maine and Missouri support the proposals? These are not oil-producing states, and Maine is way up North.
You say a general energy tax is "hardly terrifying." It certainly terrifies all industries that are large fuel consumers. Steel producers might as well shut down most of their plants. (The aluminum and airline industries, thanks to their fine lobbyists, have squiggled out of this one.) Equally disadvantaged will be those United States exporters for whom transportation forms a large percentage of their f.o.b. (free on board export ship) costs, such as rice, grain and coal producers. Our trade balance will get even worse.
The public is not yet terrified of the B.T.U. energy tax because it has not been told the truth. The truth is that this tax would affect all of us intimately, in our jobs and in our kitchens and bathrooms; it will drive up inflation, and the poor will be hurt most. It terrifies me.
If, after cutting Government waste, we really need to raise more money from fuel, a gasoline (not diesel) tax at the pump would produce none of the above ills. It would curb undesirable atmospheric emissions, reduce road accidents and congestion, and give public transport a needed boost. It would not hurt the transportation of goods by air, road, rail or water. Thus our economy would remain competitive.
 
BOB BUSH
Edison, N.J., June 4, 1993
 
The writer is general manager of a tanker company.

HEADLINE: Answer: A Value-Added Tax

BYLINE: By Lester C. Thurow; Lester C. Thurow is dean of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Equity or efficiency arguments can be made for each of President Clinton's tax proposals. But there are also legitimate problems with each of them.
Opening up a large gap between the maximum personal income tax rate (a proposed 40 percent) and capital gains tax rate (28 percent) creates an enormous incentive to get back into the loophole business. 
 While no one likes to pay taxes, all tax increases are not created equal. Each vested interest opposing the President could probably agree on one thing. They would rather see a general value-added tax (commonly called VAT) than the tax President Clinton has proposed for their sector.
The President should propose a VAT large enough to replace the current corporate income tax and Federal payroll taxes, like those for Social Security and Medicare, for both the employer and the employee, and also large enough to raise whatever is desired for deficit reduction and additional health care spending (if that is required). Social Security benefits would still be determined by earnings, but the taxes to pay for them would be collected when individuals spent their money, not when they earned it.
Here's how the VAT would work: It would collect revenue based on the difference between the selling price of a product and the price of components purchased from other suppliers. To make the tax progressive, the first $4,000 in personal spending should be exempted, giving a family of three a $12,000 exemption. The tax payments on this $12,000 would be returned through lower withholding payments or an end-of-year refund.
With the additional exemption of state and local government purchases, a 14 percent VAT would raise enough revenue to replace the corporate income and payroll taxes. For every $42 billion needed in additional revenue, the VAT rate would need to go up by 1 percentage point. Fifteen to 25 percent VAT's are common in Western Europe.
Getting rid of the corporate income and payroll taxes would create a huge incentive to invest in plant and equipment and add employees. Capital and labor would be much cheaper to employ. Exports would go up and imports down. Payroll and corporate income taxes wouldn't have to be built into the prices of U.S. products, and VAT payments could be rebated on exports and collected on imports. The President desperately needs an economic stimulus program, and this would give him one without having to make the deficit worse.
To have a world-class future standard of living, Americans must build a tax system with strong incentives to shift spending from consumption to investment. The VAT offers broad incentives to reduce consumption; it is not focused just on one sector. It creates jobs. It is a way to tax the underground economy: Drug dealers never pay income taxes, but they would pay a VAT when they spend money. The high-income elderly can be taxed on consumption, making it unnecessary to impose higher income taxes on their Social Security benefits.
Traditionally, liberals have objected to the value-added tax on the ground that such consumption taxes bear more heavily on low-income families, who have to spend a larger proportion of their income. But by replacing the payroll tax and adopting a $4,000 personal exemption, a VAT lowers tax burdens at the bottom.
Conservatives have objected to VAT on the ground that it is too "good" a revenue collector and would encourage Government liberals to spend. But from their perspective, a VAT is much better than what the President proposes. Maximum income tax rates would not have to be increased. It is a good conservative principle that individuals should pay taxes based on what they take out of society (consumption), not on what they put in (the income they earn from work or investments).
Political experts have proclaimed the VAT unpassable, but that judgment was made when large, more onerous tax increases weren't on the political agenda. I suspect that now that President Clinton has softened Congress up, he might find it easier to get a value-added tax approved by talking about removing two horrible taxes, the corporate income and payroll taxes, than he would to get his current tax proposals enacted.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Cost Cutters Shouldn't Target Elderly Widows

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your longstanding commitment to defending the rights of those without access to political power deserves the commendation of all of society. In editorials and columns, your newspaper has championed women, minorities, the less affluent and the disadvantaged. However, a group that is overwhelmingly composed of older women, many of them members of minority ethnic elements, is being subjected to unfair treatment by the Federal Government. I refer to the future survivors, almost all widows, of retired Federal employees. 
 Budget resolutions from both houses of Congress will change the method of calculating survivor benefits so that future survivors will suffer a reduction of almost 10 percent in their annuities. The survivor benefit is not a magnanimous freebie, but is bought and paid for by each retiree who elects to suffer a 10 percent decrease in pension income for as long as he or she lives to provide for the surviving spouse.
The average survivor benefit is no more than $13,000 a year, so this reduction will cause real hardship.
It is difficult to conceive of a more ill-advised attempt to cure the country's economic ills than by penalizing elderly widows. Is any other group so vulnerable and yet so severely dealt with by the budgetary powers? Your voice and that of others dedicated to ethical threatment for all should be heard on behalf of a group that needs support.
 
STANLEY M. ADELMAN
Marlboro, N.J., May 26, 1993

HEADLINE: What Makes Energy Tax Scary;
It Will Create Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There are at least two aspects of the energy, or British Thermal Unit, tax that seem to be missing in the debates on the subject:
(1) The tax will create jobs, rather than lose them and will not necessarily lead to inflation because, as it becomes economically disadvantageous to waste energy, we will insulate our homes better. Then, reduced energy consumption will reduce pollution and the needs for extensive and expensive emission controls. Also, we will build, rather than merely talk about, high-speed rail lines in high-density traffic corridors. Insulating homes, building tracks and railroad cars will provide new jobs. Jobs come and go: we now produce very few horse-drawn carriages, full-fashioned stockings or vacuum tubes. 
 (2) The tax need not be regressive if graduated tax credits or rebates are given to those with correspondingly low incomes.
 
LEON W. ZELBY
Norman, Okla., May 28, 1993
 
The writer is a consulting engineer.

HEADLINE: When Americans Are No Longer No. 1

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "New Tally of World's Economies Catapults China Into Third Place" (front page, May 20): In proposing to abandon measuring the size of national economies by current exchange rates in preference for purchasing power equivalents, the International Monetary Fund replaces one imperfect method with another. 
 The first reflects a country's international purchasing power, a reality experienced daily by American tourists ordering a coffee in, say, Italy or Japan, and experienced even more harshly by poor African countries when the dollar-denominated price of oil goes up. The second method, as its name suggests, measures equivalent domestic purchasing power and is therefore much less affected by wildly fluctuating changes in currency values -- but also disguises the fact that, when, say, the dollar loses value, the United States does indeed suffer a decline in its international purchasing power.
Surely, it is preferable for agencies like the I.M.F. to publish both measures, and not just for comparative gross national products, but also for labor productivity rates, the "human development index," and so on, since the selection of one method over the other can radically alter the lists -- as in China's promotion from 10th to third place in national economies, according to the new I.M.F. measure.
Finally, if North American economists abandon exchange-rate measurements, they ought not to be surprised if others decline to follow suit. During a recent visit to Japan, I was asked by some distinguished business editors: "Why is the Clinton Administration trying to force a rise in the value of the yen? Doesn't it realize that if Japan steadily revalues to, say, 80 yen to the dollar, we will possess the biggest economy in the world? What will the Americans do when they are no longer No. 1?"
My reply that such a fact would be disguised from Americans because we would measure national economies solely through purchasing power equivalents brought bewilderment to the editors. Are we creating here yet another example of how different countries will look at things in different ways?
 
PAUL KENNEDY
J. Richardson Dilworth Professor
of History, Yale University
New Haven, May 25, 1993

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The S.E.C. asked 30 Wall Street firms for documents in an investigation into links between political contributions and the awarding of municipal bond underwriting business. [Page D1.]
The Treasury is planning to study whether money market funds and nonbank lenders should be required to follow the Community Reinvestment Act and make loans to poor areas. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Haiti's Premier Quits After Four Ministers Refuse to Step Down

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 8

 BODY:
Prime Minister Marc Bazin resigned today, saying that the refusal of four ministers to step down after their dismissal had made governing impossible.
Mr. Bazin, appointed by the ruling military nine months after the coup that overthrew the the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, said the actions of the four ministers gave him no choice. 
"A change in the Government is necessary on account of the pressure and threats made against personalities that I have chosen to be part of my new team," his resignation letter said. "I was in an impossible position."
[Father Aristide, in Managua for a meeting of the Organization of American States, told The Associated Press that Mr. Bazin's resignation might mean he could return to his country within days.]
The ministers of Finance, Commerce, Information and Public Works were dismissed on Friday but announced on Monday that they would not leave their posts, saying that would breach an agreement signed last year to form a "consensus" government of anti-Aristide politicians.
The military high command met today to discuss the matter, but made no public statement. The Senate met and called upon Mr. Bazin to remain in office as a caretaker until he can be replaced.
Joseph Nerette, who was named provisional President after the coup that toppled Father Aristide on Sept. 30, 1991, declared he was ready to take the reins again. The Supreme Court president, Emile Jonnaissant, 80, was also mentioned as another possible replacement.
Mr. Bazin has come under increasing pressure in recent days as negotiations aimed at returning Father Aristide broke down and the Clinton Administration froze the assets of many said to have been involved with the coup.
Mr. Bazin is blamed by many for the rapidly deteriorating state of the country's economy. Some 300 demonstrators voiced their opposition to the former World Bank official in downtown Port-au-Prince on Monday.

HEADLINE: Angelenos Vote A Conservative As New Mayor

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 8

 BODY:
Richard Riordan, a conservative businessman, was elected Mayor of Los Angeles tonight, ushering in a new political era after the 20-year leadership of Tom Bradley and his coalition of blacks and white liberals.
Mr. Riordan, 62, defeated Michael Woo, a liberal City Councilman, in a hard-fought, nonpartisan race in which personal attacks drowned out serious debate over the future of this city as it struggles with its evolving multi-ethnic identity and with the aftermath of last year's riots. 
 "I think it's great," Mr. Riordan exclaimed as he watched the returns this evening. Mr. Woo conceded defeat late tonight as the vote stood with Mr. Riordan ahead 54 percent to 46 percent.
Mr. Riordan's victory came despite the endorsement of Mr. Woo by President Clinton, who visited Los Angeles shortly after traveling to Texas where his separate endorsement also failed to help a Democratic Senatorial candidate, Bob Krueger, in a race won by Kay Bailey Hutchinson, a Republican.
Mr. Riordan, the first Republican Mayor in more than 30 years for this largely Democratic, liberal city, has his electoral base in the San Fernando Valley, a predominantly white area. His election comes at a time when minorities, particularly the fast-growing Hispanic community that makes up about 40 percent of the population, is beginning to exercise greater political muscle.
Though about two-thirds of the city's population is now made up of members of minority groups, more than two-thirds of voters are white.
The main issues in the campaign were public safety and the economy, and Mr. Riordan's most striking pledge was to lease Los Angeles International Airport and privatize some city services to pay for more police.
He pledged to convene on his first day in office, on July 1, the heads of various law enforcement agencies to find ways to put more police officers on the streets immediately.
These public-safety concerns reflect in part the new realities of Los Angeles, particularly the concerns of the white community, following the 1992 riots, which infused the city with a new sense of insecurity.
In a televised debate Monday night on the eve of the vote, Mr. Riordan described his vision like this: "When I leave as Mayor, I want the city to be clean and safe. I want children to be educated so they have the skills to compete in our society. I want the environment to be clean, and I want every citizen of L.A. to be proud to be an Angeleno."
Although he has never held elective office, Mr. Riordan, a self-made millionaire, philanthropist and lawyer, has for a long time been a power broker in Los Angeles. A self-described "rescuer" who has helped restructure ailing companies, he campaigned under the slogan "Tough Enough to Turn L.A. Around."
He has campaigned as an outsider, and his placards imitate those of Ross Perot with their blue lettering and red star. But he has served on government commissions and has been a major contributor to most of California's major politicians, both Republicans and Democrats.
He poured $6 million of his own money into the campaign, flooding the city with advertisements and glossy, carefully targeted mailers to emerge from relative obscurity to lead a field of 24 candidates, along with Mr. Woo, in last April's first round of voting.
Unaccustomed to the limelight, Mr. Riordan has appeared somewhat awkward on the stump and often fumbled his words in three televised debates with Mr. Woo, an articulate, rapid-fire debater who attacked him with almost every sentence.
Mr. Riordan voiced relief today that the bruising campaign was over. "We won't tolerate that kind of campaigning," he said as he awaited the results of the vote. "I think it's so bad it discourages anybody from running. You need somebody to be as tough, maybe a little crazy, as I am to withstand it."

HEADLINE: Immigrants Both Renew and Unsettle Chinatown

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The elderly man, influential and well known in Chinatown, stood in the front room of his office on Mott Street and hovered between the desire for full disclosure and the need for discretion.
He talked about illegal immigrants, like the ones who came ashore in Queens on Sunday morning. He worried that they faced years of misery and hardship here, that they would contribute to a loss of control in the community, a lessening of the influence of the old guard. Some of them, he said, would inevitably be tempted by gang membership, already a growing problem in Chinatown. 
 It was his mention of gangs that made him not want to talk anymore.
"People are scared," he said.
"Who knows who's behind this, what kind of international gang?" he continued, alluding to the smugglers of the latest illegal immigrants from Fujian Province who are now in the custody of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. "I get my name in the newspaper. Is the Government going to protect me? Tomorrow I'm not here. For what?"
 
A Web of Emotions
 The mood in Chinatown after a ship carrying nearly 300 illegal immigrants went aground off Queens on Sunday was mixed and complicated, just as Chinatown itself has become in the last several years.
Unease was easy to detect. There was sorrow too, especially for the six people who died trying to swim ashore from the grounded freighter. They were, after all, only trying to do what many thousands who now live in Chinatown have done before them -- start a new life in America.
Above all, perhaps, there was a tip-of-the-iceberg feeling, a pervasive belief that the spectacularly failed arrival of nearly 300 illegal immigrants on Sunday was only a small part of a broader pattern. It was a reflection of the fact that this colorful part of New York has been going through rapid and sometimes unsettling change.
"The history of Chinatown in less than 25 words?" said David S. Chen, the executive director of the Chinatown Planning Council, a state-financed agency that provides social services to many new immigrants. "Growth, complexity, more complexity and diversity."
 
On the Surface
 To the average outsider who comes for the occasional meal, Chinatown has an entirely deceptive simplicity as the place of Chinese culture in New York, the home to thousands of little shops with exotic signs and restaurants. Chinatown is the place of storefront Buddhist Temples, martial arts parlors and dozens of associations -- often grouped by surnames like the Li Family Association and the Eng Family Association -- that typify the extended welfare systems of traditional Chinese life.
But beneath the surface, Chinatown is, and always has been, a place in constant flux. More than anything else, Chinatown has long been a kind of transit center, the place where Chinese immigrants -- especially those with little money, no English and not much formal education -- come first, before making some money and moving away, to be replaced by new arrivals.
"Nobody wants to stay in Chinatown," said Simon Wong, a reporter for The United Daily News, a Chinese language daily. "But even though people leave, Chinatown continues to expand because the numbers of new immigrants, both legal and not, are so high."
Before American immigration laws were changed in 1965, total immigration may have been a hundred or so people a year. Now, China and Taiwan each have quotas of 20,000 legal immigrants a year. Hong Kong is allowed to send 5,000. Many of these immigrants come first to New York with a result that the overall Chinese population in New York, perhaps 70,000 or so in the mid-1960's, has soared to more than 500,000 today. And that is just legal immigration. "The numbers are astonishing," said Mr. Chen of the Planning Council.
 
Emerging Chinatowns
 Given that growth, it is not surprising that several Chinatowns have emerged in lower Manhattan and several others in Queens and Brooklyn.
One of the several Chinatowns is the older, more established place, the original Chinatown of before World War II, which was largely settled by people from a single Chinese county, Tay Shan, in southern Guangdong Province. This is the Chinatown west of the Bowery and south of Canal Street, relatively posh and glittery, the tourist attraction and gourmet center, where venerable institutions like the Chinese Benevolent Association, an umbrella group for some 70 social services agencies and family associations, still wield influence.
"Of course we feel sorry for the ones who died," said Victor Loui, the secretary of the association, speaking of the events over the weekend. But, Mr. Loui allowed, there were some feelings of resentment mingling with the sorrow among the older Chinatown residents. The new arrivals, he said, are reputed to work for such low wages that they drive down the wages of others.
"And then, they have to pay off big debts," Mr. Loui said. "And when the smugglers who brought them here want their money, some of them are forced into something illegal, women as prostitutes for example. Some of the men maybe will be forced to rob or whatever. Because if they don't get enough money to pay the smugglers, they can be beaten or even killed."
Another Chinatown is farther to the east, a spill-over Chinatown on the other side of the Bowery, a bit rougher, more unkempt, more Wild West than the older quarter of Mott Street.
 
Places for New Arrivals
 There in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge are a few dingy storefronts with names like Hong Kong Employment Agency and Asia Employment Agency, which everybody in Chinatown knows as the gathering places for new arrivals.
Every day, the men stand three or four deep in airless rooms beneath strips of fluorescent light bulbs trying to push to the counter where female agents have job openings at $3 an hour in the back rooms of restaurants and in garment factories.
It is widely believed in Chinatown that Fujian, a coastal province across a narrow strait from Taiwan, is probably the source of more Chinese immigrants, especially illegal ones, than any other region. Nobody seems to know how many there are in New York, or how many came legally, but among other residents of Chinatown the Fujianese have a reputation.
"They are very tough and they work very hard," said Mr. Wong of The United Daily News. What he did not say, but what is commonly believed is that there are whole new networks of Fujianese associations that operate parallel to the older Cantonese establishment of Chinatown. The Fujianese are also seen as the most likely recruits for underground groups.
The Fujianese are in a sense at the bottom of the complicated social and economic ladder of Chinatown. At the top are earlier immigrants who have made fortunes or who are highly educated professionals who came to the United States from Taiwan and Hong Kong to earn degrees from Harvard and Yale and who do not so much live in Chinatown as visit the district for the marriage of a daughter or to shop or to see their lawyers.
"There are the ones who come by plane," said Mr. Chen of the Chinatown Planning Council, "and those who wade ashore."
 
No Single Pattern
 There is no single pattern, no easy generalization about the lives they lead after they come to this country, Mr. Wong said. A number of them, unable to pay their debts, end up in the criminal underground. Some end up murdered. More commonly, they work very hard for several years, living several to a room, spending very little money, saving what they can, until they can start a small business of their own, sometimes in Chinatown, often in the suburbs or out of state.
Directly beneath the Manhattan Bridge on East Broadway is the Rong Cheng (Glorious City) Flower Shop, whose owner is said to represent a success story among recent immigrants from Fujian, supplying bouquets for wedding parties and other celebrations. One assistant inside the tiny, narrow shop, gave his name simply as Lin and said he regretted coming to the United States, which he did about one year ago from Fuzhou, the capital of Fujian Province.
"Life is hard here," he said, speaking in Mandarin Chinese. "America is not a good place."
But a visitor to the shop, who gave his name as Tony, seemed to be a success story. Tony, who was dressed in Banana Republic khaki, said he came from Fujian 10 years ago and at first worked in a garment factory. Now he has interests in a restaurant and a factory.
"I'm happy," he said. "I got a business. I made some money."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The mood in Chinatown has been mixed and complicated since a ship carrying nearly 300 illegal Chinese immigrants ran ashore. Thriving beneath the Manhattan Bridge is the Hong Kong Employment Agency, a place people in Chinatown know as a gathering place for new arrivals. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nonbanks' Community Role Will Be Target of U.S. Study

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
The Treasury Department is planning to study whether money market funds, consumer finance companies and automobile financing companies should be required to follow the Community Reinvestment Act, which calls on financial institutions to lend money to poor communities, a senior Treasury official said today.
Frank N. Newman, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, said that as nonbanking institutions like money market funds play a larger role in the economy, it was important to determine what their "community responsibilities" should be. 
 "We're talking about a substantial amount of funds" being moved from banks and thrift institutions to money market funds, Mr. Newman said. "We're talking about hundreds of billions of dollars."
Some day, Mr. Newman said, money market funds and other nonbank institutions might become so powerful in some communities that they could drive local banks out of business, thus denying those communities a main source of loans.
The nation's banks and savings and loans welcomed the study. These financial institutions often complain that it is unfair that they have to comply with the Community Reinvestment Act when many of their nonbank competitors do not.
"The banking industry is out there alone carrying the social agenda of America's lending institutions," said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, which has 6,000 member banks. "But we are controlling a smaller and smaller share of the deposits."
Joann Barefoot, a banking consultant in Columbus, Ohio, said, "The market increasingly is being taken by nonbanking entities, both on the credit and deposit side. If the banks are the only ones who have to follow the Community Reinvestment Act, we're going to have a shrinking share of the market place covered by the act."
But the study was worrisome to companies that specialize in money market funds, automobile loans and consumer finance. Several officials from these industries said the decision to carry out the study showed the prejudices of Mr. Newman, a veteran of the banking industry who used to be vice chairman and chief financial officer of the BankAmerica Corporation, the California-based banking company.
 
 
Housing Loans Cited
 Officials from money market firms said they were unsure how the Community Reinvestment Act could be applied to them, noting that money market firms do not usually make housing loans. Several banking experts said that these money market firms might, for instance, be required to invest some of their money in community development banks that aim to help low-income and moderate-income communities.
"I don't know what it means for us," Diane Coffey, a spokeswoman for the Dreyfus Corporation, said. "Our money funds do not do this kind of thing right now. We're not structured to do it, but obviously we will examine it."
Some officials also suggested that it would be unfair to require them to adhere to the act because unlike banks and savings institutions, they do not benefit from deposit insurance.
The Community Reinvestment Act states that a financial institution has an obligation to meet the credit needs of its community, including low-income and moderate-income neighborhoods.
Mr. Newman said he had not yet concluded whether nonbank industries should be required to adhere to the act. He noted that he did not know what requirements might be placed on money market firms and other industries being studied.
"You could make the argument that it's the private sector, and if the Government wants to steer funds into a particular community, the Government ought to do it itself," Mr. Newman said. "Or you could argue that the flow of funds through the economy is fundamental to opportunities for development," and that the Government should make sure that these funds are made available to needy communities.
He said that whatever he ultimately decided, he did not want to place undue burdens on any of the industries to be studied.
Under the Community Reinvestment Act, when a bank or savings institution does business in one city, it is deemed to have lending obligations to that city. But, banking experts said, when a corporation like Fidelity Investments draws money from around the nation, it is not clear what obligations such concerns should have to communities around the nation.
 
 
New Legislation
 Several banking experts said that the Administration would need new legislation to require money market firms, consumer finance companies and other nonbank institutions to comply with the act.
Banking experts noted one peculiarity in Mr. Newman's study: it would look at consumer finance companies, which often make loans to poor communities shunned by most banks.
But Richard Ferlauto, a community development expert at the Center for Policy Alternatives, said, these companies often make loans in poor communities at much higher interest rates than in other communities. He suggested that this would be a violation of the Community Reinvestment Act if such concerns were brought under the act.

HEADLINE: Housing Agency's Problems Deepen As U.S. Rescue Effort Proves Futile

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 8

 BODY:
A year ago, the Bush Administration announced at a news conference that it was taking control of this city's troubled public housing agency, the nation's fourth largest. The Federal officials promised to transform the agency into a model of efficiency and provide a national blueprint for rehabilitating other distressed urban housing agencies.
But the rescue mission was, by all accounts, ill conceived and a failure. And late last month the Clinton Administration quietly returned the agency's management to local authorities -- even though it was in even worse shape by many measures than it was before the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development intervened. 
 In 12 months of Federal management, the vacancy rate, already embarrassing, increased from 22 percent to 24 percent of the agency's 22,000 units. Maintenance work has slowed, the amount of unpaid rent has increased, construction projects have been postponed and the agency's cash reserve has fallen from $6 million to $1 million.
 
Action but No Plan
 Of the agency's 79 top jobs, 60, including that of executive director, are either vacant or held by interim officials. Meanwhile, the waiting list for apartments is growing steadily -- and now exceeds 8,000 families.
Housing experts said the reorganization failed because Federal officials never really had a plan at all. "Neither H.U.D. nor anybody else had a fully developed plan for the agency," said David Gilmore, executive director of the San Francisco Housing Authority.
Mr. Gilmore examined Philadelphia's problems last year, when the Housing Department sought to hire him as executive director of the agency here. He declined, he said, because the agency was prohibited from offering a multiyear contract.
Instead of making improvements, most public housing experts here say, Federal managers simply let most services deteriorate. The results can be seen clearly at the Mill Creek Housing Development -- three 16-story beige brick buildings and several blocks of two-story row houses in a downtrodden section of West Philadelphia where there is more broken glass than grass.
 
Complaints Go Unheeded
 Balconies on the high-rise buildings are enclosed with chain link fence, and razor wire covers first-floor windows. The floors are unadorned cement, the walls are painted cement blocks and as in nearly all public spaces in the building, there is an overpowering stench of urine. The elevators rattle and continually break down, tenants say.
Brenda Barr, 25 years old, lives with her boyfriend, Vince Dennis, 29, and her three small children on the seventh floor of one high-rise. There is one working fluorescent lamp in the narrow public hallway, and live electric wires dangle below a second, broken fixture. In Ms. Barr's apartment, the dingy yellow walls have not been painted in at least four years, and her repeated complaints about a bathroom leak have gone unheeded.
Ms. Barr, who subsists on a monthly welfare check of $316 and pays $197 a month for her two-bedroom apartment, had nothing good to say about the Federal managers who ran her housing development. "They didn't do nothing here," she said.
Two of the four apartments on the seventh floor have been vacant for almost a year. Ms. Barr said that she had complained about drug addicts' using the vacant apartments and that it had taken workers six weeks to board up the empty units.
 
A Matter of Politics
 Although the Housing Department can take over any local housing authority it subsidizes, Federal officials have taken partial or full control of only six housing authorities in the last 25 years.
The impetus for the takeover of the Philadelphia Housing Authority seemed to be more politics than a particular crisis. The Housing Department announced its plan on May 21, 1992, just a week before hearings by the House Subcommittee on Employment Housing and Aviation on contentionsthat the agency had been lax in overseeing the housing authorities here and in Washington.
The subcommittee hearings raised serious questions and offered some disturbing answers about how the Housing Department managed its $6.2 billion-a-year public housing program. Agency officials defended the department at the hearings, saying among other things that the agency had an obsolete data collection system and that the department did not have a large enough staff to handle the work with the 3,100 public housing agencies across the country.
One paradox of the Government's failure in its takeover of the Philadelphia agency is that even Federal officials were unable to make a local housing agency operate efficiently under cumbersome Federal regulations. Federal officials, for example, failed to meet deadlines for submitting a grant application and, as a result, lost $50 million for renovating units here.
"If ever there was a bureaucracy of the highest order producing nothing, it's H.U.D.," said Elton Jolly, an experienced administrator who was appointed by the Housing Department to reorganize the housing agency here. Mr. Jolly, who had no previous experience in public housing administration, is now serving as the agency's interim executive director until the position is filled.
The Housing Department, which provides nearly two-thirds of the Philadelphia agency's annual budget of $150 million, justified the takeover by saying that 13 years of audits showed rampant Democratic patronage, corruption and flagrant mismanagement.
Those audits dating back to the 1970's found that Philadelphia's housing agency was a dumping ground for incompetent and often corrupt political appointees. The agency, for example, received more than $1 million in Federal subsidies for operating nonexistent apartments and its 627 maintenance workers were able to make basic repairs to only 25 apartments a year.
In mid-May, nine former agency employees, including the former director of maintenance, were indicted in Federal court here on charges that they had received illegal payments totaling $535,000 from six contractors, who were also indicted. Nearly all are expected to plead guilty.
Michael A. Smerconish, the Housing Department's former regional director here who began the reorganization effort and oversaw it for nine months, acknowledges that it failed because of poor planning, among other things.
"Our shortcoming was in the fact that we focused exclusively on personnel, and to focus too much on that was to fail at everything," he said. "But I think it was an insurmountable task, given the limited resources we had to address the problem and institutional resistance to change from both H.U.D. and the Philadelphia housing authority."
Under Mr. Smerconish's direction, the city agency sought to replace most of its 1,700 workers, nearly all of them political appointees without civil service protection. "I prioritized personnel over the delivery of services because if I had focused on services, it would have been undermined by an incompetent staff," he said.
But Mr. Smerconish's hiring plan ran into major political problems, when the agency's executive search firm recommended replacing many black managers with white ones. Tenant groups protested and ultimately, the agency put a freeze on new hiring.
 
Concern in Congress
 Officials in the Bush Administration say the reorganization could have worked, but it was not given a chance. Bill Dal Col, the chief of staff to former Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, said, "If the plan is deemed a failure, it should not have been turned over until it was corrected."
Housing officials in the Clinton Administration have said little about the Bush Administration's initiative here and why they ended it. Terrence R. Duvernay, Deputy Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said in a recent interview, "I will personally go to Philadelphia to review where we are and make recommendations for how we address the problem."
Members of Congress say they will ask the Housing Department for complete review of the Philadelphia takeover. Representative Collin C. Peterson, a Minnesota Democrat who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Employment, Housing and Aviation, said his panel was "concerned that H.U.D. is returning the agency without fixing any of the problems we identified last year."
The failure of the Federal takeover came as a great disappointment to many tenants. "I had truly hoped that things would be better when H.U.D. took over, but everything's worse," said Nancy Carroll, a tenant leader in northwest Philadelphia.
With the Federal managers gone, the housing authority's Board of Commissioners has regained control of the agency, picking up where they left off a year ago in apparent disarray. The board has four political appointees, who chose a tenant representative as its fifth member.
Peggy Jones, the tenant representative on the board, said of her colleagues, "The four knuckleheads on the board don't know what they want to do about anything."

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Backs Military Spending the Pentagon Never Sought

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
A Senate committee followed the House today in approving $1.2 billion in military spending that the Pentagon had not asked for.
With no extended argument or questioning, the Appropriations Committee sent to the Senate floor a measure that also includes $400 million of the $19.3 billion in economic-stimulus spending President Clinton asked for last winter. 
The committee heeded the standard admonition of its chairman, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, to "refrain from offering controversial amendments," and no challenges were offered to any important provision.
But two other Democrats, Senators Frank J. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, said they would fight the additional Pentagon spending when the $1.9 billion catchall appropriations bill is considered by the full Senate.
Mr. Lautenberg contended that the military spending would add to the deficit even though neither the Administration nor the Pentagon requested it. But Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the Hawaii Democrat who heads the defense appropriations subcommittee, announced, "I'll discuss this with Senator Lautenberg later."
Mr. Inouye broke down the spending, saying $750 million would go toward relief efforts in Somalia, $295 million for health insurance costs, $100 million for Air Force operations over Iraq, $71.6 million for repairing storm-damaged Marine bases, $23 million for aid to Kurds in Northern Iraq and $10 million for "higher education in the international arena."
 
Pentagon Has Other Plans
 The Pentagon told Congress it could meet the $750 million in spending for Somalia by transferring money from other programs, but some senators said they had not been aware of the position.
The House Appropriations Committee had been irritated by the Pentagon's plan, which called for forgoing $274 million worth of new executive jets and small transports, largely for use by the National Guard and reserve forces. The planes are built in many states, including Mr. Byrd's West Virginia, and Congress usually increases such Pentagon requests.
When the measure was before the House last month, the Clinton Administration called for its passage, though it did not mention the Pentagon money at all. Instead it cited money for Small Business Administration loans, a part of the President's stimulus package, as a reason for supporting the bill. But today the Senate committee voted no money for the loans while keeping the Pentagon money intact.
Today, Dee Dee Myers, President Clinton's spokeswoman, said she was not familiar with the bill or the justification for the Pentagon spending.
Barry Toiv, a spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget, said tonight that it was essential that the Somalia operation be paid for. He said: "We would have preferred that it be done the way the Administration proposed. However, Congress wants to do it differently."

HEADLINE: The Woman in Command in Warsaw

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, June 8

 BODY:
In a country where women are reverentially greeted by men with a kiss on the hand, Prime Minister Hanna Suchocka has surprised most Poles, and perhaps even herself, by surviving for the last year as a popular national leader through tough economic and political times.
Her Government fell nearly two weeks ago after losing by one vote a no-confidence motion called to protest her tight budget. But Ms. Suchocka stays as Prime Minister until September elections, which she could win, and in an interview on Monday she showed in her firm yet cautious manner how a woman has succeeded in a position of power in such a male-dominated society. 
 Displaying little of the combativeness of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, to whom she is often compared and of whom she keeps a framed photo in her office, Ms. Suchocka, 47, said she would continue to run the country in a way that pleased the Western financial institutions.
"While I am still in office, that is sure," she said, underscoring the importance of recently concluded agreements with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
 
Disappointed by Community
 And she will continue to press the European Community for faster acceptance of Poland into its markets and political forums. So far, she said, she is disappointed by the community's foot-dragging.
"I sent a letter to the 12 chiefs of the European states and I described what Poland expects from the European countries," she said, speaking in Polish in her office furnished with gleaming reproductions of Biedermeier furniture. "What's important now are new forms of aid. Not only the technical aid that was accorded to us four years ago."
At the same time that Ms. Suchocka (pronounced sue-HUT-skuh) is eager to push Poland into the Western European embrace, she must also watch Poland's eastern flank with the former Soviet Union, where she said she was concerned about the "extremely difficult economic situation."
The West, she said, has not found the right way to help the former Soviet Union. "Just giving credits, just giving money does not solve the problem," she said. "What's more it can even increase tensions between Russia and the former Soviet states and all this creates very complicated problems."
 
Balkan War 'a Lesson'
 Ms. Suchocka said it was not a matter of Washington's being more aggressive in granting aid but rather "finding more effective forms of aid." Otherwise, she said, conflicts like those in the former Yugoslavia could break out in the former Soviet Union.
"It must be seen as a lesson," she said of the Balkan war. "We must have certain means and ways of resolving the problem before it breaks out."
A constitutional lawyer with a reputation as a conciliator, Ms. Suchocka was chosen as a dark horse prime ministerial candidate last July when her predecessor, overwhelmed by political bickering, was unable to form a Cabinet.
Few people outside Parliament had heard of her and even she confessed later that she was shocked at being asked.
She was immediately confronted with industrial strikes. By standing firm, she eventually prevailed, setting the stage for international financial agreements that had previously eluded Poland. She has often said Polish workers must learn that losing a dismally paid job in a state company should provide a challenge of finding more satisfying work at a better salary.
 
Opposed to Abortion
 Ms. Suchocka is a social as well as a fiscal conservative. She has never married, and her single status makes some educated Polish women with families believe she is too far removed from social issues to fully comprehend the economic difficulties of impoverished families.
Further, these women assert, she might not hold such conservative views on abortion if she had seen more of everyday life in the cramped housing of Poland's cities. She is a practicing Roman Catholic -- more than 90 percent of Poles belong to the Catholic Church -- and she holds firmly to the church's views on abortion.
She voted for a bill this year that forbids abortion except when a mother's life is threatened or when in the first three months of pregnancy the fetus is found to be defective. She voted against her own party's amendments that made some exceptions.
But on Monday, Ms. Suchocka suggested that it would be best if the church, which in the post-Communist era has gone so far as to promote some political candidates, stayed out of the nitty-gritty of the coming elections.
"I hope that the church will be restrained in these elections in involving itself in the support of political parties," she said.
 
High Popularity Ratings
 But it is not yet clear which tack the church will take.
"There is a searching of a place for the church in the new social and political conditions," she said, adding that the behavior of the church in the September elections would be important for its future role.
While there is a vague physical similarity between Lady Thatcher and the younger Ms. Suchocka, she lacks the go-for-the-jugular instinct of the former British Prime Minister.
Does she want to be Prime Minister after the September elections? "I am unable to answer this question at this moment," she said. It all depends on the results, she said, manifesting the moderation and even modesty that seems to be at the heart of her popularity ratings, which were as high as 76 percent earlier this year and still stand at 66 percent.
