HEADLINE: True to Style, Mayor Tells Boston He Will Get His Way as Envoy to Vatican

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 8

 BODY:
People here have been telling Ray Flynn stories since the popular, populist Mayor announced at a tearful news conference outside his Gate of Heaven church in March that he would leave by early July to become Ambassador to the Vatican.
But now the latest one, already being proclaimed a Ray Flynn classic, is unfolding: the former Providence College basketball star goes one on one with the State Department over his job description, and wins. 
 After creating a brief flurry of suspense for his beloved Bostonians -- especially the eight candidates campaigning hard for the Mayor's job -- Mr. Flynn received assurances from the President late today that he would have the authority to take his human rights campaign to poor countries around the world, as he had planned.
So the Mayor, who has been saying since Sunday night that he might stay on at City Hall, will be going to Rome after all. And, in typical Ray Flynn style, he called a news conference -- in the West Wing of the White House.
 
'Ray Being Ray'
 "Everyone was calling, saying, 'Can you believe Ray?' " said Elaine Guiney, the campaign manager for Thomas Menino, who will take over as acting Mayor when Mr. Flynn resigns and hopes to win the job permanently in November's nonpartisan election. "It's Ray being Ray. At this point, he should be on about page 12 of the newspaper. But he's a lame duck at the center of attention."
Mr. Menino, after 20 years of watching Mr. Flynn at work, proclaimed himself awed. "He's like Michael Jordan and Larry Bird," he said. "You think he has no more moves left, and he gives you another one. It's vintage Ray Flynn."
This is a Mayor who is famous for his daring front-page exploits -- pulling old ladies from burning buildings, getting smuggled into the Gdansk shipyards on a flatbed truck for a meeting with Lech Walesa when Solidarity was under siege in Poland, outmaneuvering Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, the Congressman, during Bill Clinton's campaign visit so that the news was dominated by Ray and Bill drinking beer together at a working class Irish pub.
Just last Thursday he was strolling across the Boston Common after yet another ceremony in his honor, telling a reporter how excited he was about going to Rome. "I want to go to Sudan and Somalia," said Mr. Flynn, the son of a longshoreman and a cleaning woman who still lives in the working class Irish immigrant neighborhood of South Boston, where he was reared. "Northern Ireland, Peru, Cambodia. I want to really focus on the issues of AIDS and poverty."
 
Informal Politician
 Mr. Flynn, who would rather shoot baskets with kids in Roxbury than sit behind his desk, or fraternize at places like the Ritz Carlton (when he did show up there, in February, he was ushered out because of his un-Ritz-like garb, a Red Sox cap, and polo shirt with no jacket), said he would not be spending a lot of time at formal state dinners.
The drama began in a meeting with the Mayoral candidates late Sunday night, two days after The Boston Herald quoted unnamed State Department sources saying that the Mayor was treating the job "as a two-year junket," and suggesting that his requests for increased funds for travel and entertainment had gone way beyond normal for Ambassadors.
Piqued, Mr. Flynn said he might not take the job after all. If he was not going to have the authority and money to travel to poor countries and hot spots around the world, he said, he was not interested in the job.
 
Back on Page 1
 Suddenly, the Mayor, who is known as the master of the Saturday news release, was back on the front page.
"Those comments riled him as they would rile anybody," said Arthur Jones, a White House spokesman and Mr. Flynn's former press secretary.
Mr. Jones said Mr. Flynn had apparently been seeking to define what he would be doing as the ambassador to the Holy See. "I think this was all about clarification," Mr. Jones said.
 Now, official statements released by Secretary of State Warren Christopher and the White House today indicated victory for Mr. Flynn. Referring to him as "a close friend and a national figure in social justice," President Clinton said he had "the highest respect for the Mayor's ability as a powerful advocate on issues of conscience and social and economic justice throughout the world."
Mr. Christopher said, "The President and the department often need a special emissary to promote America's humanitarian goals, and we know Mayor Flynn would be able to deliver the message forcefully and persuasively."
At his news conference, Mr. Flynn proclaimed that he had not been worried about the travel budget for the Ambassador's job.
"It was never a question of money," he said. "I just wanted to be able to make a contribution to advancing the United States' interest in concerns over economic justice." At issue, he said, was "whether I had the authority and the support of the President and the Secretary of State to visit countries around the world, particularly ones that are suffering human neglect."
Mr. Flynn's nomination to the Vatican job has not officially arrived at the Senate yet.
 
Pit Bull Confrontation
 Just last Thursday Mr. Jones had been recounting the story of the Mayor and the pit bull. It was July 14, 1987. The Mayor's police radio crackled with the report of a hostage situation in Roxbury. "We sped to the scene of course," Mr. Jones said. "The word comes down that the guy has a pit bull. We heard the worst: the guy was a killer; maybe there was even a chopped-up woman in the refrigerator. I'm there with all the reporters. Then someone said, 'Flynn went in.' "
The man brandishing a shotgun at his front door seemed to know the Mayor. "He said, 'Ray Flynn, is that you, I saw you playing basketball in Providence,' " Mr. Jones said. "They start having a conversation. The door is open. The dog is there. The deputy police superintendent went for the rifle, and the Mayor went for the dog. He pinned him against the wall with the fence gate."
The three-hour police siege was over. And the Mayor had made the evening news yet again. Asked about the pit bull incident on Thursday, Mr. Flynn grinned. "That was a great day," he said. "I wasn't afraid of the gun. I was afraid of the dog."
 
There Are Some Critics
 After nine and a half years at City Hall, Raymond L. Flynn has his critics, of course, who blame him for failing to improve the troubled public schools and carp that he should have spent more time managing the city, say, than holding news conferences and schmoozing on the streets. But in the rush to farewell, at least up until Sunday night, there has mostly been an extraordinary outpouring of affection.
After 16 years of Kevin H. White, "Kevin Deluxe," the debonair Mayor of the Downtown, Ray Flynn was the plain-spoken Mayor of the Neighborhoods. "Millionaires don't need mayors," he said in an interview last week. "Poor people do."
This Mayor was on the scene -- a fire in Mattapan, a funeral in Dorchester, last month's street fight between black and white youths outside his alma mater, South Boston High School, where 35 years ago in this sports-crazed town he was "Flynnzo," a three-sport hero.
Whatever the particular components of his style, it has worked for Ray Flynn in Boston from 1983 to 1991, when he was re-elected, with 75 percent of the vote, until now. Mr. Flynn, who as a state representative in the 1970's opposed forced busing to integrate the public schools, but as Mayor has been widely credited with diminishing racial divisions, won an overwhelming majority in the black community in the last two elections.
In a 1991 Boston Globe poll, 43 percent of the voters said they had met Mr. Flynn. That wasn't good enough for the Mayor, who is 53 and runs marathons. "That poll's a lie," he snapped the other day. "There aren't 43 people in this town who don't know me."
 
Small-Town Mayor
 To spend a day with him is to see Boston as a small town, where at least half the 600,000 residents seem to be friends of Ray. At a park in Dorchester he and eight black men who all said they knew him reminisced about the days when a teen-age Ray Flynn played for the Bruins, a semipro basketball team out of Roxbury.
"You could shoot," said another ex-Bruin, Rudy Cabral.
The next stop was Doyles's, an Irish institution in the multi-ethnic Jamaica Plain neighborhood, where the Mayor downed a bowl of vegetable soup and greeted by name, among others, Stanley Pailbin, a lieutenant detective, Dan Howlett, a sub-contractor, and Peter Fallon, a retired construction worker.
Another of his friends, 15-year-old Stephen Byrd, who hustles candy after school at Doyles's, pulled a chair up to the Mayor's table.
 
Teen-Age Constituent
 "So, when are you leaving?" asked Stephen, who had no way of knowing that six days later thousands of other people would be wondering the same thing.
"Are you making A's and B's?" asked the Mayor who, with his wife, Cathy, has raised six children.
This was the Mayor of Boston? The smiling, blue-eyed man in the Providence College jacket seemed like television's version of a public official, maybe Andy from Mayberry?
On the other hand, Ray Flynn is not exactly unmindful of his image.
Heading back downtown in his station wagon, with a basketball in the backseat, he popped a cassette of Irish melodies on the tape deck, and began to sing. "I sang this on '60 Minutes,' " he said between choruses of "A Mother's Love's a Blessing."
Now more than ever, many politicians here -- particularly the eight Mayoral candidates -- say they just hope Ray Flynn leaves by mid-July, as planned. But this afternoon, plenty of his constituents were still hoping he would decide to stay.
"He's everywhere," said one of them, Michael Wilson, who works for the Department of Public Safety. "He's in my neighborhood. He's in your neighborhood. He's on TV. He's a hands-on guy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Raymond L. Flynn has spent the last nine years as Mayor of the Neighborhoods in Boston. He played basketball recently with youths at a playground in the Jamaica Plain section of the city. (Evan Richman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Russia Will Formally Seek Full Status in Trade Group

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
As part of an effort to integrate Russia into the world economy, President Boris N. Yeltsin is expected on Friday to present an application for full Russian membership in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 111-nation, Geneva-based group that oversees world trade, a senior official of the organization said today.
In a telephone interview, the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Moscow would probably not become a member for at least a year, and perhaps not for several years. He suggested that the changes it would have to make to meet GATT standards would undoubtedly accelerate the nation's transition to a market economy. 
 Western officials said GATT membership would be a boon to Moscow because it would carry with it preferred trading status with other members of the organization.
 
Looking at Russia Positively
 "You have potentially a very dynamic, highly competitive economy," the GATT official said. "At the same time, you have a market that ultimately would represent a huge opportunity for companies in other GATT countries."
In an interview, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said Washington was working with Moscow on its application. "It's part of moving from a command economy to a market economy," he said. "You set up a system of tariffs. You regularize trade. You have a system of rules that people can rely on. It makes it more comfortable for other nations to deal with them in trade."
There are no detailed requirements for admission to the organization as a full member. It is generally required that a commitment be made to removing most trade barriers, but it is not mandatory to have a market economy. Poland and Romania, for instance, were members while they were still Communist.
In 1990, the Soviet Union was granted observer status, and two years later, Russia took its place as the Soviet successor state.
 
Tariffs, Accounting
 Before Russia can be admitted, GATT officials are expected to ask hundreds of questions over a period of months. These are likely to touch on Russia's tariff structure and other trade barriers, its accounting system, agricultural reforms and subsidies to industries, among other matters.
Mr. Yeltsin is to present the application for full membership on Friday when GATT's Director General, Arthur Dunkel, visits Moscow. Then on June 16, GATT is expected to designate a working group to deal with the Russian request for admission.
GATT officials said that as a result of Moscow's application, they expected many of the 14 other former Soviet republics to soon apply for membership. They said it was impossible to know exactly how long it would take for Russia to be admitted.
China is not a member. It applied in 1986, but its chances dissolved in June 1989, when Chinese troops, on instructions of top political leaders, put down democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, killing hundreds.
GATT officials said that they now expect China to become a member next year.

HEADLINE: CLINTON BACKS OFF PLAN FOR NEW TAX ON HEAT IN FUELS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
Warned by leading Democratic senators that he was probably facing defeat, President Clinton backed away today from his proposal for a new tax based on the heat content of fuels.
Later, Democrats in the Senate met for more than two hours over lunch to try to forge a compromise that would be acceptable to the White House and could command a majority in the Senate. No consensus was reached, but senators said afterward that a different form of energy tax was still likely. 
 This change of position is by far the biggest concession the President has made in his economic plan. But if the rest of the plan is enacted more or less intact, it will be considered a major political victory for the new Administration.
 
Met Vigorous Opposition
 The Clinton proposal was vigorously opposed by energy-intensive industries, like petrochemicals, that believe their products would lose a competitive edge in international markets, and by states where those industries are concentrated.
The new version of the energy tax, like the old one, is expected to apply to all forms of fuel, but it would be smaller. Different forms of taxes under consideration would affect various businesses and regions differently.
As recently as last weekend, Mr. Clinton's top economic advisers insisted publicly that a tax based on the number of British thermal units generated by different forms of energy was an essential element in his economic plan. A B.T.U. is the amount of energy required to raise the temperature of a pound of water 1 degree Fahrenheit.
 
Doesn't Want 'Name Game'
 But at a picture-taking session this morning before he met with Congressional leaders from both parties, Mr. Clinton carefully avoided saying he would insist on a such a tax.
"I don't want to get into a name game here," he asserted in answer to a reporter's question about where he stood on a B.T.U. tax.
At a news briefing afterward, the President's press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, clearly following the instructions of her superiors, said over and over again every time she was asked about a B.T.U. tax that Mr. Clinton was "committed to a broad-based energy tax."
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said tonight, "It will not be a B.T.U. tax."
Today's statements were in sharp contrast with what officials said in public over the weekend. For example, after meeting with the President on Sunday morning, Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, said, "We want to maintain a B.T.U. tax," and he called it "one of the basic principles of the Administration's program.
Mr. Clinton had said for months that his energy tax was essential because it was the fairest and most environmentally sound way to raise revenue to lower the budget deficit.
The change in course apparently followed Mr. Clinton's meeting Monday evening with his main economic advisers and Senators George J. Mitchell of Maine and Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York. Mr. Mitchell, the majority leader, and Mr. Moynihan, the chairman of the Finance Committee, are the most important Democratic Senators on tax and budget matters.
According to an official who was there, the Senators told the President that prospects for Senate approval of the fuel tax in the form he proposed it were "extremely gloomy."
Mr. Clinton, the official reported, said little and mostly listened. But at one point he was said to have emphasized how important it was for him to win Senate approval of his budget plan before he goes to Tokyo early next month for the meeting of the heads of state of the Group of Seven industrialized countries.
The B.T.U. tax Mr. Clinton offered would raise $72 billion of the $250 billion in additional taxes the President has proposed for the next five years. Most of the remainder would come from higher tax rates on wealthy individuals and corporations.
 
What Kind of Tax?
 The alternative proposals now under consideration are expected to raise somewhat less money than Mr. Clinton proposed, in part to answer objections that the Clinton plan is too heavy on tax increases and too light on spending cuts.
These are examples of the kinds of broad energy taxes that might replace the B.T.U. tax:
*An ad valorem, or sales tax on fuel. This would require consumers to pay in taxes a certain percentage of the cost of energy, whether gasoline, electricity or whatever. This would be the simplest tax to collect.
*A volume tax. This would place a tax, for example, on each gallon of gasoline, each cubic foot of natural gas and each ton of coal consumed.
*A carbon tax. This would tax each form of energy on the basis of its carbon content or the pollution it emits, a step many environmentalists favor.
When the economic plan was being drafted, Mr. Bentsen favored an ad valorem tax, and Vice President Al Gore supported the B.T.U. tax.
Mr. Gore's position won out in Administration councils because it was believed to encourage more reliance on clean sources of energy and thus to be more environmentally sound.
Mr. Clinton also said often that he picked this form of tax because it seemed to treat all regions of the country evenly.
 
An Unworkable Measure?
 But the B.T.U. tax immediately came under sharp attack, and the House of Representatives, with the Administration's approval, included so many exemptions from the tax in the bill it approved last month that many economists and accountants said the measure had become unworkable.
Mainly, the complaints came from companies that produce energy-intensive products like petrochemicals, steel, class and cement. Politicians representing states and districts where such companies are important employers said they feared that the tax would make American products uncompetitive in international markets.
Senators and Administration officials said they were nowhere near a consensus on what approach to take now. Some senators said they favored a tax just on gasoline. Others supported one on all transportation fuels, which would also include, for instance, diesel and jet fuel.
But those measures seem too narrow to meet the President's concern that the tax be "broad-based."
A carbon tax is also believed to be unlikely, mainly because of the opposition of lawmakers from regions where coal is produced. Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, is one such lawmaker, and his support is critical to the President's chances.
 
A Working Lunch
 The winners and losers under a sales tax or a tax on volume would depend to a large extent on the specifics of the proposal. But environmentalists are less enthusiastic about a sales tax because they say it would be difficult to write it in a way that rewarded the fuels that pollute least and penalized those that cause the most pollution.
All this was kicked around at length at the Democratic senators' lunch today. Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Moynihan spent much of the day sounding out individual senators.
Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a Democrat who holds a swing vote on the Finance Committee, said, "Everything's under consideration, but there have been no decisions."
At the lunch, strong opposition was raised to Senator Moynihan's proposal for an additional $35 billion in cuts in Medicare over the next five years. The Clinton budget already includes $50 billion in reduced Medicare costs.
"It would be a tremendous burden on the elderly in this country," Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, said afterward.
 
Bradley Offers Opinion
 Senator Bill Bradley, a New Jersey Democrat, suggested that instead of cutting Medicare to pay for lower energy taxes, the Senate should eliminate some of the tax breaks in the bill approved by the House and supported by the President. Three such breaks alone -- a less rigid minimum tax, new writeoffs for investors in real estate and more generous deductions for equipment purchases by small businesses -- would cost the Government about $20 billion in lost revenue over five years, Mr. Bradley said.
Several of the more conservative Democratic Senators met at noon in the office of Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma and issued a statement saying the budget should include more spending cuts than tax increases, more discipline in controlling spending on benefit programs and no B.T.U. tax.
Mr. Boren has led the fight against the Clinton fuel tax, and this evening he issued this statement: "I am encouraged that there is a growing momentum to kill the B.T.U. tax. As more attentionis focused upon this tax, the more people see that it is unworkable and unfair.

HEADLINE: Behind Dinkins Budget: Recovering From Gamble

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
In the end, the election-year budget that Mayor David N. Dinkins hoped would demonstrate his managerial mettle came a year too soon.
The staffs of the Mayor and the City Council were still working last night, five days into their final round of negotiations, trying to resolve the last details of the city's spending plan for the fiscal year starting next month. But the budget's thrust is clear: it will feature about $300 million in spending cuts and a retrenchment in some services not likely to endear Mr. Dinkins and other political leaders with voters this fall. 
 The $31.4 billion plan proposed by the Mayor and now being modified in talks with Council leaders represents a sharp contrast to the somewhat more expansive budget they were able to put together a year ago.
That budget put a decisive end to nearly three years of unremittingly dismal fiscal developments in the city. It stabilized spending, and even added a few relatively inexpensive but innovative programs, including new health clinics in poor areas, longer library hours and opening school buildings for after-school programs.
The budget won praise last year for the Mayor from fiscal experts and Wall Street, and the new programs it contained have become centerpieces in his standard political campaign speech, vital elements in the case he presents for re-election.
 
A Calculated Gamble
 So why was last year's budget relatively bountiful, at least in the context of a crushing four-year recession? And why, only 12 months later, is this year's budget so difficult to balance?
As in most matters governmental, chance and design each played a role. In effect, some elected officials say, the Dinkins administration took a calculated gamble a year ago, choosing to build up a budget surplus last spring to stabilize the city's finances during the current fiscal year and to allow them to add a few new programs that would put the Mayor's stamp on local government.
The Mayor and his senior aides took the unconventional step of crafting an election-year budget in his third year -- and not in his fourth, as he was beginning his re-election campaign -- in recognition of his low standing in the public-opinion polls and in the hope that the economy would turn around this year.
But the economy did not swing around, and other events also intervened to make it first difficult and then impossible for Mr. Dinkins to avoid spending cuts now in the midst of an election year.
Last January, for example, the Mayor reached a modest, 8.25 percent, 39-month labor settlement with 19 municipal unions, a raise that may barely keep pace with inflation. But it will still cost the city more than $400 million in the coming fiscal year.
 
Source of Great Strain
 The Dinkins administration also said, around the same time, that because of the prolonged recession, the city's property-tax revenues would be more than $400 million lower in the coming fiscal year than currently. Together, those two developments have caused great strain on the budget for the coming year.
But factors much more directly within the Mayor's control also contributed to the current fiscal distress. "I believe the seeds for the mess today were sown a year ago," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances.
One prime reason that Mr. Dinkins was able to stabilize the city's finances a year ago and add some new programs was a surplus of $566 million in the fiscal year that ended last June. That surplus has been used in the current fiscal year.
The surplus occurred for many reasons. Among them: the city did not use $150 million in general reserve funds and received $146 million more in tax revenues than expected.
 
Transfers From the State
 But the surplus was cobbled together, as well, because the administration invoked a number of accounting measures, including the calling in of $106 million in claims from the state. Mr. Proctor contends that the accounting changes, while perfectly legitimate, could have been used any time. By invoking them last year, he said, the administration in effect bulked up the size of the surplus and created an unrealistically rosy view of the city's fiscal condition.
"Much of last year's surplus came from one-year transfers from the state," Mr. Proctor said.
Those budgetary calculations reflected a broad political gamble, some politicians believe. After having been battered, both politically and personally, by two and a half years of spending cuts, hiring freezes, layoffs and other grim fiscal developments, Mr. Dinkins and his advisers decided to pull out all the budgetary stops a year before he would seek re-election, the elected officials say.
The budget approved in May 1992 buoyed the spirits of the Mayor, his aides and his commissioners, and it no doubt helped lift Mr. Dinkins's standing in polls. But it also left the Mayor with hundreds of millions of dollars in one-time revenues from the surplus to finance recurring city programs, making him more vulnerable to having to cut back spending now unless other new revenues could be found this spring.
Some mayoral aides denied that they had made any special political calculations in the spring of 1992 or that they took extraordinary actions to build up the size of the surplus last year. They acknowledged that the city's improved fiscal condition last year had allowed them to craft some small but significant new programs -- allowing Mr. Dinkins finally to begin leaving some legacy on city government besides shrinking the work force and cutting spending.
 
Waiting for Washington
 Mayoral advisers also admitted that, starting last fall, they had hoped that two things would make budget deliberations easier this spring: the anticipation of a small economic upswing and the presence of the first Democrat in the White House in 12 years. The upturn did not occur, and Mr. Clinton has not yet delivered new Federal aid for the city.
The Mayor, structuring his argument narrowly, in recent days has blamed Republicans in Congress for the lack of additional Federal money. He also has blamed Republicans in the State Senate for his inability to win most of the $280 million in additional state aid he was seeking.
But fiscal critics view the debate in broader terms. They fault the Mayor for not taking more aggressive action to confront the City Hall's underlying financial problem -- expenses are growing faster than revenues -- by eliminating services that the city's tax base can no longer afford.
"They concentrated on filling budget gaps with one-shot measures as they came along," said Charles Brecher, research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group. "They did that again last year, but they've run out of one-shots just as the new fiscal year approaches."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
A Peek Behind the Smile At Rough Journey's End

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman

 BODY:
THE photograph on the front page of The Times on Monday showing a huddled mass of Chinese certainly evoked hard passages and disorientation. It showed the illegal refugees looking out in grayness at the grounded steamer that had carried them 17,000 miles to Jacob Riis beach. But there in the left-hand corner was a laughing face. Wet and cold, a man was plainly laughing.
For months he traveled on a tramp steamer where close to 300 people ultimately gave up sharing a single toilet. He has arrived in America with nothing more than his clothes and they were soaking wet. He may not have realized it when the picture was taken, but at least six of his fellow passengers died in the last leg of the voyage through the waters of Queens. 
 We don't know the man's name, but if he is like most of the illegal Chinese refugees who preceded him, he is a poor man from a rural village who has amassed mountains of debt to pay for the journey. He is separated from friends and family and surely he knows he faces years of grinding labor at minimum wage or below before he can free himself of obligations.
So why is he laughing so robustly?
While he was at sea there came news reports about zooming and prodigious economic growth in the China from which he was fleeing, reports like one from the International Monetary Fund saying that China's economy is four times larger than anyone had thought and that it now ranked third in the world behind the United States and Japan. The people on the ship had no access to news, so the laughing man couldn't have heard that.
Nor is he likely to be aware of other reports about how bad things are in New York, reports like the one last week that described unemployment among the city's youngest job seekers as worse than it has been in a quarter century and twice what it was two years ago.
"None of that would make any difference to any of these guys," said Lawrence Zheng, a Chinatown businessman, who knows other people who came as human contraband. "You know why the guy is laughing? Because he has won."
As Mr. Zheng explained it, the laughing man and the others who swam to shore with him, were most likely villagers who, despite boom times, earned no more than $30 a month.
The cost of the illegal passage, he said, was about $30,000. "In the past you had to put up half before you left, but now there is so much competition from different agents you need only 10 percent," Mr. Zheng said. This down payment was either borrowed from family members, who might look on a relative in America as a lifeline for the future, or from usurers.
"Money in Chinese banks earns 7 or 8 percent interest, but if you lend it to people for passage the rate is around 30 percent," said the businessman. He said the illegal immigrants usually send back the money in cash installments of less than $2,000 through the Bank of China.
"When a man like your laughing man first comes, he is a slave," said a Chinatown social worker, who asked to be identified only as Pearl. "He earns maybe $200 a week and works 15 hours a day every day, usually in restaurants." Such refugees are fed at work, which enables them to send back almost all their wages except for $80 a month used to pay for beds in crowded cribs where people sleep in shifts.
The drudgery seems to be from another time, recalling turn-of-the-century slum life as portrayed by Jacob Riis -- for whom the beach where the Chinese landed was named -- in "How the Other Half Lives." But the Chinatown section of that classic offers nothing to explain the laughing man. Instead, its pages contain surprisingly racist passages noting that the Chinese "are a constant and terrible menace to society" and that "the severest official scrutiny, the harshest repressive measures are justifiable in Chinatown, orderly as it appears on the surface."
It is possible, of course, that the laughing newcomer, now in detention awaiting immigration hearings, did not know of the rigors ahead. According to Christopher Kiu, the executive secretary of Asian Americans for Equality, a housing advocacy agency, people often come with fairy-tale images. "They heard that the streets have gold on them," he said. "They find they have to work harder than they thought and some older ones even go back, losing face and money."
Mr. Zheng said he had heard of some people returning, but he said he thought that most found a better life. "For more than 95 percent things work out. They pay back what they owe in three or four years and become free. I think most know how difficult life will be when they arrive."
So why was the wet man laughing on the shore of America?
Perhaps he was deceived about what lies ahead. Perhaps he felt he would be getting more than just the blanket in which he was wrapped. Maybe he was crazed by the trip. Or, perhaps he just knows things about opportunity and desperation that people who have been here longer may have forgotten.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENT;
Princeton President Addresses Graduates

 BODY:
Princeton University conferred 1,075 undergraduate and 611 advanced degrees yesterday at its 246th commencement held on the lawn in front of Nassau Hall in Princeton, N.J.
The valedictory was delivered by Niles A. Pierce, a mechanical and aerospace engineering major. D. Graham Burnett, a history major, was the salutatorian, delivering his speech in Latin as Princeton tradition requires. 
 Harold T. Shapiro, the university president, delivered brief remarks at the conclusion of the commencement ceremonies.
Mr. Pierce told fellow graduates: "In order to start raising a generation of children who read books, we must first educate a generation of future parents who do not. My classmates, that is our generation."
Honorary degrees were awarded to William O. Baker, retired chairman of Bell Laboratories; Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund; Richard Charles Levin, president-designate of Yale University and the William Beinecke Professor of Economics at Yale.
Also, William S. Merwin, the writer; Sybil Collins Mobley, dean of the School of Business and Industry at Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University; James W. Rouse, developer and chairman of the Enterprise Foundation, and August Wilson, the playwright.
Over the weekend, an honorary degree was presented in a private ceremony to Kurt Weitzmann, professor emeritus of art and archeology at Princeton. On Monday, he died at the Princeton Medical Center.

HEADLINE: Reviving Ailing Retail In Downtown Hartford

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 7

 BODY:
In the eerie darkness, one can still make out the splendor of the former G. Fox & Company, once the grande dame of Connecticut department stores.
Above the faded mauve rugs gleams the playful splendor of Art Deco. Wooden and aluminum strips run side by side along the wall; elaborate swirls of aluminum still sweep alongside a silver escalator. 
 The question for Hartford is what to do with all this grandeur.
After the store closed in February, the city bought the building and an adjacent parking garage from the May Company for $1. It hopes to find a new use that will help revive the city's downtown retail industry.
So far, two large developers have approached the city with proposals for discount centers on the lower floors of the 11-story building; several community groups have proposed moving arts companies or a historical museum into the building, and a city task force is studying options.
Hartford is not alone in struggling with both the decline in downtown retailing and the vacant department stores that symbolize the problem.
From New Haven to Newark to Syracuse, downtown department stores have been closing, and their hulking buildings often remain empty for years, said James W. Hughes, associate dean of the School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University.
 
Combinations That Work
 Such stores are the victims of both the sprawling suburban malls and people's changing shopping habits, said Lawrence A. Alexander, director of the Downtown Resource and Development Center in Manhattan.
"It's not that downtown is weak," said Mr. Alexander, whose group publishes studies and newsletters on downtown issues. "It's that people are not that interested in shopping in department stores any more."
He added: "People over 60, they say, 'We're losing our heritage.' All they've really lost is a commercial entity."
Today's downtowns, Mr. Alexander said, rely less on retail and more on offices, culture and government. Mr. Hughes agreed, pointing out that complexes that combine retail and cultural attractions have worked in several cities, like the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan, Harborplace in Baltimore and Faneuil Hall in Boston.
 
New and Different Anchors
 "That's sort of what downtowns can do if they have historical assets," Mr. Hughes said. "They can take on this kind of touristy-cultural kind of thrust."
Downtown's new anchors -- anything from a college to a medical center -- are often in former department stores, said Richard Bradley, director of the Washington-based International Downtown Association.
The Portland School of the Arts in Portland, Me., is now in the former Porteous Department Store, he said. And De Paul University has a campus on State Street in Chicago in the former home of Weibolt's Department Store. In Bridgeport, Conn., a community college will soon be moving into a failing downtown mall.
Mr. Bradley said it was also common for a city or other nonprofit entity to buy a building for development. That allows them to use the revenue from the retail portion to cut costs for less profitable enterprises.
Hartford is weighing just such an approach, but the economics could present a problem.
 
Economic Assessments
 William M. Russell, vice president of Aetna Life & Casualty and co-chairman of Hartford's retail task force, said the city would have to borrow to renovate the 1917 G. Fox building before it can be used again.
"You don't do that with art schools and music schools that are barely going to be able to pay their expenses, let alone pay a high-priced rent," Mr. Russell said. "There is plenty of room to do everything. We need to find the basis on which the rest of these can stand."
Mr. Bradley said that mixed uses have worked elsewhere, but he emphasized that it was difficult for one-time department stores to remain primarily retail.
"It just doesn't fit in today's market," he said. "It's kind of a dinosaur, and retail today is run by gazelles, if you will."
Yet not all cities are convinced that downtown retailing is dead.
New Haven, for example, is planning a $400 million upscale retail complex to fill the gap left by its two closed department stores, Macy's and the Edward Malley Company, which closed in 1982. Like Hartford, it is hoping for state aid -- in New Haven, up to $100 million -- to make the plan work.
Howard J. Stanback, Hartford's City Manager, said that some retail was essential for the tax base.
"If it works anyplace, it should work in Hartford," Mr. Stanback said. "Here you've got a block of over one million square feet of space with a store that's off Interstate 84 and Interstate 91. And you've got all these people in the region. I'm not sure any downtown can do it, but I think this one can."
Nevertheless, downtown Hartford continues to lose retail stores. Wilson H. Faude, executive director of the Old State House, a historic site in the middle of downtown, moved his office and small gift shop a year ago into an adjacent mall called the Pavilion at State House Square while the State House undergoes renovation. Since then, 13 stores have moved out of the mall, he said.
Of the 18 stores left, 12 are small food establishments -- a coffee shop, an ice cream store and the like -- catering to the downtown lunch crowds.
"I'm the anchor tenant, they say," Mr. Faude said.
Mr. Faude said that more radical solutions for saving cities -- like a reduced sales tax in Connecticut's largest cities -- must be tried.
"One of the things our cities need to understand: No one has to stay here. Not Pratt & Whitney, not G. Fox, not Travelers. The Old State House," he said, motioning to the building behind him, "I can't move. Everybody else can move."

Fox & Company, once the grande dame of Connecticut department stores, and the adjacent parking garage for $1 after it closed in February. Now new tenants are being sought to revive the city's downtown retail industry.; Inside the G. Fox & Company store, a worker stands in the elaborate interior, still defined by the swirls of a silver escalator. (Photographs by Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Says It Won't Rely On Japan Market Target

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
While the Clinton Administration's new trade proposal to Japan will include plenty of numerical targets, Clinton officials said today that they were trying to avoid relying on the numbers that bother the Japanese most: targets for the market share of imports.
Japanese officials and some economists have denounced market share targets as managed trade since the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, began suggesting an aggressive use of them recently. 
 The best example of a market share target is a provision in a 1991 agreement between the United states and Japan in which the Japanese officially acknowledged the expectation that 20 percent of semiconductors sold in Japan should be foreign-made by the end of 1992.
 
Other Measures Planned
 While market share targets may still be used for a few industries, the Administration plans to pursue an array of other measures for foreign access to the Japanese market, Administration officials said today.
While precise targets have not yet been chosen, the approach would include measures like monitoring the number of Japanese car dealers who agree to sell American cars to more "qualitative" goals like making American, Japanese and European laws similar for the production of certain goods, the officials said.
The stance represents a slight shift of emphasis but not an about-face by the Administration. When it was announced in March that Japan had met the computer chip target for 1992, Mr. Kantor endorsed the use of market shares but also said that the United States would continue to use other measures of market access. These would include the extent to which Japanese consumer electronics and computer makers consult American chip makers before designing new products.
Some business executives say that the Clinton Administration is now discouraging them from even asking for market share targets, so as to avoid having to turn them down. "They haven't been encouraging using market shares as indicators," one lobbyist said. "It seems to ring so many chimes on the Japanese side."
 
Not So, Administration Says
 But a senior Administration official denied that any such signal had been sent. "We haven't been discouraging anybody," from seeking such targets, the official said. "What we're saying is, it makes sense to have multiple benchmarks."
At a White House briefing today, senior Administration officials said that while the plan did not include any explicit threat of automatic retaliation, it did not represent a softening of the American stance toward Japan. The officials said that the plan would not prevent America from continuing to use domestic laws that now provide for retaliation if past trade agreements are broken.
One of the senior officials also addressed the longstanding complaint of some economists that reducing Japanese trade barriers would not reduce the United States trade deficit. The line of reasoning is that the deficit reflects differences in the two countries' savings rates.
In response, the senior official said that the United States wanted Japan to reduce its overall trade surplus with the world to 2 percent of its economic output from 3 percent by increasing Government spending there. Most economists believe that this would increase Japan's demand for imports, although it is unclear how big the increase would be.
The White House briefing was held on condition that the officials not be identified because the policy was not being explained by the actual Cabinet-level negotiators, such as Mr. Kantor. Their aides conducted the briefing.

HEADLINE: Yielding, French Accept Farm Pact

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 8

 BODY:
France today accepted part of an agricultural agreement between Europe and the United States that it had vowed to veto, opening the way for progress in broader, and long-stalled, world trade talks.
At a meeting of European Community foreign ministers in Luxembourg, the recently installed center-right Government of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur said it would drop its objection to a major point in the deal reached in Washington in November. 
 That agreement substantially reduced production in European Community countries of oilseed crops like soybeans, which make up a vast part of world agriculture and are used in vegetable oils and animal feed. The United States has complained for a number of years that it is losing its share of world markets to subsidized oilseed products from European growers.
 
Sharp Tactical Reversal
 "We gave our accord on the oilseeds," the French minister for European affairs, Alain Lamassoure, said today.
The agreement by Paris represented a sharp reversal of the new Government's early position. Last month, Mr. Balladur had said that anyone wishing to press France into rapid action on trade talks would be disappointed.
Nonetheless, the French change of heart was only partial. The Government maintained its reservations on another aspect of the November accord, which calls for a 21 percent reduction in the tonnage of subsidized European grain exports over six years.
Mr. Lamassoure said this would be discussed in the broad trade talks being held under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. France is known to be seeking concessions in other areas, including wider access to American markets for its banks, in exchange for agreement to all aspects of an eventual GATT farm accord.
Diplomats said that France's main European partner, Germany, had put strong pressure on the Balladur Government to end its obstruction of trade talks.
With European economies deep in recession, Bonn feels that a breakthrough in the six-year-old tariff talks -- widely known as the Uruguay Round -- is vital to reviving business throughout Western and Central Europe.
In addition, France last month secured an agreement from the community, increasing by about 30 percent the amount of money paid to farmers who are required to take 15 percent of more of their land out of production. At the time, the French Agriculture Minister, Jean Puech, said the deal would allow France to adopt "a more open attitude in international talks."
Under the agreement last November with the United States, the European Community said it would take 15 percent of land used for oilseed crops out of production in the first year and a minimum of 10 percent permanently.
 
Farmers Predictably Outraged
 Today, French farmers objected strenuously and predictably to the change of position. The National Center of Young Farmers called the decision a "a serious strategic error." The Socialists, who governed France last November and signed the Washington agreement, said France had surrendered to the United States. The party is now the chief opposition group in Parliament.
Although the French farm lobby is vocal and politically influential, it appeared that the Balladur Government had decided to try to make progress in the broader GATT talks before the meeting next month in Tokyo of the leaders of the world's seven major industrial nations.
Other European leaders welcomed the French move today. Prime Minister John Major said in London that the decision "removes one of the roadblocks toward moving to a comprehensive GATT agreement."
There have been many similar, and ultimately unfounded, expressions of optimism about the GATT negotiations in the past. But for the moment, there appears to be some new political will on both sides of the Atlantic and in Japan to seek compromise rather than further confrontation.
This possibility of compromise was in a sense foreshadowed last week in talks here among the trade and finance ministers of leading industrial nations under the sponsorship of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
A measure of optimism, if not harmony, prevailed. The two-day session certainly had its share of less-than-friendly sparring over basic trade issues by the United States and Japan.
But those disagreements were minimized in a final statement that somewhat innocuously noted the two trade rivals' positions, while pointedly declining to adopt their characterizations of managed trade, closed markets or other elements of their adversarial relationship.
Officials of national delegations, in particular Mickey Kantor, President Clinton's special trade representative, said then that they were optimistic about soon reaching a breakthrough in what have been the halting efforts to lower international trade barriers.
The officials said that by next month, they expected to achieve a consensus on the elimination or reduction of tariffs on hundreds of products, and that such agreement would presumably lay the groundwork for a comprehensive international trade treaty, something that has eluded negotiators in various forums for decades.
It was not clear, then or today, what concessions the Clinton Administration, the Japanese and the Europeans might be required to make to reach such an agreement. Still, Mr. Kantor expressed a kind of exuberance.
"We are at least within striking distance, he said last week, "of the outline of the largest market-access package in history."

HEADLINE: Big Board Stocks Continue Their Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Like a staggered prizefighter, the stock market came off the floor a number of times yesterday, trying to rally but still closing lower for lack of buyers.
Many of the stocks that declined on Monday, like technology and gaming issues, continued their losses, but others, like banks, found support among investors looking for bargains. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average lost 21.59 points, to 3,510.54. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 240.6 million shares, slightly higher than Monday but still off the pace of recent weeks.
 
 
Widespread Weakness
 Weakness was widespread. The New York Stock Exchange composite index was down 1.65 points, to 245.15, as losing issues outnumbered gainers by a ratio of slightly more than 2 to 1. The American Stock Exchange index lost 3.72 points, to 437.18; the Nasdaq composite dropped 6.87 points, to 687.74, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 2.98 points, to 444.71.
Dennis E. Jarrett, chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company sees the market in a defensive posture. "A couple of large sell programs really accentuated the feeling in the market yesterday," Mr. Jarrett said.
Looking ahead to the release Friday of inflation numbers for May, he said: "We, the market, tend to anticipate the worst, and as humans discount the event by making strategic shifts in and out of portfolios. But when it happens, it's usually not as bad as we first imagine it to be."
A weak bond market also worked against stocks yesterday, as the 30-year Treasury bond fell in price, as did other maturities.
Gaming stocks, which had been on fire lately, showed signs of weakening yesterday as traders began to suspect that they were overpriced.
Oil stocks attracted attention amid meetings of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva this week and negotiations between the Administration and Senate leaders over President Clinton's energy tax proposal.
Apple Computer, down 7.5 percent on Monday over concerns that earnings would fall below analysts' estimates, lost 1 1/4, to 49 1/2, as several analysts dropped their ratings and earnings estimates.
 
 
BankAmerica Shares Slip
 BankAmerica, the most actively traded issue on the Big Board yesterday, also fell victim to ratings and earnings estimate changes by analysts, losing 3/4, to 41 1/4. Traders said Prudential Securities lowered the rating and earnings estimates on Monday because of the drag California's economy was having on BankAmerica's results.
Shares in Deluxe fell 6, to 39 5/8, after the check printing company said it would close 16 of its 60 printing plants and cut 8.5 percent of the division's 10,300 employees and take a restructuring charge for the quarter.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
As Yen-Buying Accelerates, Dollar Falls to Another Low

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell to another record against the Japanese yen yesterday, losing ground despite the apparent efforts of the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan to support it.
Still, the dollar gained ground against several other leading currencies as traders sold European denominations to buy more yen. 
 Gold prices were narrowly mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded contract for gold for August delivery slipped 10 cents, to $375.60 an ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for spot gold at $373.75, up 25 cents an ounce.
Dealers said that the session was characterized by huge yen-buying beginning overnight in Asian markets. The purchasing of the Japanese currency continued throughout the European and domestic sessions, dominating trading.
 
Dollar at 106.33 Yen in Japan
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 106.33 yen, down 1.14 yen from Monday's close, another postwar low. And in New York, the dollar dropped to 106.40 yen, against 107.25 yen on Monday.
Traders said there were indications that the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan stepped in, as they reportedly have in recent days, to buy dollars in an attempt to stem the currency's decline. The dollar appeared to stabilize, but the intervention was not considered to be substantial enough to actually lift the dollar much off its lows.
Much of the yen-buying came at the expense of the European currencies, and the dollar was caught in the crossfire, said John McCarthy, foreign exchange manager at ABM-AMRO Bank N.V. "There is a big repatriation of funds back to Japan," he said. While the economic situation in Japan seems precarious, Mr. McCarthy said that relative to other countries "Japan doesn't look so bad as, perhaps, Germany, and it's neutral against the U.S."
 
U.S. Reports Anticipated
 Mr. McCarthy said currency traders would need more evidence that the United States economy was improving before they stepped in and bought up dollars. Such evidence could come Friday, when the Government is scheduled to report on producer prices and retail sales, both for May.
The dollar also rose to 1.6250 German marks in New York, from 1.6205 marks on Monday. The British pound, meanwhile, fell to $1.5201 from Monday's $1.5220.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Not Pleased by U.S. Proposals

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 8

 BODY:
Japanese officials said today that they would reject proposals made by the United States regarding trade relations because the proposals included numerical targets for reduction of Japan's trade surplus and for increasing imports of specific products.
American officials, at a briefing in Washington on Monday, said that although the proposal would set numerical benchmarks, there would be no automatic retaliation against Japan if the targets were not met. But if that was meant as a concession to Japan, it did not seem to have registered here. 
 "I think it is especially important that we make clear that the Japanese Government cannot accept this point," Foreign Minister Kabun Muto said at a news briefing today, reiterating Japan's oft-stated position that setting numerical targets would lead to "managed trade."
 
No Promises Made
 Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said it would be "unrealistic" for Japan to promise to reduce its trade surplus by a specific amount by a specific date, as called for in the American proposal. "Because it is a free economy, no one can control exports or imports," he said.
Japanese bureaucrats were poring over the proposal they received this morning from the United States. They said the proposal consisted of a one-page outline devoid of many important details.
A meeting of American and Japanese officials is scheduled for Friday in Washington to begin negotiations on establishing a framework for trade between the world's two largest economies. The goal is to reach a basic agreement before the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations in Tokyo in early July.
 
Possible Compromises
 Whether Japan will relax its opposition once negotiations begin, as has happened on occasion in the past, remains to be seen. Some experts have said there may be room for Japan and the United States to agree on some broad policy goals. Japanese officials have, for instance, said that their nation's huge trade surplus was undesirable and should be reduced.
The American proposal calls for Japan's current account surplus to be reduced to 1 to 2 percent of Japan's economic output in three years; it is now about 3 percent of output. It also calls for an increase in Japan's imports of manufactured goods by about a third. Benchmarks are also expected to be set for imports of specific products like autos.
Tatsuya Terazawa, deputy director of the Americas division of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said Japan had not yet received any explanations from Washington about how the United States would enforce the numerical targets. Senior Clinton Administration officials said the proposals did not include automatic retaliation if the targets were not met. Because of a lack of information on this aspect, Mr. Terazawa said the ministry could not comment.
Other officials said that it would be difficult to agree to any targets, even if they were nonbinding. Once a numerical target is mentioned, they said, it tends to take on a life of its own and becomes a source of friction.
The semiconductor agreement between Japan and the United States set an expectation that foreign companies would achieve 20 percent of Japan's computer chip market, but specifically said the 20 percent was not a guarantee.
Nevertheless, Japanese officials have repeatedly complained, the United States treated the number as a commitment by Japan and was considering imposing sanctions on Japan until the 20 percent goal was unexpectedly met late last year.
 
Friction Over Autos
 Japanese automobile manufacturers agreed during President George Bush's trip here in 1992 to try to buy $19 billion worth of American auto parts by the fiscal year that ends in March 1995. Japanese officials have recently complained that the United States is regarding what had been a voluntary plan by the private sector as a Government-backed pledge.
Others here say that it would be foolish for Japan to agree to targets that it cannot control. The trade surplus, for instance, is a result of actions by private companies and by other nations, not just Japan.
"We are not in control of all of the variables," said one Foreign Ministry official. He said that the American trade proposal included a pledge that the United States would work to reduce the Federal budget deficit, but that the American Government did not set a specific target for itself.
"There's an asymmetry already there," he said.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Adventures in Spoletoland: Conservative but Not Bloodless

BYLINE: By ALEX ROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 6

 BODY:
Spoleto Festival U.S.A., held annually here, is troubled by difficult questions in its 17th year. Has this multi-disciplinary event lost its edge, its experimental thrust? Will it overcome internal squabbles and financial crises? Could it survive without the guidance of its 82-year-old founder, Gian Carlo Menotti?
A single weekend's visit did not provide ready answers. For the moment, the festival seems to be on reasonably firm musical ground; there were solid productions of two unjustly neglected operas, some attractive programs of chamber music and a brand-new children's opera by Mr. Menotti. Crowds were large, concessions brisk, publicity relentless. 
 The contemporary programming, however, was discouragingly limited. Mr. Menotti is a composer of conservative bent, and the festival's new musical director, Steven Mercurio, apparently reflects his tastes. The three "20th-Century Perspectives" programs were dominated by traditionalists like Ned Rorem, David del Tredici and Stephen Albert. Works by Peter Lieberson ( "Raising the Gaze") and Roberto Sierra ("Piezas Caracteristicas," a brilliant fusion of simple intervals and sophisticated rhythm) provided balance, but these "perspectives" could have been far wider.
 
'Der Zwerg' by Zemlinsky
 Still, even if the festival has become less adventurous, it has found rich territory to explore. The American premiere of "Der Zwerg" ("The Dwarf," also known as "The Birthday of the Infanta"), a 1922 opera by Alexander von Zemlinsky, was an important gesture on behalf of music that had previously been consigned to obscurity. Minor political imbroglios notwithstanding, it was the festival's major news.
Zemlinsky, a protege of Mahler and the teacher of Schoenberg, is a composer who perpetually needs to be re-introduced. Although he died utterly forgotten just outside New York City in 1942, his European associates -- Schoenberg, Berg, the philosopher and critic Theodor W. Adorno, even Stravinsky -- kept his name alive, and in the last decade his instrumental works have slowly been edging into the repertory. His operas are still essentially unknown, at least in the United States.
With Zemlinsky, it is best to avoid breathless superlatives. No lonely iconoclast, this composer compulsively echoed Brahms, Strauss, Mahler, even the young Korngold. But Adorno argued in his 1959 essay on Zemlinsky that the very reticence of the music, its stylistic equivocation, becomes a virtue. In an age when composers were storming triumphantly toward various dead ends, Zemlinsky evolved an intricate and subtle style from an approachable late-Romantic idiom.
Lacking a voice indisputably his own, Zemlinsky asserts himself through a sort of musical conjuration. He draws the listener on with a certain amount of patter and setup, with stylistic allusions and orchestral illusions, then suddenly lets forth a flash of lyric splendor. His magical fragments of melody, gliding across a rich but delicate instrumental texture, had a crucial influence on the atonal Romanticism of Berg.
"Der Zwerg" is perhaps his most immediately arresting score. Georg Klaren's libretto is based on Oscar Wilde's "Birthday of the Infanta," a parable of innocence and intolerance. On her birthday, a young Spanish princess is presented with a singing dwarf who, having never seen himself in a mirror, thinks himself very handsome. When the truth dawns and the princess spurns him as a mere toy, he falls dead of a broken heart. Zemlinsky, not handsome himself, identified strongly with his subject; the merriment is colored darkly at the edges, and the tragic end is cruelly concise.
The problem is that the story does not quite furnish enough material for a full evening's entertainment; both libretto and score have a few empty stretches. When the Hamburg Opera revived "Der Zwerg" in 1981, it cut and revised the text to sharpen its impact: the opera was even renamed after the Wilde story. In this version, the opera has been heard repeatedly in Europe. Mr. Menotti, who directed the production, unfortunately reverted to the longer and more diffuse original, while retaining the "Infanta" title.
Mr. Menotti's staging was straightforward: an ornate interior with a light-suffused courtyard at the back. One might have wished for a more sumptuous decor to match Wilde's catalogues of royal extravagance, but the story was served. Friday night's cast was led ably by Robert Brubaker, who overcame the demands of the dwarf's lyric-dramatic tenor line with only a few struggles. Mary Dunleavy captured the icy innocence of the Princess, and Marie Plette gave emotional intensity to the compassionate maid Ghita. The Spoleto orchestra, under Mr. Mercurio's direction, played with admirable commitment.
Will this belated American premiere further advance the Zemlinsky cause? "Infanta" would certainly make a strong double bill with Zemlinsky's other Wilde one-acter, "A Florentine Tragedy." The composer is well represented on recordings; the Koch-Schwann label has released the two Wilde operas and also the sharp-edged bourgeois satire "Kleider Machen Leute," and Capriccio has superbly documented the lush fairy tales "Es War Einmal," and "Der Traumgorge" and the dazzlingly eclectic "Kreidekreis," a response to the atmosphere of the Weimar years. All do justice to Zemlinsky's remote, seductive voice.
 
'Comte Ory' by Rossini
 While its Zemlinsky production preserved the composer's original version, Spoleto's "Comte Ory" replaced a French libretto with an Italian translation. It's not a wild leap; Rossini pillaged material from his own "Viaggio a Reims" in concocting "Ory," which is indisputably opera buffa to the core. But the switch seemed to peel away a layer of subtlety from Rossini's final comedy.
Spoleto's production, directed by Giulio Chazalettes and designed by Ulisse Santicchi, is a handsome and vivid affair. The first act takes place amid masses of greenery and earth tones, the second in the high-vaulted bedroom of a medieval castle. Stretching an already improbable scenario, Mr. Chazalettes chose to eroticize the encounter between the Countess and the Page in the dizzying, climactic trio; a gauze bed curtain is the instrument of confusion as the lascivious Ory, dressed as a nun, makes love to his own page by mistake. (The page, of course, is played by a woman; Rossini was gleefully testing the limits of convention.)
On Saturday night, the young cast was superb. Jan Grissom sang the Countess with a light but lucidly beautiful soprano tone, and Charles Workman had no trouble with the high tenor reaches of Ory. John Hancock, a baritone, delivered the jester role of Raimbaud with tremendous enthusiasm, stealing all his scenes. Victoria Livengood was boyishly compelling as the page Isolier. Michele Patzakis, Jane Gilbert, Thomas Hammons and Curt Peterson filled out the cast, and the Westminster Choir proved adept at physical comedy. Robert Duerr, a talented young conductor, drew a sharp performance from the Spoleto orchestra.
 
'Singing Child' by Menotti
 Finally, there was Mr. Menotti's "Singing Child," which had its premiere on May 31, and which I saw on Saturday afternoon. This 48-minute portrait of a child neglected by his wealthy parents follows in the footsteps of the ever-popular "Amahl and the Night Visitors," which remains a masterpiece in the field of American children's opera. The subject is something short of universal, but Mr. Menotti's dramatic instincts are reliable even on a small scale. Two members of the American Boychoir, William Cole and Harold Haughton, winningly played the unhappy boy and his imaginary singing friend; Maria Fenty gave comic breadth to the role of the nasty baby sitter.

HEADLINE: ON THE SET WITH: Sylvester Stallone;
All Right Already, No More Mr. Funny Guy

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
JOEL SILVER, the producer and maestro of those Lethal-Weapon-Die Hard-Predator action movies, bounds over to Sylvester Stallone on a glittering, futuristic movie set at Warner Brothers studios in Burbank.
"How's it going, big guy?" Mr. Silver asks.
The big guy grunts in reply. He has just pumped iron for 90 minutes. He has had his standard breakfast of a protein drink mixed with eight egg whites (but only two yolks) and a half cup of oatmeal and some rice. He drinks mineral water all day. 
 "I'm like a race horse," the 46-year-old movie star said later. "You eat the same thing, you get a similar kind of performance."
Mr. Stallone's latest adventure film, "Cliffhanger," is No. 1 at the box office, although it will most certainly be overtaken by Steven Spielberg's dinosaur epic, "Jurassic Park," which opens this weekend. No matter. Sylvester Stallone is back on top after years of trying, in vain, to break away from the Rocky and Rambo movies that made him unusually rich, which he likes, and an unwitting symbol, which he detests.
"I ended up becoming very defensive," Mr. Stallone said, walking around the set of his new movie, "Demolition Man," which takes place in a weird 21st-century Los Angeles in which there is no crime and everyone is polite and refrains from smoking, drinking and using bad language. "The down side was, I, Sylvester Stallone, became synonymous with mindless, monosyllabic violence. I was reduced to this prehistoric, bestial caveman. People were taking this fictional character and putting him in realistic situations. It was like defending your religion -- you could never win. And the more I protested, the more foolish I looked."
He continued: "Remember when Reagan bombed Qaddafi? He said, 'After seeing Rambo, I know what to do.' And then Saddam used it in his bunker. He said, 'This is not Rambo.' Can you imagine? It became synonymous with a mindset. I became a . . . symbol. I was always worried when I traveled abroad. There were always a lot of threats. When I went to Cannes they said I'd be dead. When I would go to third world countries, it was not so pretty."
And did it hurt him in Hollywood, which takes its politics and causes so seriously?
"Silently, I think it did," Mr. Stallone said. "I don't think people would vocalize it because 'Rambo' was a commercial idea, but politically I wasn't invited to the more genteel events. I didn't realize how liberal the Hollywood community was. And if you're a Republican you really stand out. And I was a Republican by association. When I went to the White House -- that did it. I had been there under Carter. But when it was under Reagan -- ooohh." He waved an admonishing finger.
For "Demolition Man," the movie star is dressed in form-fitting black shirt and trousers for his role as Sgt. John Spartan, who is on the hunt for a psychopathic criminal played by Wesley Snipes. He seems to enjoy the camaraderie of the movie set, joking with the crew and actors. Now and then, he wanders off alone to his big trailer to make phone calls, to read the script, to rest.
Mr. Stallone's arms and muscles are, well, awesome. Yet he seems thin, with not a sliver of fat. "I'm exactly 5 feet 10 1/2 inches and I weigh 176," he said, seated on a chair on the set and waving as Mr. Snipes, in a blond wig, walked past. "When I'm doing a movie I eat the same thing every day. For lunch, it's tuna salad or chicken salad and cole slaw. That's it. For dinner it's either veal and rice, fish and rice or steak and rice. It gets boring, boy, does it get boring."
"Every morning I crawl out of bed," he went on, "I sit there and think, 'Do I really need this?' And I drag myself to the gym in my garage. It's not fun. I hate it. I work out alone. Weights. I got 25 different complicated machines and you're all alone and you're stiff and you still got sleep in your eyes and every bone in your body hurts and you look at the machine and you know there are 390 or 400 pounds on it and the heaviest thing you've been lifting for eight hours is a pillow. I do not like it."
Well, of course, there are compensations for all that heavy lifting. He earns $12.5 million to $15 million a picture.
Mr. Stallone was married 10 years and had two children before divorcing Sasha Stallone. He was briefly married to Brigitte Nielsen, and now his companion is Jennifer Flavin, a model. He lives in the style of a 1940's movie star, with homes in Malibu and the Benedict Canyon area of Los Angeles and a newly purchased mansion in the Coconut Grove area of Miami, where he plans to spend a lot of time.
"I'm not too bullish about L.A.," he said. "L.A. has some problems that are really unique unto itself and I don't they're reversible. Unemployment is skyrocketing. Ecological problems are horrific. There's organized gang warfare that makes Al Capone seem like a choir boy. People are being polarized -- black, white, Hispanic. And it's gotten to a point where everything has to be so politically correct, so diluted. Everyone is walking on eggshells. I don't think it's a place conducive to peace of mind."
Mr. Stallone -- "Sly" to virtually everyone -- moves before the cameras on the set of "Demolition Man." The director, Marco Brambilla, who is making his debut, is a youthful, Milan-born film maker who has spent years in Canada and the United States making commercials. Everyone is given cloth coverings for their shoes to keep the floors glistening on the sci-fi set.
Outside, on the sun-drenched lot, Mr. Stallone walks past his white Mercedes toward his trailer. He signs an autograph for a tourist, poses for a picture and kids around with a teen-age boy.
"I joke around on the set, deliberately," he said. "I know I can't play funny roles in movies. I tried and it didn't work. I don't see myself as Rocky or Rambo. I see myself, sometimes, as a funny guy. There's a different side to my personality. But when I tried to extend that image on screen I brought too much baggage with me. So I put my creative ego back in the suitcase.
"Some of it is obviously physical. Woody Allen wouldn't be believed as Rambo."
Mr. Stallone's career has been framed by Rocky and Rambo. In 1976, as an unknown, he wrote the screenplay for "Rocky" and starred in the movie. In 1982, with "First Blood," he portrayed John Rambo, a grunting, angry ex-Green Beret who flees a false arrest by some small-town cops. The Rocky and Rambo characters spawned a total of six sequels, and Mr. Stallone became an international star and director.
But Rocky and Rambo also imprisoned him. Efforts to do something different, in comedies like "Rhinestone" (1984) with Dolly Parton, "Oscar" (1991) and "Stop! Or My Mom Will Shoot" (1992), were major disappointments.
"I appreciate people reminding me that they were bombs," he said. "I don't look at them as bombs so much as eye-openers into the impact films have in stereotyping individuals. I'm a stereotype. I can't break away from that."
He attributes his inability to reach beyond adventure movies to his tough-guy style, his Noo Yawk accent and his thick muscles and voice. "My voice is deep, too deep for comedy," he said. "It's a dark voice. Definitely too low. Voices are like fingerprints, from Cagney to Bogart. They never lost it. My voice is instrumental in categorizing me."
Meanwhile, Arnold Schwarzenegger began taking over the action genre.
"Yeah, I think we're competitive," he said. "We've talked about this. We're kind of like Ali and Frazier. LaMotta and Sugar Ray. Arnold and Sly. Arnold's been nice. He was very complimentary at the opening of 'Cliffhanger.' I'm going to his movie this Sunday." (Mr. Stallone is partners with Mr. Schwarzenegger, whose new movie is "Last Action Hero," and with Bruce Willis, among others, in the Planet Hollywood restaurant chain.)
In "Cliffhanger," Mr. Stallone gives a restrained, even vulnerable, performance as a National Park Service ranger fighting an evil international bunch on a snowy mountaintop. The film, shot in the Italian Alps, has generally earned positive reviews.
That film's success is, he says, a validation. "It's a wake-up call for me," he said. "I've got to do what audiences expect me to do. Let's face it, there was a bond between me and Rocky and Rambo. Over the years, it became difficult to tell the fictional and real characters apart. When I try to exert some artistic leverage and show the other side of my personality, it's rejected. O.K., I accept it."
Mr. Stallone's next film after "Demolition Man" will probably be what he calls an erotic drama and adventure, tentatively called "Fair Game." He is working on the movie with Mr. Silver.
As he discussed the new venture, he knew he sounded like a character out of "The Player," the scathing movie about Hollywood in which every new movie is succinctly characterized with references to previous movies.
"The new movie," he said, laughing, "is 'Body Heat' on wheels."

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By Ron Alexander

 BODY:

DEAR Diary:
Walking along Sixth Avenue, headed for CBS the other morning, I was confronted by a gray-haired woman in a raincoat and carrying an umbrella. She said, "You're Frank Field and you said it was going to be a nice day and that the dark clouds would clear."
I said, "Yes, it is going to be a nice day and the dark clouds will clear."
She said, "No, they won't."
I said: "Yes, they will. Trust me."
She replied: "I'll bet you a dollar they won't. It's going to rain."
I said: "O.K. You have a bet." With that we went our respective ways.
I had forgotten all about the incident until a few days later, when I opened a letter and a dollar fell out. There was also a note: "Enclosed find $1 for the bet we made yesterday concerning rain. I lost! I am not a deadbeat." It was signed, "The gray-headed lady you met."
I am going to send the lady a thank-you note and tell her I knew she wouldn't welsh on the bet and I am going to contribute her dollar to a charity. -- FRANK FIELD
