Dear Diary:
The scene was my local video store in Greenwich Village, where I asked for a film just released on tape, a movie it seemed everyone but me had seen.
Clerk: "Howards" what?
Me: "End."
Clerk, scanning computer screen: Nope. But we've got "Howard the Duck" and Howard Stern.
Me: No thanks. I can wait. I've waited this long. -- BILL HARTFORD

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Dear Diary:
Reading about the paint-smeared fur coats that demonstrators recently wore to protest the showings of fall furs, I considered how New York attitudes had changed from those of the city I knew in childhood.
Back then, it would not have seemed possible that women would protest the wearing of fur coats, which were the sine qua non of status.
My mother, who grew up poor in the Bronx, married a guy who made lots of money and liked to show her off. Dad always got the best and lots of it for his smart-mouth doll. Eventually the walk-in closets were so full that the doors flew open without warning. So some nice outdated coats and stoles found their way up to the Bronx, to my grandmother and the aunts.
My grandmother kept Mother's furs carefully. (We might be poor again and need to sell them.) She sewed threadbare sheets into protective dust-covers for them. She wore them only on holidays, for picture-taking, or when she was bidden downtown to dine with Mother and Dad.
My grandfather was a frequently unemployed cartoonist, and those furs had been a long time in coming to her. Grandmother was not about to give them over to the coat-check girl. She clutched the furs tightly, and carefully folded them inside out. She had the bearings of a duchess, but she knew the value of things.
Dad was a well-known sports figure and it embarrassed him to be seen with a woman who looked like a million but acted as if someone were going to steal her coat.
Dad told Mother, so Mother told Grandmother: "Take it easy. Act rich. Be casual. Drape the furs. Be theatrical. Think Barbara Stanwyck, Lizabeth Scott, Bette Davis."
Next monthly dinner, Dad chose Dinty Moore's, a former speakeasy in the theater district. The maitre d'hotel led the way to my parents' table and behind them marched my unhappy, martyred little grandmother. Her head high, her fist clutching the collar of her mink coat with great purpose, she trailed it behind her, cutting a swath through the sawdust. -- SHEILA SHIKI y MICHAELS

Dear Diary:
This morning, at the tail end of rush hour, a Manhattan-bound No. 5 train pulled into Franklin Avenue in Brooklyn. A little dog trotted through the open door, spotted a comfortable place under a seat and settled down.
A few minutes later, the train drew to a stop at Brooklyn Bridge. The doors opened, the dog looked up matter of factly and exited the train.
"I suppose this is where his office is," one rider said.
I say: Listen, it's a dog-eat-dog world. -- BONNIE HILLER

HEADLINE: The Golden Venture, Plus 100,000

 BODY:
The four-month nightmare voyage of the Golden Venture ended Sunday morning when the tramp freighter dumped its starving and frightened cargo of nearly 300 Chinese immigrants into frigid waters off one of New York City's most popular public beaches. Six passengers died from drowning or exposure, several had to be hospitalized and the remainder were sent to detention centers to await Federal hearings.
But for the estimated 100,000 illegal Chinese immigrants who arrive each year, mostly to New York, the nightmare typically goes on and on. The $3,000 down payment they make to "snakehead" smugglers before departure -- several years' earnings for a typical Chinese -- covers barely a tenth of what they must ultimately pay to travel huddled below deck for months without adequate food or sanitation. The remaining money must be paid off through years of indentured servitude -- virtual slavery -- in Chinese restaurants and sweatshops. 
 For the immigrants, it's a cruel deception of the hopes that lured them from China in expectation of a "golden land" of easy affluence. For New York area law enforcement officials it's an explosive problem, as the Asian gangs and freelance criminals profiting from this human traffic grow increasingly rich, brazen and violent. And for Washington it's another warning -- after the Haitian fiasco -- that America's ad hoc asylum policies have slipped out of whack with post-cold-war realities.
Given the probable size of recent illegal Chinese immigration, the numbers of indentured laborers in the New York area must be huge indeed, certainly reaching the tens of thousands. City, state and Federal labor inspectors must make greater efforts to uncover scandalous labor conditions now masked by the terror of victimized workers, language barriers and an insular Chinatown culture. Specifically that will require recruitment and training efforts aimed at increasing the number of inspectors and law enforcement agents who speak the Chinese dialects used by most of the new immigrants.
Cracking down on the gangs and immigrant brokers will be especially difficult, given their decentralized nature. But it must be done. Almost weekly now, new reports surface of immigrants held hostage in warehouses. And last month's deadly shootout in Teaneck shows the escalating potential for tragedy. Trafficking in humans is now said to offer easier profits than trafficking in drugs, and the penalties faced by those caught are much lighter, an anomaly that needs to be corrected.
Finally, well-intended Federal asylum policies have unwittingly encouraged widespread illegal Chinese immigration. Four years ago George Bush ordered that asylum be granted to those who left China to escape Beijing's harsh rule of one child per family. That claim could plausibly be made by hundreds of millions of Chinese who would not otherwise be considered political refugees.
The vast majority, perhaps 95 percent, of illegal immigrants from China enter the U.S. undetected and never see a Federal immigration officer. But of those who do, virtually all now claim asylum, and an astonishing 80 percent of those claims are approved, many times the percentage for other national groups. When word of the lenient new American policy got back to provincial China, departures for the U.S. began to surge dramatically. By some indicators there has been a tenfold increase in just the past two years.
One answer on the Federal level would be to subject these asylum claims based on the single-child policy to stricter standards of proof that actual persecution might take place. Another would be to expedite the hearings while preserving due process. Asylum claims now take about 18 months to evaluate, during which many claimants simply disappear into the general population. Washington could also work with Chinese authorities to publicize the indentured servitude and bleak prospects facing illegals in the United States, thus deflating the false hopes that fuel the boom in smuggling of human cargo.
It's unrealistic to pretend that illegal immigration from China, or anywhere else, can be completely halted. Economic incentives at both ends of the traffic are just too powerful. But it should be possible to reduce it to the more manageable levels that prevailed before 1991. The alternative is not just tolerating more Golden Ventures. It's tolerating slavery, in New York, in 1993.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Increase As OPEC Meets in Geneva

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Crude oil futures rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but finished off the day's highs as a result of continued disagreement among members of OPEC over limits on production.
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is meeting in Geneva to set third-quarter production levels and to allocate member quotas. 
 Light sweet crude oil for July delivery settled 11 cents higher at $19.65 a barrel. July heating oil was 0.13 cent higher at 53.71 cents a gallon. July unleaded gasoline was 0.03 cent higher at 56.15 cents a gallon, and July natural gas was 9 cents cent higher at $2.129 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Energy futures gained in early trading on reports from Geneva that Saudi Arabia would insist on compliance with OPEC quotas and that more oil should not be put onto the market. That was a reversal of the Saudi position on Monday, when the country's representatives said they would accept some tinkering with production quotas.
 
Kuwaitis Reject Plan
 The Kuwaitis said they would refuse to accept a 200,000-barrel-a-day increase in their third-quarter quota, which has been suggested as a way to pacify Kuwait. It is pushing for an increase of 400,000 barrels a day in its current supply quota of 1.6 million barrels a day.
The emirate, rebounding from the Persian Gulf war damage to its oilfields, wants to earn extra money to pay off the $50 billion costs of the conflict and rebuild its oil industry.
Recent reports estimate that the dozen nations of OPEC increased pumping last month. In May, the nations pumped 600,000 barrels a day above the current crude ceiling of 23.6 million barrels a day, according to the reports.
Jim Turner, an analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in New Jersey, said that despite the market's higher close, it settled in a downtrend. He noted that although the expiration of the July contract was weeks away, investors were bailing out in large numbers.
"To be in a spot month during an OPEC meeting is gambling," Mr. Turner said.

HEADLINE: Whitman Pursues 'Family Business'

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 8

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman tonight won both the Republican nomination for governor and a place in New Jersey political history.
In her quest for the governor's office, Mrs. Whitman has presented herself as a political outsider. In truth, given her family background, it would have been surprising if she did not go into politics. 
 She was exposed from childhood to a circle of powerful people and every recounting of her biography includes the story of how, at the age of 14, she sold lemonade to raise money for the 1960 Presidential campaign of Richard M. Nixon, the father of two of her childhood friends.
 
Challenges Bill Bradley
 Nearly 30 years later, when Mrs. Whitman decided to buck the odds and to challenge the seemingly invincible Democratic Senator Bill Bradley, the reclusive Mr. Nixon helped raise money for her campaign.
While contacts like these gave her a head start, she built her campaign for governor from the ground up, crisscrossing the state this year in a leased 1992 Mercury Sable, locking up endorsements from many county leaders before her opponents got on the road at all.
The 46-year-old is an adroit politician whose strongest asset is an affable style. That has helped offset the elitist image that her Republican primary opponents tried to paste on her, not the least by reminding voters that she has never held a job in the private sector.
Tonight at Mrs. Whitman's victory celebration in East Brunswick, her brother, Webster B. Todd Jr., suggested that such criticism was off the mark.
"Politics really is the family business and she's continuing a job in the family business that she started with dad and Eisenhower when she was just a little kid," said Mr. Todd, a Montana rancher and former member of the New Jersey Assembly.
That family business will get even more family involvement soon if Mr. Todd, a volunteer adviser to his sister's primary campaign, takes on a bigger role in the fall race, as many people expect.
Mrs. Whitman's father, the late Webster B. Todd, was Republican state chairman for a decade, a major figure in the national G.O.P. and an adviser to President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Her mother, the late Eleanor Schley Todd, was a Republican national committeewoman and leader of the New Jersey Federation of Republican Women.
Mr. Todd was a building contractor whose projects included Manhattan's Rockefeller Center and Radio City Music Hall and historical Williamsburg, Va. It enabled him to amass a personal fortune, which he frequently used to bankroll Republican campaigns and which gave his children the luxury to dabble in politics and public service.
Her marriage to John Whitman, a financier, placed her in another equally impressive political family and sphere.
Mr. Whitman is the grandson of Charles S. Whitman Sr., the governor of New York from 1914 to 1916. His father, Charles S. Whitman Jr., was a Circuit Court judge in New York.
John and Christine Whitman have two children, 16-year-old Kate and 14-year-old Taylor.
Mrs. Whitman graduated from Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., in 1968 with a bachelor's degree in government, and went to work for the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity and later the Republican National Committee.
 
First Bid for Office
 In 1982, she made her first bid for political office, a seat on the Somerset County Board of Chosen Freeholders, the governing body for the county. She won and was re-elected in 1985, serving a total of five years before Gov. Thomas H. Kean appointed her in 1988 to serve as president of the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities.
Still, she was largely unknown outside of Republican circles when she decided to run against Mr. Bradley in 1990. She easily won the Republican nomination, in a large part because most better known politicians thought it foolhardy to challenge the immensely popular Mr. Bradley, a former National Basketball Association star player and a Rhodes Scholar.
Focusing her campaign on Mr. Bradley's refusal to comment on a $2.8 billion tax increase pushed through the Legislature by a fellow Democrat, Gov. Jim Florio, Mrs. Whitman came with two percentage points or less than 59,000 votes of beating the incumbent.
It immediately propelled her into statewide prominence and made her the favorite to capture the G.O.P.'s gubernatorial nomination in 1993.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 12, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in some copies on Wednesday about Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican nominee for governor in New Jersey, misstated the term served by her husband's grandfather, Charles S. Whitman Sr., as Governor of New York. It was 1915 through 1918.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Post Modest Rise

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday in light trading, accomplishing little more than making up the losses of the day before, traders said.
"There seems to be a pattern of reversing the previous day's move when we are in a thin market" and there is no new economic data to trade on, said Alan Levenson, the money market economist at UBS Securities. 
 "It is like the third week in August," he added, referring to the light trading of the summer doldrums. "To say that it is quiet is an understatement."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond due in February 2023 was up 14/32 point, to 1033/32, as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 6.88 percent. On Tuesday, the price of the bond fell 16/32 and the yield rose to 6.91 percent.
The price of the two-year Treasury note was up 2/32, which pulled the yield down to 4.28 percent, reversing the 2/32 -point decline the day before.
 
 
No Major Economic Data
 There were no major economic data released yesterday. And it did not appear that the efforts in Washington to reach a compromise on the President's deficit reduction plan had any significant impact on the market because it was still too early to tell what the outcome of negotiations would be.
The focus continued to be on the next two inflation reports, the May Producer Price Index, which will be released tomorrow, and the May Consumer Price Index, which will follow on Tuesday.
It appeared that forecasters were not expecting the kind of bad news on inflation that jolted the bond market last month, when the April consumer price report showed that inflation this year was running at an annual rate of 4.3 percent. If these forecasts are right, the Federal Reserve may be able to hold off for another month on deciding whether to raise short-term interest rates as a signal of its determination to resist rising prices.
Mr. Levenson was expecting a two-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Producer Price Index for finished goods and a three-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index. "These are fairly benign numbers," he said, adding that the risk is that the Producer Price Index would be higher while the Consumer Price Index would be lower.
Michael A. Strauss, the chief economist at Yamaichi International, said he expected the Producer Price Index for finished goods to rise one-tenth of 1 percent and the Consumer Price Index to increase by two-tenths of 1 percent. He said that the cut in brand-name cigarette prices last month would not help lower prices in May because the prices of generic cigarettes had risen and seasonal adjustment factors were likely to make tobacco prices a little higher.
Neither Mr. Levenson nor Mr. Strauss expected that the increases in the two key inflation barometers would be enough to force the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates. The Fed has indicated recently that it has shifted its position to a bias toward higher interest rates because of the sharp rise in inflation during the first four months of the year.
 
 
Retail Sales
 Mr. Strauss said that in the end, retail sales data for May, which will also be released tomorrow, might be more important than the inflation figures.
He expected sales to rise by about 1 percent, in part because of the recent rebound in automobile sales. If the number is at this level it could be another strong indication that the economy in the second quarter is growing at a 3 percent annual rate rather than a pace closer to the nine-tenths of 1 percent creep for the first quarter of the year.
Proof that the economy is moving ahead at this faster pace would make the inflation data -- even if subdued -- a little more troublesome. With an economy picking up momentum it would become less likely that inflation could slow enough in the second half of the year to take the worry on prices out of the market.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Fed Approves Acquisitions by Bank of Boston

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board allowed the Bank of Boston Corporation yesterday to buy two New England banks, even though three Fed governors publicly objected to the approval of one acquisition.
The board had initially voted June 1 to reject Bank of Boston's bid to acquire the Multibank Financial Corporation, a chain of local banks based in Dedham, Mass., with $2.36 billion in assets. But the board reconsidered the proposal after the Bank of Boston, which has $32 billion in assets, agreed to raise $170 million in new capital.
 
Revised Application Opposed
 Three Federal Reserve governors, David W. Mullins Jr., Edward W. Kelley Jr. and Lawrence Lindsey, abstained from the vote on the Multibank acquisition. They later released a sharply worded dissent saying that the Bank of Boston should not have been allowed to modify its capital plan after the application was submitted. 
 The Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, and three governors -- Wayne D. Angell, John P. LaWare and Susan Phillips -- voted for the Multibank acquisition. All seven voted to approve the Bank of Boston's purchase of the Society for Savings in Hartford, which has $2.4 billion in assets.
In their dissent to the Multibank purchase, the three governors wrote, "Our abstention reflects our strong dissatisfaction with the way in which this application was considered."
The Bank of Boston "had ample opportunity prior to the time that this matter was scheduled to make changes to its proposal," the three dissenters said. Allowing banks to change proposals after the board has considered them "would encourage applicants to submit marginal proposals and then attempt to negotiate an acceptable proposal directly with the board."
The Bank of Boston has been recovering from severe problems stemming from the New England recession. The bank reported losses of $394 million in 1990 and 27 million in 1991. But it earned $263 million last year.
Both Multibank and Society for Savings were also hurt by the region's poor economy, although their condition has also been improving.
 
Capital Level a Concern
 Bank of Boston reported Tier 1 Risk adjusted capital of 7.15 percent. Tier 1 capital is one of the key measures of financial strength used by the regulators. While that level is more than the 6 percent minimum, the bank ranks 46th of the country's top 50 banks in Tier 1 capital.
While the two purchases would not greatly reduce the bank's capital, the Fed said in a statement, they would lessen the Bank of Boston's "capacity to serve as a source of strength for its banking subsidiaries."
"New capital should be maintained to meet the unexpected problems in BBC's subsidiary banks if necessary," the Fed said.
Charles K. Gifford, Bank of Boston's president, said that he did not think "we were by any means undercapitalized before the $170 million" in new capital. But he said that the new capital would further strengthen the Bank of Boston's reserves. He declined to comment on its dealing with the Federal Reserve.
Lawyers and investment bankers familiar with the deal said that the Federal Reserve staff asked the Bank of Boston to modify its proposal to include more capital and that bank officials refused, agreeing only after they learned of the initial rejection of the application. It is unusual for banks to learn of rejected applications before they are made public and more unusual for the bank to be allowed to change its submission.
 
A 'Board Tradition'
 "It is board tradition that once a proposal is submitted it can't be modified or changed," said Michael Bradfield, a partner with Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue and a former general counsel of the Federal Reserve. "The board doesn't want applicants testing it."
The issue is more one of style and personality in the relations between the bank and the Federal Reserve than one of financial substance.
"Experienced acquirers know how to deal with the Fed," said a lawyer familiar with the Federal Reserve. "If you get the hint, you take it. You don't take a chance for $50 or $100 million," he said.
The new capital, while only modestly adding to the bank's cushion against problems, has little additional cost for the bank. Bank of Boston reported total capital of $3.6 billion at the end of 1992. It plans to issue $70 million in preferred stock and $100 million in subordinated debt that will carry combined interest cost of about $12 million a year, investment bankers estimated.

HEADLINE: Budget Talks With Mayor In a Standoff

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Four days after the City Charter deadline for adopting a new budget, talks between the City Council and the Dinkins administration degenerated yesterday into a schoolyard standoff. The two sides spent the day finger-pointing and saber-rattling, but failed to make progress on the three main issues dividing them.
The Council Speaker said the standoff was the Mayor's fault for leaving City Hall the other night when, in the Speaker's view, a deal was at hand. But the Mayor's staff said the Council had derailed the deal by insisting on last-minute concessions that the Mayor could not accept. 
 Both sides resumed talks last night to try to put a deal back together.
Under the City Charter, the Council is required to adopt a budget by June 5 to leave ample time to prepare for the start of the new fiscal year on July 1. But in fact the city misses the deadline far more often than it makes it, with no practical effect. Several fiscal experts said last week that it did not worry them if the Council missed the deadline, as long as the added time leads to a better budget.
 
Service Cuts Debated
 The dispute in recent days has focused not on the bulk of the city's mammoth $31 billion spending plan but on a disagreement over service cuts affecting less than 1 percent of the budget, a philosophical dispute over a new agency for the homeless and an institutional battle over who will oversee a new quasi-public corporation to build health clinics.
For six days, the two sides have been trying to find a way to fill a $300 million budget gap that opened up because Mayor David N. Dinkins had been too optimistic about how much Federal and state aid to count on.
Before the talks stalled early Tuesday, negotiators agreed to a package of $250 million in savings from some modest spending cuts, delays in programs, revenue re-estimates and a partial hiring freeze, Council and administration officials said.
But the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, and the Mayor could not agree on the last $50 million in spending cuts necessary to close the gap. Complicating matters, the Council insisted that the adminstration find other revenues or alternative savings that would allow lawmakers to restore nearly $40 million in cuts to parks, centers for the elderly, day care and other high-profile services.
Another major sticking point has been a new agency for the homeless proposed by the Mayor. So far, the Council has refused to approve the new agency, which would cost $8 million to start up and would replace several divisions in the Human Resources Administration, unless Mr. Dinkins agrees to restore some of the cuts that Council members hold dear.
The Council has also raised objections to another of the Mayor's pet proposals: the Primary Care Development Corporation, a quasi-public entity that would use city-guaranteed bonds to build 30 new health clinics.
Mr. Vallone, who has long advocated that the Council oversee public corporations like the Water Authority and Economic Development Corporation, has insisted the Council have some say in how the new agency operates. The corporation would use $17 million in city taxes to start up.
With no accord in sight yesterday, Mr. Vallone threatened that the Council would pass its own budget on Monday if a compromise cannot be forged by then. In response, Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, said Mr. Dinkins could use an arcane part of the City Charter to rule that the budget was out of balance and force the Council to cut spending or raise taxes.
Mr. Vallone said the negotiations had suffered a serious setback at 1:20 A.M. on Tuesday, when Mr. Dinkins abruptly broke off negotiations with the Council and walked out of City Hall. Moments earlier, the two sides had been close to an agreement, the Speaker said, but the Mayor destroyed the momentum of the talks.
"I really believe this would have been over and done with by 5 in the morning if all the principals had remained," Mr. Vallone said.
But a senior mayoral aide said the Council had caused the breakdown in talks. Earlier in the evening, the Mayor had agreed to restore $40 million in proposed cuts and the Council had said it would approve the new homeless agency, the aide said.
But that deal was scuttled when the Council refused to budge on its request for oversight over the health corporation and suggested giving the homeless agency only $2 million. Mr. Dinkins interpreted those proposals as signs that the Council was not negotiating in good faith and broke off the talks, the aide said.
Mr. Vallone said yesterday that the Council was willing to approve the new agency on the condition that it could be dismantled after two years if the Council finds it lacking. He said the funds could be negotiated. He also said he favored taking the health corporation out of the budget and passing it in separate legislation later.
But First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said the two sides remained far apart on how to cut the final $50 million needed to balance the budget. Mr. Dinkins's current position is that he will not talk about restorations until the Council agrees to find the last cuts to close the deficit. "We have said the first job for all of us is to get to $300 million," Mr. Steisel said.
Marc V. Shaw, the Council budget director, said both sides were meeting last night to try to resurrect the accord that fell apart. "What we're tring to do is to put back together the deal that almost occurred," he said.

HEADLINE: Tirana Journal;
'Hallelujah' Is Heard in the Arch-Atheist's Temple

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania

 BODY:
If Enver Hoxha, Albania's dictator for more than 40 years, is turning in his monumental grave on a hillside above this capital, it would not be surprising.
On the steps of the spectacular marble-and-glass structure resembling a winged pyramid that was built to honor the man who made Albania the only country that outlawed religion, men and women who said they came from the Foursquare Gospel Church of Los Angeles were laying hands on shattered limbs, blind eyes and aching bodies the other day, and with many a "Praise the Lord!" and "Hallelujah!" prayed for healing. 
 True, the police barred their way into the building on the ground that the crowd seeking to enter was too big for the former Hoxha Museum, now the Hall of International Culture. And the police finally made the members of various groups of reborn Christians from the United States, Canada, Romania and the Netherlands, who held several days of meetings devoted to healing through faith, disperse from the steps.
But their outdoor rallies met no obstacles, and the many disabled people who gathered at the former shrine of atheism proved by their presence the effectiveness of religious propaganda in post-Communist Albania and the completeness of the break with the past, in which Albania ranked with North Korea as the most dogmatic and reclusive of Communist nations. The gatherings also bore witness to the inadequacy of medical services in this deprived country.
Albania's last census, before the Italian invasion of 1939, showed the population to have been 70 percent Muslim and virtually all the rest Orthodox or Roman Catholic. Religious practice in this land of 3.2 million people is reviving today; most Albanians questioned say they consider themselves nonpracticing Muslims.
Many here still call the Boulevard of the Martyrs of the Nation, on which the former museum stands, Stalin Boulevard because of the larger-than-life statue of the dictator that adorned it. Today, a privately owned coffee bar has been erected in front of it, hiding its empty pedestal. Across the street, where Lenin's likeness once towered, the pedestal has been decorated with a tribute from a spray can to Pink Floyd.
The boulevard runs through the center of this city of 200,000 from the vast square on which stands the Tirana Hotel, a grim example of the massive, featureless Communist architecture of the 1960's, to the university, a specimen of the Fascist style that dominated in the 1930's, even before Italy occupied Albania.
In the Communist era, the broad avenue about half a mile long was the image of Hoxha's Albania. There were the statues and soulless buildings housing the all-powerful party leadership, the Government, the Presidency and the feared Ministries of Internal Security and Defense.
There were neither houses in which people lived nor shops. There was no private trade -- just as there were no lawyers, because Albania's Communist society was deemed so perfectly just that they were not needed.
Police officers and soldiers bearing automatic rifles at the ready kept pedestrians at respectful distances from the houses of power. The rare cars in a country that had no privately owned vehicles conveyed the leaders between villas and offices.
The buildings still stand, and armed soldiers still guard the ministries. But they no longer inspire awe.
In midafternoon on these warm days, pedestrians take over the boulevard. Young and old, whispering lovers and boisterous teen-agers, humanize the charmless thoroughfare by being themselves despite a setting that was meant to intimidate.
The end-of-day promenade had not stopped in the Communist years, but the flow of strollers was kept at a distance from the halls of the mighty by the guards, and this cast a pall over gaiety. Albanians say the scene was monotonous because of the virtual uniformity of dress in a country that offered modest, dark or white clothing in a few standard models.
Nowadays, strollers treasure eccentricity in dress and carry the messages of the T-shirt culture.
Albanians marvel at what seem to them multitudes of private cars, mainly old vehicles that failed safety checks in other countries. But cars are still few enough for the curbs on both sides to be lined with people sitting to chat.
Along the sidewalks, private dealers lay out small quantities of illegally imported candy bars, cookies, soft drinks and beer and sacks of dried pumpkin seed. The poverty of this largely unemployed city can be measured by perhaps 20 sellers waiting until late in the evening with a stock whose total value, for the length of the boulevard, would fall short of three digits in dollars.
Comza Gjeci sells rarer goods. On sheets of newspapers, he displays books -- novels of Albanian and foreign writers deemed publishable by the former authorities and, even rarer, books from earlier days in foreign languages that Albanians kept, often hidden because the old leaders considered them "bourgeois."
The 63-year-old retired teacher and his wife, whose joint monthly pensions total less than $30, share their two-room apartment, plus a small room rented nearby, with their three grown children and their families, 10 people in all. None have regular jobs. Mr. Gjeci does not want to sell his own books yet, he said, so he buys books others are forced to part with in this time of need.
"When I take their books, it seems to me I take their hearts," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the shadow of the marble and glass pyramid that is the tomb of Enver Hoxha, practices banned under his rule in Albania are stirring. (Henry Kamm/The New York Times)
 
Map of Albania showing location of Tirana.

HEADLINE: Administration Rethinking Mental-Health Coverage

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Concerns about cost have forced the Administration to reconsider its initial plan to provide open-ended, comprehensive insurance coverage for treatment of mental disorders under President Clinton's health program.
The cost and scope of mental health benefits have become a subject of impassioned debate inside the Government and have generated some tension between Tipper Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton, Administration officials say. 
 Mrs. Gore, the wife of Vice President Al Gore, has led those arguing for generous benefits without limits on the number of visits to psychiatrists and psychologists. Mental health experts working for the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform generally agree with Mrs. Gore, who has training in psychology and advised the task force on mental health issues. But Mrs. Clinton, the head of the task force, recently expressed doubt about "the political and financial feasibility" of such extensive coverage.
In view of concerns about the overall cost of Mr. Clinton's plan and the cost of mental health benefits in particular, the White House has drafted alternative proposals that would limit coverage for psychotherapy sessions and hospital care of people with mental disorders.
 
Fighting Discrimination
 Mrs. Gore has repeatedly opposed such limits. "We're fighting to end discrimination against diseases of the mind, to treat mental illness on a par with physical illness," she told the American Psychiatric Association last month.
Aides to Mrs. Gore said she still hoped to convince President Clinton that generous insurance coverage for the treatment of mental disorders, drug addiction and alcoholism would not cause overuse of those services or an explosive increase in costs.
Indeed, the staff of the task force concluded that treatment for depression and other emotional disorders ultimately saved money by increasing workers' productivity and reducing homelessness, crime and the need for costly hospitalization.
A senior White House official called the open-ended benefit "better health policy" but added, "The actuaries' initial estimates indicate that it has a significantly higher cost, and we want to be very conservative."
Data from the United States and Canada suggest that people make limited use of mental health services even when generous insurance coverage is available. Dr. Darrel A. Regier, chief epidemiologist at the National Institute of Mental Health, said that half of the people using such services reported seven or fewer visits to mental health specialists in a year, while 80 percent had 25 visits or fewer.
Dr. Marvin Margolis, a psychoanalyst in Detroit, said: "It's just too painful. Most people with serious emotional problems avoid long-term psychoanalytic treatments because they find it too disturbing to confront unconscious conflicts that originated in early childhood. They prefer short-term treatments that provide support, counseling and advice."
Richard C. Surles, the Mental Health Commissioner of New York State, said that only 6 percent of the state's 2.8 million Medicaid recipients used mental health services last year.
"Claims that a comprehensive mental health benefit will break the bank are not correct, based on our experience, and our Medicaid program has the most liberal mental health benefits in the country," Dr. Surles said.
Under the proposal recommended by Mrs. Gore, described in confidential work papers from the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, treatment would be guaranteed to all people with a diagnosable mental disorder that "poses a serious risk for functional impairment in family, work, school or community activities."
The disorder would have to meet criteria in the diagnostic manual of the American Psychiatric Association.
Robert O. Boorstin, a spokesman for the task force, said mental and physical illnesses should be covered under the same rules. But he said, "There's a real problem because health economists and actuaries disagree over how much mental health benefits will cost."
Because of the uncertainty about cost and financing, Administration officials are considering several alternatives that would set limits on mental health coverage.
Under one proposal, they said, mental patients would have hospital coverage for 30 days at a time, with a maximum of 90 days a year. For a certain number of visits to the office of a psychotherapist, perhaps 10 or 15, patients would have to pay 20 percent of the cost, the same proportion as for the treatment of physical illnesses. But for additional visits, patients would have to pay 50 percent of the cost.
Federal officials are also considering limits on rehabilitation services, which help people with severe mental illnesses adjust to life in the community. Chris Koyanagi, a lobbyist at the Bazelon Center for Mental Health Law, said: "That's a very short-sighted approach. Without such services, people deteriorate and need more expensive and intensive care in hospitals."
The proposal for comprehensive coverage assumes that existing Federal and state mental health programs will be blended. Moreover, it assumes that state and local governments will maintain current levels of spending in a new health-care system to be designed largely by the Federal Government.
"The current state and local investment in alcoholism, drug abuse and mental health services must be retained in the new system to make it financially viable without a major infusion of new Federal funds," the work papers say.
But state officials have balked at turning over state revenues to the Federal Government. To pay for comprehensive mental health care without the state money, the Federal Government would have to set higher premiums for employers and employees, raising new obstacles to political acceptance of the President's plan.
Dr. Bernard S. Arons, leader of the mental health team working for the White House, said state and local government agencies spend $16 billion a year on mental health and drug-abuse services. If that money is available to pay for benefits under Mr. Clinton's plan, Administration officials say, the Federal Government could set a premium of $300 a year for mental health benefits, representing 10 percent of the total premium of $3,000.
But, they said, if the state money is not available, the premium for comprehensive mental health services would more than double, to $700 a year, and the overall premium would be $3,400.
Small-business lobbyists have told the White House that they are concerned about the cost of such benefits.
Leslie J. Aubin, a health-policy analyst at the National Federation of Independent Business, said: "Mental health coverage is very important for some people. But if you include a high level of mental health coverage, you run a risk that the package of benefits will become too rich. If it becomes too rich, it's not affordable any longer."

HEADLINE: U.S. Experts Say 'Safe Havens' Won't Help Much

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
American intelligence officials have told the White House that the plan to create "safe havens" for the besieged Muslims in Bosnia would do little in the long run beyond creating six impoverished refugee compounds with limited law and order and no economic future, a senior Clinton Administration intelligence analyst said today.
And the official said there is little hope of restoring a single Bosnian state along the lines of the plan developed by Lord Owen and Cyrus R. Vance. He added that the most likely outcome is the partition of the country into Muslim, Serbian and Croatian areas. 
 The bleak assessment of Bosnia's future came as as Secretary of State Warren Christopher met with European Community foreign ministers in Luxembourg and restated American support of the "safe haven" plan in an effort to create the impression of Western unity on policy toward the Balkans.
The plan was endorsed by the United States and its allies after Mr. Christopher, on an earlier trip, failed to persuade the allies to go along with the Administration's plan to arm the Bosnian Muslims and use air power to protect them.
 
A Way to Slow the Killing
 The Administration and its allies have portrayed the safe havens as a way to slow the killing while the West uses economic pressure to roll back the Serbs' gains and persuade them to go along with the peace plan negotiated by Mr. Vance and Lord Owen.
Under the "division of labor" worked out by the allies, the United States would use air power to protect ground forces sent by European and other nations to defend the enclaves.
But the senior Administration official, who spoke to reporters today on the condition of anonymity, painted a generally pessimistic picture of the proposals that had been put forward to bring peace to Bosnia.
He said the plan for six safe havens was at best a stopgap measure, and would not stabilize the situation in Bosnia over the long term. And he declared the Vance-Owen plan to be essentially dead.
"I think the view that Vance-Owen as now written is not viable is probably fairly broadly shared," the senior official said, referring to the assessments sent by American intelligence analysts. "And the view that safe havens involve extrordinary problems of managing refugees over the long run without logistical support is also probably broadly shared."
Both views have been communicated to the White House and other top decision makers, the official added.
In some ways, the comments by the senior official did not depart radically from Administration policy. The Administration has always described the safe haven plan as a short-term expedient and has begun to talk about the need to "build on" the Vance-Owen plan instead of implementing it as drafted.
But Clinton Administration spokesmen appeared to be concerned with the vivid way in which the senior official described the drawbacks of the safe haven plan, as well as his assessment that the partitioning of Bosnia was the most likely outcome.
The official, for example, described the safe haven plan as a "polka dot solution" that would lead to the creation of six burgeoning refugee camps plagued by crime, animosities between long-term residents and the influx of new Muslim refugess.
By creating safe havens, he said, the West will "wind up owning six little West Banks in Western Europe with enormous problems."
Trying to bring food to the camps past Serbian forces under the restrictive rules of engagement used by United Nations peackeepers would be a problem, and the enclaves would have no economic future, he said.
"If it is the short run, I think the polka dots may save some lives," the official said. "The problem is that you wind up owning these areas which are totally dependent on logistical support, on the tolerance of the Bosnian Serbs and Serbia."
"You can't create a viable economic economy inside a polka dot," the official added.
Discussing the economic leverage that the West says it is counting on to force the Bosnian Serbs to go along with the Vance-Owen plan, the official said that President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia has failed to follow through on his commitment to seal the Serbian border with Bosnia to deliveries of all but relief supplies.
Lord Owen cited the Serbian leader's comments in arguing against the Clinton Administration's plan to arm the Bosnians. But the senior official said that Belgrade was not moving to cut off supplies of fuel and war material.
"There was some change in the early stages, but it has not been a big change," the senior official said.
Addressing military options, the official said that the White House's proposal to lift the arms embargo on the Bosnian Government and protect them with air power did not have a high probability of success and would still leave the Serbs as the dominant military force.
With the Europeans opposed to lifting the arms embargo, Western nations unwilling to put in a large number of ground troops, and economic sanctions providing only limited leverage, the senior official said that the most likely outcome for ending the fighting would be the partition of Bosnia into Serbian, Muslim and Croatian areas. Two or three of the larger Muslim areas could become a Muslim state, the official said, adding that such an enclave would have more "viability" than a safe haven and could create a de facto alliance with Croatia as a balance of power against the Serbs.
A spokesman for Mr. Christopher denied that there had been a change of policy, saying that the Administration still believed in safe havens and in building on the Vance-Owen plan.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
For The Second Time, a Forecast For 1993 Ad Spending Is Lowered.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
ARE there any figures falling faster than President Clinton's approval ratings? Try Robert J. Coen's forecasts for 1993 advertising spending growth.
Mr. Coen, in his semiannual presentation of the outlook for ad spending in this country and overseas, cut his estimates for the year a second time, and, for good measure, lowered his final figures for 1992. 
 "The media marketplace is more up than down, but not quite as strong as we expected," Mr. Coen, senior vice president and director of forecasting at McCann-Erickson U.S.A., told an attentive audience yesterday at the University Club in midtown Manhattan.
"Directionally, it's going where we had expected," he added, "but irregularly, not in a smooth way."
Mr. Coen, perhaps the most widely followed prognosticator of ad spending, trimmed his domestic estimate for this year to $139.3 billion. That represents a 6.1 percent increase from his final 1992 total of $131.3 billion, revised downward from the $132.7 billion he had projected in December.
Last June, Mr. Coen initially estimated 1993 ad spending at $143 billion, then sliced that six months later to $141.2 billion.
Mr. Coen's forecasts represent more than just a Madison Avenue version of the groundhog Punxsutawney Phil's annual shadow play over whether spring is nigh. The ebb and flow of ad spending often reflects, and sometimes foreshadows, the direction of the nation's economy.
In this case, Mr. Coen said, the primary culprit in retarding the growth of ad spending has been an abrupt mood reversal among consumers, whose optimism after the Presidential election has dissipated.
Among advertisers, he said, "that has created a need to sit on your hands." Even so, Mr. Coen said he was "more optimistic about the second half of the year improving than I was a month ago," adding, "I hope I'm right."
One reason for Mr. Coen's optimism is that in the first quarter of 1993, many major advertisers increased spending in national media, albeit intermittently. Those advertisers account for nearly 50 percent of the money spent in national media, and include restaurant chains, manufacturers of personal-care products and pharmaceutical companies. Another reason is that spending in local media climbed during the first quarter, particularly in radio and television.
A rosy outlook by Mr. Coen, who has been tracking ad spending trends since 1948, is not surprising. His forecasts usually exceed actual spending totals, a discrepancy especially noticeable since the mid-1980's.
"He's typically optimistic," said one person at the presentation, Karen R. Ficker, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore, voicing the general sentiment. She called Mr. Coen's newest estimate "probably more in line" with how the year would turn out.
Mr. Coen's domestic estimate of $139.3 billion breaks out at $80.4 billion to be spent in national media, up 5.8 percent from 1992, and $58.9 billion in local media, up 6.5 percent. The total would represent 2.26 percent of gross domestic product, compared with 2.21 percent in 1992, 2.23 percent in 1991 and the peak of 2.42 percent in the boom year of 1987.
His estimate of a 6.1 percent rise in American ad spending also compares with a consensus forecast that the gross domestic product would increase by 5.7 percent this year, versus 4.8 percent in 1992 and 2.8 percent in 1991. And it would mean that the growth in ad spending would outpace an expected rise this year in the Consumer Price Index of 3.2 percent.
Outside the United States, Mr. Coen predicted that ad spending in 1993 would grow 4 percent, to $169.6 billion from $163.1 billion in 1992. If that is correct, it would be the first time in nearly a decade that the growth rate for ad spending in the United States would exceed the rate in the rest of the world. Mr. Coen attributed that to lagging economies in nations like France and Japan.
And if his forecast holds, it would bring ad spending worldwide to $308.9 billion this year -- topping $300 billion for the first time.
In a preliminary prediction for 1994, Mr. Coen projected total ad spending of $149 billion in this country, up 7 percent from his revised 1993 estimate. He also projected overseas spending of $181 billion, up 6.5 percent. That brings his total estimate for next year to $330 billion, an increase of 6.7 percent from his 1993 estimate.

HEADLINE: A Talk With Bhutto: Is Her Sure Touch Slipping?

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAHORE, Pakistan

 BODY:
Benazir Bhutto sat in a stuffed armchair in her office in Islamabad, her eyes flaring at times in anger, her voice harsh with frustration and irritation.
Once beloved by Pakistani voters, once a darling of Washington, once Prime Minister, she has seen her political fortunes evaporate like a puddle on a scorching pavement. 
 On May 26 the nation's highest court wrenched control of the Government from the indirectly elected President, Ghulam Ishaq Khan, and restored to office the popularly elected Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, and Parliament, an act that did much to improve the reputation of the pliable judiciary.
Much of Pakistan shouted in joy, but not Benazir Bhutto. Not the Benazir Bhutto who was dismissed as Prime Minister in 1990 for corruption and incompetence, much the same grounds cited when Prime Minister Sharif was expelled from office in April.
 
Maelstrom of Intrigue
 "We don't know," she said, "how the judges can pick and chose between parliaments they like and prime ministers they like and parliaments they don't like and prime ministers they don't like. After all, there were the same grounds of dissolution offered both at that time and this time."
Her words turned frosty. "All I can say is, the Supreme Court never gives a verdict which is in accord with the popular mood of the country."
Since Mr. Sharif was restored to power, Pakistan has plunged into a maelstrom of political machinations, maneuvering and intrigue. What it means for the nation, however, remains murky.
In many ways, the political conflict here is more a collision of powerful personalities than a matter of divergent policies and ideas.
Mr. Sharif, for example, is faced off against President Ishaq Khan, who dismissed Mr. Sharif's Government two months ago. Ms. Bhutto had been a bitter enemy of the President, but then jumped into his camp, deciding that her antipathy to Mr. Sharif was more intense.
 
A Stolen Agenda?
 Much of Ms. Bhutto's frustration stems from what she says is Mr. Sharif's theft of her agenda, particularly the privatization of state-owned banks and other companies. But in fact, Mr. Sharif has moved far more aggressively toward liberalizing the economy than Ms. Bhutto had ever suggested.
Then in another turnabout, the newly returned Mr. Sharif recently offered Ms. Bhutto an olive branch during an emergency session of Parliament, and a startled Ms. Bhutto said, tentatively, that she would try to work with the Prime Minister.
With all this came a steady drumbeat of rumors of a military coup.
"There is a period of instability ahead," said Arif Nizami, the editor of The Nation, a national daily based in Lahore, "because Ghulam Ishaq will not accept defeat. As long as he won't resign, he's the center of political crisis."
Since her ouster as Prime Minister, Ms. Bhutto has struggled to pull together her Pakistan People's Party and to challenge the growing influence of Mr. Sharif. She did so as the leader of the largest opposition party, and as the aggrieved daughter of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was hanged in 1979 on a murder charge after being deposed by the military.
 
Bhutto's Political Missteps
 Ms. Bhutto has remained the largest crowd-puller of any politician in Pakistan, yet in the two months since Mr. Sharif was dismissed she has floundered politically.
"She's lost whatever leverage she had," said Ahmed Rashid, a journalist in Lahore. "Every step she's made has been wrong, beginning with joining the President."
"I don't see where she can go," said a Western diplomat here who once viewed Ms. Bhutto quite favorably. "Just about everything she's done recently has backfired. She seems desperate to me."
A tall, striking woman in an Islamic country that discourages women from working, much less taking an active part in politics, Ms. Bhutto captivates crowds. While Mr. Sharif is an uninspiring orator and a rather stodgy campaigner, Ms. Bhutto injects drama and energy into her political rallies. Yet her sure touch may be fading.
Perhaps nothing stunned Pakistanis as much as Ms. Bhutto's decision to support President Ishaq Khan's decision to remove Mr. Sharif and call for new elections. This act, the third time in five years that a president had removed a prime minister, and the second time Mr. Ishaq Khan had done so, was seen by many as a blow to this country's effort to leave behind 25 years of military rule.
 
The Interests of Democracy
 But Ms. Bhutto, who had labeled the dismissal of her Government undemocratic and unconstitutional, this time found the President's actions in the best interests of democracy. "The democratic way to resolve this was to go to the people," she said in April.
Mr. Ishaq Khan is a 78-year-old bureaucrat who has weathered military dictatorships, ferocious political infighting and a spell as Chairman of the Senate. Regarded as the consummate survivor, he became acting head of state after the death of Mohmammed Zia ul-Haq in an air crash in August 1988 and that December was elected President by parliamentary vote.
He is expected to run successfully for a second five-year term this year. He has become the single most important defender of Pakistan's nuclear program, refusing to let the elected politicians negotiate over it with India, the United States or the United Nations.
Although the presidency was intended largely as a ceremonial post, Mr. Ishaq Khan has used the powers created by the revised Constitution of 1985 to thwart Ms. Bhutto and Mr. Sharif.
Prime Minister Sharif emerged from a family of business people, his father rising from ironmonger to industrialist in Lahore. He was the chief minister of Punjab for 10 years before becoming Prime Minister after elections in 1990.
Ms. Bhutto had managed to cobble together a workable coalition in Parliament and in 1988 became the first woman to lead an Islamic country. Educated in the United States, she quickly won American support and for a time pushed a program of modest economic liberalization. After her Government was deposed, she insisted Mr. Sharif was leading an illegitimate Government.
But her political judgment, once so sure, has faltered.
Last July, Ms. Bhutto tried to force new elections by threatening the resignation of the 42 members who supported her in Parliament. But with 217 members, the resignations would have meant little, so she quietly shelved the plan.
At the end of November, she called for a series of rallies as she traveled by train across the country, rallies that were to be so huge that Mr. Sharif would be forced to call new elections.
But when the crowds at many stops proved smaller than she had expected, she suddenly called off this "long march," and the exercise dribbled into inconsequence.
 
A Battle Over the Army
 In January, President Ishaq Khan appointed a new head of the army, Gen. Abdul Waheed, over the opposition of Mr. Sharif. The Prime Minister, incensed that the President would override his objections so blithely, sought an alliance with Ms. Bhutto to strip Mr. Ishaq Khan of his constitutional powers to appoint the army's leader and to dismiss the Government. These powers are enshrined in the Eighth Amendment Bill of 1985, a legacy of military rule.
In a gesture of political conciliation and expediency, the Prime Minister offered Ms. Bhutto the post of chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee in Parliament, which she accepted. As the month wore on, back-room deals were hatched, with Ms. Bhutto reportedly offered new elections in exchange for her votes in Parliament. In February, Ms. Bhutto flew to London to give birth to her third child.
Then, convinced he had a deal, Mr. Sharif declared that he would begin efforts to strip the President of his powers. Ms. Bhutto remained silent, and stayed in London. The political test of wills continued until Mr. Sharif was dismissed.
Ms. Bhutto, silent throughout, had returned the day before the dismissal. The next day she declared her support for Mr. Ishaq Khan. The President, with whom she had been a bitter enemy for two years, graciously put her husband, Asif Zadari, in the caretaker Cabinet.
Now, though Ms. Bhutto seems to be making at least small signs of reconciliation with Mr. Sharif, the resolution of the political battles is far from clear.
"I feel very uncomfortable going back to such a Parliament," she said in the hours before the assembly gathered. "After all, I have never accepted its legitimacy."

HEADLINE: Bolivian Assured of Presidency as Foe Concedes

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 9

 BODY:
Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada was guaranteed the presidency of Bolivia today when his chief rival, a former dictator, conceded defeat in Sunday's elections.
A Sanchez de Lozada presidency is certain to step up Bolivia's free-market policies, which include low inflation and privatization, efforts that he initiated in 1985 as Planning Minister. 
 But perhaps more important, Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, a mining entrepreneur, has promised to elevate the political status of Bolivia's large Indian population. His vice-presidential running mate, Victor Hugo Cardenas, is an Aymara Indian, and his presence as the No. 2 political leader is expected to endow Bolivia's Indians with new political muscle.
"You have troubles with violent indigenous movement around the continent," Mr. Sanchez de Lozada said. "Here we are putting more power in their hands and creating a nonviolent indigenous society."
Mr. Cardenas, an educator, aligned his indigenous-based party with Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's Nationalist Revolutionary Movement last year. Mr. Cardenas, seen as an intellectual among the Aymara Indians, was born in a mud hut along Lake Titicaca.
At a victory celebration on Monday night, his wife, Lydia, wore the traditional dress of Aymara women, the small bowler hat, multilayered skirt and a shawl. This was in stark contrast to Mr. Sanchez de Lozada and his wife, who are often referred to as the gringo and the gringa, because he speaks Spanish with an American accent, having been raised in the States.
Bolivia's indigenous groups often live in deep poverty, eking out a subsistence growing potatoes and other root vegetables. A United Nation study last fall found that 97 percent of Bolivians in rural areas live in poverty, the worst rural poverty in the world.
In addition to an anticorruption campaign, Mr. Sanchez de Lozada promised Bolivia's Indians, who make up more than half of the country's seven million people, that he would give them more political power, let them use their native language in schools and work for social equality.
"Around the continent governments worry that indigenous groups are fertile ground for extremist, terrorist groups," he said. "We are trying to make sure that doesn't happen here."
Mr. Sanchez de Lozada credited his running mate with bringing in crucial Indian votes in the rural areas to earn him 36 percent of the popular vote, compared with 21 percent for the former dictator, Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez of the Patriotic Accord alliance.
Since no candidate received more than 50 percent, the new Congress has to choose a new President when it convenes on Aug. 6. General Banzer, as well as most other parties, has instructed his delegates to support Mr. Sanchez de Lozada as President.
Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's strength will obviously be his innovative economic thinking, which he showed in 1985 in dealing with an inflation rate of 25,000 percent.
Although the Bolivian public bristles at the word "privatization," Mr. Sanchez de Lozada prefers to call it "capitalization." His plans would sell as much as 49 percent ownership in Bolivia's state oil company, airline, railroads and electric power plants to foreign investors and give them management control. But the remaining ownership he would distribute free to the Bolivian public in the form of tradable stock.
"We are talking about a major redistribution of income equal to one-half of our gross national product," he said. "We are getting the Government out of these businesses, giving ownership to the Bolivian people without getting rid of the market economy."
Mr. Sanchez de Lozada said he would also rethink Bolivia's drug policies.
"There is a national consensus building here that drugs are doing a great deal of damage to the Bolivian society," he said. "Before people didn't consume it, so it was he West's problem. But now they are consuming it and seeing the effects in rising crime. It is a high priority item. And I think we feel now it is truly a Bolivian problem."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
When Soros Speaks, World Markets Listen

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Once again, George Soros is putting his mouth where his money is. He published a letter in The Times of London yesterday saying that the German mark is bound to fall, causing Europe's mightiest currency to do just that.
Mr. Soros has no seat on the boards of the German Bundesbank or the Federal Reserve, but central bankers might well envy his power to make currency markets rattle and quake. 
 Yesterday was the third time in recent months that the timely disclosure of his investments helped increase their value. "It's a new way of making money," David C. Roche, a London-based strategist for Morgan Stanley, said. "A combination of judicious investment at the bottom of a market and a publicity coup."
 
 
A Soros Market
 Yesterday, the mark fell against the dollar, as traders in the United States and Europe agreed that it was a Soros market. In New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.6358 marks, from 1.6250 marks on Wednesday. Earlier in Europe, the dollar jumped to 1.6390 marks, from 1.6225.
Previously, investors also rushed in to buy gold and gold stocks after the disclosure in April that Mr. Soros had taken a large stake in Newmont Mining. Just last week, the announcement of his venture with the British Land Company to buy British property set off a rally in real estate stocks.
Mr. Soros manages the Quantum Fund, which has billions of dollars -- and billions more through borrowing -- to deploy in any of the world's markets. He reportedly earned more than $1 billion last September betting against the British pound and other currencies that fell sharply when they fled the European Community's system of fixed exchange rates.
A spokesman for Mr. Soros refused yesterday to comment on his current investments, saying only that his letter stood for itself.
With his latest position, Mr. Soros baldly confronts Helmut Schlesinger, chief of the Bundesbank and prime defender of the German currency. "I expect the mark to fall against all major currencies," Mr. Soros said in a lavishly displayed letter of article length in yesterday's Times of London.
The Bundesbank is determined to keep the costs of German unification from reviving inflation and eroding the value of the currency. To bolster the mark, and throttle inflation, the central bank has kept interest rates high, making German currency and investments relatively attractive.
But Germany's recession has become so serious that Mr. Schlesinger's retirement in a few months will produce an abrupt change, according to Mr. Soros. To stimulate the economy, he said, "Short-term interest rates will have to be lowered, whether the Bundesbank likes it or not."
Mr. Soros said that German bond prices would then rise in marks, but fall in value once exchange rates are factored in. "For the sake of full disclosure, I am talking my book," or promoting the value of his investments, Mr. Soros said parenthetically.
European leaders have railed against speculators like Mr. Soros, with one French official even speaking of beheading. As the global trading of currencies, for commerce as well as investment, has reached $1 trillion a day, the central banks' efforts last fall to defend their currencies succeeded primarily in handing large chunks of their reserves to the speculators.
 
 
Defends Activities
 Mr. Soros, a native of Hungary, defended his activities in his letter, first noting that his investment profits financed his charitable work in Eastern Europe.
"I do not seek profits in Eastern Europe and I do not act as a philanthropic institution in the financial markets," he said. "I try to avoid speculative activities that could prove wantonly destructive, but I see no reason to abstain from moves that would happen even without my participation. Of course, in making such judgments, I am no more infallible than the central banks."
In London, the hub of currency trading, many others take his side. "Most of us in London are absolutely delighted," Thomas J. Berger, manager of the Blanchard Short Term Global Income Fund, said. "We think the dollar will move ahead against the mark. We're happy to have him on the team."
Currencies could bounce much more with the release of United States producer prices tomorrow and consumer prices next Tuesday. Steven Bell, an economic advisor to Deutsche Bank Research, said that renewed inflation could cause the Federal Reserve to lift interest rates, further raising the value of the dollar against the mark.
The unemployment report out last week suggested a strengthening economy that might also foster higher interest rates. The exchange rate promptly jumped, more than after Mr. Soros's remarks yesterday -- evidence, he might say, that he is ultimately following the markets rather than leading them.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Dollar's Other Gains
 By The Associated Press
Along with rising against the German mark, the dollar posted other gains and held its ground against the Japanese yen yesterday.
Andrew Hodge, vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert, said the dollar's strength against most major currencies reflected signs of growth in the American economy. These included the May employment report and sharply higher new home sales.
Yet trading remained subdued yesterday in advance of tomorrow's producer price report, a key measure of inflation. A report showing moderate or light inflation could hurt the dollar since the Federal Reserve would be less likely to raise interest rates to control inflation, traders said. Higher rates would make the dollar more attractive overseas.
Financial markets in Japan were closed yesterday, a national holiday, for the wedding of Crown Prince Naruhito. In New York, the dollar closed at 106.45 yen, up from 106.40 yen late Tuesday.
The British pound, meanwhile, fell to $1.5155 in New York, from $1.5201 on Tuesday. The decline was attributed in part to a speech by Norman Lamont, Britain's former Chancellor of the Exchequer, in which he harshly criticized Prime Minister John Major's leadership.

HEADLINE: Liberals Fight Clinton Plan To Ease Tax on Companies

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
For many large companies, the best news about President Clinton's economic package is a little-known, frighteningly complex provision that would ease requirements for companies to pay a minimum tax when their profits fall to zero.
But the bad news for these companies is that Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat, and some liberals are making a last-ditch effort to scuttle this provision, which, according to Congressional estimates, would cut corporate tax payments by $8.9 billion over the next five years. 
 The Administration proposed relaxing the alternative minimum tax on companies -- and the House of Representatives approved such a relaxation -- after several major corporations made it their No. 1 lobbying priority. Officials from Chrysler, Bethlehem Steel, Champion International and other capital-intensive companies assert that the minimum tax discourages new investment and penalizes them unfairly when hard times squeeze their profits.
"This is probably the best piece of the package for us," said Gary L. Millenbruch, Bethlehem Steel's chief financial officer. "It's something we've been working for."
Senator Bradley and some liberals counter that proposals to reduce the minimum tax are thinly veiled efforts to put loopholes back into the tax code when lawmakers are straining to find ways to slice the budget deficit.
"The tax was established to provide a measure of a corporation's true income and to insure those with real income paid real taxes," Mr. Bradley said. "The carve-out proposed would effectively gut this principle. It would distort sound tax policy and cost taxpayers $8.9 billion payments for no sound economic purpose."
He and his allies, liberal lobbying groups, fault the proposed change not only because it is expected to cost many times more than the $1.3 billion the Administration originally estimated, but also because it could largely wipe out the minimum tax. According to officials with the Joint Tax Committee of Congress, the minimum tax, before the proposed changes, is expected to collect about $10 billion over five years.
The alternative minimum tax on corporations was enacted in 1986 after many lawmakers became embarrassed that scores of corporations were paying no income tax, largely as a result of generous depreciation provisions enacted in the early 1980's.
 
Some Payment Required
 By requiring many companies to use less generous depreciation rules, the tax made hundreds of companies pay some tax even though they had minimal or no tax obligations under the standard corporate income tax.
"The theory behind the tax is that there are various tax breaks out there, but if you use them too much, then you're going to be hit by this other tax," said Jane Gravelle, a tax economist with the Congressional Research Service.
Mr. Bradley is working to persuade his colleagues on the Senate Finance Committee to keep as much of the minimum tax as possible, but he faces heavy industry opposition. At the same time, another powerful member of the committee, David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat who is a fierce critic of the President's economic plan, says that easing the minimum tax will do more than anything else in the package to create jobs.
Companies pushing to relax the minimum tax argue that it was originally aimed at companies that avoided corporate income taxes by milking arcane tax loopholes, like safe-harbor leasing, to the maximum. But critics of the tax say that it now hits companies that made heavy modernization investments in recent years but have seen their profits decimated by recession and slow growth.
 
'Harsher' Than Intended
 "Far more companies are paying the alternative minimum tax than had been contemplated when it was passed," said Gillian Spooner, national tax director at KPMG Peat Marwick. "It's hitting manufacturers far more harshly than had been intended."
Tax experts say that the winners under the proposed changes include auto makers, steelmakers, commercial airlines and paper companies. Officials from companies benefiting from the changes have been among the most vocal corporate supporters of Mr. Clinton's economic package.
Some Democratic supporters of the tax wonder why Mr. Clinton wants to cut the revenues from the minimum tax by twice as much as former President George Bush would have. Mr. Bush made a proposal to scale back the minimum tax, which became part of an economic package that the former President vetoed because it contained some tax increases.
Several Administration officials said Mr. Clinton proposed greater cuts in the minimum tax than his predecessor because he was so eager to spur investment. "We had an assignment to put together a package that would stimulate investment," a Treasury official said. "This was on the list of obvious things to do for capital investment."
The new minimum tax rules would apply only to future investments.
 
Aim of Clinton Plan
 Mr. Clinton's proposal aims both to reduce the minimum tax burden and to simplify the tax. Under current law, in addition to calculating their regular tax burden using the standard accelerated depreciation rules, companies must do an alternative set of tax calculations based on two less generous, but still complicated sets of depreciation rules. Corporations must pay the minimum tax when their tax burden as defined by regular corporate tax calculations falls below their tax burden as defined by the less generous minimum tax.
The Administration's proposal would simplify tax preparation by requiring companies to use one set of depreciation rules rather than two sets. In addition, the new depreciation rules would be more generous because they would state that equipment has a shorter life for depreciation purposes. For example, steel-making equipment could be depreciated over seven years, rather than 15 years under current minimum tax rules.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold and Silver Prices Fall In Advance of Inflation Data

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Gold and silver prices sank yesterday ahead of Government reports on wholesale and retail prices that some traders expect will show a tempering of inflation last month.
Gold for August delivery, the most actively traded contract, fell $2.60 an ounce, to $373 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. And July silver dropped 5.3 cents an ounce, to $4.345. 
 "It was another erosive session, with Mideastern syndicate selling in Europe setting the tone before we got some support from banks," an analyst said.
Gold has ridden a wave of speculative demand, in part based on a general feeling that inflation was returning. Inflationary pressures are traditionally a signal to investors to hedge their holdings in precious metals.
 
Slower Inflation Seen
A number of traders expect the Government to report tomorrow that its Producer Price Index rose one-tenth to two-tenths of a percent in May, a significant cooling down from April's jump of six-tenths of a percent. A report on the Consumer Price Index is scheduled Tuesday.
"The market is looking for Friday's data to provide a clue to the next direction," an analyst said. "The market has turned a bit more cautious because we're a bit overbought."
Oil prices stagnated after reacting the previous two days to inconclusive events at the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, July crude eased 1 cent, to $19.64 a barrel.
Unleaded gasoline prices retreated after Tuesday's American Petroleum Institute data showed a rise in domestic gas supplies. July unleaded dropped 0.49 cent, to 55.66 cents a gallon, while July heating oil rose 0.15 cent, to 53.86 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Trade-Law Study Sought

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, asked an independent Federal agency today to perform a two-year review of American trade laws that restrict imports sold at unfairly low prices or with foreign Government subsidies.
The results of the study by the agency, the International Trade Commission, are likely to be disputed. 
 Many economic studies by academics have concluded that American antidumping and antisubsidy laws help a few industries at the expense of the nation's economy. But the laws are popular in Congress, and a succession of Administrations has avoided official studies of their economic effects.
Mr. Kantor's predecessor during the Bush Administration, Carla A. Hills, officially asked for the study shortly before leaving office in January. Don E. Newquist, the commission's chairman and close ally of many members of Congress, objected soon after Mr. Kantor took office, contending that his agency lacked the staff to perform the study. Mr. Kantor today confirmed Mrs. Hills's original request, but gave the commission an extra six months for the study, until June 30, 1995.
