HEADLINE: Irishman to Lead GATT, With Mandate for a Pact

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 9

 BODY:
Peter Sutherland, an Irish lawyer with a strong record of fighting trade protectionism, was named today to be the new Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, with the mandate of bringing long-stalled trade liberalization talks to an early conclusion.
Unsurprisingly, perhaps, he was at first reluctant to take the job. Arthur Dunkel, the former Swiss diplomat whom he will succeed at GATT headquarters in Geneva on July 1, has known little but frustration over the last seven years as he tried to nudge the 111-nation organization toward a global trade package. 
 Mr. Sutherland, though, on the eve of his appointment, had something to celebrate. With France dropping its objections, European Community foreign ministers on Tuesday approved a deal with the United States limiting the production of oilseed crops like soybeans. This removed one major obstacle to a global trade agreement.
In a statement today, Mr. Sutherland said his priority was "a quick, comprehensive and far-reaching conclusion" to the talks. He noted that for progress to be made, "we will need deeds, not words," at the meeting in Tokyo next month of the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations.
When the so-called Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations began in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este in 1986, the goal had been to conclude an agreement by December 1990. Instead, the talks collapsed, at what was to have been a final session in Brussels, over disagreement between the European Community and the United States on trade in farm products.
Since then, the agricultural disputes have not been fully settled, and issues like market access and intellectual-property rights have arisen and must be resolved. The prospects for a broad agreement to liberalize $200 billion in world trade have been further dampened by the recession gripping economies in much of the industrial world.
Mr. Dunkel, who has been GATT's Director General since 1980, twice agreed to stay on past announced retirement dates, hoping to complete the Uruguay Round. And though his job gave him no executive power, he struggled endlessly to find the consensus needed for an agreement. Now this is Mr. Sutherland's challenge.
 
Selection Process
 The 47-year-old lawyer, who was Ireland's Attorney General from 1981 to 1984, was the first choice of both the Europeans and the United States. When he initially turned down the job, two aspirants from Latin America stepped forward.
Mr. Sutherland in time agreed to move to Geneva and take charge of GATT, requiring European and American officials to persuade the two Latin Americans -- Luis Fernando Jaramillo of Colombia and Julio Lacarte-Muro of Uruguay -- to step aside. Mr. Sutherland was formally selected today.
His appointment is generally popular because, as the community's competition commissioner from 1985 to 1989, he was a strong advocate of free trade, helping reduce barriers within the community and combating monopolies and cartels.
He has served as chairman of Allied Irish Banks, a major financial conglomerate, and of Shannon Aerospace P.L.C. since 1989.
The GATT position is initially for two years, with an option to extend his contract for four years beyond that. He will be the fourth European to lead the organization since it was created in 1948.

HEADLINE: Small Businesses in a Credit Pinch

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 5

 BODY:
Anthony Dolphin is just the kind of borrower every banker in Massachusetts is looking for. Rodman Forter is not.
Both men manage small businesses in Massachusetts: Mr. Dolphin, a computer hardware repair company in Springfield; Mr. Forter, a machinery manufacturing company in Middleboro. Both companies need credit to emerge from the financial upheaval that has gripped the state through the trying recession and its stagnant aftermath. 
 The vastly different reactions they get when they talk to bankers -- five banks have expressed interest in one company, none in the other -- illustrate the two-tiered credit system that seems to be emerging in Massachusetts as the economy struggles to shake off the credit squeeze of the last few years.
The shortage of credit in Massachusetts was one hallmark of an economic downturn that involved many banks whose shaky portfolios of loans both contributed to the slump and were made even shakier by it. The process has been mirrored to varying degrees around the nation.
Alleviating the credit squeeze has been a top priority of banking regulators since the Clinton Administration took office, and it still preoccupies local politicians and business groups in Massachusetts even as they say economic conditions are finally improving. The Administration's bank examiners, seeking to free loans for the small businesses that are considered important engines of growth, have told bank examiners not to be so strict in auditing banks.
And the banks have been given new tools intended to make lending cheaper and easier: they can, for example, assemble pools of small-business loans that require less rigid documentation than usual, and they can increase the amount of real estate collateral used to back commercial loans without having to obtain the usual property assessments.
The pressure is on to do even more. On Thursday in Washington, members of the New England Congressional delegation will meet with top Federal regulators and local business groups to assess the progress so far.
"Despite the fact that the banks say they have money, a lot of people can't get their hands on it," said Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat who sits on the Banking Committee and has closely followed the credit problem in his state.
"The biases created over the past few years are such that everybody has to jump through hoops," he said. "It's a terrible price for small businesses to pay for the banking problems."
Mr. Forter, for example, who is president of the Read Corporation, finds little receptivity in the banking community. His company is shifting its product line away from the construction business and toward environmental services, with an earth sifter designed for use by landfill operators. The company's existing loans, once held by the Bank of New England, which has since failed, are now part of the loan pool being liquidated by the Recoll Management subsidiary of the Fleet Financial Group.
"We are not bankable in the traditional sense," said Mr. Forter, who this month will submit new proposals to refinance his equipment loans.
 
Entrepreneurs' Venture
 The situation is different at Mr. Dolphin's company, the Springboard Technology Corporation, which is a spinoff of the Digital Equipment Corporation. When Digital, which is restructuring, wanted to get out of the business of repairing disk drives and other computer memory devices, Mr. Dolphin and his fellow entrepreneurs decided to run it as a small business, with Digital as a big customer. All five banks he spoke to were "extremely receptive to the proposal," he said.
The two stories can be found across the state: from Back Bay to the Berkshires, banks are flush with cash to lend and companies are eager, but not always able, to borrow it.
Bankers interviewed in communities across the state said that the efforts to loosen regulation have made little practical difference, at least so far. If anything, the bankers said, their lending standards are higher than ever, making it hard for some borrowers to qualify for loans.
The regulatory changes are widely viewed as being of only marginal value, especially at smaller banks, although they might help the bigger banks in the state, which have introduced special programs to emphasize small-business lending.
 
Seeking the Causes
 The reason for the banks' caution probably lies in the causes of the credit squeeze, which was largely not a result of regulatory strictures.
Studies by economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston suggest that what really caused the credit problem was the weakening capital condition of the banks after real estate markets in the region had collapsed. When regulators ordered the banks to shore up their capital, the lenders had little choice but to call in loans.
Now the banks are in much better financial health, said Richard F. Syron, president of the Boston Federal Reserve.
But small borrowers continue to feel the pinch. One reason is that it can be relatively expensive for banks to process a small loan. Regulatory changes might help there. But another reason is that the small companies emerged from the credit squeeze shakier than ever, and the banks more cautious than before.
David R. Danker, vice president for commercial loans at the Springfield Institution for Savings, said his bank's caution was still dictated partly by continuing attempts to shore up its portfolio, which continues to have "a fairly high nonperforming-loan ratio." The bank is under orders from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to shed loans that cannot be repaid.
"The criteria we use now have gotten more conservative, and the balances of people who come to us are not as strong," he said. "It is difficult to meet the needs of people who come to us."
People's Bank of Holyoke has money to lend, said James S. Thompson, its senior vice president. With $430 million in assets, it is the second-largest mutual savings bank in the western part of the state. It would like to have between 75 and 80 percent of those assets in loans, and right now the figure is at the low end of that range, he said.
But he said regulatory changes were not likely to make lending any easier. "The basket of loans is not particulary attractive to us, although it might be to somebody else," he said, commenting on one of the new tools made available by regulators. "Appraisals -- we still want the full-blown appraisal. So the effect on us has been kind of minimal."
 
A Troubled Category
 Although some sound borrowers are beginning to appear, Mr. Thompson said, weaker companies remain hard to serve. "And those who are in Recoll find it virtually impossible," he said, referring to companies whose shaky loans were assigned to the liquidation subsidiary of Fleet after it acquired the assets of the failed Bank of New England. "You have to have some really solid reason to lend to them -- a turnaround in profits, new collateral."
Kerry Stackpole, an official of the Smaller Business Association of New England, said, "Having your loan in Recoll was a scarlet letter."
The Read Corporation offers an example of what a difficult situation that can be. Mr. Forter said the company had probably borrowed too much from the Bank of New England, taking out a working capital line of credit, an equipment loan and real estate debt. But it had always made its payments until the bank failed and the debt was handed over to Recoll. Then the working capital line was frozen, Read could not make all its payments, and Recoll wanted its money back.
Read has been told to pay off the equipment loan by October, which means seeking refinancing.
"We would dearly like them to disappear," Mr. Forter said bitterly. "They are a loathsome crowd to deal with. But our ratios are still not traditionally acceptable to bank lenders. I can't say I have given up on banks, but I am not really optimistic."
He said he would be approaching alternative lenders, like commercial financing companies.
 
Shift in Attitude
 Even the stronger companies, which weathered the recession and expect to be able to borrow again, are looking at their banks differently.
Channing L. Bete Jr., the head of the Channing L. Bete Company, a specialized printer in South Deerfield, said he was worried when his main bank, the Springfield Institution for Savings, was under orders from the F.D.I.C. to shape up.
"At that time, we could not have found another bank in New England," he said. "We are now looking for a national money-center bank to backstop our local bank.
"The bank comes in and checks you out," he said, describing the new relationships between banker and borrower. "But for the last three years, we have been checking the banks out. We call them in and they explain their financial condition to us."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
If The Fed Tightens, The Casualties May Be Jobs -- And Clinton.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
GOOD news: Some 425,000 workers were added to payrolls in April and May, the largest two-month increase in many a moon. This bright figure, only slightly tarnished by the fact that fully half of the increase was a product of computerized revisions in Labor Department estimates, have pushed the "consensus" forecasts for the economic growth to a solid 3 percent in 1993.
But don't book that second honeymoon at the Ritz just yet. The May increase barely brings employment back to the June 1990 peak. And in spite of the fact that labor markets are slack and unemployment remains a demoralizing 6.9 percent, the anti-inflation wolves at the Federal Reserve are baying for blood. If they persuade the Fed to tighten credit, there is a chance Americans will not see the better side of 6 percent joblessness before Bill Clinton is freed to pick out the carpet pattern for his Presidential library. 
 Confused? Join the throng. "Government officials are perplexed by the ambiguities," David Hale, an economist at Kemper Financial, diplomatically confirms. There is just no precedent for fine-tuning the economy in the midst of a long, agonizing restructuring of both industry and the Federal budget.
While the last revision in the job-counting equation changed the estimates more than usual, the figures are still credible, concludes Janet Norwood, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute who earlier headed the Bureau of Labor Statistics. But the additional jobs discovered by the computers do not change Ms. Norwood's view that this water glass is half empty.
"It's taken 27 months to recover the jobs lost in the recession," she notes -- three times longer than it took to go down the slope. With entry into the labor force likely to pick up in coming months and industries ranging from defense to financial services still handing out pink slips by the tens of thousands, Ms. Norwood remains "very worried about the pace of job creation."
Seen through the lens of circa-1970's Keynesian economics, the $50 billion fiscal tonic prescribed by a covey of Nobel Prize-winners before the election makes almost as much sense now. Indeed, many of these economists think President Clinton flubbed an opportunity to sell Congress on insurance against slow growth by presenting his stimulus program as an old-fashioned jobs (translation: pork barrel) bill.
But it is also possible that the on-again, off-again recovery is on for good -- that employers who have been making do with overtime are now being forced to hire workers or lose orders. Plugging the April and May job figures into a standard computer model of the economy, Mr. Hale points out, yields a forecast of 4 percent growth for the next 12 months -- a lusty pace by contemporary standards and about as much as anyone believes possible without encountering bottlenecks.
Of course, if the American economy is already shaking and baking, it is time to do something about inflation before it is factored into business and labor psychology. That, at least, is the view of a hard-line minority of Federal Reserve Board governors and regional bank presidents who sit on the Fed's policy-making open market committee. "There's a wing of the open market committee that is looking for a reason to put on the brakes," said Robert Hall of Stanford University -- a wing eager to drive inflation back below 2 percent at first opportunity.
In May the committee responded to three months' worth of data that implied producer prices were rising at a 4 to 5 percent pace by leaking its "bias" toward raising short-term interest rates. And while the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, presumably remains reluctant to rain on Bill Clinton's parade, the bias will probably translate into action if May inflation figures show more of same.
What makes this inclination to tighten credit in the absence of crystal-clear inflation signals even more problematic is that Congress is poised to tighten fiscal policy. Higher taxes and cuts in spending would, of course, advance the worthy cause of deficit reduction. Arguably, it would even serve the cause of economic expansion by proving Washington is serious about deficits, thereby lowering long-term borrowing rates for business.
But that is speculation. What is not speculation is the fact that deficit reduction will temper demand for goods and services while the economy is running at least 3 to 4 percent below capacity and several million people who want full-time jobs cannot find them.
It is possible that time will make the choices less agonizing. Mr. Hale guesses that the May Producer Price Index will settle back to the 2 percent range, allowing the Fed to put off any change in monetary policy until the fall. It is also possible, though, that the Fed will feel compelled to play tough cop on the inflation beat.
With hindsight, one could say that the Federal Reserve's reluctance to accommodate growth in 1990 cost George Bush a second term. With foresight, one might wonder whether a similar stand will cost Bill Clinton his chance for an extended lease on 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

HEADLINE: CLINTON NOW SEEMS PREPARED TO DROP ANY WIDE FUEL TAX

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Barely a day after giving up his demand for a $71.5 billion tax on the heat content of energy sources, President Clinton seemed close today to retreating from his fallback position as well: that any substitute for that tax must cover the gamut of fuels, from oil to electricity to natural gas.
Instead, Senate and Administration officials said, Mr. Clinton's aides were looking closely at a proposal by Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat Louisiana, to replace the heat tax with a $40 billion tax on gasoline and other transportation fuels and $30 billion in Medicare cuts through the fiscal year 1998. 
 Mr. Breaux's proposal -- effectively a sales tax totaling about 7.3 cents per gallon of fuel -- would cover everything from truck diesel to jet kerosene to the high-test used in automobiles. It differs sharply in structure from Mr. Clinton's proposed tax, which would have covered a wider range of fuels and was based on the heat content of fuel as measured in British thermal units and not on the fuels' cost.
 
The Same, Yet Different
 At least in some cases, the effect on consumers would be substantially the same. For example, the B.T.U. tax would have resulted in a 7.5- to 8-cent increase in the cost of a gallon of gasoline.
An energy tax is among $250 billion in proposed tax increases and new taxes that Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee are studying this week, in preparation for a vote next week on that and other parts of Mr. Clinton's five-year budget package.
The transportation tax was not the only option that senators and Clinton aides reviewed in a day of back-to-backroom meetings and limousine shuttles between the Capitol and the White House. But for the moment, they said, it was easily the hottest one.
Tonight, Mr. Clinton's budget director, Leon E. Panetta, said the White House had not endorsed any substitute for the B.T.U. tax and might not until July, after the Senate has passed the budget package and begun working with the House on a final version that suits both chambers of Congress.
 
Hoping for Momentum
 "The key right now is to move the process forward," Mr. Panetta said. "Whatever it takes to move the process forward, we'll encourage."
Speaking of the Finance Committee's deliberations, he said, "We are kind of standing aside in this process."
Administration officials and several senators nonetheless said that Mr. Breaux's plan was the starting point of today's discussions, and that Mr. Clinton's long-stated position -- that he will take nothing less than a "broad-based" energy tax that spreads the burden over most fuels -- is now more a matter of semantics than reality.
Mr. Breaux's transportation tax "isn't as broad as a B.T.U. tax, but it's broader than a gas tax," one Administration official said.
Asked whether Mr. Breaux's proposed transportation tax meets the Clinton definition of "broad-based," the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, replied, "That's one of the questions we'll be considering."
Senators and some Senate aides agreed privately that Mr. Panetta and the White House had handed the reins on the tax issue to the Finance Committee but largely because they had lost control of the debate in the preceding weeks.
Today's meetings were variously attended by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and his deputy, Roger Altman; Senator Mitchell; Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Finance Committee; Mr. Panetta; the White House chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, and a clutch of oil-state senators and Congressmen.
 
'Whole Range of Options'
 Earlier today, President Clinton told the Business Roundtable: "Senator Breaux has some ideas that he wants to float, and some others have some ideas. I think you'll have plenty of time to react to them. A lot of them want to rely more on a broad-based transportation tax, but that also has some economic difficulties if you -- even if you raise less money."
Another Administration official said that a formal decision on a replacement for the B.T.U. tax (a B.T.U. is the amount of heat needed to raise the temperature of a pound of water 1 degree Fahrenheit) could be delayed as long as possible, in part to shorten the amount of time lobbyists and politicians would have to whack away at it.
The politics of the B.T.U. and transportation taxes reflect crucial differences. Many lawmakers from farm states and heavily industrial states, along with farm and manufacturing lobbies, argued that the B.T.U. tax would cost jobs and give foreign competitors an edge.
Manufacturers prefer a gasoline tax, but Western and farm-state senators oppose it because their rural constituents must drive farther and more often -- and use more gasoline -- than do city dwellers.
Mr. Moynihan's committee is supposed to approve a package of some $250 billion in tax increases and lesser cuts in Federal benefit programs by a week from Friday.
Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Moynihan acknowledged tonight that Mr. Breaux's transportation tax was under study, but they stopped short of endorsing it. Other Senate and Administration officials, who refused to be identified, said the proposal was high among the alternatives, in no small part because it would satisfy political forces who hold some of the keys to the budget's fate.
Among them are two of the 11 Democrats on the Finance Committee, David L. Boren of Oklahoma and Kent Conrad of North Dakota, who have publicly criticized the B.T.U. tax, and whose votes are essential if the budget is to make it to the Senate floor.
Today, Mr. Conrad called Mr. Breaux's plan "better not just for my section of the country, but for the economy as well," although he withheld judgment on the Senator's proposed cuts in Medicare. Aides to Mr. Breaux said that Mr. Boren, who has waged a ceaseless battle against the B.T.U. tax, seemed "favorably disposed" to the Breaux plan.
For their part, Administration officials conceded that Senator Breaux's proposed transportation tax was a far cry from the B.T.U. tax, which had covered coal, electricity, natural gas and petroleum to varying degrees, but that it was the best vehicle they had for the moment.
The B.T.U. tax already had been so gutted by special interests, who obtained exemptions for industries and for certain types of fuels, that it was not all that far from a fuel tax anyway, they said.
Some House Democrats who voted for the B.T.U. tax last month under duress were enraged when they discovered the White House had backed away from it.
Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico said the White House could lose 40 to 50 House votes if a final compromise bill included a smaller tax like a transportation fuel tax and deep new cuts in social spending. "The bill will be in danger if we continue to cut Medicaid and Medicare and continue trumpeting the victory of big business and big oil," Mr. Richardson said.
 
What Long-Range Effect?
 At first blush, a transportation tax might seem unacceptable to oil-state lawmakers, like Mr. Breaux, who are embracing it. But, in fact, economists say, the relatively minor increase that it would impose on the cost of fuels would do little to dampen demand for oil. And because the tax would fall entirely on consumers, the large manufacturers and oil drillers who complained loudest about the B.T.U. tax have no cause to oppose the Breaux proposal.
One economist and energy expert, Philip Verleger of the Washington-based Institute for International Economics, predicted that the demise of the B.T.U. tax would be a particular boon to the Northwest, where hydroelectric power would escape taxation, and in the Midwest, where heavy industries are concentrated.
Small refiners who supply residual fuel oil to utilities and industry would also gain from the tax's demise, he said.
Mr. Breaux's proposal to reduce Medicare expenses got a far more muted reception than the tax plan. The Senator suggested that the $30 billion in revenues lost by moving to a smaller energy tax could be regained by cutting Medicare benefits to the well-off, reducing inflation adjustments for hospital costs and other changes.
But participants in the budget negotiations said today that the Finance Committee was unlikely to propose anywhere near that amount of cuts in Medicare and that some of the lost revenues might well be made up by cutting spending on programs like transportation, education, space exploration and science.

HEADLINE: U.N. COUNCIL PLANS TO ORDER FULL BAN ON OIL FOR HAITI

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 9

 BODY:
The United States and other United Nations Security Council members have decided to impose a mandatory worldwide ban on the supply of oil to Haiti as part of a new campaign to restore to power the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Plans for enforcing the blockade, which also applies to arms supplies, have not been worked out yet, diplomats said today. But the resolution imposing the ban, which is expected to be approved formally next week, will be adopted under Article 7 of the United Nations Charter, which allows the Council to enforce its orders. 
 American officials said they expected that once the resolution is approved, European nations that have been supplying 90 percent of Haiti's oil will stop doing so. The United States has imposed an oil embargo on Haiti since the end of 1991 in line with the recommendation of the Organization of American States, which had called for a total trade embargo.
 
Easy to Monitor
 Some diplomats said that given the ease of monitoring oil shipments to Haiti, enforcing the ban would not be a major undertaking. Most oil enters through the harbor of Port-au-Prince.
In another repercussion of Haiti's turmoil, the Clinton Administration said today that it would comply with a Federal court ruling and free 158 political refugees who have been detained at an American naval base in Cuba since they fled Haiti. The Administration had sought to bar those Haitians from entering the United States because most of them tested positive for the virus that causes AIDS. [Page A12.]
The United States has told other Council members that it is studying plans to send American warships to the Caribbean to police the new trade ban against Haiti, one of the world's poorest nations. A senior diplomat said that if the United States sends ships to enforce the ban, other maritime nations will also be asked to do so.
Diplomats in Haiti have long said that only a worldwide ban on oil imports would have a meaningful impact on the Haitian military, which up to now has survived the much less comprehensive embargo imposed by the O.A.S.
Enforcing the oil ban raises a potential problem because Haiti shares the island of Hispaniola with the Dominican Republic. It is unclear what steps the Council will take to prevent oil from being smuggled by road into Haiti from the Dominican Republic.
In addition to banning deliveries of oil and weapons, the Security Council also plans to order all nations to freeze overseas bank accounts and other financial assets belonging to Haiti's rulers.
The United Nations mediator for Haiti, Dante Caputo, the former Foreign Minister of Argentina, has announced that he will make another attempt to negotiate Father Aristide's peaceful return to power at a meeting of Haiti's political leaders, which he plans to hold here next week.
"The moves are complimentary," Mr. Caputo said at a news conference here. He said his strategy will be to put pressure on Haiti's rulers through the Security Council embargo at the same time that he promotes a "national dialogue" aimed at securing the return to power of the country's first democratically elected ruler, who is a Roman Catholic priest.
Today's moves come only a day after a new power struggle broke out in Haiti involving the dismissal of Prime Minister Marc Bazin, apparently on the orders of the military leaders. Mr. Bazin was thought to have been forced out after he tried to reassign two ministers chosen by the army.
In calling for mandatory Security Council sanctions against Haiti, the United States is backed by France, Canada and Venezuela, which have been working together informally to resolve the political crisis gripping the island since the military overthrew President Aristide in 1991.
 
Approval Is Expected
 Diplomats say they expect the embargo to be approved without major dissent, although China may abstain. While there is no civil war under way in Haiti, they argue that the exodus of refugee boat people is destabilizing for the Caribbean region as a whole, justifying Security Council action. They also point out that the Security Council has taken action in the past against countries where there was widespread violation of human rights, as is the case in Haiti today.
The proposed embargo as well as the seizure of assets would replace the largely ineffective voluntary trade embargo that the O.A.S. imposed on Haiti after Father Aristide was forced to flee in September 1991.
While the United States and other O.A.S. members could ban their companies from selling oil to Haiti, the governments of European and other countries that do not belong to the organization had no legal basis for stopping their citizens from doing business with Haiti's current military rulers.
About 90 percent of Haiti's oil supplies now comes from Europe, most of it from the Netherlands. Haiti is believed to have enough oil to last through July. And diplomats here want the Security Council to enact the new embargo rapidly to prevent the country's current leadership from building up stocks.
The United States, France, Canada and Venezuela decided to press for an oil embargo against Haiti after Mr. Caputo's mediation efforts collapsed last month when the military authorities rejected his proposals for Father Aristide's return.
In inviting Haiti's "main political forces" to a renewed dialogue at the same time that the Security Council moves to impose sanctions, Mr. Caputo made clear today that representatives of the military would not be taking part in the talks and that all those who came must accept in advance that Father Aristide is "the legitimate, constitutional President of Haiti."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Aristide Hopeful on Embargo
 MIAMI, June 9 (Special to The New York Times) -- Father Aristide said here today that he believed that a United Nations embargo on oil shipments to his country would quickly lead to a toppling of the military leadership that ousted him.
Combined with the resignation of Prime Minister Bazin on Tuesday, he said at a news conference, an international oil embargo would further isolate and weaken the military and its few civilian allies. He described the country as near "a social explosion" because of worsening economic conditions and said he stood by his statement on Tuesday that he would return to Haiti "within weeks, perhaps within days."

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Elects a Conservative As Mayor and Turns to a New Era

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 9

 BODY:
Los Angeles entered a new political era today as its conservative Mayor-elect, Richard Riordan, outlined plans to use his skills as an entrepreneur to bring the city out of its economic slump and social turmoil.
The first Republican to lead the city in a generation, Mr. Riordan, a self-made millionaire of 63, campaigned with promises to lure more businesses and hire more police officers, sweeping aside the coalition of blacks and white liberals that had sustained the retiring Mayor, Tom Bradley, for 20 years. 
 Reaching out from his base of white conservatives in the San Fernando Valley, Mr. Riordan also appealed to some middle-class Hispanic and Asian voters as he defeated Michael Woo, a liberal City Councilman, by 54 percent to 46 percent in Tuesday's vote.
The election of a white conservative who had never before run for office aroused concerns among leading blacks, almost all of whom supported Mr. Woo as they sought a mayor who would address some of the social concerns dramatized by the 1992 riots.
 
'Rhetoric of Toughness'
 "There is a great deal of apprehension and uncertainty among many in the black community about his rhetoric of toughness," said John Mack, regional director of the Urban League. "It is important that he reaches out and makes it clear that he intends to be mayor of all the people and that he will not work to the detriment of South-Central."
But some political analysts said that rather than pushing social issues higher on the agenda, the riots in South-Central Los Angeles had created an atmosphere of insecurity in which a law-and-order candidate like Mr. Riordan offered broad appeal.
"In the short term, the events of last year had exactly the opposite outcome of what people expected: they really strengthened the forces of order," said Raphael J. Shonenshein, author of "Politics in Black and White" (Princeton, 1993), a study of Los Angeles politics. The author is a professor of political science at California State University at Fullerton.
Following a bitter campaign in which both candidates poured their resources into attack advertisements, there was a sullen air to Tuesday's balloting, with many voters telling poll takers they were selecting "the lesser of two evils."
 
An Electorate Divided
 The voting was also characterized by the racial and economic divisions that have riven this city since the riots. An exit poll conducted by The Los Angeles Times found that most of Mr. Riordan's supporters were white, and that Mr. Woo won most of the minority votes. Close to two-thirds of this city's 3.5 million people are members of minority groups, but a majority of its voters are white.
According to initial figures from the Elections Division of the Los Angeles City Clerk's office, Mr. Riordan won 302,786 votes and Mr. Woo got 259,820, for a turnout of 44 percent of registered voters. The preliminary figures point to a turnout higher than anticipated and higher than any of those that elected Mayor Bradley. They indicate that Mr. Riordan cut well into Mr. Woo's core constituency.
Illustrating a sharp ideological divide, Riordan voters said by a 2-to-1 ratio that the problems of minorities and the inner city are problems of personal responsibility rather than problems of racism and economic imbalance, while Woo voters said exactly the opposite by the same 2-to-1 ratio.
 
An Official Roadblock
 At a news conference today, Mr. Riordan acknowledged the need to reach out to the many constituencies in this fast-changing city where minority groups are jostling for their shares of a shrinking economy.
"I will take steps immediately to unite this city," he said. "My government will involve Democrats, Republicans and independents, people of every race, creed, color and sexual orientation." Mr. Riordan's four-year term begins July 1.
One of the roadblocks facing him comes with the office: Los Angeles has a weak mayoral system in which department heads are autonomous and protected by Civil Service rules. Voters on Tuesday defeated a measure that would have given the Mayor more authority over them.
But Mr. Riordan voiced optimism about his ability to lead the sluggish and fragmented branches of government, with whom he has worked during his service for the city.
 
The Business Approach
 A venture capitalist worth an estimated $100 million who has served on a number of city commissions and has been a power behind the scenes in city government, Mr. Riordan made it clear that his approach will be fundamentally that of a businessman.
Asked what he would do for the Hispanic population that now makes up about 40 percent of the city, he said, "The first thing we have to do with the Latino community as well as other communities is make Los Angeles safe, because businesses do not want to come into a war zone."
He said he would meet today with Police Chief Willie L. Williams and with the head of the police union, which endorsed him for mayor, in a first step toward implementing his promise to put 3,000 more officers on the street by the end of his term.
Despite concerns about public safety, voters have twice in the past year defeated measures to pay for more police officers. Analysts have raised questions about the feasibility of Mr. Riordan's stated plan to pay for the officers by leasing out Los Angeles International Airport and turning some city services over to private groups.
 
To Meet the Governor
 Mr. Riordan said his second order of business, on Thursday, would be to travel to Sacramento to meet with Gov. Pete Wilson and legislative leaders to lobby against a huge proposed reduction in state funds for cities.
"It is bad, bad, bad for the State of California to desert the City of Los Angeles," he said. "To abandon Los Angeles as a war zone is going to hurt the state."
He also implied that he would lobby in Washington for Federal funds. He said that although President Clinton had endorsed Mr. Woo in the campaign, the President's chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, had telephoned him this morning to congratulate him.
The Mayor-elect acknowledged that government was a more collegial enterprise than private business and said: "I've got to share power with the City Council and with other citizens of this city. I feel comfortable doing that."
At a separate press conference, Mr. Woo attributed Mr. Riordan's victory to the $6 million of his own money that he poured into the campaign, to the success of the public-safety issue and to an anti-incumbency mood in which Mr. Woo was seen as the City Hall insider and Mr. Riordan as a can-do outsider in the mold of Ross Perot.
 
Anti-Incumbency Mood
 Political analysts here also saw an anti-incumbency mood in the defeat of the two City Council incumbents who ran for re-election. Altogether, four of the Council's 15 seats were contested this year, and all four will now be filled by new members.
One of these is Jackie Goldberg, a former member of the Los Angeles school board who will be the first openly homosexual member of the City Council. Another is Richard Alarcon, who will be the first Hispanic member from the San Fernando Valley, where the Hispanic population is increasing rapidly.
"I think the whole deck has just been thrown up in the air," said Joel Kotkin, a political analyst with the Center for the New West.
Though his campaign slogan was "Tough Enough to Turn L.A. Around," Mr. Riordan's demeanor is avuncular, as he smiles and fumbles slightly for words.
His supporters say he is far from the conservative demagogue portrayed by Mr. Woo in his bruising negative campaign, and they point to his philanthropic work and participation in attempts to improve the city's crumbling school system.
He has donated thousands of dollars to set up educational programs for minority youngsters and was the only white member of a leadership group called 100 Black Men.
Mr. Riordan did gain the support of a key Hispanic politician, City Councilman Richard Alatorre, and of Stan Sanders, a black lawyer who ran for mayor in the first round of voting last April, in which Mr. Riordan and Mr. Woo emerged the leaders. When Mr. Riordan left town for his mother's funeral in the last week of the race, these two men campaigned as his surrogates.
A graduate of Princeton University and the University of Michigan Law School, Mr. Riordan came to Los Angeles in 1956 to join a law firm. He became a venture capitalist, engaging in restructuring insolvent companies, and built a fortune out of a modest inheritance.
In an interview during the campaign, he said: "All my life I've been a rescuer. There is a vacuum of leadership. I am going to fill it."
He is once divorced and is separated from his second wife. He has three daughters.
He said today that he planned to remain in his book-filled $6 million home in the Brentwood area, rather than moving into the official Mayor's mansion. His mind turning again to economic matters, he said he might convert the mansion into a "capital of the Pacific Rim" to lobby for Asian business.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Democrat Wins Panetta Seat
 By The Associated Press -- In other elections Tuesday, voters along California's central coast elected a Democratic state Assemblyman, Sam Farr, to fill the Congressional seat Leon E. Panetta left to become President Clinton's budget director. Mr. Farr won easily, taking 52 percent of the vote to the 43 percent by a Republican lawyer, William Campbell.
In Arkansas, no one won the majority needed to win the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor, a post that has been vacant since Jim Guy Tucker succeeded Mr. Clinton as Governor. Two Little Rock lawyers, Nate Coulter and Tom McRae, will compete for the nomination in a runoff June 22. The winner will face a Republican Baptist minister, Mike Huckabee.
In Montana, voters overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to impose the state's first sales tax, which had been advocated by the Gov. Marc Racicot, a Republican.

HEADLINE: Whitman and Florio Attack As New Jersey Battle Begins

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 9

 BODY:
The morning after winning the Republican gubernatorial primary, Christine Todd Whitman began her general election race today by breaking bread with her Republican rivals at a "unity brunch" and revamping her campaign staff, putting her brother in charge.
And she went after the man whose job she wants, Gov. Jim Florio, accusing him of playing politics by flirting with tax cuts in an election year. 
 Governor Florio, who was unopposed in the Democratic primary, wasted no time attacking Mrs. Whitman. His workers began the day slipping fliers under pressroom doors in Trenton attacking her economic program, the centerpiece of her campaign.
Those skirmishes were a preview of what will certainly be a focus of the fall campaign: New Jersey's troubled economy, and who has the vision and experience to deal with it.
Mr. Florio will argue that the $2.8 billion tax increase he pushed through in 1990 was a nasty, but necessary, dose of fiscal medicine. Mrs. Whitman will argue that he should not be so proud of an economy in which the jobless rate was recently the highest in the nation, at 9.1 percent, although it has since fallen to 7.4 percent.
In a speech during the brunch in nearby West Windsor, Mrs. Whitman attacked Mr. Florio for hinting that he would support a $100 million tax cut this year.
"In an election year, the Governor should resist the cynical call to promise tax cuts for purposes of re-election when the money isn't there," Mrs. Whitman said.
 
Mixed Reviews of Choice
 With that remark, Mrs. Whitman started down the tricky political path that she must walk to attack the Democratic Governor without at the same time damaging and alienating the Republicans who control the Legislature. Although the intended target was Mr. Florio, her barb also hit senior Republican legislative leaders who support the push for the election-year tax cut.
Later at a news conference, Mrs. Whitman said she did not mean she would rule out supporting such a tax cut.
"If they say the money is there and they are able to identify the cuts, of course I would back them up," she said.
Mrs. Whitman also said her brother, Webster B. (Danny) Todd Jr., would become her campaign manager and oversee the day-to-day operations. In the primary race, he was an untitled volunteer though one with unquestioned influence over the candidate and the campaign.
Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian and Virginia Littell, chairwoman of the state Republican Party, praised Mrs. Whitman's choice of Mr. Todd.
But a senior Republican Party official said some other Republican leaders worried about Mr. Todd's inexperience and tried to persuade Mrs. Whitman not to turn over complete control of the campaign to her brother, a member of the State Assembly from 1968 to 1970 who has spent the last several years in Montana as a rancher.
"She is convinced that this guy won the primary for her," the party official said. "If that's so, he is the same guy who squandered a 30-point lead at the beginning of the campaign down to less than a 10-point lead by Primary Day."
At the news conference today, Mrs. Whitman said she was confident that her brother was the person for the job.
 
New Chief Spokesman
 "He is someone who knows New Jersey very well, politics very well and me very well," she said, "and that is a dynamite combination."
Mrs. Whitman also introduced a new chief spokesman, Carl Golden, who worked for former Gov. Thomas H. Kean. He will replace Joseph Justin.
Mr. Kean was appointed a campaign co-chairman, a symbolic unity gesture, and Mrs. Whitman said Ed Rollins, the man who ran Ronald Reagan's "Morning in America" Presidential campaign, would continue as chief campaign strategist.
"We anticipate that Jim Florio is going to run a terribly nasty campaign," Mr. Rollins said. "We've got a long, hard fall campaign ahead; I expect a real donnybrook."
The revamping of the Whitman campaign, which one aide said would also include the replacement of the present political advertising agency, Russo Marsh & Associates of Sacramento, Calif., and Washington, resulted from evaluation of a primary effort that was successful despite itself. Mrs. Whitman started the race in February with polls showing her 25 percentage points ahead of her closest challenger, former State Attorney General Cary Edwards.
By last night, when the last votes were counted, that lead had slipped to seven points, enough to guarantee a comfortable victory but evidence of general disarray in the last days of a campaign that had been under way for three years.
With 99 percent of the state's 6,002 precincts reporting, Mrs. Whitman had 159,666 votes, 40 percent of the total. Mr. Edwards won 131,017 votes, 33 percent; former State Senator Jim Wallwork won 95,959 votes, 24 percent. Trailing far behind were two other candidates who each accounted for 2 percent of the total: Charles P. Hoffman, with 6,742 votes, and J. Patrick Gilligan, with 6,047 votes.
Governor Florio made it immediately clear that there will be little surcease from the pounding that Mrs. Whitman took in the primary.
"We've taken some lumps over the past three and a half years," Mr. Florio said last night. "Now it's our turn at bat."
James Carville, Mr. Florio's chief political strategist, said in a telephone interview from San Francisco, where he was giving a speech, that the Florio campaign would emphasize both his accomplishments and her liabilities.
 
Homestead Rebates
 "One of the Governor's great advantages," Mr. Carville said, "is that his opponent apparently doesn't have the foggiest notion of what's going on in the homes and businesses of New Jersey."
In the closing months of the campaign, Mrs. Whitman was battered by her opponents for a series of gaffes that underscored their attempts to portray the multimillionaire candidate as someone with no understanding of the problems of the middle class.
In one incident, Mrs. Whitman said, in reference to the state's homestead rebate program, which returns up to $500 to taxpayers, that, "It may seem funny, but $500 is a lot."
In another, she explained her failure to vote in school budget elections by saying that she sent her children to private schools and should not tell parents of public schoolchildren how to spend their money.
In the interview today, Mr. Carville said: "Well, it's not that she's a patrician that will hurt her. It's that she is a 'Let 'em eat Oat Bran' type of person."
Her statements, Mr. Carville said, indicate a lack of concern over "things like having a family budget and the future of the public school system."
 
Building Toward a Blitz
 Mrs. Whitman's primary opponents also criticized her for taking a farmland assessment on family-owned property in Somerset County, reducing her property value assessment by millions of dollars.
Mr. Florio faces liabilities of his own, chiefly anger over the tax increases that he pushed through the Legislature in 1990.
The recent resignation of his chief of staff amid a Federal inquiry into whether state bond business was improperly steered to certain bond houses could also have a negative political impact.
Mr. Carville noted that the Governor had issued new regulations requiring bids for state bond business and had recommended restrictions on campaign contributions from bond houses, although his campaign has so far continued to accept them.
"I think the Governor has acted decisively, changing the way they issue bonds, but I don't know how it will play out" in the campaign, Mr. Carville said.
Campaign aides on both sides indicated that the summer months would feature preliminary skirmishing, with each side husbanding the bulk of the nearly $6 million it has to spend for a television advertising blitz in the final weeks before the Nov. 2 election.
On top of that, early indications are that the Republican and Democratic Party organizations will spend even more -- the Democrats as much as $10 million, the Republicans $7 million to $8 million in "soft," or general party, advertising to help their candidates.

HEADLINE: Democracy's Doldrums

 BODY:
A book entitled "Giants of the Democratic World" would be exceedingly short, briefer even than "Gems of English Cookery." Nobody can recall when so many leaders have found so little public favor. Not only are incumbents of various brands unpopular. They are also generally smaller than life. Europe as a whole fits the writer Jane Kramer's description of Austria: a grand opera performed by understudies.
Bill Clinton, whose 36 percent approval rating is the lowest for any President after four months, can take cold comfort from the advice of a fellow sufferer. During a White House visit, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada urged the President to "wear unpopularity as a badge of honor." But proud defiance did not save Mr. Mulroney, who in February stepped down as party leader as his Progressive Conservatives plunged to a 21 percent approval rating, chiefly due to economic miseries. 
 Nor can Mr. Clinton find much solace in the plight of Britain's John Major, whose Conservatives were re-elected just 14 months ago. Mr. Major's approval rating dipped last month to 21 percent owing to a weak economy and clashes over European integration; it was the lowest registered for any Prime Minister since polling started in the 1930's. Insouciance is Mr. Major's method of dealing with adversity. He was planting delphiniums when he shrugged off new Gallup findings that voters saw him as tired and weary. He later offered this take-it-or-leave-it response: "I am fit. I am well. I am here -- and I'm staying."
The broad pattern has distinctive twists. In Italy, revulsion over widespread corruption has deepened disenchantment. Age helps explain the setbacks of France's Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, who was drubbed in parliamentary elections and is now a lame duck, forced for two years to share power with his rivals. Germany's Christian Democratic Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, has been unable to quell right-wing violence or to deliver on promises of painless unification with eastern Germany.
But mingling with local circumstances are common sources of electoral discontent. No leader has yet come up with a remedy for persistent underemployment and listless economies. As the cold war has vanished, so has the unifying potential of a common adversary or a great enterprise. Pursuing consensus, politicians appear to tread water -- a complaint rarely uttered about Margaret Thatcher.
Personal charm and weak adversaries have enabled Spain's Felipe Gonzalez to hang on for a third term as Prime Minister, though his Socialists failed to retain a majority in Sunday's election. But in Spain, too, voters complain of 21 percent unemployment and political drift. Democracy is in the doldrums, for the two reasons that humbled George Bush: a sense of economic decline and neglect of "the vision thing." Hence the special dismay about Mr. Clinton's faltering start, and the widespread hope that he may soon do better. As the old saying goes, a rising tide lifts all boats.

HEADLINE: Human Rights for Women

BYLINE: By Geraldine Ferraro; Geraldine Ferraro is a member of the U.S. delegation to the U.N. world conference on human rights.

 BODY:
What to do about Bosnia? Development? At its world conference on human rights in Vienna, which begins today, the United Nations will wrestle with these issues. Women's human rights are at the center of both of them.
Women's human rights? Yes. In New York, U.N. diplomats from a world outraged about the Balkan carnage, including the systematic rape of countless women, have argued about what to do. And elsewhere in the U.N., diplomats are looking a year ahead toward a world conference on population and development, where women hold the key. 
 Several years ago, women's rights advocates worldwide began to turn up at the same conventions, seminars, university settings, diplomatic receptions and refugee centers. They had many different problems. But as they listened to one other, they saw they had at least one concern in common that no international organization was talking about: violence against women. Female infanticide. Genital mutilation. Wife murder. Sex tourism. Rape. Assault. Discrimination in health care. Barriers to political, social and economic equality that make millions of women less than third-class citizens.
As they talked, the women made a global connection: these weren't scattered "women's problems," not "minor" abuses that some governments had passed to a study commission and forgotten. The women recognized gender-based violence as a matter of fundamental human rights.
Although the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights nominally includes women, the icon of human rights abuse has been a man behind bars, tortured for speaking his mind. Abuse unique to women has been dismissed -- as traditional practice, as too common to worry about, as less important than other things. These are family problems, men say, and the family lies beyond international jurisdiction.
Some nations argued recently in Geneva that human rights are not universal -- that the concept of such rights shouldn't apply to poor countries struggling to develop. At a preparatory meeting for the conference, which is aimed at strengthening human rights, they accused the industrialized North of using charges of human rights abuses as an excuse to avoid giving aid. Development, they said, is a human right, too, much more important than trivialities like the right to vote. Not to mention the rights of mere women.
When women are beaten, raped and killed, as if it didn't matter, they are denied full humanity -- and beings who are less than fully human cannot be allowed to take part fully in government, business, development.
When little girls get less food, less medical care, less education and more work than little boys; when women can't travel, marry or leave home without some man's permission; when rights to vote, meet and speak out are circumscribed; when children and property belong legally only to men; when women are denied the right to control their bodies, how can women be fully human?
The systematic rapes in the former Yugoslavia have aroused the world. The quieter rapes, the quieter abuses, that go on daily have aroused at least half the world, the female half. How can any nation call itself civilized, how can any nation develop properly, until it recognizes the talent of half its population? The Tailhook scandal, the Anita Hill story, show that America is not beyond this blindness.
Slavery was a national and "family" custom and torture has been a traditional practice. The world now condemns them. Women's rights are also human rights. In Vienna, the Global Campaign for Women's Human Rights will press the conference to recognize this for the first time and to denounce abuse of women as abuse of human rights.
The campaign, involving more than 800 women's human rights groups, wants the conference to recommend that women's concerns be integrated into every level of U.N. operations. A liaison should be appointed to make sure women's human rights are considered in every U. N. project, and women's status should be studied in every nation's human rights report.
If this happens, governments will have to act on rights abuses that do not occupy the spotlight daily. And women will be freer to make their full contribution to economic growth.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Polish Thatcher

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
Next to Hillary Clinton, the most powerful woman in politics today is Hanna Suchocka. This is true despite the fact that the Government headed by the first female Prime Minister of Poland -- and the first woman to lead the nation since Queen Jadwiga in the 14th century -- was recently overturned by a single vote.
Her former Minister of Justice, whom she fired the week before for his habitual tardiness, claims he did not oversleep. He says he left a wake-up call with the hotel operator, who rang him; he told his wife to call him from home, which she did; and he set his alarm, which duly rang. Despite this tintinnabulation of bells, he just did not make it to the Parliament in time for the confidence vote, and the Government fell. We all have mornings like that. 
 The result is a wonderful forward fumble. The old Polish Parliament was a wrangle of 29 splinter parties, many nibbling at Ms. Suchocka's market reforms, deficit reduction and privatization of industry. The no-confidence voters did not expect to win, and even if they did win, expected the usual reshuffling of the old deck.
When Sleepyhead failed to show up and the naysayers upset the Government, President Lech Walesa surprised them all by seizing the chance to dissolve Parliament and to call new elections, keeping Ms. Suchocka (pronounced sue-HUT-skuh) in place as caretaker.
Here's the beauty part: A new law on the books raises the threshold for proportional representation, limiting the parties to a half-dozen or so. The upshot will be a more stable government; the betting is that the Prime Minister whose popularity rating is in the 70's (about that of Mitterrand, Major and Clinton combined) has a good chance of emerging with a stronger hand for reform.
This handsome, matronly, unmarried lawyer of 47 has the unmistakable presence of a head of government. A social and fiscal conservative, she came from a small village, worked her way up the Communist-approved democratic opposition and allied herself with Solidarity. An admirer of Margaret Thatcher, she prefers "Ms." to "Madame" and says: "I am not linked with any feminist movement. But there exists some kind of women's solidarity."
Jane Perlez, the New York Times correspondent I accompanied to an interview with the P.M., is covering the coming campaign and the hopes of Ms. Suchocka that both Mr. Walesa and the Catholic Church will support "reformist tendencies." Steve Engelberg, just returned to The Times's Washington Bureau from Poland, is preparing a magazine profile on Ms. Suchocka. I see my role as pundit to set all this in vast global perspective.
1. Poland faces West with its hopes, and East with its fears. Poles see Russia and Ukraine as nuclear powers with unstable Governments posing a genuine danger. That's why the breakup of the former Yugoslavia, with the world's response only to worsen the mess, troubles a nation bordering these republics of a former union.
2. Poland is expected to be a strong ally of the U.S.; C.I.A. Director James Woolsey was here last week to set up cooperation among spooks. But Warsaw gets little respect from our State Department. When Secretary of State Warren Christopher traipsed about Europe on his halfhearted mission to sell the Clinton plan to arm and protect Bosnian Muslims, he never even sought Poland's help -- and Warsaw has peacekeeping troops in Bosnia.
3. Poland is the prime example so far of the benefits of a sharp turn away from command economy to capitalism. But the shocks, especially to retirees and older workers, are not over; the workers' movement that started it all now finds its members facing more layoffs in dinosaur companies that require streamlining.
4. By their willingness to bear privation in the prospect of economic freedom, the people are ahead of the parliaments across most of Eastern Europe. This legislative lag, most pronounced in Russia, is being overcome by steady pressure from the beginnings of a middle class. In September's election I suspect the Poles will back Hanna Suchocka and oust many of the foot-dragging hacks impeding economic transformation.
A combination of the people's grit, good new leaders and the profit motive have made possible the formation of a more stable, reformist government in Poland -- along with a little bit of luck from a politician who hit the snooze button and pulled the covers over his head.

HEADLINE: Florio Bars Blind Trusts for State's Top Officials

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 10

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio issued an executive order today that will eliminate the use of blind trusts by top state employees. The order is intended to stop New Jersey officials from using blind trusts to shield assets that would otherwise be subject to conflict-of-interest scrutiny.
The order would also prohibit companies owned by the workers -- senior officials of the executive branch and others appointed by the Governor -- from doing business with government at any level, from Federal to local. 
 The rationale for the move was in part political, as Mr. Florio tries to distance himself from a damaging election-year investigation into a company owned by his former chief of staff, Joseph C. Salema.
Whatever the order's impact on Mr. Florio's future, it could bring about big changes in state government because of its long-term potential to require financial sacrifices of government employees.
New Jersey law does not prohibit state employees from investing in companies that do business with the state. But through a blind trust, a New Jersey government employee could place personal assets under the control of an independent trustee to avoid the appearance of conflict of interest.
Though a blind trust is usually considered a good-government measure, one that involves ownership of a single company, as it did in the Salema case, would allow a government official to know his assets and how his goverment actions could affect them.
Under Governor Florio's order, people with assets in blind trusts would have to either sell those assets or leave their jobs.
The order applies to all executive-branch employees in policymaking positions and unpaid appointed members of state commissions and boards, about 2,000 people in all. Five state workers, all of them in senior positions, have blind trusts now, the administration said. It did not have any figures on how many of these employees were involved in companies that did government business.
The state workers would have until the end of the year to dispose of assets in blind trusts or leave state service. The same timetable would apply for any holdings that have government-related business.
"Some have said that heightened disclosure might keep qualified people from choosing to serve in state government," Mr. Florio said. "But it is clear the public's trust has to be the primary concern."
The Governor also acted today to tighten rules issued in 1990 requiring employees to file yearly disclosures of assets and sources of income. Now the affected employees and their spouses will have to file amended disclosure statements within 30 days of engaging in a business relationship covered by the order, instead of the current annual disclosure.
Juanita Scarlett, a spokeswoman for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, said state employees are barred by New York State ethics laws from owning companies that do business with the state. A state official whose assets are held in a blind trust must still fully disclose his financial holdings.
 
Challenge to Whitman
 After Mr. Florio released his order today, Democrats moved swiftly to turn the issue into a political club against Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican gubernatorial nominee. In a letter to Mrs. Whitman, the leader of the Democratic minority in the Assembly, Joseph V. Doria Jr., asked her to disclose all assets and their value and sources of income.
Mr. Doria also said Democrats would introduce legislation within a week that would require full disclosure for all gubernatorial candidates.
Mrs. Whitman is a millionaire whose wealth was an issue during the Republican primary as her opponents tried to portray her as an elitist out of touch with the electorate. Mr. Florio, who has no assets in blind trusts, clearly intends to continue stressing that theme.
Mrs. Whitman said today that she called last month for specific measures to tighten the way that blind trusts are used. Her proposals would require any assets that present an actual or potential conflict of interest to be sold before entering government.
 
Federal Inquiry
 Today's executive order followed one issued on May 4 that required all state agencies and authorities to accept competitive bids on bond underwriting and other professional services. Both are part of an effort by Mr. Florio to distance himself from the troubles growing out of investigations of sales of New Jersey Turnpike Authority bonds that are being conducted by the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan and by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Federal sources have said the investigation centers on Armacon Securities, a bond consulting company in Camden County that is owned by Mr. Salema and Nicholas H. Rudi. Both men are close political friends of Mr. Florio.
Mr. Salema's 50 percent share of Armacon was in a blind trust. He resigned on May 25 to avoid becoming a political liability for his boss and long-time friend, Mr. Florio, who is facing a tough re-election fight.
Jon Shure, the Governor's spokesman, said today that the executive order Mr. Florio signed would have barred Mr. Salema from owning a share of Armacon and would have prohibited the company from doing business with the state.
There are five other senior state officials with blind trusts: Brenda J. Bacon, chief of management and planning; M. Robert DeCotiis, chief counsel; Robert E. Hughey, director of the State Office of Economic Recover; Steven P. Perskie, chairman of the Casino Control Commission, and Lawrence J. Lockhart, an assistant commissioner in the Department of Human Services.
Under the Governor's executive order, the State Ethical Standards Commission will immediately begin ending blind trusts held by everyone covered by the order.
By June 30 the trustee administering a blind trust is required to notify the commission of all assets held in the trust. The commission is to review the information to determine which assets the official must divest himself of and notify the trustee by Aug. 15. From that point, the state employee would have 120 days to dispose of the assets or to leave state service.
David Bradford, a professor of economics at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University, said the strict new guidelines may make it difficult for New Jersey to retain or attract some people to work in state government.
Mr. Bradford also was a member of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Bush Administration.
"I know what I went through, a very, very stringent environment," he said. "At some point, people do say, 'Am I going to subject myself to this?' You do lose people."
