HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Newspaper Whose Independent Streak Helps Boston Define Its Image

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
It claims to have been the first big newspaper in the country to call for an American withdrawal from Vietnam. During the agonies of Boston's school integration struggle in the 1970's, someone fired shots at its headquarters in Dorchester. In the Brahmins' Boston of the late 1800's, it battled hospital rules that barred Roman Catholic priests, even if their task was to administer the last rites to their Irish immigrant parishioners.
In the more than a century since its founding, The Boston Globe -- usually self-consciously responsible, sometimes flamboyantly liberal -- has helped shape the identity of Boston and played a part in the life of the nation. 
 "The Globe is a critical element of Boston life," said Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, the latest Massachusetts politician in the famous family that The Globe has occasionally battled and, some say, too often championed. "Whether you're talking about the social, economic or political life of the biggest city in the region, The Globe is important," Representative Kennedy said this week.
 
'Paddle Our Own Canoe'
 Through the generations, especially since big media companies began to gobble smaller newspapers in the 1970's and 1980's, The Globe has prized its independence as a business. Its image as a newspaper that answered to no one was central to its view of itself. And there were some who said that that was what propelled it to become the dominant newspaper in New England.
"We have been willing to take risks editorially, and we've been able to paddle our own canoe," the newspaper's current publisher and chairman of its parent company, William O. Taylor, told a Globe historian in 1981. Mr. Taylor, 60, who took over from his father as publisher in 1978, is the fourth generation of Taylors to run the newspaper.
Charles H. Taylor, The Globe's original Taylor, who was given the title of "General" because he once served as a military secretary to a Massachusetts Governor, is described as the paper's rescuer rather than its founder.
The Globe was begun in 1872 when the booming city had 10 newspapers. The rival Herald accounted for about half of the papers' combined daily circulation of 170,000. But The Globe quickly prospered, and by the turn of the century, it had the largest circulation in New England.
The Depression brought a change in fortunes, allowing The Herald to regain the lead, which it held until the mid-1950's, while the number of newspapers in the city dwindled to four.
The Globe's founders were six Boston businessmen, including Eben D. Jordan, the founder of the Jordan Marsh department store company. Within a year after the paper was started, most of the original investors were gone. Mr. Jordan remained and quickly called upon General Taylor, then 27, who had already worked as a soldier, a reporter and a printer. General Taylor was originally hired as the temporary business manager. He would become the central figure at The Globe and an important figure in the Northeast and beyond.
Counted among The Globe manager's friends were the movers and shakers of the era, including Joseph Pulitzer (though General Taylor disapproved of Mr. Pulitzer's brand of journalism, saying the owner of The New York World would not be happy unless he saw blood dripping from the pages of the newspaper every day).
Adhering to rectitude as a guiding rule, General Taylor and his descendants have run the newspaper since 1873 and have shared voting control with the heirs of Eben Jordan.
 
Trusts Set to Expire
 The corporate entity that formally owns The Globe, Affiliated Publications, Inc., sold stock to the public beginning in 1973 and is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Separate trusts set up for the Jordan and Taylor heirs own 33 percent of the stock in Affiliated. But together, the two trusts have 68 percent of the voting power in the company.
The trusts are scheduled to lapse in 1996, and some of the more than 100 heirs are believed to be eager to disentangle themselves from the newspaper. Quietly over the years, a host of potential suitors, including big media companies, have made inquiries about a potential sale. William O. Taylor turned away most of them.
This week, as rumors of the merger with The New York Times Company swirled, there were some in The Globe's newsroom and in Boston who suggested that the independence of the city's top newspaper may have had something to do with the way Boston has viewed itself over the years.
Under the merger, The Globe would retain its management and its editorial autonomy.
 
Not The New York Times
 A sophisticated, world-class city with its own rough edges, Boston had its own world-class newspaper that was -- and this sometimes appeared to be the main point -- not The New York Times. That may have helped the city keep its own distinct identity, said Martin Nolan, a nationally known reporter for The Globe and former chief of its editorial page.
"Do you know what it's like to live in the shadow of New York? It's deep in the New England psyche," Mr. Nolan said. "My own gut instinct," he said of his fears about the deal with The New York Times, "is we're going to be in the farthest reaches of Fairfield County; we're going to be a prominent New York suburb. This is a loss to that New England psyche."
Of course, there are those in Boston who have never forgiven the New York Yankees for buying Babe Ruth from the Red Sox in 1920.
Mr. Nolan, who has been with The Globe 31 years this week, is one of those who remember that The Globe, as he put it, was "a sort of a laughingstock of a newspaper" when he started. For three-quarters of a century until 1967, it did not endorse a political candidate, and its coverage was sometimes seen as parochial.
That changed.
Partly because of the ferment of the times, partly because it began to prevail in the 1960's in its long battle with its archrival, The Boston Herald-Traveler, and partly because of a back-slapping Harvard alumnus named Thomas Winship, The Globe built a national reputation.
Mr. Winship succeeded his father as editor of The Globe in 1965. In his youth the younger Mr. Winship worked at The Washington Post. At The Globe, he emulated the style of his friends Benjamin C. Bradlee, The Post's editor (whose son is now a rising editor at The Globe), and Philip Graham, The Post's publisher.
 
Cambridge and Georgetown
 Mr. Winship traveled the "Cambridge-Georgetown axis" of Harvard and Washington intellectuals and government servants, as the writer J. Anthony Lukas put it in his book on Boston, "Common Ground." Mr. Winship propelled The Globe toward a broader national perspective and toward a more activist stance on local issues.
It was not always a clear path, and there were always -- and are still -- questions about how committed to Boston's urban core the mass-distribution Globe was. "The Globe's prevailing voice" during some of Mr. Winship's term, Mr. Lukas wrote, "was that of a Harvard-educated lawyer from the suburbs -- affable, humane and well intentioned, but no longer entirely comfortable in the city of his youth."
Long strong in its coverage of sports, Mr. Winship's Globe refined a specialty in political reporting. It was host to lively columnists. Its investigative reporters zeroed in on local wrongdoing like bid-rigging in the government of Somerville, Mass., with enough punch to win a Pulitzer Prize.
In 1980, perhaps the height of the Thomas Winship era, The Globe won three separate Pulitzer Prizes.
 
Crisis Over Busing
 But the Boston school crisis was especially difficult for the newspaper. It was sometimes criticized for appearing to be too protective of its city. On the first day of court-ordered school busing, The Globe's headline said "Boston Schools Desegregated, Opening Day Generally Peaceful." Other national newspapers, including The New York Times, focused on the rock-throwing, jeering crowds that greeted black students in South Boston.
The Globe did aggressively persist on the school story, though, sometimes angering residents so much that the newspaper took its name off the cars used by reporters.
In 1975, the paper was rewarded with a Pulitzer Prize for "massive and balanced coverage of the Boston school desegregation conflict in a bitterly emotional climate."
There were other Pulitzers and other controversies to come. But since 1984, the newspaper has not won a Pulitzer. In journalism circles, that fact is often said to be an indication of editorial troubles in recent years.
After Mr. Winship retired in 1985, the publisher appeared unable to settle on a successor. There were high-level departures, and there was dissention among the news staff.
One editor, Michael C. Janeway, left after 14 months and a bitter battle over his management style and conflicting visions for the future of the newspaper. For a long period, The Globe simply left the position of editor vacant. During the tenure of Mr. Janeway's successor, John S. Driscoll, The Globe was widely criticized for appearing to drift, and it was sometimes beaten on Boston news by The Herald, now owned by Rupert Murdoch's News America Publishing Company.
"I just don't think it's been aggressive enough on public issues," Mr. Winship said this week. But he and others said that in recent months The Globe appeared to be, as Mr. Winship put it, "coming back on the tracks" under the stewardship of Matthew V. Storin, 50, who was appointed editor in February.
After a long career in high-level editorial positions at The Globe, Mr. Storin resigned in 1985 because of a dispute with Mr. Janeway. In his time away from The Globe, he held a series of journalism jobs, including the editorship of The Chicago Sun-Times and the managing editorship of The Daily News in New York.
Mr. Storin returned to The Globe last summer as executive editor. In the months since his promotion to editor, Mr. Storin has received high marks for increasing competitiveness in news and upgrading national coverage. He is also perceived to be trying to alter the newspaper's image of recent years as a publication aimed at Boston's suburbanites and the region's intellectual elite.
"I think he understands that the paper was perceived as relentlessly liberal and out of touch," said Mark Jurkowitz, the media critic at The Boston Phoenix weekly, "and he's trying to do something about both."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TICKER: NYT (AMEX) (66%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: MASSACHUSETTS, USA (94%); NORTHEAST USA (92%); 

CITY: BOSTON, MA, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: Medical Group Battles to Be Heard Over Others on Health-Care Change

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 10

 BODY:
When the 435 delegates to the American Medical Association's governing congress arrive here Sunday for their annual summer meeting, the first speaker on the agenda will be Hillary Rodham Clinton. The doctors will be listening closely for hints on who among them -- if anyone -- the Clinton Administration has been heeding as it develops its proposal for overhauling the nation's health-care system.
Until recently, there would not have been any question. The medical association was the undisputed, all-powerful voice of medicine in Washington, and no major overhaul had much chance of succeeding without its cooperation. 
 These days, though, the association is battling to make itself heard over some 80 medical specialty groups, many of whose views on health reform differ substantially from those of the A.M.A.
And splits within the doctors' ranks are part of a larger trend that has undermined the association's stature in Washington. Insurers, hospitals, medical-equipment makers, pharmaceutical companies and support professions are all much more powerful players than before.
 
'Other Centers of Power'
 "As medicine became the nation's biggest business, other centers of power arose," said Dr. Quentin Young, a prominent Chicago internist.
In the early days of the health debate, the medical association and the other trade groups all found themselves shunted to the sidelines as secret groups appointed by the Clinton Administration weighed possible overhauls. Eventually the cold shoulder was supplanted by a polite ear, allowing Dr. James S. Todd, the association's top executive, and other representatives to have frequent meetings with top Government policy makers.
Dr. Todd says he is convinced that those meetings have resulted in modifications of the Administration's thinking. But, he adds, "We won't know the results until we see the proposal."
The medical association has about 290,000 members -- roughly 41 percent of the nation's doctors. While the number is higher than ever, the percentage is well down from the 70 percent level the organization enjoyed before dues were increased sharply in the 1970's and the specialty groups began expanding rapidly.
The organization still commands both public and professional respect for its anti-smoking and other public health campaigns, and its many scientific publications. And its political action committee, by far the richest of any in the health field, remains the profession's preferred vehicle for trying to catch Washington's attention with dollars. In the last two years, the committee has donated more than $2.9 million, most of it to Congressional candidates -- more than any other lobbying group except the National Association of Realtors.
 
'Need More Input'
 But the membership includes many doctors, especially women, members of minorities and students, or residents, who feel that their views and needs are given too little weight because aging white males dominate its governing boards and activities.
"A lot of the individuals at the top need more input from those of us who are going to practice for the next 30 years," said Dr. Jorge Menendez, a young plastic surgeon from Stamford, Conn., who attended a medical association meeting in Washington in March.
Most of the major specialty groups send representatives to the association's House of Delegates, a medical version of Congress that meets twice a year to set policies for the group. Citing the representatives' participation, the association asserts it speaks to and for 90 percent of the medical profession.
That may be true on issues like the group's campaigns against smoking or reducing malpractice suits. But it is hardly the case in the current debate on revamping the health-care system.
Some specialty groups like the 80,000-member American College of Physicians and the 72,000-member American Academy of Family Physicians have split with the medical association by endorsing a national cap on health spending. Several smaller groups, like the 6,000-member Physicians for a National Health Program, go further, arguing for a Government-managed system like Canada's.
 
A.M.A. Proposals Criticized
 The schisms were most vivid last year when the medical association's revamping proposals were publicly derided by Dr. John Ball, executive vice president of the College of Physicians, for lacking any "realistic or effective cost-containment measures." The public hatchets were buried after a January meeting between the two groups.
But Congressional staff members say many medical groups are complaining privately that the association's views are getting too much attention. And most specialty groups have little confidence that the association can be relied on to protect all of their interests.
The increased visibility of other medical groups and of trade groups that laid out varying overhaul ideas has helped Dr. Todd and a new generation of A.M.A. leaders that came to power in the late 1980's push the association's old guard toward compromises and advocacy of national changes that would have been unthinkable a short time ago.
Dr. Todd, a 62 year-old Cape Cod native who practiced surgery in New York City and New Jersey for more than 20 years before joining the association's staff in 1985, took over as executive vice president in 1990. That same year, the association shocked the Bush Administration by calling for major overhauls, including requirements that employers provide minimum health insurance for all workers and that the Government finance insurance for everyone else.
"The White House called us on the carpet," said Dr. Todd, recalling with relish the publicity that ensued. "I asked what they wanted us to do and Dick Darman just said, 'Cool it!' " Dr. Todd added, referring to Richard G. Darman, President Bush's budget chief.
The association did not back away, but many other groups, including a number of medical specialty societies, were already advocating far bigger changes. The association has responded with a flexibility that has impressed many former critics.
"The Government may have arrived a little after Hippocrates, but they've decided they have to negotiate with us and that we shouldn't be treated with disdain," said Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health.
In an effort to broaden the appeal of its proposals, the association has gradually softened its opposition to broad spending limits, provided doctors can participate in setting them. And association leaders have suggested they might back voluntary price controls to help keep costs down as changes are being phased in, if the package includes reduced exposure to malpractice suits, streamlined insurance systems and less Government regulation.
"Our proposals and the College of Physicians are now pretty similar when you take into account all the fine print," said Dr. Todd, who constantly preaches the virtues of coalition-building over confrontation. "The Clinton Administration has definitely been encouraging everyone to come to them separately to divide and conquer us."
Leaders of rival medical groups and Washington insiders agree that the association's influence could grow when it comes time to cut deals over legislative and regulatory language. No other group is in a better position to find and expand points of consensus.
"We deal with the A.M.A. only," said Michael Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents 1,400 for-profit hospitals and is one of several hospital trade groups active in the debate on health reform. "We're not going to run around dealing with all the splinter groups of doctors."
The association encourages such attitudes by supporting 17 Washington lobbyists, a presence that dwarfs other medical groups. And the group has the wealth -- a $200 million total annual budget, most spent on educational activities, and $100 million in reserves -- and experience mobilizing doctors to shape public and Congressional opinion.
"My colleagues listen to folks from home and that's the A.M.A.'s strength," said Representative Stark.
 
The Biggest Challenge?
 Perhaps the A.M.A.'s biggest challenge will be to combat the general assumption that it is more interested in its members' welfare than the public's. The group's own surveys show that the average doctor's earnings jumped from $48,000 in 1973 to more than $170,000 in 1991, about 15 percent more than general inflation.
But the figures mask wide disparities. Dr. Todd said that many doctors have lost ground during that period. Surveys also show an overwhelming majority of doctors saying that increased regulation has made medicine far less satisfying over the years.
As the debate unfolds, the group continues to flesh out its position with new reports. The upcoming congress, for example, will review the organization's latest plan for what should be included in a basic health-insurance package for all Americans. But Dr. Todd is already trying to prepare his members for a sobering outcome.
"I don't think the A.M.A.'s influence is waning but the problems are so much greater that no one is getting everything they want," he said.

HEADLINE: U.N. to Weigh Options on Bosnia Border Monitors

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 10

 BODY:
The Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution today asking Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to prepare a report on "options for the possible deployment of international observers" to verify that Serbia is keeping its promise to cut off military aid to the Bosnian Serbs.
But the Council's decision remains an empty gesture that is unlikely to bring any action soon, because President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia has refused to allow such monitors into his republic. 
 The resolution's main supporters -- Britain, France, Russia and Spain -- argue that the Council must at least prepare the legal framework for deploying the monitors along Serbia's border with Bosnia even if they cannot immediately be sent into Serbia. Failing to do so, they say, would amount to letting President Milosevic dictate the Council's agenda.
Britain's delegate, Sir David Hannay, said it would be in Belgrade's interest to cooperate with the Council by accepting the monitors rather than engaging in "a new act of defiance."
 
U.S. Remains Skeptical
 The American delegate, Madeleine K. Albright, said she remained skeptical about Mr. Milosevic's willingness to put real pressure on the Bosnian Serbs. But she said the world would soon know whether he was sincere about ending the war or "engaging in another elaborate hoodwink."
Other members went along without enthusiasm. Several argued that the Council would only further sacrifice its already diminished credibility in the Bosnian crisis by adopting another resolution whose outcome is in question.
The United States and the Council's members from the developing world have made clear that they favor a different approach that involves lifting the arms embargo against Bosnia's Muslims so they can rearm and recapture lost territory.
But last month the Clinton Administration abandoned that position after running into implacable opposition from Britain, France, Russia and Spain, which said it would only escalate the fighting and force them to suspend relief work.
 
Show of Allied Unity
 Instead, in an attempt to show allied unity toward, Secretary of State Warren Christopher joined the Foreign Ministers of these countries in devising a three-part program at a meeting in Washington on May 22.
Under this plan, they agreed to create a tribunal to hear war-crimes charges, to send more soldiers to protect the six safe havens that the Council has designated for Muslims in Bosnia, and to deploy monitors to the border between Serbia and Bosnia.
The Council has already taken action on the first two proposals. Supporters of the program see it as an attempt to start enforcing portions of the peace plan prepared by Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, which would divide Bosnia and Herzegovina into 10 semi-autonomous provinces under a weak central government in Sarajevo.
The monitors would attempt to reinforce the United Nations trade embargo in an effort to pressure the Serbs to accept the Vance-Owen plan. The decisions to protect safe havens and create a war crimes tribunal were intended to halt Serbian "ethnic cleansing." But it remains unclear whether any of these measures can be put into effect soon.
Next week, the United Nations Secretariat is to tell the Council that it needs a force of 5,000 to 10,000 soldiers to protect the safe havens -- far less than the 25,000 soldiers it initially requested but which the United States and others warned could never be raised or funded.
The United Nations already has forces in all of the safe havens except Gorazde. But countries contributing additional troops will not allow them to be sent in without the permission of the Bosnian Serbs. And it is not clear whether the Serbs will allow reinforcements.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

FLORIO BANS BLIND TRUSTS
Governor Florio has issued an executive order to eliminate the use of blind trusts by key state employees and prohibit companies owned by these workers from doing business with government. . The rationale is in part political, as Mr. Florio tries to distance himself from an inquiry into a company owned a former aide. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
PEACE CORPS JOB FOR BELLAMY?
President Clinton is expected to nominate Carol Bellamy, former president of New York's City Council, as director of the Peace Corps, Administration officials say. Ms. Bellamy is an investment banker for Bear Stearns. A16.
 

MASTERCARD STAYING IN NEW YORK CITY
In a decision that company officials say turned more on New York City's intangible assets than on simple economics, Mastercard International will keep its headquarters in mid-Manhattan rather than move to Westchester County. B2.
 
PLAN TO REBUILD DOWNTOWN BRONX
Gambling that an infusion of public money will reverse two decades of decline, state, city and Bronx officials have announced an ambitious plan to rebuild the Bronx's downtown with a development called the Bronx Center. B3.
 
KOCH ENDORSES BADILLO
A former Mayor, Edward I. Koch, has endorsed a fellow Democrat, Herman Badillo, for New York City comptroller, saying that it would not "upset" him if the endorsement helped the Republican "fusion" ticket. B3.
 
LOWEST DROPOUT RATE REPORTED
Schools Chancellor Fernandez has reported the lowest dropout rate ever recorded in New York City, a rate far lower than that reported by virtually all other large urban school systems. B3.
 
A former police officer, Michael Dowd, pleads guilty to crimes that made him a symbol of corruption in the New York Police Department. B3.
 
REGION
 
SEVERANCE DEAL IS CRITICIZED
The state Insurance Superintendent says that Albert A. Cardone, the deposed head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, has severance agreements that could cost the financially troubled company $2 million. In a letter to the company's board, the superintendent, Salvatore A. Curiale, urged Blue Cross not to pay. B4.
 
YONKERS ARGUES THAT IT HAS CHANGED
The City of Yonkers has tried to show in Federal District Court that it has had a change of heart and that it is moving aggressively to create subsidized housing for more than 700 poor or middle-income families in largely white neighborhoods of the city. B5.
 
ILLEGAL DUMPING IS ADMITTED
Two landfill operators have pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Riverhead, L.I., to appropriating 25 acres of state land at the edge of the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center in Brentwood and turning it into a sand mine and dump. B5.
 
INDIAN TAX PLAN IS THROWN OUT
New York State's highest court has thrown out a state plan that was intended to help the state collect taxes on the sale of gasoline and cigarettes by Indian retailers to non-Indian customers. B5.

HEADLINE: As Iran Chief Faces Vote Today, West's Doubts Rise

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, June 10

 BODY:
When President Hashemi Rafsanjani first took office in 1989, some diplomats greeted him as a moderating force in a country dominated by radical Islamic clerics.
Just over a year ago, some Western envoys hailed the ouster of some parliamentary hard-liners as a victory for the President and a turning point in Iran's relations with the West. But as Mr. Rafsanjani heads into an election on Friday that he seems virtually assured of winning, diplomats are increasingly skeptical that he will use his second four-year term to cut off Iran's support for shadowy groups threatening other governments in the region. 
After a series of assassinations of exiled Iranian dissidents and renewed friction over Teheran's backing for Islamic and Palestinian militants in Egypt, Algeria, Lebanon and the Israeli-occupied territories, American diplomats have reassessed the 58-year-old President's intentions and his influence.
 
Focus on Economy
 Mr. Rafsanjani's struggle for control of revolutionary Iran now centers on free-market reforms to revive the economy, they say, and he has little interest in jeopardizing his fragile power base by seeking to ease political repression or end state-sponsored terrorism.
Western diplomats suggest that the President's chief aim in cultivating a moderate image was to attract European and Japanese investment and woo back the Iranian business managers and engineers who fled after the Islamic revolution in 1979. So far he has achieved neither goal, and envoys in the region doubt that he has enough domestic support to restructure bloated industries influenced by hard-line clerics.
Meanwhile, the strategy for containing the Islamic Government's activity abroad has sharply divided Western allies. Countries like France, Germany and Italy still view Mr. Rafsanjani as the only hope of curbing Iran's sponsorship of state terrorism and its hard-line clerics; the United States insists that Iran must remain a pariah, no matter who governs, until its policies change.
"It is not in our interest to have an economically powerful and politically resurgent Iran," a senior American diplomat in the region said. "While President Rafsanjani talks of opening Iran to the West, he means opening Iran to Western technology and capital. The longer Iran remains economically crippled, the less damage it can do."
 
U.S. Withholds Ties
 The Clinton Administration, disturbed by Iran's support for militant Islamic groups in the region and by what it describes as a steady arms buildup, including an effort to buy or develop nuclear weapons, refuses to lift trade sanctions or to resume diplomatic ties with Iran. Last month a State Department report assailed the country as the "world's principal sponsor of extremist Islamic and Palestinian groups."
The repression characteristic of presidential campaigns here involves few subtleties, and Iranians interviewed on Teheran's tree-lined avenues raised their eyebrows in amazement when asked to predict the outcome of Friday's voting.
Political parties are banned in Iran. Only contenders chosen by a council of conservative clerics can run. There are no campaign rallies. Television and newspapers are in the hands of Islamic fundamentalist organizations, and the three unknown opposition candidates have vied to lavish praise on the incumbent.
"The selection of four presidential candidates does not mean that these four people should represent four different points of view," said one candidate, Abdullah Jasbi, president of the Islamic Open University.
Also running for President are a former Labor Minister, Ahmed Tavakoli, and a former member of Parliament, Rajab Ali Taheri.
 
Uses of the Election
 But while the vote has stirred little enthusiasm here, diplomats expect Mr. Rafsanjani to use it to promote his free-market program.
"I hope that at the end of the second term the country will be in a totally different shape than it was at the beginning," Mr. Rafsanjani said in his second and final campaign broadcast Monday night.
Still in tatters from an eight-year war with Iraq, the Iranian economy is paralyzed by a lack of foreign investment and by inefficiency in many industries. Though the official unemployment rate is reported to be 10 percent, diplomats believe that it is much higher, and inflation has been running at an annual rate of 40 percent.
Fourteen years after the Islamic revolt that overthrew Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, many Iranians are also tiring of the sermons that monopolize state television, the police squads that roam cities enforcing Islamic tenets of dress and behavior, and the restraints on civil liberties.
To allay public discontent, the Government recently drew on its limited hard-currency reserves to restock shops with electronic goods and food products that had all but disappeared over the last decade.
 
Often Stymied by Hard-Liners
 But even with the backing of Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the President's economic program is often stymied by hard-line clerics, many of whom have called for a boycott of the election on the ground that no candidate has proposed an alternative to Mr. Rafsanjani's free-market policies.
Political and economic power in Iran is shared by about 150 clerics. Many of them are linked to five main Islamic charity foundations that essentially operate as vast holding companies, controlling industries that produce shoes, cars, aluminum, pharmaceuticals, candy and even ham for export.
The foundations employ hundreds of thousands of workers. However inefficient some of those industries are, the clerics who run them show little inclination to turn them over to the private entrepreneurs Mr. Rafsanjani says he has waiting in the wings.
"The outcome of the election is preordained," a Western diplomat said, "but what will follow is not. How much reform is possible? How much power can be centralized?"
For Abdel Rezza Ahmed, an official at the 15th of Khordad Islamic charity organization, the future can be summed up in one word: Islam.
Sipping tea from a glass cup and nibbling coconut cookies, Mr. Ahmed sat placidly on a recent morning in an office whose walls bore a poster showing the British author Salman Rushdie clutching a copy of his book, "The Satanic Verses." Mr. Rushdie and his novel were being devoured by bright orange flames.
The organization for which Mr. Ahmed works has offered to pay more than $2 million to anyone who kills Mr. Rushdie, who was condemned to death in 1989 by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini for blasphemy.
"When Mr. Rushdie is dead," Mr. Ahmed said, "it will mean we have removed one more obstacle on the path to an Islamic paradise."
Faced with such pronouncements, some European diplomats in Teheran criticize what they say is the shortsightedness of the United States Government.
"President Rafsanjani is the best alternative we have," a European Ambassador said. "If he fails, what will follow will be much, much worse and the United States will have to bear most of the blame."

Last week, Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, above, led prayers on the fourth anniversary of the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini at his shrine in southern Teheran and raged against the United States' "open animosity." (Agence France Presse)

HEADLINE: Dow Falls by 20.21 as 3M Shares Tumble

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
A big plunge in shares of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, one of the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average, sent the blue-chip index lower yesterday.
Without 3M's decline the market was fairly flat, analystss said. The Dow industrials finished down 20.21 points, to 3,491.72. 
 3M said second-quarter earnings would be higher than a year earlier, but by less than previously expected because of slowing United States sales growth. The stock dropped by 10, to 105 3/4, on 2.29 million shares traded, nearly 10 times its three-month daily average of 297,300.
Another big decline came in Helene Curtis, which also scaled back its sales and earnings outlook. Its shares tumbled 5 1/2, to 28.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 232.6 million shares, down from 249 million shares Wednesday, as declining issues outpaced gainers by a ratio of 5 to 4. Except for the Nasdaq composite, which was off 1.19 points, to 688.05, the other market indexes were off less than a point each.
Many investors were on the sidelines, analysts said, ahead of today's report on producer price inflation for May.
"A lot pulled back because everyone knows that the Federal Reserve has the green light to raise short-term interest rates, so today's May Producer Price Index number is important," said Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist at First Albany. "But if the number shows an increase of one-tenth of a pecentage point, or less, it could touch off a spirited rally in stocks and bonds.
Gene J. Seagle, director technical research at Gruntal & Company, sees little worry over inflation.
"Looking at the stock market, the Dow industrial average was at 3,232.50 at its January bottom," Mr. Seagle said, "and despite worries about the Fed, Russia, President Clinton, the health program, and a myriad of other depressants made an all- time high on May 27 of 3,554.83.
"The market is still correcting its May move from 3,400 to 3,580 in intraday trading and also working off an overbought condition." He expects the Dow to rise to at least 3,600 this summer.
 
Drug Stocks Exhibit Strength
 Some drug stocks exhibited strength yesterday. Merck, the only drug stock in the Dow industrial average, rose 7/8, to 37 5/8; Bristol-Myers Squibb 1 1/4, to 59 1/2, and Schering-Plough rose 2 1/4, to 66 1/4.
Semiconductors came under pressure as Texas Instruments fell 1 1/2, to 66 1/4, and Intel dropped to 54 5/8, down 1 1/4.
First Savings Bank, in Greenville, S.C., saw the price of its stock jump by 2 and finish at 13, after the bank said it was in talks to be acquired. First Savings did not indicate by whom or for how much.
Andrea Electronics stock fell 9 5/8, to 31 7/8, after the company confirmed reports that the Securities and Exchange Commission was conducting an informal inquiry on the wild trading activity of its stock, but that no formal investigation has commenced. It also said it was in negotiations with certain companies in the public telephone industry for the sale of its Active Noise Cancellation products.

HEADLINE: Wanted: Contributors in Search of Immortality

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Call it an answer to the yearning for immortality: for a price, universities and colleges will carve the name of a generous benefactor in limestone on an imposing building. Too costly? The donor can opt for a piece of the building -- a student lounge, a science laboratory, a library, even a photography darkroom -- dedicated in perpetuity with a bronze plaque.
The practice of marketing buildings and other campus landmarks is hardly new, but it is reaching new dimensions. Squeezed between faltering government support and rising expenses, private universities and colleges are pursuing potential donors as never before, with lists of "naming opportunities" ranging from research institutes to plastic seats in an athletic stadium. 
 Rutgers University, for one, will put the name of a donor on a locker in the locker room for the men's football team for $1,000. Fifteen have been designated and 10 are waiting adoption by loyal fans of the Scarlet Knights. Rutgers also has pricier offerings, like a new library wing under construction on the New Brunswick campus, available for a $2.5 million gift.
To name a building, a donor does not have to pay the entire cost of construction, but most schools require signing on to pick up at least a third to half of the cost.
The pursuit of major donors is commonly entrusted to a high-ranking school administrator, though universities are increasingly bringing in outside consulting businesses. Typically, the opportunity is broached during a friendly luncheon and the potential donor gets a glossy photograph of the offered properties and a price list.
 
Giving Something Back
 "At New York University, we encourage people to put their names on things," said Naomi B. Levine, the senior vice president for external affairs who has a reputation as an adept strategist in matching the school's priorities and donor preferences. "In many instances, a gift is the donor's way of saying, 'I want to give something back in return for my education.' "
If a persuasive word is needed, Mrs. Levine can call on a board of trustees including such influential New Yorkers as Laurence A. Tisch, president of CBS, who is the board chairman; Leonard N. Stern, chairman of the Hartz Group whose name is on the university's Business School, or George H. Heyman Jr., an advisory director at Lehman Brothers who plays a significant role as volunteer chairman of the University's Development Committee.
"There is not a door these men and women cannot open for me," she said.
Mr. Tisch, whose family donated $30 million to name the hospital that bears their name (formerly University Hospital), invites other trustees to luncheons where they identify prospective donors and decide which board member is best positioned to pursue the goal.
New York University, in the midst of a campaign to raise $1 billion by the year 2000, has a long list of naming opportunities including a 23-story biomolecular medicine building waiting for a donor willing to make a $10 million gift. It also has a new business library to be named in appreciation of a $5 million contribution, and four student residences.
 
A Seat for $5,000
 At Columbia University, for $25 million each, donors can put their names on the college's library, the Neurological Institute or the law school library. Columbia has other lower-priced naming opportunities, including the molded plastic chairs in Wien Stadium at $5,000 apiece.
In the past, the largest gifts to the university have not been designated for buildings. John W. Kluge, the chairman of Metromedia and a 1937 graduate, gave Columbia $60 million for minority scholarships last April, saying at the time that he was not interested in buildings named after him and "would rather do something for human minds." Two earlier gifts totaling $50 million went for minority scholarships and assistance to young scholars and junior faculty members.
Occasionally, a college will take a building in use for decades under one name, and rededicate it in honor of a new donor, with the approval of the first donor's surviving relatives.
In some instances, college authorities will rededicate the building with ceremony but take care to keep a plaque honoring the first donor in some less commanding position. Others use both names, hyphenated.
 
A Second Opportunity
 Brandeis University, for example, got a second naming opportunity for a building that was to be rededicated as a new admissions center after bearing the original donor's name for many years. The grandson of the original benefactor agreed to the change, saying, "After much soul-searching, I decided my grandfather would have wanted the university to benefit in any way possible."
The campus of Brandeis, which opened in Waltham, Mass., in 1948 without benefit of the financial cushion of an endowment, offers abundant evidence of its debt to benefactors: a tribute wall and hundreds of plaques on everything from buildings, classrooms, walkways and even a boulder.
Abram L. Sachar, its first chancellor, has said Brandeis, which had no prospects of substantial alumni gifts for a least a generation, survived only because of its wide circle of donors.
 
Roosevelt Memorial House
 Hunter College also offers a renaming opportunity as it casts about for donors to provide $3 million to renovate and endow a double town house at 47 and 49 East 65th Street, originally purchased by Sara Delano Roosevelt to be shared by her son and daughter-in-law, the newly married Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt. The house, donated to Hunter College in 1943 to serve as an interfaith center, needs extensive repairs to restore the President's library and equip the center for college and community activities promoting religious and racial harmony.
The building's name will be retained as the Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House, but a number of rooms will be offered for naming.
The practice of honoring benefactors goes back centuries. A young Puritan minister named John Harvard started the process in the American colonies in 1636 by bequeathing a few hundred pounds to establish a college on the Charles River in Massachusetts.
New Jersey's ailing state university was rescued in 1825 by Col. Henry Rutgers, who gave the school $5,000 and a bronze bell, a gesture that led to the naming of the school in his honor. The bell is still in use, and each of the college's 2,000 graduates is invited to ring it at commencement each year.
 
An Urban Garden
 High on Fordham University's list of naming opportunities is a property the size of half a city block, just south of Lincoln Center on West 62d Street between Ninth and Amsterdam Avenues, which now resembles a parking lot. Fordham would like to turn it into a grassy urban garden with space for a sculpture area and a glass-enclosed dining section and still leave room for students to toss flying disks.
The university was offered the property in the early 60's by Parks Commissioner Robert Moses, who approached the late Laurence J. McGinley, Fordham's president.
"There was some grumbling about whether the university was taking on an investment that would become an economic liability," said Bruno M. Santonocito, vice president for development and university relations, "but the university agreed and so became owner of one of the city's most valuable open spaces." Depending on how Fordham develops the site, it will need between $250,000 and several million dollars -- and has identified six naming opportunities for people with that much money.
Fordham also is looking for benefactors to share the costs of developing a library at its Bronx campus. The building itself has been named for Daniel C. Shedrick, a businessman who made a fortune selling baseball, football and hockey cards and gave $10 million to his alma mater, the school's largest gift. But naming opportunities exist for rooms and work stations in the building.
The Jewish Theological Seminary of America is looking for donors to renovate its landmark tower destroyed in 1967 -- a restoration likely to cost millions. The seminary recently lost one benefactor's name: after his conviction for insider trading, Ivan Boesky, the arbitrageur, asked the seminary to remove his name, saying he wanted to save the school embarrassment, and it obliged.

HEADLINE: MOYNIHAN HOLDING WELL-TIMED PARTY

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
A week before the Senate Finance Committee began reworking President Clinton's economic package, supporters of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan mailed invitations to lobbyists for a fund-raising event that reminded them of the New York Democrat's enhanced influence as chairman of the panel.
No laws were broken by Mr. Moynihan or by his campaign organization, and his aides noted that the Senator did not know who was invited nor who was responding to the invitation to an event that will be held a month after the committee completes its work. 
 But an advocate for changing the way campaigns are financed said the Senator had been insensitive at a time when public skepticism about the influence of lobbyists on Congress is especially sharp.
Invitations to the $5,000-a-person event at the Rainbow Room in Rockefeller Center, which will be limited to 30 people, is scheduled for July 19. That will probably come before a Senate-House conference committee reconciles versions of the economic package that emerge from the two Houses.
Mr. Moynihan is up for re-election next year.
 
Oversees 98% of Revenue
 The invitation, mailed last week, noted, "Most importantly, Senator Moynihan is now chairman of the Finance Committee where he will oversee 55 percent of all Federal spending and 98 percent of all revenue raising, as well as health care reform and trade."
Mr. Moynihan's office referred questions about the letter to William T. Cunningham, a consultant to the Moynihan campaign. "I can't imagine how you can put pressure on somebody to buy tickets for something when the items they are most interested in have already been decided," said Mr. Cunningham. "During his entire career, a question has never been raised about conflict of interest in his fund-raising, and it shouldn't now. Senator Moynihan has been fastidious."
Mr. Cunningham added: "If you had public financing you wouldn't have to do this stuff. No matter what date you pick, somebody is going to say there's an appearance of conflict of interest."
Ellen Miller, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a group that lobbies for campaign finance changes, disagreed. "It's a serious conflict of interest," she said. "In a time in which concern over the role of special interests is at an absolute height -- a campaign finance bill is on the floor of the Senate, the President is bashing lobbyists every day -- for a senior member of the Senate to be insensitive to this seems to be absurd."
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who was Mr. Moynihan's predecessor as chairman of the Finance Committee, was sharply criticized six years ago when he invited lobbyists to join a breakfast club for $10,000 apiece. Mr. Bentsen withdrew the idea, calling it "a doozy"of a mistake.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits New Low Vs. the Yen

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
The dollar hit a new low against the yen yesterday even as the manager of the nation's currency market dealings stressed the need for stability.
Administration officials have been talking the dollar down against the yen this year to promote exports and discourage imports, in hopes of narrowing the vast trade deficit with Japan. William J. McDonough, manager of the Federal Reserve System's open market account, set a contrasting tone at a quarterly briefing yesterday, stating the Government's intent to avoid a headlong selloff. 
 As of late April, he said, "The dollar-yen exchange rate was at that point moving too far, too fast, in part due to apparent misperceptions in the market of U.S. policy makers' views." He later added, "If the market perceives a U.S. policy in appreciation of the yen, the market is mistaken."
Lending detail to moves already familiar to market strategists, he confirmed that on April 27, the Government sold a modest $200 million in yen for dollars, evidently coordinating its support for the dollar with the Bank of Japan.
 
Dollar at 106.16 Yen
 That intervention braked the dollar's decline at about 109 yen, then a record, but only temporarily. As the dollar has fallen since then, currency traders have seen the Fed's hand in the market several more times, into the beginning of this week. These moves have generally been slight, however, more to indicate the Government's sentiments than to fight the trends.
Yesterday, the dollar fell to 106.16 yen from 106.45 in New York, leaving a currency worth 20 yen less than in January.
Against the German mark, the dollar fell to 1.6295 marks, from 1.6358 late Wednesday, after gaining on Wednesday from some well-timed comments by George Soros, the manager of a large investment fund. Mr. Soros said that German interest rates were likely to fall, reducing the mark's attractiveness.
Traders saw no reason to relent in selling the dollar against the yen, however. So far, the American and Japanese Governments have tried only to slow the dollar's decline, not halt it, said Michael Levy, a currency options trader at Societe Generale. "As long as that happens, you will have people trying to push it down and down," he said. "Why stop now?"
Speculators can use strategies that yield huge profits from even a slight change in rates. These strategies often accelerate the market's momentum.
The dollar dipped below 105.9 yen before recovering yesterday, but Mr. Levy predicted a test of the 105 level. Traders will be watching today's report on producer prices, and Tuesday's on consumer prices, for signs of revived inflation, which could produce higher interest rates and a stronger dollar.
At yesterday's news conference in New York, Mr. McDonough, in tones of measured forbearance, formally confined his remarks to the three months through April, the Fed's own distinctive quarter. The Fed's press release went to the extent of quoting Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, on the risk that currency volatility would hinder growth.
In late May, Mr. Summers released a report noting that the yen's rise could reduce the trade deficit but then denied that the Government was seeking any such thing. Far better, he said, for the Japanese to reduce the trade deficit by stimulating their economy and increasing consumption.
Traders said that with the Japanese economy already stagnant, the Bank of Japan had become increasingly restive about letting the yen's appreciation stifle exports.
Volatile exchange rates can upset other financial markets and cause business planners to hesitate. The President himself has a stake in containing the dollar's decline against the yen and keeping it from spreading to other currencies, said Steven H. Axilrod, vice chairman of Nikko Securities in New York.
"It's a piece of baggage you don't need, because the signal it gives is that neither Americans nor foreigners are that confident about the Administration," he said.
Despite the Fed's independence in monetary matters, the Treasury has the final say when it comes to the currency. Mr. McDonough said that the Government, committed to floating exchange rates, had not endorsed any targets or changes. April's support for the dollar, backed by some statements from Treasury officials, only signaled the markets and, as he put it, "re-established a sense of two-way risk."

Gold and Silver Fall
 By Reuters
Gold and silver prices declined again yesterday on expectations that today's Government report on producer prices will show a cooling down of inflation at the producer level.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery dropped $2, to $371 an ounce. The actively traded gold contract had lost $2.60 on Wednesday. Meanwhile, July silver fell 3.5 cents, to $4.31 an ounce.
 Analysts said the market seemed to be factoring in forecasts for a rise of only one-tenth of a percent in the Producer Price Index for May, down from April's increase of six-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: Paternity Suit Just Another Crisis in Rhode Island

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 10

 BODY:
Democrats and Republicans alike today dismissed an unfolding scandal over a paternity suit against Gov. Bruce Sundlun of Rhode Island as a titillating but temporary problem.
The suit was filed by a 17-year-old Michigan girl whose mother was involved with the 73-year old Democratic Governor for several years in the 1970's, after his second marriage. 
 But residents of the country's smallest state today jammed the airwaves, on radio talk shows, to debate the Governor's obligations to Kara Kathleen Hewes, whose news conference in Birmingham, Mich., was broadcast live on Wednesday afternoon on Providence television.
Ms. Hewes, who bears a strong resemblance to the Governor, appeared to capture the sympathy of many Rhode Island residents with her clear, calm responses to reporters.
Ms. Hewes, along with her mother, Judith Hewes, on Wednesday filed a paternity complaint against Mr. Sundlun in Oakland County Circuit Court in Michigan, asserting that he is her father and seeking an undisclosed amount of financial support with back payment to her birth.
The complaint asserts that DNA and blood tests show with 98.96 percent certainty that Kara Hewes is the Governor's daughter. Mr. Sundlun has 28 days to respond to the lawsuit once it is served.
 
More Difficult Crises
 Guy Default, chairman of the state's Democratic Party, said Mr. Sundlun had weathered more difficult crises since his 1990 election. Upon taking office he froze 250,000 credit union accounts as he confronted a statewide banking crisis; in 1991 his wife, Marjorie, nearly died in a car accident, and he has to contend with what is proportionally the largest budget deficit of any state.
"This'll be a short-term blip," Mr. Default said. "Rhode Island being so small, this is a very learned electorate. They've come to focus on substantive issues rather than on insignificant but titillating ancient history."
A Republican political consultant, Thomas J. Cashill, offered a similar assessment. In an interview today he said Rhode Islanders had known that they were electing a "womanizer" in the Governor, who married his fourth wife in 1985.
"It doesn't really matter," Mr. Cashill said. "These things last about 72 hours."
The Governor was the first to mention the suit in a news conference on Tuesday, and he addressed the issue again on Wednesday and today. He said it was very likely that he was Ms. Hewes's father. But Mr. Sundlun, who is a millionaire, said a 1976 agreement and a $35,000 settlement with Judith Hewes had relieved him of further financial responsibilities. He also said that "my own rights of fatherhood were lost upon Kara's adoption by Mr. Hewes in the late 1970's."
Judith and Robert Hewes were divorced in 1985, Kara Hewes's lawyer, Henry Baskin, said. Mr. Hewes's Miami telephone number is unlisted.
In an interview taped today by the NBC affiliate in Providence, Governor Sundlun directly addressed his daughter Kara: "It's going to be difficult. But somehow or other, you and I have got to fight our way through those obstructions. We've got to get by Mr. Baskin; we've got to get by your mother. My hands are out and my heart is open. I hope yours is, too."
In the news conference on Wednesday, Mr. Sundlun defended his treatment of Kara but criticized her mother's handling of the situation. "I really do not think that I can be accused of ignoring Kara or not wanting to have a relationship with her," Mr. Sundlun told reporters. "Candidly, I do not feel the same about Judith Hewes."
Governor Sundlun acknowledged on Tuesday that he had had an affair with Judith Hewes, then Judith Vargo, in the early 1970's when he was single, and headed an airline company in which Ms. Vargo served as chief flight attendant. But the Governor's office issued a statement today saying that the affair continued briefly during his third marriage to Joy Carter Sundlun.
Neither Kara Hewes nor her mother could be reached for comment yesterday, because they were resting, Mr. Baskin said.

HEADLINE: Middle of the Road;
Clinton's Policy on Trade, It Turns Out, Has Similarities to the Bush Approach

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
As a symbol of how President Clinton's newly announced Japanese trade policy is similar to President George Bush's, consider Harold A. Poling, the strong-minded chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, who accompanied Mr. Bush to Tokyo last year for trade negotiations that proved to be a political disaster
On Friday, Mr. Poling will be coming to Washington to join another round of talks with Japan, this time for President Clinton. But while his business companions last year were other Big Three chairmen, they will be replaced on Friday by the chief executive of a far broader group of companies -- Motorola, Apple Computer, Tenneco Automotive and American International Group, the insurance giant. 
 After months in which trade watchers puzzled over often-contradictory signals from the Clinton Administration over its trade policy, the proposal announced this week seems to be what President Clinton in February said it would be: something in between.
 
Similarities and Differences
 It tracks the Bush approach by keeping America open to imports, seeking to tear down Japanese barriers and avoiding public threats of trade sanctions. And it pursues a middle path between free trade and protectionism much like the Bush Administration, which denounced managed trade while obliging Japan to limit its car shipments here, and Taiwan to limit its shipments of factory tools.
There are significant differences, too. The Clinton policy uses a few extra numerical targets like seeking to reduce Japan's trade surplus with the rest of the world to between 1 and 2 percent of Japan's annual economic output.
Former Bush Administration trade officials are most alarmed by the setting of targets for Japan's overall trade surplus with the world. The reason is that the trade surplus could be trimmed not by opening the Japanese market to imports but by cutting its exports to the United States.
 
Could Shift Produciton
 "Japanese multinationals have factories throughout Southeast Asia, so if there was a need for them to reduce the surplus, they could always shift production," said Eric I. Garfinkel, who was President Bush's Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Import Administration. The result of such a shift in production would be larger American trade deficits with countries like Thailand and Malaysia instead, he added.
The Clinton Administration's response to that problem is a second target: increasing Japan's imports of manufactured goods by a third within the next several years. Japan imports a smaller percentage of its manufactured goods than any other industrialized country.
The new strategy also takes clear precedence over national security concerns, unlike the Bush Administration approach, and it is backed up by the prospect of sanctions later. It enjoys support from both ends of the business spectrum and includes lavish financial backing for export-oriented high-technology companies.
All told it combines American complaints about the way the Japanese economy is organized with complaints about specific industries' trade barriers, instead of handling them separately. And it coincides with an enormous expansion in the Japanese trade surplus that has increased world pressure on Japan.
In Mr. Clinton's first Presidential address on trade, he outlined a vision of a world in which free trade was kept alive by aggressive action to dismantle unfair barriers, and promised a trade policy that would confront foreign trade barriers without restricting the entry of foreign goods into the United States.
 
Middle of the Road
 He posed the idea as one that fell between what he called "voices from the extremes."
"One says government should build walls to protect firms from competition," he said. "Another says government should do nothing in the face of foreign competition, no matter what the dimension and shape of that competition is, no matter what the consequences are in terms of job losses, trade dislocations or crushed incomes."
As President Clinton promised then, the new American strategy is a combination of unilateral, bilateral, regional and global initiatives. The White House plan is also combined with domestic policies aimed at strengthening the same industries that would benefit from more open international markets.
"This is consistent with what our membership has been calling for," said Willard Workman, the United States Chamber of Commerce's vice president for international affairs.
Mr. Workman, a former Reagan Administration trade negotiator, said that the Clinton Administration might be wise not to threaten Japan publicly with trade sanctions, leaving it to journalists and other trade policy observers to point out that domestic American law allows considerable freedom for the Administration to limit imports from Japan if it becomes dissatisfied with the pace of negotiations.
"When you have a hammer, it's always better to have someone else say you have a hammer," he said.
According to the International Monetary Fund, Japan's current account surplus has widened to $117.6 billion and 3.2 percent of economic output last year, from $35.8 billion and 1.2 percent of economic output in 1991.
"Japan's surplus is, today, the major asymmetry in the world economic system," just as the American trade deficit was a large disorder in the world economic system in the mid-1980's, a senior Administration official said on Tuesday. Whereas the United States ran large trade deficits with most of the world eight years ago, it has now moved into balance with most countries.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Drop

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 2,000 last week, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance totaled 345,000, down from a revised 347,000 in the previous week. Claims were previously thought to have totaled 344,000 for the week that ended on May 29. They totaled 338,000 in the week that ended on May 22. 
 Many economists had predicted that claims would drop by several thousand last week.
The less volatile four-week moving average of jobless claims, which analysts prefer to track because it more accurately reflects the labor situation, rose to 342,750 in the latest reporting period, up from 340,750 a week earlier.
The Labor Department report also said 26,104 applications were filed under a Federal emergency unemployment program in the week that ended on May 29, down from 26,559 in the previous week. The emergency claims and individual state figures lag behind the overall total and the four-week moving average by one week.

HEADLINE: Ruling Scuttles Plan to Collect Taxes on Reservation Sales

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 10

 BODY:
New York State's highest court outlawed a state plan today that was intended to help the state collect taxes on the sale of gasoline and cigarettes by Indian retailers to non-Indian customers.
The unanimous decision killed a State Department of Taxation plan intended to do two things: collect as much as $100 million in unpaid taxes and force up prices on Indian reservations, where sales by tax-free stores to non-Indians are booming. 
 The ruling, by the State Court of Appeals, outraged the owners of hundreds of gasoline stations and convenience stores outside Indian reservations, who say they are losing ground to a growing number of Indian-owned businesses that sell tax-free goods.
"Competition I can handle; this I can't," said Salvatore Aronica, the owner of a gas station and store seven miles outside the Seneca Nation reservation south of Buffalo. Mr. Aronica said he has been pushed to the brink of bankruptcy by Seneca businesses that sell gasoline for 20 cents less a gallon than he does.
 
Hailed by Indians
 New York State Indians hailed the ruling as an important affirmation of their sovereignty, one that would help economic development on reservations by safeguarding the tax-free advantage maintained by Indian businesses.
"If this case went the other way, we would have lost hundreds of jobs," said Barry Snyder, head of the 6,000-member Seneca Nation. "But this has never been about money. It has been about honoring our treaties."
Today's ruling does not question the right of the state to collect taxes on sales by Indians to non-Indians. But because Indian land is under the jurisdiction of the Federal Government, states cannot seize property there to enforce tax collection.
The state regulations struck down today represented a novel attempt to circumvent such restrictions by collecting taxes from non-Indian cigarette wholesalers before they had even sold their goods to Indian retailers. The cost of the taxes presumably would have been passed along to the retailers and then to their customers.
Under the 1989 regulations, state officials made estimates of how many cigarettes were sold to Indians on certain reservations. Based on those estimates, the state allowed wholesalers to sell a certain number of tax-free cigarettes to Indian businesses. But sales beyond that would be taxed on the theory that they would be resold to non-Indians.
The regulations, which could have been applied later to gasoline wholesalers, were challenged almost immediately by a Buffalo cigarette distributor, Milhelm Attea & Brothers, Inc., who said the state was interfering with commerce on Indian reservations in violation of Federal laws.
 
Appeal Remains Possible
 In writing for the court, Associate Judge Richard D. Simons agreed, saying that "no room remains for state laws imposing additional burdens" upon companies doing business with Indians.
State Commissioner of Taxation James W. Wetzler said the state had not decided whether to appeal the case in Federal court. But he said a solution to the state's problem of attempting to collect taxes to which it is legally entitled would come from either Federal legislation, the United State Supreme Court or a negotiated settlement with Indian nations.
Mr. Wetzler said the tax-free status of Indian reservations have made them attractive to tax-evasion schemes by non-Indians. For instance, some distributors try to avoid taxes by claiming they sell exclusively to Indians when they actually do thriving business with non-Indians.
Mr. Wetzler estimated that Indian stores account for about 7 percent of all the cigarette sales in the state, over 113 million packs a year. He said uncollected taxes on sales by Indians to non-Indians amount to over $70 million on cigarettes and $30 million on gasoline each year.
The state levies a tax of 56 cents on a pack of cigarettes and 32 cents on a gallon of gasoline.
At the Shinnecock Smoke Shop on the Shinnecock Indian reservation in Suffolk County, a pack of Marbloros costs $1.90. But at the Townhouse Deli down the road in Southampton, the same pack costs $2.95, up from $2.75 a week ago because of a 17-cent increase in state taxes.
"They have a line for their cigarettes like you wouldn't believe and we are losing sales big time because we are getting slammed by taxes," said Robert C. Capo, owner of the Townhouse Deli.
Organizations that represent gasoline station and convenience store owners reacted angrily to today's ruling, calling on the state Legislature to find relief for non-Indian businesses.
One bill proposed by Senate Republicans would reduce state taxes on businesses near Indian reservations by 50 percent. No similar bill has been introduced into the Democratic-led Assembly.
Constance K. Barrella, vice president of the New York Association of Convenience Stores, said Indian businesses have grown rapidly in recent years because their proprietors are now marketing their tax-free status more aggressively.

HEADLINE: Plan Seeks To Rebuild Downtown Of the Bronx

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
Gambling that an infusion of public money will reverse 25 years of decline, state, city and Bronx officials announced yesterday an ambitious plan to rebuild the Bronx's downtown. They said the plan was aimed at encouraging private investment in the borough and keeping the Yankees in the Bronx.
The officials, announcing a proposal developed through Borough President Fernando Ferrer's office, admitted they had no guarantees on financing. Rather, they said, the plan was intended as a framework for rebuilding the area around four huge public projects in the next decade at an estimated cost of $1 billion. 
 In a ceremony at Alex and Henry's restaurant off 161st Street, Mr. Ferrer, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Bronx community advocates spoke of the plan as the economic shovel they hope will bury the area's poverty as well as the symbol of the Bronx as the pre-eminent example of urban decay.
"As Charlotte Street came to be a metaphor for urban struggles in the 1970's, let this Bronx Center become synonymous with an urban success story for the 1990's and beyond," Mayor Dinkins said.
The announcement, if an idealistic call to combine money, education and culture in one 300-block area, was also firmly grounded in political reality. The Mayor hinted that the looming budget gap could hurt the plan. And as he faces a mayoral race in which the Hispanic vote will be crucial, Mr. Dinkins was effusive in his support for community organizers, Mr. Ferrer and the plan itself, which could have a broad impact on the largely Hispanic communities surrounding the Bronx Center.
 
'A Very Special Capacity'
 Whatever the political implications, Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, said in an interview that the plan appeared to be a wise move, even if the politicians faced public skepticism because no money was in place for it.
"This is an effort to take current public investments and to link them to give them a greater impact than any one project would have," he said. "We have to appreciate that New York has a very special capacity to propose partially funded visions that become reality. The point is they are going to take existing public money and try to get other investments."
Though the numbers are vague, the plan could mean thousands of jobs, both in construction and in permanent positions, said Richard A. Kahan, president of the Urban Assembly, the Manhattan nonprofit planning group retained to develop the $200,000 report. The total cost would be as much as $3 billion and the overall plan would evolve as it developed to include small parks, high schools, shopping areas, health-care units, access to the Harlem River and improved transportation.
The plan, developed with community groups extensively involved, includes the area bounded by 165th Street on the north, 147th Street on the south, the Harlem River on the west and St. Ann's Avenue on the east. This area is already the Bronx's economic and municipal core, including Yankee Stadium, the Bronx County Building, Bronx Criminal Court, the Bronx Terminal Market and the Hub, a central shopping district.
The 48-page document released yesterday centers around four projects already in planning or construction: Melrose Commons, a 2,600-unit housing development off Melrose Avenue; the new Police Academy, at Grand Concourse and 153d Street; the new State Supreme Courthouse off 161st Street; and the Juvenile Detention Center, at 149th Street and Brook Avenue, the only one of the projects already under construction.
 
New High Schools
 The plan calls for three new high schools in the area: one near the Police Academy for teen-agers interested in becoming police officers; another in the court building to train high school students for legal careers such as paralegals, stenographers and secretaries, and another near Yankee Stadium focused on sports-related careers like trainers and managers.
The plan would also encourage retail development along the Grand Concourse and would upgrade the Metro-North station on Park Avenue and 161st Street to bring more people into the area. The first project would be to renovate the ground floor of the old County Courthouse, a Beaux-Arts landmark at Third Ave and 161st Street. This project would cost $600,000 -- not yet raised -- and the building would the center for the plan's development over the next few years.
High on the planners' priorities were concessions to the Yankees baseball team, whose lease on the stadium expires in 2002. The city is currently in negotiations with the team owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, and the plan would include ferry service to the stadium, a baseball museum and a 3,000-car garage near the river, on top of which is planned a park and possibly an arena.
