HEADLINE: Mastercard and Midtown: City Hall Wins in New Tack

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
In a decision that company officials say turned more on New York City's intangible assets than on simple economics, Mastercard International will keep its headquarters in mid-Manhattan rather than move to Westchester County.
For the city, Mastercard's decision to move from its current Manhattan headquarters into nine floors of the old Burlington House on the Avenue of the Americas means holding onto 450 jobs, and if Mastercard's own growth projections hold true, getting another 750 within the next 12 years. 
 But beyond the numbers, it also amounts to a symbolic victory in the Dinkins administration's long-running battle to keep corporations from fleeing the city. And both they and Mastercard officials hailed the company's decision as validation of the city's position as the nation's pre-eminent business center, despite its high taxes and other costs of doing business.
Mastercard executives insist that the ultimate decision never came down to a playoff between incentive packages, that their talks with Westchester never reached that stage. They concede that moving to White Plains would have reduced their occupancy costs over the next 20 years by 25 percent. They say that the availability of a more sophisticated labor pool in New York and the city's vibrant atmosphere ultimately kept the company in Manhattan.
 
New Strategy by City
 "If you want to hire people who are multilingual, who have international experience, and if you thrive in a stimulating environment, then being in New York is just more important than being able to sneak a midweek round of golf in the suburbs," said Alex W. (Pete) Hart, Mastercard's president.
Still, Mastercard received an unusual package of tax incentives that Dinkins administration officials said signaled a new strategy in their economic-development efforts. The package represents New York's first offer of abatements that are tied not just to existing jobs, but to job growth.
Under the agreement, if Mastercard maintains its current employment level of 450 jobs, it will receive a relatively small package of incentives amounting to no more than $2 million over the next 20 years. It will receive a real-estate tax credit for each employee it hires above that level. But if it increases its staff to 900 -- something that its managers expect to do by the year 2000 -- the tax breaks would amount to $8 million, prorated over the 20 years.
"For us this is a new approach to jobs in this city," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation. "We've spent a lot of years looking at job retention. Now, for the first time, we are focusing on job growth. We held onto a lot of jobs during the recession, and now we don't want to play defensive ball anymore."
According to the city's estimates, keeping Mastercard, with a staff of 450, would mean $81 million to the city from corporate taxes, personal income and sales taxes, and related business travel. With a staff of 900 people, the boon to the city is estimated at $176 million.
 
Earlier Decisions
 Neither the incentive numbers nor the revenue numbers are huge, particularly compared with the multimillion-dollar packages that the city has offered larger companies like BankAmerica or Morgan Stanley to locate here or to stay here.
BankAmerica, with 1,700 jobs in the city, announced that it would take eight floors at the World Trade Center in April, after the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the center's owner, offered the huge bank two years' free rent, and after the city offered it a package of sales tax breaks and other incentives worth $15.5 million over the 15-year term of its lease. Similarly, last year when Morgan Stanley considered moving 4,100 jobs to Stamford, Conn., the city kept it in Manhattan with a tax-incentive package worth $39.6 million over a 10-year lease.
But for New York it represents a new way of figuring the importance of a company to the local economy, not in terms of immediate cash or job infusions, but in terms of future growth.
 
Company's 3-Year Study
 Mastercard's lease calls for it to take seven floors now and an additional two floors in a couple of years -- a total of 350,000 square feet -- at 1345 Avenue of the Americas, at 55th Street, the old Burlington Industries building. Veteran deal-watchers in real estate said Mastercard had negotiated a rent in the high $30's per square foot a year, along with a substantial contribution to the cost of building the offices to Mastercard's specifications, as well as more than a year's free rent. Those numbers represent a good deal even for large, credit-worthy tenants.
Mastercard's decision is the culmination of a three-year study that began with looking at whether Mastercard should consolidate its international headquarters, which was crammed into 170,000 feet at 888 Seventh Avenue, at 53d Street, with its huge data center in St. Louis -- and if that consolidation took place, whether the newly combined company should be in New York, Missouri or elsewhere.
By the fall of 1991, Mastercard had already decided that it would lose too many people if it tried to move either operation and decided to keep them separate.
But the next decision was not so cut and dried: Should Mastercard keep its headquarters in midtown or move it to Westchester.
Westchester -- and particularly White Plains, with its easy rail and car accessibility -- was an early leader. Costs were lower, and Mastercard's chances of getting a building built to its own specifications were far higher.
 
The Other 20%
 Still, Mr. Hart and many of his senior executives were reluctant to give up what they saw as the international prestige of a mid-Manhattan address, as well as the availability of what they considered a higher-caliber cadre of professional staffand a more sophisticated atmosphere.
"People tend to believe that relocation decisions are driven entirely by economic factors," said Les J. Cranmer, a principal of PHH Phantus Consulting, a management consulting firm in Florham Park, N.J., that Mastercard hired to help it evaluate the repercussions of moving. "In fact, in a front office relocation, maybe 80 percent of the things are quantifiable, and 20 percent are things you just can't attach numbers to."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Shares of 3M Plummet on Sales Report

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 10

 BODY:
Shares of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company plunged today after the company said slower-than-expected domestic sales growth would cause it to miss Wall Street's projections for the second quarter.
3M shares fell $10, to $105.75, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The 8.6 percent decline accounted for much of the drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, in which 3M is one of 30 stocks. 
 Analysts scratched their heads at the steep decline. "It's a surprise but not a shocking one," said Eugene Glazer, who follows 3M in New York for Dean Witter Reynolds. "They are reporting a moderate slowdown."
Some analysts speculated that institutional shareholders had rushed to lock in profits generated by the 20 percent run-up in 3M shares over the last year, to a recent peak of $117. The consensus earnings forecast for the year was cut yesterday by 2.4 percent to $6 a share, from about $6.15.
 
Modest Gains Expected
 3M, which is based in St. Paul, and best known for its Scotch brand tapes, is one of the most diversified manufacturers of industrial, medical and consumer products in the United States. It makes more the 60,000 products, many derived from its expertise in what Kimberly Retrievi, who follows the company for Lehman Brothers, described as "goos, films, or goos spread on films."
The company said it expected to report only a modest gain from the second quarter of 1992, when it earned $317 million, or $1.45 a share, on sales of $3.5 billion, instead of the growth of about 10 percent that many analysts had projected. The company's information and memory storage products have been among the hardest hit by the slowdown, but L.D. DeSimone, the chairman and chief executive of 3M, said an across-the-board slowing of the American economy seemed to be the main problem.
"A majority of our businesses have experienced slower U.S. growth so far this quarter," Mr. DeSimone said.

HEADLINE: Hint to Fed On Rates Is Louder

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
A day before the release of a closely watched report on inflation, the White House subtly turned up the pressure today on the Federal Reserve not to raise short-term interest rates, suggesting that inflationary pressures remain weak.
After announcing that President Clinton met Wednesday night with the Federal Reserve's chairman, the White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, sent the central bank a clear message, saying that Administration officials "believe there is no real inflationary pressure in the economy." 
 Ms. Myers also said she believed that the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction program "would help keep interest rates down."
 
 
Fed Asks for Clarification
 Hours later, however, Ms. Myers issued a clarification, at the central bank's request, saying her comments did not mean that Mr. Greenspan had endorsed the plan.
Interest in the Fed's stance remains particularly high as economists try to get a better fix on how fast inflation is actually rising while the economy continues its slow growth.
On Friday, the Labor Department will issue its report on wholesale prices in May, and many economists say that if the report shows a sharp increase, coming after a surprising jump in inflation in April, the Federal Reserve may raise short-term interest rates immediately.
In recent days, Mr. Clinton, in what is widely seen as a signal to the Federal Reserve, has said several times that it is critical for interest rates to remain low. On the defensive over the economy's lackluster performance, the Administration has repeatedly underlined the importance of low interest rates for lifting the economy out of its slump.
 
 
Link to Deficit Package
 A rate increase would also upset the White House because President Clinton has often boasted that his $500 billion deficit-reduction package has set the stage for a period of low interest rates.
Administration officials said that when Mr. Clinton and Mr. Greenspan met Wednesday night in the Oval Office, they discussed the President's budget package and the state of the economy, including inflation and interest rates.
At her daily news briefing, Ms. Myers apparently made a faux pas that upset the Federal Reserve chairman by saying, "I believe chairman Greenspan thought that the deficit reduction" of the President "would help keep interest rates down."
Administration officials said the Federal Reserve had asked for a clarification of Ms. Myers's statement. Although Mr. Greenspan had told Congress that the President's deficit reduction plan would help push down interest rates, the Fed chief was worried that her statement might be construed as saying he endorsed the President's embattled plan.
 
 
Avoiding Conservatives' Wrath
 Since many conservatives tore into Mr. Greenspan for initially praising the President's plan, the central banker has appeared to be straining to show that he is not in Mr. Clinton's pocket.
Within hours, Ms. Myers issued a statement saying that she "did not mean to imply" that Mr. Greenspan "in any way endorsed the President's economic package now before Congress."
Her statement added that Mr. Greenspan "said the President's economic initiative had set into motion a process that he feels reasonably assured will in the end lead to significant deficit reductions. He went on to say that passage by the Congress of any credible deficit-reduction plan would help to keep long-term interest rates low."
 
 
A Sensitive Time
 One Administration official said the White House produced its clarifying statement so quickly because it was eager not to offend the Federal Reserve at such a sensitive time.
Administration officials said that Mr. Clinton had asked for the hourlong meeting and that it was something the two men planned to do periodically.
Among the other officials attending the meeting were Robert E. Rubin, coordinator of the National Economic Council, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and David Gergen, the White House counselor.
Even as Ms. Myers sent subtle signals to the Fed today, she tried to show that the White House was not trying to push around the proud central bankers. "The Fed is an independent agency and we don't presume to control their decisions," she said.
 
 
'We Remain Optimistic'
 "However, I think most of the people here, the economic advisers, believe that there is no real inflationary pressure in the economy, although there's been some uptick," she added. "We remain optimistic about inflation."
Federal Reserve officials are tilting toward raising rates because they are concerned that inflation has jumped to a 4 percent rate in recent months. But many central bank officials believe that the wholesale prices report on Friday and the consumer prices report on Tuesday will show lower inflation.
The Clinton Administration's gentle nudging of the Fed has been far different from the Bush Administration's muscular jawboning. Fed officials say in private that relations with the new Administration have been far better than with the Bush Administration even though all the current Fed governors were appointed by Republicans.

HEADLINE: Japan's Chief Economist Sees Signs of Recovery

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 10

 BODY:
Japan's chief economist, in a step toward declaring an end to the nation's worst recession in two decades, said today that the economy would deteriorate no further and that signs of recovery were coming into view.
"The economy has generally hit bottom," Hajime Funada, director general of the Economic Planning Agency, told a Cabinet meeting today. His remarks came as the agency submitted a monthly report on the economy that while far from ebullient had a somewhat more positive tone than in recent months. 
 A recovering Japan would be welcome news for its struggling companies and pessimistic consumers, and for America and the rest of the world. A healthy Japan would buy more foreign products, reducing Japan's nettlesome trade surplus.
 
 
Other Views
 But many politicians, business leaders and economists, while agreeing there are some positive signs, do not agree that the recession is anywhere near over or even that the bottom has been reached.
They say that corporate profits are expected to decline this year for an unprecedented fourth consecutive year, consumer spending is weak and the rapid rise of the yen is about to deal a fresh blow to Japan's already weakened automobile and electronics companies.
"When you look at data, most economists in town would agree that we're past the worst," said Jesper Koll, chief economist at S. G. Warburg Securities. "But being past the worst doesn't mean the economy is going to recover to 3.3 percent growth," he added, referring to the Government's official growth target for this fiscal year. "There is no section of the economy that is better off than it was six months ago, one year ago or even three years ago."
Still, the notion of a recovering Japan has touched off a bitter debate that is not so much academic as political. There is widespread speculation here that the E.P.A., with the backing of the powerful Finance Ministry, wants to declare the recession over so that Japan will not come under pressure to stimulate its economy at next month's summit meeting of industrial nations.
 
 
Rescue Packages
 In the last year Japan has announced two major economic rescue packages containing more than $200 billion in increased public works spending and other incentives, an amount, Mr. Koll noted, that is equivalent to the total economy of Belgium.
But the United States, for one, has been calling on Japan to take further pump-priming measures to help drive the world out of recession and to increase Japan's imports. Many Japanese business leaders favor another stimulus package, including possibly a cut in income taxes. The Finance Ministry is against further fiscal stimulus because it fears having a national budget deficit.
As word spread this week that the E.P.A. was preparing to declare that the economy had turned a corner, powerful voices rose in protest, including those of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry and of the Keidanren, Japan's most powerful business lobbying group.
When the report was issued today, any mention of the economy bottoming out or the recession being over had been removed. Instead, the report merely says that Japan's economy is in an adjustment phase and that some movement toward a recovery is emerging. But Mr. Funada then expressed his own judgment that the economy would get no worse and would slowly get better.
 
 
Criticism of Government
 Business leaders have complained since the recession began that the Government failed to notice that the economy was slipping into recession two years ago and took too long to devise countermeasures.
The E.P.A. in particular has been criticized for being too optimistic. It held to an unrealistic forecast of 3.5 percent economic growth last year, before finally cutting the figure to 1.6 percent, which still might prove too optimistic. This year's target, 3.3 percent growth, compares with some outside economists' forecasts of only 1 percent growth.
"These guys are excellent at turning out very good quality statistics but they are slightly out of touch with the realities of a very dynamic economy," Mr. Koll of S. G. Warburg said.
Kenji Umetani, an E.P.A. official, said today that there were several signs of recovery: housing starts were picking up, the economic stimulus packages were starting to kick in and sales of some electric appliances were showing signs of life. Domestic sales of videocassette recorders in April rose 4.5 percent from a year earlier, the first year-to-year increase in nine months.
In addition, Mr. Umetani said, excess inventories had been worked off and the diffusion index, a group of leading economic indicators, had been in positive range for two months.
Kenneth S. Courtis, strategist in Asia for Deutsche Bank, said he thinks the economy hit bottom at the end of last year. But he said the rise of the yen, which would make Japan's exporters less competitive, could wipe out much of the growth expected for this year. In Tokyo trading today, the yen rose to another record high.
Still, some other highly visible economic figures, such as automobile sales and department store sales, continued to fall.

HEADLINE: Tough Talk on Trade By U.S. Envoy to Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 10

 BODY:
With the United States and Japan heading into a period of unusually bitter exchanges on economic issues, the American Ambassador here described Japan's efforts to depict itself as a free trader as "propaganda." He said it would only stiffen the Clinton Administration's resolve to use market share targets to open Japan to imports.
"I admire the chutzpah that this P.R. campaign represents, and in some respects I welcome that the Japanese are touting themselves as the champions of free trade," the Ambassador, Michael Armacost, said in an interview today. "It goes without saying that those who wish to enjoy that reputation will be held accountable to a higher standard of conduct."
 
 
Reflection on Difficult Times
 Mr. Armacost, a highly regarded career diplomat, is expected to wind up a four-year tour here this summer, and to be replaced by former Vice President Walter F. Mondale. Reflecting on the difficult times he has spent in Japan, he said he was pleased at how well the two nations had managed the array of tough security and political issues that had followed the end of the cold war. 
 But he openly expressed frustration over the fact that years of negotiated agreements and promises from the Japanese have produced only a temporary reduction in their trade surpluses, which are now soaring to record levels. He characterized the harsh protests by the Japanese against the Clinton trade proposals as little more than an attempt to deflect attention from the huge surpluses.
"I hope people are not being too persuaded by some of the P.R. that's been flowing so freely recently, which is designed to dismiss the problem, or suggest that it's a product of short-term factors that will take care of themselves, or, in any event, the surplus will be recycled and in the long run it will go away," Mr. Armacost said. "That isn't an adequate answer."
The only alternatives, he indicated, are the sort of proposals the Clinton Administration had made, which will be negotiated intensively in the next several weeks. The United States is demanding that Japan agree to specific targets for imports and market access for foreign companies.
Japanese officials have vehemently denounced President Clinton's new strategy as a breach of the principles of free trade, and some have started personal attacks on the President, describing him as a neophyte in international affairs who is relying on his heart rather than his head. Some officials have also attempted to argue that Japan's economy is more open than America's.
Mr. Armacost, who had long backed a much broader and less specific approach to balancing Japan's trade, said he now feels that the Clinton Administration's tougher approach is justified. He added that while at one time such economic concerns took a back seat to the more pressing demands of trying to hold the line on the spread of Communism in Asia, times had changed.
 
 
'Undermines Confidence'
 "I do believe that in the post-cold war world the United States cannot afford to subordinate its economic interests to strategic concerns," he commented, and added, "There is a belief that a failure to come to terms with these problems undermines confidence in the alliance."
Mr. Armacost said that both sides shared some of the blame for the bitter edge in the relationship, at least in the economic sphere. For several years the United States failed to bring down its budget deficits, he said, and those have contributed to America's trade deficits.
But the Clinton Administration is now taking concrete steps to bring the deficit under control. Meanwhile, Mr. Armacost said, the Japanese surplus is expanding wider than ever, with the Japanese Government offering little more than denunciations of the new trade policies in Washington.
"Unfortunately there has been a kind of reversion to the old pattern of exporting their way out of the current recession," Mr. Armacost said. "I sense a loss of momentum in the effort to deregulate the economy."
 
 
Global Trading System
 He also criticized Japan for not taking firmer steps to help bring to a conclusion negotiations to revitalize the global trading system. For several years now the major trading nations have been struggling to design a new trade regimen that would open markets further and enhance the free flow of goods as well as services.
Japan, Mr. Armacost said, has benefited more than most countries from the global trading system, and thus ought to be a leader in making the difficult political decisions necessary to open markets further. This, he said, was another area in which Japan was obliged to show leadership by taking the initiative in using its huge markets to benefit other countries.
"I believe we do practice different forms of capitalism," Mr. Armacost said of Japan and the United States. "The differences, I think, are increasingly familiar. What is needed, I think, is a harmonization to some degree, but not a homogenization."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boeing Sees 600-Seat Jets in Future

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said yesterday that preliminary marketing studies indicated that the world's airlines could need 400 to 500 so-called Very Large Commercial Transport planes during the first decade of the next century.
The feasibility of the plane, known as the VLCT, was being studied by Boeing and four European companies. The plane would carry about 600 passengers, compared with 421 in the Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet. 
 Separately, Boeing said three airlines had ordered nine Boeing 767 jets at a total value of about $700 million. Boeing shares fell 37.5 cents, to $38.375, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
The announcement on the very large plane was made at the Paris Air Show by the directors of the study, which was being conducted by four European aerospace companies -- Aerospatiale of France, British Aerospace, CASA of Spain and Deutsche Aerospace of Germany -- and Boeing.
The yearlong study began in January, and Boeing and the European companies have met monthly since February to discuss technical issues, develop marketing forecasts and examine the feasibility of creating a consortium to produce the plane.
 
'All Signs are Positive'
 "We're a long way from deciding whether to launch a big airplane," John Hayhurst, the Boeing program director for the joint study, said in a statement. "But so far, all the signs are positive."
Jurgen Thomas, the European program director for the study, said: "The study is off to a faster start than we had anticipated. We agree on many points, and we both believe that the only way the VLCT will be produced is through an international partnership."
The two directors said the technology existed to develop a 600-seat airplane, adding that a plane of that size could operate out of most big international airports. They said a VLCT could have an initial range of about 7,000 nautical miles, with the possibility of future derivatives that could carry more than 600 passengers or fly farther.
"If our initial estimates hold up, it appears that there could be a viable market for the VLCT" starting about the end of the decade, Mr. Hayhurst said.
Separately, Boeing said Gulf Air, which is based in Bahrain, had ordered two 767-300ER's (extended range); EVA Airways of Taiwan had ordered four 767-200's, and Japan Airlines had ordered four 767-200's. Delivery dates were not announced.
 
Orders Are Encouraging
 Available in various configurations, the 767-200 carries 181 passengers and the 767-300 carries 218 passengers. To date, 50 customers have ordered a total of 665 of the 767's.
"I'm encouraged by the level of orders we're seeing given the economic environment," said William B. Whitlow, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities in Seattle. "Asia is kind of weak right now, and we're especially nervous about Japan because J.A.L. is such a key customer for Boeing, so the fact that they placed an order is a positive."
Mr. Whitlow said the very large transport plane presented both positives and negatives for Boeing: While it would create a huge new market opportunity in the long term, it would require significant research and development spending that would squeeze earnings in the short term.
"On balance, it's a positive because Boeing seems to be in a position today to take the lead in that market," he said. The joint effort under way "with key Airbus partners would seem to preclude Airbus from doing it," he said, referring to the European aerospace consortium which makes Airbus planes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A drawing from the Boeing Company of a jetliner that could carry 550 to 800 passengers. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Haiti: End the Charade

 BODY:
After 20 months of dithering, Washington finally seems to have summoned the political will to apply serious pressure for the restoration of democracy in Haiti.
The United States, Canada, Venezuela and France are preparing to ask the U.N. Security Council to slap a worldwide ban on oil shipments to Haiti, backed up by Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, which authorizes the use of military force. The oil embargo would reinforce a toothless Western Hemisphere economic embargo. And it would be accompanied by a new round of political negotiations timed to exploit Tuesday's resignation of Marc Bazin, the military's figurehead Prime Minister. 
 American will has been the issue all along. Haiti's corrupt and undisciplined 7,000-man army stands isolated at home and abroad, no match for determined international pressure. Traditionally, Haiti's top generals have been eager to accommodate Washington's wishes, provided those wishes were clearly and consistently expressed. The generals' intransigence this time around has been fed by the mixed signals emanating from Washington since the September 1991 coup.
The Bush Administration publicly proclaimed its commitment to restoring President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's democratically elected Government. But American diplomats privately sent signals to the generals that they distrusted Father Aristide, whose uncompromising assaults on the corrupt and violent crowd he replaced triggered the coup and the reign of terror that followed. And by its blatantly racist policy of delivering would-be refugees from the terror back to Haiti, the Bush Administration eased the pressure on the rest of the world to achieve a political solution.
President Clinton ignored his own campaign denunciations of the mistreatment of Haitian refugees and continued the cruel Bush policies. He promised accelerated diplomacy. But Mr. Clinton was thwarted by the Haitian military's contempt for a process it sees no reason to take seriously. Able to evade regional sanctions by importing oil from Europe, and noting the Administration's backpedaling on Bosnia and other issues, Haiti's generals have simply folded their hands.
Tougher policies are needed, but that doesn't mean sending in the Marines. Haiti endured 19 years of U.S. military occupation earlier this century, and no one, President Aristide included, favors even a brief reprise of that unhappy experience.
The right way to get tough is to enforce a worldwide oil embargo. Most of the oil reaching Haiti comes by sea from the Netherlands and is unloaded in Port-au-Prince harbor. For the past year the U.S. has demonstrated the capacity to stop tiny refugee boats from leaving Haiti's most remote beaches. Big deep-water tankers should be a lot easier to turn around.
The U.S. would not have to enforce the embargo alone. Canada has already offered ships, and Venezuela, Argentina and France might also be willing to help. With enough cooperation from exporting countries, active naval enforcement may prove unnecessary. And, with help from the Dominican Republic, Haiti's single land border can also be sealed. With outside supplies cut off, oil stockpiles would run out within a month or two.
Already, thousands of Haitians have died and tens of thousands more have tried to flee for their lives while two American Administrations played pretend diplomacy. Twenty months after a brutal clique overthrew Haiti's first democratically elected Government is not too soon for Washington and the rest of the world to get serious about defending legitimacy, democracy and human rights.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: It's Not Too Late for Clinton to Get It Right

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A History of Gergenism" (editorial, June 2) and "The Constant Hearts" by A. M. Rosenthal (column, June 1): Americans of my generation, children of the Depression years, who grew up during World War II and were very active and centrist Democrats, voted for President Clinton because we believed he was an intelligent and practical professional politician who had learned from his McGovern activist days and his governorsip of Arkansas that we as a nation are people of the center. Many of us had voted for Ronald Reagan and George Bush in 1988 because we did not agree with the ideology of the Democratic Party or feel represented by its shrill, often faddish culture. We voted for President Clinton.
I am at a loss to understand how this intelligent man could have misunderstood the "centrist" message he conveyed during the campaign and made a first priority of the sexual roles of military personnel; then the firing of the travel bureau of the White House in what appeared to be a failure of due process, and then getting a haircut in a plane on a runway while holding up traffic. 
 What I think the President has to realize is that he has to be himself, not a product of gimmicks or advisers. John F. Kennedy could cavort with the Hollywood set because we were then a successful nation in a different era. Today we have what I call a managed depression, and the President was voted in with the hope that he could do something to create jobs and a better economy -- setting the tone for hope.
Good lawyers, in negotiation or litigation, have a clear-cut goal in mind and prepare for their job. That's what a good politician has to do. There is a perception in this country that the President is a little bit of a phony with no real beliefs. If that perception does not change, President Clinton will disappoint me and lot of other people. I believe he can change, and I still have confidence in him, but he has credibility problems that only he can correct.
I was office manager for the New York Committee for Stevenson, Kefauver and Wagner in 1956, an aide to Adlai E. Stevenson and treasurer of Citizens for Eugene McCarthy in 1968.
 
LAURENCE W. LEVINE
New York, June 4, 1993

HEADLINE: It's Not Too Late for Clinton to Get It Right;
Alternative Budget

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With all due respect, you seem to miss the point of the alternative budget plan I introduced with Senators John C. Danforth of Missouri, William S. Cohen of Maine and J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana. "A Deal on the Economic Plan" (editorial, June 3) and other editorials level the charge that it was just oil state senators out to protect that industry. 
 That argument ignores that two of the authors are not even from oil states and that the British thermal unit tax had already been changed so that it would not hit oil producers. The tax, now abandoned, was to be collected not at the wellhead, not at the refinery, not even at the utility, but from consumers. Consumers in New York would have paid every bit as much in B.T.U. tax as consumers in Oklahoma. It would have cost jobs in all 50 states by making our products less competitive in world markets.
In offering an alternative budget plan, we wanted to provide a third option to the unacceptable choice between a budget plan that proposed to bring down the deficit primarily with tax increases and doing nothing at all. Ours would reduce the deficit with twice as many spending cuts as tax increases, without the anti-competitive B.T.U. tax and with controls on entitlement spending, which is 46 percent of the budget.
Our suggestion was the first major bipartisan budget proposal made since Bill Clinton became President. We wanted to send a signal to the country that some Democrats and Republicans want to set aside childish partisan bickering and work together in the national interest.
President Clinton deserves to be encouraged and congratulated for his decision to add the highly respected David Gergen to his staff and for signaling he is willing to change his budget plan by adding spending cuts and reducing tax increases. These are steps in the right direction.
We sought to give the President room to get back to the center of American politics. For the sake of the party, and above all for the sake of the country, that is where he needs to be.
 
DAVID L. BOREN
United States Senator, Oklahoma
Washington, June 8, 1993

HEADLINE: Reaganomics, With a Mexican Accent

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind is executive editor of The National Interest.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The growing opposition in Congress to the North American Free Trade Agreement may save the Administration from its own confusion.
The President has ignored the contradiction between his ambitious program for domestic revitalization and his support for a much freer flow of capital and labor between the United States and Mexico. The trade agreement and continuing high levels of immigration from Mexico can derail his vision of a high-investment, high-wage, high-tech America. 
 Mr. Clinton was elected because cheap-labor economics failed to improve life for most Americans. Under Ronald Reagan and George Bush, real wages, in constant dollars, stagnated or sank for most workers, benefits were slashed and job security declined. For most of the 1980's, the minimum wage was held constant despite inflation, creating a disguised pay cut for the poorest workers.
The expatriation of U.S. industry replaced many high-wage manufacturing jobs with low-wage service jobs. The results were predictable: higher profits for corporations and investors, and a decline in real pre-tax income for all but the wealthiest Americans. Levels of private-sector investment in productivity-enhancing new capital equipment fell far below Japanese and German rates -- and below U.S. rates of the past 30 years.
Most of those who voted for Bill Clinton and Ross Perot repudiated this cheap-labor policy. Its ghost lives on, however, as the spirit of the free-trade agreement.
Naftanomics is Reaganomics with a Mexican accent. Though proponents argue otherwise, it is almost certain that Nafta, if ratified, will tend to depress U.S. wage, benefit and consumer-safety levels toward those of Mexico. Many well-paid U.S. breadwinners in the Rust Belt and Sun Belt will lose their jobs to poorly paid Mexicans in shantytowns. Nor will most displaced U.S. workers move from sunset to sunrise industries. If the 1980's are a precedent, they will go to work in low-paying service jobs at a fraction of their former salaries.
If Nafta is bad news for many workers, it is even worse news for the Administration. Making it easier for U.S. multinationals to relocate and take advantage of cheap Mexican labor without benefits will undermine Mr. Clinton's expensive effort to extend health care benefits to all citizens: Companies with factories in the U.S. could claim that paying more for employees' health care would make them uncompetitive with rivals that have Mexican operations.
Similarly, public investment in upgrading the U.S. infrastructure will hardly persuade U.S. corporations to invest in domestic operations as long as they can make windfall profits by exploiting Mexico's labor costs.
Even if Nafta did not threaten Mr. Clinton's reform agenda, the continuing mass immigration of mostly unskilled Mexican workers would. Few economists deny that the flood of poorly educated Latin Americans in the last three decades has depressed wages for less-skilled U.S. workers.
Unskilled immigrants from Mexico compete with poor blacks and whites in such cities as Los Angeles and Houston for entry-level jobs. Compared to U.S. citizens, they are also disproportionately likely to go on welfare or end up in jail, at taxpayer expense. Voters who fear that their tax dollars are going to indigent or violent immigrants are more likely to resist the tax increases without which Mr. Clinton's program cannot work.
For Mr. Clinton to try to raise middle-class incomes and taxes while Mexican and other third world immigrants are depressing wages and raising the costs of law enforcement, education and welfare would be like bailing water from a leaking canoe.
Mr. Clinton promised to put the material interests of workers and taxpayers above those of foreign economic rivals and the affluent few in the U.S. That means rejecting Naftanomics and restricting unskilled immigration. If he does not recognize this, he may say hasta la vista not only to his domestic program but to the White House as well.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Israel Looks Like the Winner

BYLINE: By Shibley Telhami; Shibley Telhami, associate professor of government at Cornell, is author of "Power and Leadership in International Bargaining: The Path to the Camp David Accords."

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
Although Middle East peace talks are scheduled to resume on Monday, the Arab-Israeli conflict is really over. Victory is Israel's to clinch -- or squander. And America is in a position to tip the balance one way or the other.
For decades, the Arabs oscillated between finding an ally other than the U.S. and working to erode U.S. support for Israel by replacing it as a strategic ally. Egypt recognized the futility of the first strategy in the early 1970's. The rest of the Arab world reached that conclusion at the end of the cold war. 
 After the Camp David accords were signed in 1978, America's Arab allies believed that offering themselves as a strategic alternative to Israel could weaken the U.S.-Israeli relationship and give them an edge in the confrontation with Israel.
Since the gulf war, a remarkable transformation has taken place. The Arab governments have finally and genuinely accepted that U.S.-Israeli relations are beyond their reach. Some have even come to believe that the quickest route to Washington goes through Israel. And today, the rich Arab countries are wooing Washington for security needs, the poor ones for economic needs.
King Fahd of Saudi Arabia chose an important religious occasion to call for peace with Israel. Most Arab countries have dropped the boycott of companies that do business with Israel and some have entered into joint ventures with Israeli companies. The Libyan Government, usually the most hostile to Israel, recently authorized a pilgrimage by private citizens to Jerusalem, apparently as a way of improving relations with the U.S. Morocco and Tunisia have accepted Israel's suggestion to hold Middle East talks on their soil. Many Arabs, officials and academics, seeking access in Washington find it expedient to go through the very Israeli lobby they once sought to undermine.
Arab leaders are clearly preparing their publics for a deal with Israel. More importantly, some view their potential relations with Israel as strategically beneficial. For the Arab-Israeli conflict, 1993 could turn out to be what 1989 was for the cold war.
To clinch a deal, Israeli leaders have to be wary of outsmarting themselves. Israel holds considerable leverage, while the Arabs, especially the Palestinians, have precious little. Even if Israel can get Arabs to accept most of its conditions, it cannot ignore Palestinian and Arab domestic politics. An agreement that does not secure the bare minimum requirements for each side will not endure.
The primary obstacle to peace lies in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. Even in the difficult Syrian-Israeli negotiations, the issue of linking a Syrian-Israeli treaty to a Palestinian-Israeli treaty is a key obstacle. Although the Palestinians have agreed to a transitional period of autonomy before a settlement can be reached, wide disagreements with Israel remain on the scope of autonomy.
Given its leverage, Israel feels it need not offer much. Israel can prevail. But unless an autonomy agreement makes possible the creation of independent Palestinian institutions that could ultimately sustain self-determination (a powerful legislature, for example), the Palestinians will have few incentives to cooperate. And unless diaspora Palestinians envision the possibility of settling on the West Bank and in Gaza in the future, replacing the dream of returning to Israel, they will work to defeat an agreement.
One problem for the Israeli Government is the difficulty of domestic political compromise unless there are short-term incentives or threats. This is where the U.S. comes in. To help the Israeli Government negotiate with its own public, the U.S. has to take the lead in inducing necessary concessions -- something that has been missing so far.
It's easy for a mediator to get concessions from the weak. It is not always wise. An Arab-Israeli agreement would be a boon to the Administration -- but not an agreement that would blow up in its face.
Even if negotiations failed, Israel would still have a strategic edge. Failure would possibly be more painful for the Arabs than for Israel. But in the end, all would lose. While a favorable deal is within Israel's reach, who knows what tomorrow will bring?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

Economic Reports Ease Fear of Inflation Surge
Producer price inflation was flat in May and retail sales posted a weaker-than-expected rise. The reports pointed to slow economic growth and allayed fears that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates to curb inflation, which had surged earlier in the year. Page 35.
 
Cable Price Cuts Delayed
 The Government-imposed reductions in cable television rates will be delayed because the F.C.C. needs more money to put them in place. Page 35.
 
Doubt Over Ukraine Arms
 With Ukraine's leadership in disarray and its economy in a downturn, the ability to make the transition to a non-nuclear state is in doubt. Page 5.

 The Chicago Bulls beat the Phoenix Suns to take a commanding 2-0 lead in the National Basketball Association championship series. Page 29.

HEADLINE: NORTH KOREA SAYS IT WON'T PULL OUT OF ARMS PACT NOW

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 11

 BODY:
Averting a major confrontation with the West, North Korea said today that it would not withdraw for now from the international treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons.
The announcement came just hours before the North Korean pullout was to take effect on Saturday. 
 In a surprise announcement after intensive negotiations with the United States, the North Korea Government said that it would "suspend" its treaty withdrawal, for the time being at least, and continue to allow international monitoring of some of its nuclear sites.
 
Short of U.S. Demand
 But North Korea gave no indication that it was ready to let inspectors into the most sensitive installations, where the West believes North Korea is producing material for nuclear weapons.
The Central Intelligence Agency has said that North Korea may have produced enough plutonium to make at least one nuclear weapon. The prospect of a nuclear-armed North Korea is widely regarded as one of the most serious threats to stability in the region and the world.
The North Korean agreement to honor the treaty for a bit longer fell short of the complete acceptance demanded by the United States. American diplomats said the agreement was the best they could obtain, but warned that more pressure would be necessary before North Korea opens sensitive sites to international inspectors.
There was no indication that Washington had made any significant concessions to persuade North Korea to take its step today.
 
No Mention of Pledges
 Before the talks, United States negotiators had made it clear that Washington would reward a total North Korean reversal by canceling joint military exercises with South Korea and by giving assurances that it would not reintroduce nuclear weapons into the Korean peninsula.
But because North Korea's action fell short of what was wanted, there was no reference today to such pledges.
Some experts say that the threat of a nuclear-armed North Korea is so great that military force might be justified to stop its nuclear program. But South Korea, Japan and many United States officials fear that a military attack would be dangerous and counterproductive, and they have sought to rely on pressure and negotiations.
In an unusual joint statement this evening, the first ever issued by the United States and North Korea, the countries said North Korea would "suspend as long as it considers necessary" its withdrawal from the nuclear accord.
The head of the United States delegation, Robert L. Gallucci, the Assistant Secretary of State for Political-Military Affairs, called the move "a step in the right direction" and said the United States had decided to accept something less than what it wanted because the alternative would have been "extremely unfortunate."
 
Discussions to Continue
 The joint declaration also emphasized the determination of both countries to continue their discussions and expressed support for international scrutiny intended to insure that nuclear material is not being used to develop nuclear weapons.
The drama began early this year when the United States and the International Atomic Energy Agency, which had sent inspectors into North Korea, pressed for more extensive inspections of North Korean installations.
Then on March 12 North Korea announced abruptly that it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which pledges signers to refrain from making nuclear weapons and to allow inspections.
Under the treaty, withdrawal announcements are supposed to take effect 90 days after they are made, or on Saturday, in North Korea's case. Throughout the 90 days, fears rose that North Korea was determined to proceed with a nuclear weapons program.
The announcement hours before the final deadline followed a warning by the United States that it would be "looking urgently at next steps" if North Korea went ahead with its effort to become the first country ever to pull out of the 23-year-old accord. As a sign of good faith, Washington issued general assurances of its commitment to North Korean security.
By agreeing for now to remain in the nuclear accord, North Korea has eased the United States' most immediate concern.
 
U.S. Wants New Talks>
 By refusing to actually retract its decision to withdraw, however, North Korea retains the right to take that step at any time. American diplomats said they intended to seek a new round of talks to persuade North Korea to complete its change of course, but expressed relief that the deadline would pass without the standoff turning into a rupture.
The nuclear treaty is the main international obstacle to the emergence of new nuclear powers, and American officials had feared that North Korea's withdrawal would set a dangerous precedent.
In separate appearances in the courtyard of the United States Mission to the United Nations, the two sides left no doubt that they remained divided over whether the International Atomic Energy Agency could demand the right to inspect any instalation it chose.
Kang Sok Ju, North Korea's Deputy Foreign Minister, bluntly characterized the International Atomic Energy Agency as pro-Western, and said his Government's agreement to future inspections "totally depends" on whether the agency acted impartially.
North Korea is believed to be hiding evidence of its nuclear weapons program in a plant at Yongbyon, and it was its refusal to permit the agency to search the site that kindled a dispute that led to its March announcement to withdraw from the pact.
The United States initially threatened to seek United Nations Security Council authorization for economic sanctions against North Korea. But China made clear that it would veto such a measure, and at its urging Washington agreed to the direct talks with North Korea.
 
No Other U.S. Options
 That the United States agreed to accept the mere suspension by North Korea of its pullout appeared to reflect its lack of credible options. Without Chinese support, Administration officials acknowledged, it would be all but impossible to win Security Council approval for any punishment of North Korea.
The agreement today brought the first easing in tensions between Washington and Pyongyang since North Korea announced its plan to withdraw from the pact. Although their representatives did not appear together in public, the two countries were represented by flags behind an outdoor podium, and Mr. Kang described their joint statement as "really a turning point in our bilateral relations."
For his part, Mr. Gallucci appeared less pleased that the two sides had not reached a complete accord. But American officials said the intensity of North Korea's mistrust of the International Atomic Energy Agency and its insistence on maintaining a right to withdraw from the nuclear treaty made it impossible to obtain a total reversal.

HEADLINE: NIGERIA SAYS VOTE WILL STILL BE HELD

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, June 11

 BODY:
Nigeria's military authorities announced today that the first presidential elections in nearly a decade would go ahead as planned on Saturday, despite a ruling from the nation's highest court that the voting be postponed.
The authorities said the high court in Abuja, the capital, had no right to preside over the conduct of the elections. The vote will be held as scheduled, they said, despite allegations that the election may have already been marred by fraud and vote-buying. 
 Nonetheless, the decision late Thursday night by Justice Bassey Ikpeme has suddenly altered the political landscape. Uncertainty reigned today as the excitement that normally precedes elections appeared to evaporate.
 
American Official Expelled
 Nigeria's state radio also announced tonight that the Government was expelling Michael O'Brien, the director of the United States Information Agency here, for what it called his "blatant interference" in Nigeria's internal affairs. According to the Government, Mr. O'Brien issued a statement early today saying that the postponement of the elections Saturday "was unacceptable to the United States Government."
Mr. O'Brien was given 72 hours to leave the country.
The Government also announced that it was withdrawing the accreditation for eight Americans who are here as election observers.
The two-party presidential poll is being contested by Moshood Abiola of the Social Democratic Party and Bashir Tofa of the National Republican Convention. Both are widely regarded as close friends and allies of Nigeria's military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, and the victor is not expected to stray far from the political and economic course chartered by the current administration.
An opinion poll of about 2,500 likely voters published today in The Nigerian Tribune, an independent newspaper, put Mr. Abiola ahead, with 47.3 percent of the vote, as opposed to 28.3 percent for Mr. Tofa. However, 24.4 percent of those polled did not indicate how they would vote.
In granting a temporary injunction halting the elections, Justice Ikpeme said the National Electoral Commission should not proceed until it heard allegations brought by the Association for a Better Nigeria, a group that supports an extension of military rule.
The association has led a highly visible campaign to keep General Babangida in power for at least four more years, or until -- in their words -- civilian politicians show themselves capable of establishing democracy.
General Babangida has said repeatedly that, come what may, the military will return to its barracks on Aug. 27 and leave the governing to elected civilians. But critics note that he has done nothing to discourage those who have called for him to remain in office.

HEADLINE: Economic Trouble and Nuclear Dispute Deepen Ukraine's Sense of Insecurity

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, June 9

 BODY:
After 18 months of independence, Ukraine is bogged down in uncertainty about its nuclear status and is caught in a severe economic downturn as strikes spread across its industrial and coal-mining regions.
And with the political leadership in disarray, these troubles have only increased Ukraine's innate feelings of insecurity, which lie at the root of the Parliament's continuing reluctance to approve the strategic arms agreement, known as Start I, that was worked out in 1991 by the Soviet Union and the United States. 
 The troubles are also delaying the steps necessary to declare this country of 55 million people a non-nuclear state, which its leadership promised a year ago.
With the country already talking of building up an armed force of a half million, this flirtation with nuclear weapons has become a concern for Ukraine's neighbors, most prominently Russia and Poland, and for Western nations alarmed at the uncertainties this might produce in Europe.
 
Aspin and Kohl Visit
 This has produced some unusual major diplomacy for this new nation. Defense Secretary Les Aspin and Helmut Kohl, the German Chancellor, both have been here in recent days to show their support for Ukraine's independence. They also sought to reassure Ukraine, which until now has felt that its concerns -- particularly about Russia -- have gone unheard in the international arena. This was evidently done in the hope that it would make it easier for Ukrainian politicians to end their coyness with nuclear weapons.
But Ukrainian opponents of swift approval of the arms control agreements said they still want more -- more financial help from the West to cover the cost of dismantling the 176 intercontinental missiles, and above all, a commitment from Russia that Ukraine will be compensated for relinquishing weapons that have proved to have economic as well as political value.
In the last three weeks, Ukraine's internal debate over the nuclear issue has been complicated by a three-way tug-of-war between the President, the Parliament and the Government over not only who should lead Ukraine but also how and where.
Three times now, Prime Minister Leonid Kuchma has submitted his resignation to Parliament, only to be turned down each time. At one point, President Leonid Kravchuk, the former Communist Party ideology chief who led the country to independence 18 months ago, proposed to take over the Government himself, but that proposal too was rejected by Parliament.
The political crisis may be resolved when Parliament reconvenes next week, but in the meantime, the reputation of Ukraine's leadership -- the President, the Parliament and the Government -- has been badly bruised, just as popular discontent over a crumbling economy begins to heat up.
This week, a wave of strikes swept through the Donbas coal region, which straddles Russia and Ukraine and was the largest coal-producing area in the former Soviet Union.
The strike has spread to the Kharkov region in eastern Ukraine, a bastion of heavy industry, as an estimated half million workers, many of them ethnic Russians, shut down mines and factories in protest against a new surge in prices.
In a repetition of a miners' strikes during the final years of the Soviet era, the Donbas strike leaders have issued political as well as economic demands, calling for Mr. Kravchuk's resignation, new parliamentary elections and greater independence for the Donbas.
[Appearing on national television on June 10, President Kravchuk called on workers to refrain from strikes, and pledged to come up with a package of measures "to lessen the pressure of prices," the Tass news agency reported.
[Mr. Kravchuk also declared that the "resignation of the Government and the Prime Minister is out of the question, and this question will never be raised."]
 
Inflation Is Soaring
 By any indication, the Ukrainian economy is in bad shape and getting worse. Production has been falling steadily, while the money supply increased fortyfold in 1992 alone. In the first three months of this year, prices rose fourfold, more than three times the rate of Russian inflation, and that was before a recent jump in fuel prices. In the meantime, the value of the interim national currency, the karbovantsy, has plummeted from 1,232 to the dollar in March, to more than 3,000 at the end of May.
"It would not be an exaggeration to call the situation catastrophic," said Volodymyr Cherniak, an economist from the Institute of the Economy. "Those who call it a crisis are dangerous optimists."
This view is shared by ordinary Ukrainians whose despair is now approaching panic as they try to make ends meet. With salaries averaging between 23,000 and 26,000 karbovantsy, the latest price rises have been a severe blow. A loaf of bread, which last week cost 40 karbovantsy, now costs 180, while quality meat at the farmers' market now goes for 12,000 a kilogram (2.2 pounds), compared with 5,000 a short while ago.
All this has added a new and desperate edge to even ordinary transactions. "The only people making money now are speculating on prices, or on the currency," said Mr. Cherniak.
A taxi driver who asked $5, about 16,000 karbovantsy, for a short ride in downtown Kiev, first blamed the high cost of gasoline (3,000 for a liter), and then justified himself this way: "If the Government behaves like bandits, then to survive, we have to do the same."
Mr. Kuchma, the former director of a missile factory who became Prime Minister six months ago, gets some credit for trying to stabilize the economy. But according to diplomats here, he has been undercut by Parliament, which has balked at taking even the first steps toward large-scale privatization, and continues to push the inflationary spiral upward by raising salaries, pensions and state subsidies.
Last month Mr. Kuchma appealed to Parliament to extend his powers to carry out economic changes and in particular give him control of the Central Bank and the state privatization fund. But Parliament refused his requests, thus prompting his first offer to resign.
"The crucial issue is where the economic leadership of Ukraine lies," a Western diplomat said. And the growing sense, even fear, here is that the answer will continue to be, as it has been, a muddle in which the only winners are the barons of the old Communist system who here, even more than in Russia, still dominate the political and economic leadership and who use their considerable power to protect their own interests, both personal and corporate.
"The absence of political reform has put a brake on economic reform in Ukraine," said Mr. Cherniak, who blames both the Government and Parliament for failing to set a consistent, unified economic policy, and following through on it.
 
New Demands on Bank
 This month, pressure is again building in Parliament for another round of credit flows from the Central Bank, in sums rumored to top 3 trillion karbovantsy, which would blow apart the meager attempts made so far to bring Ukraine's money supply back under control.
Although the final outcome of the political crisis is unknown, most diplomats agree that Mr. Kravchuk's standing has suffered the most. One telling indication was a recent poll, in which 56 percent of the respondents said they did not care whether the President took control of the Government.
Mr. Kravchuk, in meetings this week first with Mr. Aspin and later with Mr. Kohl, who was on his first official visit to independent Ukraine, has tried to put the best face on his position. He even reassured Mr. Aspin that a vote on ratification of the 1991 arms treaty was possible before Parliament adjourns in mid-July, a prediction that several Western diplomats here dismissed as highly unlikely under the current political circumstances.
Mr. Kravchuk has come under increasing attack from nationalists in Parliament -- who this week went into official opposition against the Government -- for his foreign policy generally, but in particular for his handling of relations with Russia, which many Ukrainians distrust. The issue of the Black Sea Fleet, which was put under joint Ukrainian-Russian command last year, erupted again last month, after dozens of supply ships raised the St. Andrew's flag, emblem of the Russian Navy.
"It was a political provocation by Russia, and our President did nothing about it," said Ihor Derkach, a 29-year-old member of Parliament from western Ukraine who belongs to a nationalist fraction.
 
Negotiations Stall
 Negotiations over the division of the Black Sea Fleet have stalled, and a planned meeting this month between Mr. Kravchuk and President Boris N. Yeltsin appears to have been postponed. Mr. Kuchma recently suggested that Ukraine would be ready to lease some of the fleet's land installations, the latest obstacle in the negotiations, but diplomats here say the crucial question, still unresolved, is how much and for how long.
For Ukraine, the arguments over the future of the Black Sea Fleet are just a warm-up for the issue of the Crimea itself, a peninsula that became part of the Soviet Ukrainian Republic in 1954, but that in the minds of many Russians, including top officials, is still bound to Russia culturally and historically. From this painful issue flows doubts, shared by many Ukrainians, about whether Moscow has truly reconciled itself to the idea of an independent Ukraine.
This uncertainty, backed up by a legacy of centuries of Russian rule, is considered to be the key to the Ukrainian Parliament's doubts about the wisdom of handing over to Russia strategic nuclear weapons that it inherited after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Ukraine is now the only one of the four former former Soviet republics holding nuclear weapons that is yet to ratify the 1991 treaty, which called for a substantial reduction of weapons by both the Soviet Union and the United States. Ukraine became a party to the treaty in July 1992, when Mr. Kravchuk joined the heads of the other former Soviet republics in signing the Lisbon protocols. In Lisbon, Ukraine also committed itself to signing the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons "in the shortest possible time."
 
Anxieties in West
 But since then, Ukraine has persistently delayed a vote on both treaties, causing new anxieties in the West. While important members of the Government have remained firmly committed to Ukraine's earlier pledges, Mr. Kuchma, in a recent closed session of Parliament in which he spoke as a deputy rather than Prime Minister, said he would support a policy by which Ukraine remained an interim nuclear power. Other deputies in Parliament have been pressing for greater security commitments from the West, as well as more compensation.
A key issue in the debate, often overlooked in the West, is Ukraine's insistence on its ownership of the missiles -- a position that has not been recognized by Russia. At stake, besides national pride, is the distribution of profits made from Russia's planned sale of the reusable nuclear materials extracted from nuclear warheads.
"We say that these missiles are the property of Ukraine, and without a resolution of this issue, nothing can move forward," said Mr. Derkach, one of a number of members of Parliament who want Ukraine to remain a nuclear nation temporarily, until the dismantled missiles are removed from its territory.
A recent proposal, advanced by Mr. Aspin, for an international commission that would keep the dismantled weapons under its control, pending their elimination, might successfully "muddle" the ownership issue, as a Western diplomat here put it, although the Ukrainian side has not yet had time either to review or endorse the position.

HEADLINE: Energy Tax Quest: Levy That Draws Least Outcry

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
As it seeks to find a replacement for the Administration's B.T.U. tax, the Senate is struggling to choose the least ugly of several alternatives.
It has quickly discovered that every option has somebody ready to loathe it. 
 Westerners who drive a lot hate the idea of a gasoline tax.
Truck drivers and struggling airlines have dragged out the heavy artillery to shoot down the leading proposal, a broad transportation tax on gasoline, diesel fuel and airline fuel.
Environmentalists dread another idea -- a sales tax on energy -- because coal, which is dirty, is also cheap. They want a tax that penalizes coal rather than favors it. Besides, senators from the Northeast dislike an energy sales tax because it would hit their region disproportionately since its electricity and energy prices are among the highest in the nation.
 
Looking For Right Tax
 As so often happens in Congress, the selection process appears to be boiling down to the tax that has the fewest, weakest, least vocal opponents.
But this time there are two other factors complicating the muddle, with environmentalists looking for the tax that will help the environment most, and economists looking for the tax that will hurt the economy least.
On that last point, there seems to be wide agreement.
After cutting through all the lobbyists' talk about how such-and-such energy tax will send such-and-such industry back to the Jurassic Age, economists say that a gasoline tax or transportation tax would do less overall damage to the economy than the B.T.U. tax that the Administration trumpeted, and then withdrew.
The reason is that while the B.T.U. tax and the gasoline tax would each hurt consumers by raising the price of gasoline, the B.T.U. tax would hurt many industries -- and would hurt them in international competition. The B.T.U. tax would be levied on nonrenewable energy sources and be based on the heat content of different fuels as measured in British thermal units.
"A straight gasoline tax has a much smaller impact on the nation's manufacturing sector," said Philip Verleger, an energy economist at the Institute for International Economics. "But with a B.T.U. tax, there would be substantial job losses in the energy-intensive sector."
Environmentalists, on the other hand, are unhappy that the B.T.U. tax has been set aside. They like it because it would help shift consumption away from dirty fuels and toward cleaner ones, like natural gas.
"If you compare the environmental benefits per dollar, a gasoline tax is just half as effective as a B.T.U. tax," said Daniel A. Lashof, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council. "The B.T.U. tax creates an incentive to switch from coal to natural gas."
The energy tax that environmentalists really love -- a carbon tax, based on the amount of carbon dioxide produced by burning each unit of fuel -- is not even being considered by the Senate. The reason: it would hit coal country hardest, and Robert C. Byrd, the powerful Democratic Senator from West Virginia, would not want that.
The Administration's B.T.U. tax died of 1,000 pinpricks after the National Association of Manufacturers, American Petroleum Institute, American Chamber of Commerce and dozens of other lobbying groups organized to kill it. Because there was so much unhappiness that the tax would hurt manufacturers, several senators concluded that an energy tax that fell mostly on consumers would have a better chance of passage.
Thus, Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, is pushing a transportation tax on airline fuel, diesel fuel and gasoline. Under one version, it would raise the price of gasoline by 7.6 cents a gallon, about the same amount as the Administration's B.T.U. tax. When fully phased in, the B.T.U. tax would raise more than $20 billion a year, while Mr. Breaux's transportation tax would raise less than half that.
Speaking about a 7.6 cent tax on gasoline, William Durbin, associate director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, said: "A tax that size will only have a marginal impact on the economy. We often see fluctuations of eight-nine cents in the price of gasoline. An increase of eight or nine cents means nothing. In some European countries, the gasoline tax is over $4 a gallon."
 
Opposing Gasoline Tax
 Nonetheless, Senator Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, opposes a gasoline tax, saying it would unfairly penalize Montanans who have to drive long distances. According to Resources for the Future, an environmental group, Mr. Breaux's gasoline tax would cost households in the Southwest and Rocky Mountain states about $100 a year, while costing Middle Atlantic households $75 a year.
"There are a lot of suburbanites on the East Coast who drive long distance to work, and they would probably face the same burden as people in Western states," Mr. Durbin said.
The Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee met for several hours today as senators took potshots at competing energy plans. They broke for the weekend still divided over what shape the energy tax should take and where spending cuts could be found. The chairman, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, said he expected a consensus could be reached when the Democratic senators reconvene on Tuesday.
For the committee to approve a bill, the Democrats must stick together. They have a majority of only 11 to 9, and all the Republicans have vowed to vote against the legislation.
Some form of tax on transportation fuels and spending cuts in Medicare still seem likely to be approved. Senators John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan said they could not support cuts in Medicare much deeper than the $50 billion over five years that the Clinton Administration has proposed.
One advantage of Mr. Breaux's proposed tax over a B.T.U. tax is that it would be far cheaper to administer. All it would take would be to increase existing fuel taxes, while administrating the B.T.U. tax would require a huge new apparatus, which some economists say could cost $10 billion a year.
Convinced that a gasoline tax would be unfair to rural states, the Administration ruled out such a tax early. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen favored a sales tax, which would be inexpensive to administer. But Vice President Al Gore persuaded the Administration to put forward the B.T.U. tax because it would be better for the environment.
Some economists favor combining a gasoline tax, which favors the densely populated East, where mass transit is more common, with a straight sales tax on energy, which would favor the West, where energy prices are cheaper. The Northwest would benefit disproportionately from a straight sales tax because hydroelectricty gives the region low-cost power.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Producer price inflation was flat in May and retail sales posted a weaker-than-expected rise. The data indicated continued slow economic growth and provided evidence that inflation jumps in April did not represent a worrisome price surge that could cause the Fed to raise interest rates. [Page 35.]
Cable television customers will have to wait a few more months for Government-imposed price reductions because the F.C.C. is short of money to handle an expected avalanche of paperwork caused by complicated new regulations. [35.]
Replacing the Administration's now-abandoned B.T.U. tax is boiling down to a process of finding a tax that has the fewest, weakest and least vocal opponents. [10.]
 
 Companies
The New York Times's purchase of The Boston Globe combines the interests of two newspaper families -- the Sulzbergers and the Taylors -- and continues a broad industry shift in which papers like The Globe, free-standing for 121 years, become subsidiaries of big media companies from somewhere else. [35.]
The Times took its biggest step yet in a 20-year effort to move beyond dependence on metropolitan New York and its flagship newspaper. [47.] Some Bostonians expressed the feeling that a big-city rival had muscled into their town. [47.]
The future of Colt's Manufacturing, the venerable gun maker, was clouded when the Connecticut Legislature banned sales of its best-selling rifle -- blaming it and other military-style semiautomatic weapons for a rise in drug-related urban violence. [1.]
Northwest's two largest unions scuttled a proposed agreement to exchange a stake in the airline for wage and benefit cuts. [37.]
Choice Hotels bought 163 European hotels for an undisclosed sum from Inovest, one of France's largest budget hotels. [37.]
General Motors said it would close or sell some parts-making units unless it gains concessions on wages. [37.]
Merck agreed to sell its Calgon Water Management business to English China Clays for $307.5 million in cash. [37.]
R. H. Macy's sales and cash flow rose in its fiscal third quarter, further evidence of its slowly reversing fortunes. [37.]
 
International
American and Japanese officials began discussions on a new framework for bilateral economic relations. But, as expected, they did not reach an agreement. [35.]
 
Markets
Bond prices jumped and interest rates fell on indications that inflation eased in May. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 6.80 percent, its lowest in more than a month. [35.]
Stocks advanced modestly, helped by a sense of relief that inflation had eased. The Dow industrials gained 13.29 points. [36.]
The dollar held its ground despite signs of eased American inflation, which hurt chances for higher interest rates. [46.]
Oil and gold prices declined as a key index of commodity prices dropped to its lowest level in more than three months. [46.]
 
Your Money
The explosive growth of initial public stock offerings has drawn many investors, some of whom have been disappointed. [33.]
Low- and no-load mutual funds are trying to attract larger investors with pampering more common at financial planners. [33.]
New tax breaks for people who buy cars that run on alternative energy sources are especially generous for electric cars. [34.]
Student loans will be cheaper, beginning with the 1994-95 academic year, under a bill approved by a Senate committee. [34.]
