HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 13.29, But Is Off 40.13 in Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Helped by a sense of relief that inflation had eased, stocks advanced modestly yesterday, but gains were restrained.
The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 13.29 points, closing at 3,505.01. For the week, however, the Dow lost 40.13 points. 
 The Government's report that producer price inflation was level in May produced a burst of early buying, which took the Dow up as much as 23.25 points. But investors later shifted their focus to other economic issues and lower corporate earnings, which analysts said held the market back from making any significant gains.
"The market focus is now on secondary growth stocks. And cyclical issues, which have outperformed the market in the first half of the year, are fading as they have the last three years," said Edward P. Nicoski, managing director for technical research at Piper Jaffray Inc.
 
Other Indexes Up
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 256.8 million shares, up from 232.6 million on Thursday, with gaining issues outpacing losers by a ratio of 5 to 4. The Big Board composite index was up 0.71 point, to 246.24, while the Standard & Poor's Index of 500 stocks gained 1.88 points, to 447.26.
The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks gained 5.14 points, to 693.19, while the American Stock Exchange composite declined by 1.48 points, to 434.32.
Traders said the fact that May producer price inflation was below expectations indicated that the jump of six-tenths of a percent in April was a fluke. They also pointed to May retail sales data released yesterday showing a gain of one-tenth of a percent, well below forecasts of an increase of as much as seven-tenths of a percent.
Taken together, the traders said, the two reports of continued slow economic growth suggested that the Federal Reserve was now no longer under pressure to raise short-term interest rates, which helped both stocks and bonds yesterday.
Investor attention now shifts to a second monthly inflation number, the May Consumer Price Index, which is due on Tuesday.
 
Bank Stocks Gain
 Bank stocks were among the issues that benefited from the low producer prices and the calming effect on fears of higher interest rates. J. P. Morgan was up 5/8, to 65 3/8; BankAmerica up 1 1/2, to 43 7/8; Citicorp up 3/8, to 27 1/2, and Federal National Mortgage Association, up 1 3/4, to 79.
Technology stocks, battered during the week, also saw some rebound as investors sought bargains. Intel was up 1 7/8, to 56 1/2, and Hewlett-Packard gained 1 1/2, to 86 1/4.
The New York Times Company fell 2 1/2, to 24 3/8, after announcing on Thursday that it was acquiring Affiliated Publications, the parent company of The Boston Globe, for $1.1 billion. Affiliated gained 3/8, to 13 5/8.
Merck rose 1, to 38 5/8, after announcing an agreement to sell its Calgon Water Management business for $307.5 million in cash.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 7.63 points, or just 0.04 percent, to close the week at 20,500.95.

HEADLINE: Bonds Rally on Good News on Prices

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
There was a sigh of relief from bond traders and investors yesterday after the Government's report that the Producer Price Index was unchanged in May.
After last week's report of a surprisingly strong jump in employment in May and with consumer prices rising so far this year at a 4.3 percent annual rate, another large jump in this key inflation indicator would have sent Treasury prices reeling and yields higher. 
 Traders and investors would have sold on fears that rising inflation would erode their fixed-income investments. And signs of sharply rising prices would probably have forced the Federal Reserve to move quickly to raise short-term interest rates to control inflation.
But that is not what happened. Instead, prices jumped sharply immediately after the report at 8:30 A.M. and then continued inching higher all day.
The credit market rally was aided immediately by the report that retail sales in May were much weaker than expected, rising only one-tenth of a percent, rather than closer to a full 1 percent. If the economy is weak, there is less chance there will be upward pressure on prices, so the two reports were quite positive for a worried market.
The price of the 30-year bond, which can be heavily influenced by inflation concerns, was up 27/32 as the yield dropped to 6.80 percent, its lowest level in more than a month, from 6.87 percent on Thursday.
The impact of the good inflation news was even stronger on shorter-term Treasury securities, where yields dropped by as much as 16 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
This was a response to the relief that the Federal Reserve would not be expected, based on May's Producer Price Index, to raise short-term interest rates immediately.
The price of the two-year Treasury note rose 9/32 and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 4.12 percent, down from 4.28 percent Thursday. The price of the three-year note was up 12/32 and the yield was down to 4.49 percent from 4.63 percent the day before.
The discount rates on Treasury bills also fell sharply as the expectation of a Fed tightening of interest rates faded for the time being. The rate on the six-month bill was 3.17 percent, down seven basis points.
The market's apprehension will not be fully over until the Consumer Price Index report on Tuesday. While forecasters expect it to increase only a moderate two-tenths of a percent, until that is confirmed this bout with inflation fears cannot be said to be over. A much higher increase would surely jolt the market.
"This certainly was welcome news today, " said James S. Fralick, principal senior economist at Morgan Stanley. "It should keep the Fed on hold for a month or two. And next month's C.P.I. could also be moderate.
John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said that "the initial strength of the market's response was a bit surprising." He said that performance of the Producer Price Index in May was only slightly better than market expectations.
 
Revisions Are Noted
 In addition, he said that although the retail price data for May were weak, the upward revisions in the April data were very large and indicate that it is "adventurous" to depend on data that can be revised so sharply. For example, sales excluding automobiles were revised to a gain of 1.4 percent from the initially reported increase of seven-tenths of a percent.
Both Mr. Lipsky and Mr. Fralick said that the positive data, even if it is borne out in the consumer price report, does not mean that the threat of a Fed tightening is over. It just means that it is put off for now. They both expect that inflation will still be higher this year than last year's 2.9 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index and higher than the 2.5 percent to 2.75 percent Fed forecast for 1993.
While the rise in short-term interest rates in the last few weeks indicated that there was a fear that the Fed might act soon, analysts generally thought that the inflation data for May would not be as bad as those for the first four months of the year and, therefore, the Fed would not be forced to act so soon. The general expectation is that the Fed will have to move sometime this fall.
The rally yesterday was helped along in the afternoon by declines in other inflation barometers that traders watch closely. Gold, whose recent price rise had increased some investors fears of inflation, fell $3.50, to $367.50 an ounce.
The price of oil also dropped in the wake of OPEC's failure to get a firm agreement on limiting its production after Kuwait said it would not agree to the limits. The price of a barrel of oil fell 30 cents, to $18.98, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Common Traditions and Visions for 2 Big Papers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
The marriage of The New York Times and The Boston Globe began with a phone call last fall from Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, a descendant of a man who stabilized an ailing newspaper in New York, to William O. Taylor, a descendant of a man who kept one afloat in Boston.
In a way, both men said yesterday, it was their similarities and the similar traditions of the newspapers they have run for much of their adult lives that brought them -- and their companies -- together. 
 "We go back a long way," Mr. Sulzberger said, seated next to Mr. Taylor in a hotel suite in New York. "My father and Bill's father. My grandfather and Bill's grandfather."
 
 
The Talk of 2 Cities
 On the day after the announcement of the biggest American newspaper merger ever, there was talk among Sulzbergers and Taylors, on Wall Street, in newsrooms across the country, and on the streets of Boston and New York, about times changing. "It's been a hell of a run and it'll be a hell of a run," Mr. Taylor said.
But, of course, the point of the day was to declare that the "run" will be a different one from now on, with The Times's parent company becoming an even bigger public company. And The Globe, free-standing for 121 years, will become, like a lot of other newspapers, a subsidiary of a big company from somewhere else.
In all of the places where the $1.1 billion deal was being studied, questions were raised that went to the heart of the modern newspaper business: Will the industry's once-high profit margins return? Does conglomerate ownership of news-gathering businesses hurt the news? Is the newspaper business still the future?
Again and again, in meetings with securities analysts and in news conferences in Boston and New York, Mr. Taylor, Mr. Sulzberger and their executives worked to convince the skeptics. Why, Times executives were asked again and again, would the company make such a huge investment in a newspaper market so much like New York or, for that matter, in a newspaper at all?
"It is a true diversification," the president of the Times Company, Lance R. Primis, answered. The economies of Boston and New York, he said, are different. As a strong regional newspaper, The Globe, which is much more dominant in Boston than The Times is in New York, is a different type of paper than any the company has owned before, he said.
And Mr. Primis said there were possibilities for joint distribution, advertising sales and new newspaper ventures like efforts to use the huge amounts of data they collect in new commercial ways.
For the moment, the stock market did not appear convinced. Class A shares of the Times Company fell $2.50 each to close at $24.375 on the American Stock Exchange. Declines in the stock prices of acquiring companies are common immediately after a merger is announced.
Shares of Affiliated Publications Inc., the parent of The Globe, rose 37.5 cents each, to $13.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Securities analysts who follow media companies were divided about the wisdom of the deal for Affiliated, with some declaring it a bargain for the Times Company and some saying the price is too high. In addition to The Globe, Affiliated owns a one-third interest in BPI Communications, a magazine publishing company; the other two-thirds is owned by BPI's managers and a venture capital firm.
In the middle ground on The Times Company's deal were analysts like John Morton of Lynch, Jones & Ryan, who said he thought Times Company shares declined because the company had paid a "fat" price. He said that according to his estimates, the Times' Company's merger with Affiliated would dilute The Times' earnings by 10 to 15 cents a share on an annual basis. Before the announcement of the merger, some analysts had predicted per share earnings for the Times Company of 85 to 90 cents a share.
Because the Times Company is expected to pay for Affiliated largely by issuing millions of new shares of stock, some dilution of the amount of earnings per share had been expected. But some analysts said the terms of the deal, as it was announced on Thursday, resulted in greater dilution of the expected earnings for each share than they had predicted.
 
 
One of a Kind
 But Mr. Morton said he thought the deal was basically a good one in financial terms, because The Globe's operation is well run and newspapers are still a good business. "Long range," Mr. Morton said, "there aren't newspapers like this for sale -- and won't be -- because newspapers like this are already owned."
Times Company executives said yesterday that were not troubled by the decline in the stock price, predicting that it would begin to climb once the full terms of the merger were understood by financial analysts. The point is important because a provision of the deal would permit Affiliated to back out if the Times Company stock dropped to $22, on average, for 10 trading days just before completion of the merger, which is expected around Oct. 1.
The Times Company can back out of the deal if the price of its stock rises to more than $35 a share in that same 10-day trading period.
There is also a "lockup" provision of the merger agreement, meant to discourage other suitors. Affiliated has two classes of stock. A vote of two-thirds of each class is required to approve the merger. As part of its negotiations, The Times obtained agreements from 58 percent of the holders of Affiliated's class B stock that they will vote for the merger.
Each of Affiliated's class A shares entitles the holder to one vote, and each B share entitles the holder to 10 votes.
Separately, the Times Company was also granted an option to buy Affiliated's class A stock, up to a total of 19.9 percent of the outstanding shares, if it is unable to complete the merger and there is another bidder. The exercise of the option would make it very expensive for a competing bidder to purchase The Globe.
 
 
Concern Over Concentration
 In most of the places where the deal was being discussed yesterday, such technicalities were beside the point, since the merger seemed all but complete.
There were those who worried, as there are with every acquisition of a giant media company, about the concentration of so much communications power under one corporate roof.
There were those who said the Times Company's promises of independence for The Globe were fine, but still expressed concern about the prospect of a New York company owning New England's most influential newspaper.
But perhaps the most common response yesterday was that the deal was just another sign of changes in the country's information businesses.
"Concentration of ownership of media companies is a fact of our times," said Reese Cleghorn, dean of the University of Maryland's College of Journalism. "It isn't particularly desirable. But it's inevitable."
Sitting next to each other yesterday, Mr. Sulzberger, 67, and Mr. Taylor, 60, seemed determined to serve as a bridge between the newspapers they inherited and the ones they will leave behind.
Mr. Sulzberger's son, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., is now the publisher of The New York Times. On Monday, one of Mr. Taylor's sons will begin work at The Globe. One of Mr. Taylor's cousin's, Benjamin B. Taylor, 46, is the president of Affiliated.
Both of the older men confessed yesterday to a bit of feeling about their deal and the way it showed how big and corporate their business has become. "Nostalgia" was how Mr. Taylor, a man of few words, expressed it.
Mr. Sulzberger described his call back in November to ask Mr. Taylor whether he would consider a sale to The Times. "I called Bill up and said, 'Should we talk about whether there's some sweet music we can play together?' "
It was the way business used to be done.
 
And Then, the Details
 Both men said that matters got more complicated after that, as lawyers and financial advisers began to negotiate stock options, lockup agreements and the like.
"As it gets bigger, it gets more complicated," Mr. Sulzberger said, looking over at his chief financial officer, David L. Gorham. "And David makes me fill out all those forms that my grandfather would never have done. But it's still a family business -- we're not going to let that get away from us."
Turning to look at Mr. Taylor, Mr. Sulzberger added: "It's a family business. And this is going to be a new member of the family."

HEADLINE: Bronx Hears a Slur and Responds With Its Cheer

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
New Hampshire's State Parks and Recreation Director was only trying to explain why he wanted to scrap some old playground equipment. The reason he gave: The state parks were starting to look like the Bronx.
Apparently, he picked on the wrong borough. The Bronx, after all, known as "the borough of parks and universities," is a place that, statistically speaking, is 25 percent park. It has the city's largest park: Pelham Bay, which, at 2,764 acres, is bigger than three Central Parks. It also has Van Cortlandt Park, the city's third largest, which, at 1,164 acres, is roughly 1-60th the size of all the parks in New Hampshire. 
 New Hampshire has Wilbur LaPage, the State Parks and Recreation Director. On Wednesday, discussing plans to remove old jungle gyms and swing sets from state parks, he said he was taking aim at "that galvanized type of equipment you expect to find in some city park in the Bronx."
 
Sounds Like a Stereotype
 Several hundred miles away, in neighborhoods that have been home to everyone from Babe Ruth to Arturo Toscanini, it sounded as if he were taking aim at the Bronx. Some even said it sounded like an all-stops-out stereotype: violent, drug infested, burned out, graffiti splattered and abandoned.
"He's just a bureaucrat trying to wax dramatic," declared the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer. "If his intent was to compare his parks with Bronx parks, his suffer by comparison."
New York City's Parks Commissioner, Betsy Gotbaum, said she was furious.
"I question the manhood of someone who would stand up there in New Hampshire and take the name of the Bronx in vain," said Ms. Gotbaum, who has been involved in setting up a nonprofit fund-raising organization, Friends of Van Cortlandt Park, to raise money for projects the park needs that the city cannot afford. "It's a cheap slight without him knowing what he's taking a swipe at."
Was he taking a swipe at the Bronx? Mr. LaPage's boss, the Commissioner of the Department of Resources and Economic Development, said no. (Mr. LaPage himself was said to be unreachable yesterday because he was attending an out-of-town dedication ceremony.)
"It wasn't intended to be derogatory," said the Commissioner, Stephen K. Rice. "The reason he used the Bronx was to draw a contrast between an urban park and a rural park setting. He could just as easily have used Boston and East Manchester, N.H."
But Arnold Getzner, a hot dog vendor in Portsmouth, N.H., said Mr. LaPage was on target in making a target of the Bronx. Mr. Getzner said he had been to New York and "wouldn't go in a park there if my life depended on it."
Neither would George Tyler, a supermarket produce manager in Newmarket, N.H. "If our guy LaPage says those places are no good," Mr. Tyler said, "he's probably right."
Wrong, countered Daly Jimenez, as her 7-year-old nephew whizzed down the sun-baked slide in Pelham Bay Park yesterday. "Our parks aren't bad," she said. "They're clean; the equipment's nice. The Bronx's image is bad, but it has beautiful parks."
This being New York, where unanimity is something of an abstract concept, not everyone sees it that way. Some Bronx residents say their parks are shaggier than they used to be, that there are more bald spots in the infields. Some even complain that when the city cuts the budget and lays off park workers, they don't start in Central Park in Manhattan.
Nora Nees, a baby sitter in Williamsbridge, said she had stopped taking the 14-month-old boy she looks after during the day to a local park known as Williamsbridge Oval.
"There's broken glass and dogs without leashes," she said. "From time to time you see the police, but that doesn't seem to make a lot of difference."
And there are a lot of wide open spaces in the big parks in the Bronx. You can find yourself alone in the middle of nowhere -- have the whole of a valley to yourself in the vastness of Van Cortlandt -- and remember that you're all alone out there, which adds a bit of anxiety to the pleasure.
"I've never been to New Hampshire, but I can't picture anything worse than the Bronx," said Stan Martucci Jr., behind the counter of Stan's Sports World, opposite Yankee Stadium. "I plan on moving out. Down south. New York's turning into a disaster area. Some kind of bad news breaking every day."
James R. Ryan, the Parks Department's Borough Commissioner for the Bronx, says his domain gets a bad rap. He offered to give Mr. LaPage a guided tour. After all, he said, 65 percent of the parks he oversees have been renovated in the last five to seven years.
"Anybody who would say this," he said, "does not know the Bronx. It's really a great place."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Co.'s Strategy: Dominate Northeast

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
With its $1.1 billion purchase of The Boston Globe, The New York Times Company is taking the biggest step in its 20-year effort to move beyond metropolitan New York and its flagship newspaper, further hedging its financial future.
The Globe purchase certainly advances that goal, analysts and consultants agree. But the question raised by the purchase, they say, is whether it is smart to make a huge bet on the Northeast, a region whose economic outlook is uncertain, and on the newspaper business, an industry often regarded as mature. 
 Times Company executives reply that the timing is right to take a big stake in the Boston market, which is starting to recover, and that a dominant regional newspaper like The Globe will remain a lucrative business for the foreseeable future.
 
 
'Buying a Market'
 "The truth is that we're buying a market," explained Lance R. Primis, the Times Company's president and chief operating officer. "We think that Boston is going to have a hell of a run again. And buying The Globe is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for us to be dominant both in Boston and in the Northeast generally."
Moreover, Mr. Primis noted, the Times Company has a tradition of investing against the grain of economic downturns in the New York economy. For example, the family-controlled company's diversification drive began in the 1970's, when the local economy was so weak that the New York City government narrowly avoided bankruptcy. Another motivation for moving outside New York was to make the company less susceptible to prolonged strikes by union workers.
Under the direction of Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the chairman of the Times Company and former publisher of The New York Times, the company went ahead with investments in new properties during the 70's, even though business was soft.
"By acquiring The Globe," Mr. Primis said, "we're repeating that strategy in the 90's."
 
 
'Very Powerful Position'
 Most analysts say that purchasing the parent company of The Globe, Affiliated Publications Inc., should prove to be a solid move for the Times Company in the long term. "It gives The Times control of much of the Northeast market, and that's a very powerful position to be in," said Craig Cline, a vice president at Seybold Inc., a consultant in Malibu, Calif.
But analysts point out that the payoff for Times Company shareholders will not be for a while. Because the acquisition is being paid for mainly by issuing millions of new Times Company shares, the per-share earnings of the combined company will be less than analysts had expected for the Times Company alone for the next couple of years. A company's share price is largely determined by the level of expected profits.
Consequently, the price of Times Company class A stock fell sharply yesterday, down $2.50 a share, to $24.375.
Kevin Gruneich, an analyst for the First Boston Corporation, estimated that earnings for the combined company would reach about $96 million this year, and rise perhaps 25 percent, to $120 million, in 1994. "But in the short term, I expect more pressure on The Times's share price," Mr. Gruneich said. "If you're in this, it's for the long term."
 
 
Patient Pursuit
 For the most part, the Times Company's diversification effort has been a patient pursuit, but one that has proved effective. At the start of the 1970's, The New York Times was virtually the company's only business. But that changed gradually in the 70's and the pace picked up during the heady years of the early and mid-80's, when the boom on Wall Street buoyed the New York economy and The Times's ad revenues. The Times Company's operating profits, before taxes, rose steadily from $83 million in 1982 to $284 million in 1987, the peak year, when the stock market crashed in October.
From 1979 to 1987, the Times Company spent about $1 billion to acquire newspapers, magazines and broadcast properties. "We rode those boom years and put the cash into diversification," said David L. Gorham, the company's senior vice president and chief financial officer.
The Times Company does not report the contribution of its individual businesses. But analysts say that by the early 80's, The Times represented about two-thirds of the company's business, a share that remained fairly steady until 1987 because, despite the string of acquisitions, The Times also grew rapidly. Today, The Times represents about half of the company's $1.77 billion in revenues. Once The Globe is folded in, The Times's share will be down to 40 percent or so.
The Times itself has moved well beyond its New York and Northeast base. The paper's national edition, begun in 1980, currently has a daily circulation of 270,000, and 340,000 on Sunday. The national edition represents a growing slice of The Times total circulation, 1,230,461 daily and 1,812,458 on Sunday.
The Times Company's first important diversification move came in 1971, when it acquired Cowles Communications Inc. for shares valued at roughly $70 million. The Cowles merger brought Family Circle magazine; a Memphis television station, WREG-TV, and three Florida daily newspapers, The Ledger in Lakeland, The Gainesville Sun and The Ocala Star-Banner.
The Cowles move set the direction for further diversification by the Times Company, building on that foundation in three key businesses: magazines, broadcasting and regional newspapers, mainly in the Southeast.
Today, in addition to The Times, the company publishes 31 regional newspapers. Analysts agree that the company has done an excellent job lifting quality and profits at most of the papers it has acquired. As a business model, the Times Company has followed the strategy of many newspaper chains, purchasing papers in smaller markets that virtually control the local newspaper advertising market.
Typically, the regional papers in the Times fold will be read by more than 50 percent of the households in their circulation area. By contrast, The Times reaches 14 percent of the households in its area on Monday through Saturday, while The Globe reaches about 25 percent.
 
 
Serious Misstep
 But the newspaper-buying spree included one serious misstep. In 1987, the company acquired The Gwinnett Daily News in a suburban area outside Atlanta that seemed poised for growth. It was, but it was also within the circulation area of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution.
Under the Times Company's wing, The Gwinnett Daily News nearly doubled its circulation, to about 50,000 by 1992. But The Journal and Constitution offered a special regional edition, cut its cover price and offered deeply discounted advertising deals.
The Times Company closed down The Gwinnett Daily News last year, and took a $53.8 million charge against earnings. "We went in and took on a major newspaper in part of its home turf," Mr. Primis explained. "We won't get in that situation again."
The company's 20 magazines, led by McCall's, Family Circle, Golf Digest, and Tennis, contributed revenues of $386 million last year. The most recent big purchase was in 1989, when the Times Company acquired McCall's for a reported $80 million. "It doesn't get much notice, but the Times Company has become a major consumer magazine publisher," said Martin S. Walker, chairman of Walker Communications, a publishing consultant.
In 1984, after years of running a small but respected book business, the Times Company sold Times Books to Random House Inc. for an undisclosed sum. At the time, company executives explained that the Times Company was getting out of book publishing mainly because it consumed too much management time and energy for a small unit that was outside its core businesses.
In 1989, the company sold its cable television business, NYT Cable TV, which it had acquired eight years earlier. The system served 162,000 subscribers in southern New Jersey; the Times Company sold it for $420 million in cash, making a handsome profit.
 
 
'Providers of Information'
 "We've decided we want to be the providers of information, not the transporters of information," Mr. Primis said in explaining that sale.
And it is as information suppliers that Mr. Primis and other Times Company executives remain confident about the newspaper business, a confidence that is behind their enthusiasm for buying The Globe.
Some combination of computer, television and telephone technology may well make inroads in how the information traditionally gathered and presented by newspapers is distributed, they say, but that information-supplying role will remain a valuable business.
Industry consultants tend to agree. "There are challenges, but that does not mean newspapers are dinosaurs," said Mark Stahlman, president of New Media Associates Inc. in New York. "If it is well managed, a big newspaper company like the Times should be in a good position to make the transition."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Japan Open Talks On New Trade Framework

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
American and Japanese officials began discussions today on a new framework for bilateral economic relations but, as expected, they did not reach an agreement, the officials said.
"The meeting was primarily an opportunity for a mutual exchange of views on economic issues," said Bowman Cutter, the deputy assistant to the President for economic affairs. "It was a useful meeting -- it was not intended to arrive at an agreement and it did not." 
 Mr. Cutter said that he and five other senior American officials would discuss the framework further in Tokyo on June 27 and 28. More talks will be held on Saturday but they will be restricted to noneconomic issues like the environment, Mr. Cutter said.
A Japanese official who insisted on anonymity also characterized the meeting as useful. He said that there had been a few differences, but that the overall tone was cordial. He echoed the confidence of American officials that a new framework for further negotiations could be put together in the next month.
The American negotiators raised concerns about the openness of Japan's market for cars and car parts, but most of the talks today were about broad issues such as how to organize the new agenda for bilateral trade relations.
The Japanese official mentioned that his Government perceived "problems" in access to the United States market and in past efforts by the Federal Government to improve the competitiveness of American industry. But the official refused to elaborate. Japanese officials in the past have urged Washington to do everything from reducing the Federal deficit to improving the quality of American schools, while criticizing unilateral American moves to restrict Japanese products ranging from factory tools to electric typewriters.
The White House plan presented today to Japanese officials is not intended to resolve any of the bilateral trade issues now pending. American officials tried instead to persuade the Japanese to consent to a new agenda -- or "framework" that would guide talks on specific issues.
 
Two Goals in U.S. Plan
 The American plan calls for an agreement on two overarching economic goals, together with the creation of five new categories for detailed talks.
The first overall goal is to reduce the Japanese trade surplus within several years to less than 2 percent of Japan's economic output, from 3.2 percent last year. The second broad goal is to increase Japanese imports of manufactured goods by a third.
The American and Japanese negotiators plan to continue talking over dinner tonight, joined by at least five business leaders and some members of Congress, but Administration officials said these talks would be less detailed.
President Clinton said today in the Rose Garden that he hoped an understanding could be reached on the framework before heads of state from the world's seven leading industrial nations gather in Tokyo on July 7.
 
Clinton Emphasizes Relationship
 President Clinton has put economic disputes with Japan at the center of what he calls the world's most important bilateral relationship. The United States and Japan "recognize that there will have to be an evolution in not only our relationship, but in the whole balance of global trade if we're going to have sustained global growth, which is what is in the interest of Japan and the United States," the President said today in the Rose Garden.
President Clinton spoke about the relationship after announcing the nomination of Walter F. Mondale to become Ambassador to Japan.
Mr. Mondale was President Carter's Vice President and ran for President in 1984. If confirmed by the Senate, he would become the fourth Vice President who has gone on to become an ambassador, and the first former Vice President dispatched as an ambassador to a non-European country, the State Department said.

HEADLINE: Worries Over Inflation Are Eased by May Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Inflation at the producer level evaporated in May, providing strong evidence, relieved economists said today, that jumps earlier in the year did not represent the start of a worrisome price surge.
The Government also reported today that retail sales in May posted a weaker-than-expected rise, an indication of continued lackluster growth in the economy. 
 The reports quickly erased fears that the Federal Reserve would act soon to raise interest rates, a move that would further slow the weak recovery by raising the cost of buying a house or a car or anything else that requires credit.
 
Markets React Positively
 The good news on the inflation front unleashed heavy buying in the bond markets that pushed interest rates down sharply. The stock market also rallied, despite the signs of continued economic sluggishness.
Prices, as gauged by what American producers receive for their finished goods, were unchanged last month after having jumped six-tenths of 1 percent in April and four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Labor Department's report showed.
The so-called core inflation rate, which does not count the erratic food and energy components, was halved from April's pace, to two-tenths of 1 percent.
Private economists hailed the inflation report, declaring that it confirmed suspicions that the early-year increases in the Producer Price Index exaggerated the danger of a surge of inflation severe enough to force the central bank to raise interest rates.
"The May P.P.I. report sharply reduces the likelihood of any Fed tightening in the months ahead," said Donald H. Straszheim of Merrill Lynch. He noted that the core producer index has risen just 1.7 percent over the last year, the slowest pace since 1967.
President Clinton's chief economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, said that while she was reassured by the latest figures, the White House had not been much worried about the earlier increases at either producer or consumer levels. Her office has been aware that in the latest three years -- and in 9 of the last 11 -- core inflation has been significantly higher during the January-April period than during the rest of the year.
This fluctuation occurs despite the adjustment of the data for normal seasonal variation, like cold weather, which would tend to raise heating oil and natural gas prices. Various analysts contend that it is deficiencies in the adjustment process that magnify inflation early in each year, though the puzzle is complicated by the fact that the elements making the biggest impact conform to no annual pattern.
 
Political Considerations
 The Clinton Administration and other Democrats have tended to play down inflation risks as they try to win passage of legislation to stimulate the economy, which has been expanding at a relatively slow pace two years after the formal end of recession. Mr. Clinton is also counting on low interest rates to offset economic drag from the tax increases and the spending cuts in his economic package.
"The inflation hawks at the Fed should lay aside their spears and stop jousting with phantom inflation," Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, head of the Senate Budget Committee, said today. "Upward price pressures are nonexistent and flat retail sales show that the economy, far from being overheated, has barely mustered any forward momentum."
The Labor Department's price figures also showed that inflation at the intermediate stage of production -- one step further removed from the consumer than finished goods -- fell two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the weakest showing since November.
Crude goods jumped 2 percent after a 1.2 percent rise in April, but this mainly reflected a 12.3 percent surge for natural gas. Apart from food and energy, the rise for crude goods slowed to four-tenths of 1 percent, from 1.8 percent in April.
The Commerce Department's report that retail sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent last month, to $170.1 billion, was below most expectations, but any disappointment was softened somewhat by an upward revision for April.
The April gain is now put at 1.5 percent instead of the 1.2 percent initially reported. March, however, was revised down slightly.
Analysts also took comfort in the fact that durable goods, accounting for 37 percent of total sales, posted a hefty advance, of eight-tenths of 1 percent. Durables -- goods meant to last at least three years -- tend to be postponable items bought with discretionary income, and analysts were encouraged that consumers still seemed willing and able to spend.
Merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes chalked up a 3.6 percent advance last month, while the gain for automotive dealers was four-tenths of 1 percent. Those selling furniture and other equipment for the home posted a decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent, a result at odds with the surge in sales of new homes previously reported for May.
Among nondurables, which declined four-tenths of 1 percent over all, general merchandise stores had a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent, while sales at stores selling apparel and accessories rose 1.5 percent and at drug and proprietary stores, five-tenths of 1 percent.
But these increases were more than offset by declines of 1.6 percent at gasoline stations, seven-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and four-tenths of 1 percent at food stores. Some of this weakness, particularly in gasoline and food, reflected lower prices rather than reduced demand.
 
Year-to-Year Comparison
 For March through May, total sales were 5.4 percent above the comparable 1992 period, adjusted for seasonal and holiday differences but not for inflation, which at the consumer level was 3.2 percent for the 12 months through April. Consumer price figures for May are to be released on Tuesday.
Among the items exerting sizable upward pressure on producer prices last month were fresh fruits and melons, beef and veal, shellfish, heating oil, tobacco products and books.
Finished goods that fell in price included automobiles, fresh and dry vegetables, pork, shortening and cooking oils, bakery products, roasted coffee and prescription drugs.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Weak Economic Data Fail To Cause Selloff in Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar held its ground against leading foreign currencies yesterday, despite reports that American wholesale prices and retail sales barely budged in May, statistics that hurt any immediate chance of higher interest rates.
The dollar, which ended mixed, apparently was buoyed by traders nervous about selling the currency during trade talks between the United States and Japan. 
 The Government reported that its Producer Price Index was unchanged in May after worrisome increases of four-tenths of 1 percent in March and six-tenths in April. A second report showed that retail sales rose an anemic one-tenth of 1 percent in May, far below expectations.
The combination sent the dollar tumbling about one and a half pfennigs against the German mark in early New York trading. But the dollar recovered later in the day, settling at 1.6260 marks in New York, only slightly lower than late Thursday's 1.6295 marks.
There has been speculation in the financial markets for weeks that May's inflation rate, if it showed a continuation of high levels established earlier this year, would prompt the Federal Reserve to tighten interest rates to help combat inflation. Higher interest rates would tend to make dollar-denominated investments more attractive to investors.
In recent days, however, expectations began to lean toward the data's showing an easing of inflation in May. David Gilmore, a currency analyst at MCM Inc., said the dollar's early plunge yesterday was more closely tied to the sluggish retail sales.
"The numbers really turn the pendulum back toward a market bearish on the economy, and I think rightfully so," he said.
Many traders, though, remained hesitant to sell dollars amid talks yesterday between United States and Japanese trade negotiators aimed at reducing the trade deficit with Japan.
In late New York trading, the dollar was at 106.15 yen, barely changed from late Thursday's 106.16 yen.
The dollar ended slightly stronger against the British pound amid mounting uncertainty about the viability of Prime Minister John Major's Government. In New York, the pound fetched $1.5225, down slightly from late Thursday's $1.5270.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Innkeeper Expands In Europe

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Choice Hotels International has added 163 European hotels to its rapidly expanding hospitality empire, bringing to more than 3,000 the number of Choice franchises in 30 countries. With its parent company, Manor Care Inc., Choice purchased the properties for an undisclosed sum from Inovest, one of France's largest operators of budget properties.
The acquisition gives Choice 144 more properties in France, plus 19 additional hotels in six other European countries, including its first hotels in Spain and Portugal. The agreement comes less than two months after Choice formed a joint venture with the Journey's End Corporation, Canada's biggest hotel management company, which owns 120 inns. 
 "It was a great opportunity because France is a target for us, and because all the properties were built in the last six years," said Gerald Petitt, president and chief operating officer of Choice. "And it brings our European properties to about 225, although we plan to more than double that within a few years."
Manor Care, based in Silver Spring, Md., is a major health-care company in the United States, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, where its stock lost 12.5 cents to close at $20.375 yesterday. Its Manor Care Hotels division owns and operates 20 hotels in the United States. Those hotels, and all those in the Choice portfolio, operate under one of seven banners: Clarion, Comfort, Econo Lodge, Friendship, Quality, Rodeway or Sleep Inns.
 
Renaming Hotels
 Manor Care revenues for the fiscal year ended May 31 are expected to be slightly more than $1 billion, with Choice contributing about $159 million.
Mr. Petitt said the Inovest hotels, most of them along the major highways in France, had been in bankruptcy courts, casualties of the country's economic downturn.
Choice will rename the 141 two-star Primevere properties Comfort Inn Primevere. Comfort is one of Choice's limited-service chains. The three existing three-star properties in France, named Saphir, will be renamed as Quality Inn Primevere and Comfort Inn Primevere.
As a result of the purchase, Choice Hotels Europe and Quality Hotels Europe will form a new Paris-based company, Manor Care Hotels (France) S.A., to oversee Primevere's hotel operations in France. But Choice's existing 14 franchised hotels in France, and future franchised properties there, will continue to be administered by Choice Hotels Europe.
Faced with dwindling opportunities for growth in the United States, Choice and other franchises are forging relationships in foreign lands with local franchise operators. In addition to its joint agreement in Canada, Choice has signed franchise agreements in recent months with partners in Singapore and Mexico, each of which will develop at least 30 hotels.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Macy Shows Gain in Sales, Cash Flow

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Offering further evidence that its fortunes are slowly reversing, R. H. Macy & Company, which is operating under bankruptcy-law protection, said yesterday that its sales and cash flow were stronger in its fiscal third quarter.
The retailer has met its plan for the last three months, and last month it announced that its expense-reduction efforts were paying off more quickly than it had anticipated. 
 Sales rose 5.8 percent in the quarter, to $1.34 billion, from $1.3 billion in the comparable period last year. Sales in stores open at least one year, which is considered a barometer of retail growth, rose 3.1 percent.
 But higher costs from closing stores and eliminating jobs resulted in a $228 million net loss in the quarter that ended May 1, compared with a $226 million loss a year earlier.
Operating losses shrank somewhat, to $54 million from $60 million, mostly because of lower overhead expenses.
Despite the negative bottom line, analysts regarded the numbers as further evidence of a positive overall trend at Macy, which operates the Macy's, I. Magnin and Bullock's department store chains as well as two specialty store chains, Aeropostale and Charter Club. "We continue to like what we see," said Jack Hersch, an analyst at M. J. Whitman L.P. who follows distressed and bankrupt companies.
 
 
Productivity Levels
 The company has been planning conservatively and trying to raise its productivity levels to offset the effects of the weak economy in most of California, as well as Long Island and Baltimore. It said sales in Texas and Florida were strong in the third quarter and less vigorous in the New York and Washington regions.
Macy's cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, was $26.5 million in the quarter, exceeding the requirements of its bank loans by about $6.5 million.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Key Commodity Index Off; Gold and Oil Drop Sharply

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
A key index of commodity prices dropped yesterday to its lowest level in more than three months as prices for oil, precious metals and some agricultural products declined. Both oil and gold prices fell sharply.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities declined 1.89 points, to 203.29. Coincidentally, the Government reported early yesterday that its Producer Price Index of wholesale prices remained flat in May. Many analysts said, however, that in the intermediate term the bureau's index was likely to rise again and even surpass the one-year high of 214.27 set in late March. 
 "It's attempting to put in a major bottom, and this always takes time," said Hans Kashyap of Analytics Research Corporation.
If this proves true, yesterday's favorable news on producer prices may be short-lived.
 
Eight-Month Lag
 William Branson, professor of economics at Princeton University, estimates that rises and falls in commodity prices precede turning points in inflation by about eight months.
Commodities analysts have said repeatedly in recent months that supply-and-demand fundamentals are improving for many commodities and that price increases are likely. Goldman, Sachs, for example, predicts an overall increase in commodities prices of about 10 percent over the next year to year and a half.
Oil prices dropped for the second consecutive day on continued disappointment over the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreement. Kuwait, which rejected the pact, softened its stance somewhat and said it would watch the market before raising oil production.
 
July Crude off 30 Cents
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for delivery in July dropped 30 cents, to $18.98 a barrel, the lowest level since January. July heating oil declined 0.16 cent, to 53.01 cents a gallon, and July unleaded gasoline fell 0.23 cent, to 54.61 cents a gallon.
Gold prices tumbled in thin trading. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded August gold contract fell $3.50, to $367.50 an ounce.
The letup in inflation at the producer level drove prices lower. Tuesday's report on consumer prices in May will be closely watched, analysts said.

HEADLINE: To Assure a Nuclear-Free Korea

 BODY:
Deft diplomacy by the Clinton Administration has coaxed North Korea back from the brink. The North had threatened to bolt from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and build nuclear arms. It will now allow routine international inspections of its nuclear sites.
Gaining access to its nuclear waste sites will require further negotiation; that could provide more evidence of how much plutonium North Korea might already have produced. But the resumption of routine inspections is a critical first step toward assuring that the Korean Peninsula is truly nuclear-free. 
 The agreement is a tribute to sensible officials in Pyongyang who chose the path to prosperity over the road to ruin. It's also a tribute to cool heads in Washington who refused to overreact to North Korea's bizarre bargaining behavior.
Pyongyang opened its nuclear reactors to inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency last year. But initial inspections turned up evidence that the reactors had been operating longer than North Korea said they had, raising fears that it could have produced enough plutonium for a bomb.
When the agency sought to clear up the discrepancy in March by visiting the North's nuclear waste sites, Pyongyang balked and threatened to renounce the Nonproliferation Treaty. Now it has agreed to "suspend" taking that rash step and allow inspections. But the North continues to resist special inspection of the waste sites as unfair and insists on "impartial" application of the Atomic Energy Agency's safeguards.
If the North carries out its commitments, that will not only help inspectors determine how much bomb-making plutonium Pyongyang amassed in its reactors but also insure that such material is properly accounted for in the future. That will reassure uneasy neighbors that the North may yet abandon its nuclear ambitions and open the way to improved diplomatic and trade ties.
Those neighbors, who had good reason to fear regional instability that would surely result from a nuclear-armed North Korea, all played a part in persuading Pyongyang to reconsider.
The new civilian Government in South Korea, wisely repudiating its predecessor's strategy of isolating the North, has made several reassuring gestures toward Pyongyang in recent months. It is ready for North-South talks to promote peaceful coexistence on the divided peninsula.
Japan, which has forsworn nuclear arms in favor of economic growth, is prepared to offer trade and aid to encourage the North to follow its lead. And China, which feared that a nuclear North Korea would trigger an arms race in the region, weighed in diplomatically as well.
Washington, which joined in needlessly provocative "Team Spirit" military exercises with South Korea while letting diplomacy lapse during the Bush-Clinton transition, now needs to pay close attention. It cannot afford to let either its vigilance or its diplomacy relax if it is to prevent proliferation on the Korean Peninsula.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: May National Service Live Up to Peace Corps

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In 1987 two professors at Mercy College in New York compared the salary history of 1,000 former Peace Corps volunteers with 1,000 Fulbright scholars. 
 What the researchers discovered would surprise Michael S. McPherson and Morton Owen Schapiro, who contend in "What Price Patriotism?" (Op-Ed, June 3) that President Clinton's national service plan is fraught with economic disincentives, on an individual and a national level.
The Peace Corps is, for good reason, often held up as the model for the new national service program; it was no coincidence that the President announced his plan on the anniversary date of the agency.
At conception, the Peace Corps, too, was criticized as idealistic and a waste of taxpayer dollars. What Richard M. Nixon failed to comprehend in 1960, Professors McPherson and Schapiro fail to see today: Americans are desirous of an opportunity to serve. It is simplistic, laughably so, to argue that the short-term benefits to one's pocketbook will drive the recruiting success of this program.
As economists, Professors McPherson and Schapiro should know it is the long-term view that matters.
In an interview with The Chicago Tribune, one of the authors of the Mercy College study said the evidence suggested that service in the Peace Corps "is better than an M.B.A., better than a diploma from an Ivy League college, may even be better than a Fulbright grant."
There followed this statement: "Former Peace Corps volunteers are consistently outperforming their fellow workers in terms of salary gains and upward career mobility."
The study showed that large percentages of former volunteers tended to choose careers in education and health services -- two of the most maligned and unappreciated, but critically needed, occupational fields in this country.
If the national service plan President Clinton proposes does indeed become a close cousin to the Peace Corps, with its graduates achieving higher salaries, and paying more taxes over a lifetime, while they are drawn to careers in critically needed areas like education and health, thousands of Americans, along with their grateful compatriots, could be in for a boon.
 
DUANE J. DEBRUYNE
Gaithersburg, Md., June 4, 1993
 
The writer was a Peace Corps volunteer in Sierra Leone, 1978-80.

HEADLINE: Raise the Cigarette Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re: "Experts Wavering on Steep Rise in Cigarette Tax" (news article, June 7): Although the costs of smoking to the American economy have been estimated at more than $100 billion a year -- more than $4 for every pack sold! -- some argue smokers shouldn't be asked to pay more through higher cigarette taxes because their early deaths save some pension and Social Security costs. 
 But the burden on nonsmokers of paying those costs through higher taxes and health insurance premiums will not be offset until 30 to 50 years from now, when today's smokers begin dying off.
No other country in the world has as low a cigarette tax burden as the United States, and many now impose far more than the proposed $2 a pack increase. All have found that higher taxes bring in much-needed revenue, even while reducing consumption -- especially among young children -- and slashing health care costs.
Cigarettes are lightly taxed in this country only because of the political clout of the industry and the reluctance of the nonsmoking majority to speak up.
 
JOHN F. BANZHAF 3D
Executive Director, Action on Smoking and Health
Washington, June 8, 1993

HEADLINE: Yonkers Outlines Barriers To Minority Housing Plan

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
In the best of circumstances, buying a cooperative requires as much coordination as juggling five balls in the air while riding a unicycle. Throw in the emotional politics and the personalities of the Yonkers desegregation case and things become even more difficult.
That became apparent in a Federal courtroom yesterday as the City of Yonkers tried to explain why in more than a year's effort to desegregate the city's housing it had yet to move a single family into a cooperative apartment. The act of lining up qualified families, fiscally stable buildings, welcoming cooperative boards, state and Federal mortgage assistance agencies, and feuding city and court officials is proving to be an extraordinary challenge. 
 In defending itself in the latest stage of a 13-year-old Federal desegregation suit, the city has been trying to persuade Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in lower Manhattan that, despite such travails, its resistance to integration is a thing of the past. The mayor for the last 18 months, Terence M. Zaleski, took the stand to testify that he and his new administration have been working doggedly since April to find housing for 709 families with incomes below $67,000 a year in middle-class, largely white areas of Yonkers.
But the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which along with the Justice Department brought the 1980 school and housing suit, contends that the effort to resolve the housing issue through existing cooperatives is largely a quixotic -- and dilatory -- one and that it would be more useful to build new housing. Under the city's current plan, only 115 of the 709 apartments are to be created through new construction, with the rest to be found in existing cooperatives or rehabilitated apartments.
 
Where Help Hindered
 Taking the witness stand for a second day yesterday, Marie Burkart, an urban planner who is Yonkers's director of community development, tried to shift much of the blame for the city's failure to house families on an agency appointed by the court to monitor the city's progress, the Fair Housing Implementation Office. She testified that the office's director, Karen V. Hill, had been expected to supply the city with names of families interested in purchasing apartments.
But of the nearly 1,000 referrals that the city received, Ms. Burkart said, hundreds of families could not be found, others were no longer interested and others had incomes too low or credit histories too shaky to qualify for mortgages, even with state and Federal subsidies. The list was eventually distilled to 60, she said, and further investigation revealed problems with many of those.
As a result of the Fair Housing office's poor referrals, she said, only four families have actually signed purchase contracts for apartments, and only two of those have received approvalfrom cooperative boards. The city, she said, is now advertising for new applicants.
Questioned by Judge Sand as to why only two applicants had received co-op board approval, she explained that there was a "Catch-22" situation in which Judge Sand himself had a part. She said the co-op boards would not approve families who had not received Government financing for closing costs and down payments, but that financing was being held up because Judge Sand wants first to decide whether the use of cooperatives is the best approach. And she said the New York State Mortgage Agency was unwilling to guarantee mortgages until subsidies were in place.
Judge Sand, a soft-spoken scholarly judge who was at one time a real-estate lawyer, wondered aloud whether the city had been putting itself through a year of unnecessary gyrations when the key factor, co-op board approval, had never been assured. He mentioned his experience with Park Avenue cooperative boards who had rejected apartment applicants for reasons of "economics or ethnicity" or reasons that he suggested amounted to pure whim.
 
Belief in Cooperation
 Ms. Burkart argued that the city had sounded out cooperative board presidents and believed it had found many interested in participating in the integration program, particularly because a weak market with a high rate of vacancies was hurting many of the co-ops. Judge Sand was not convinced, pointing out that co-op board presidents exercise only one vote on the fickle boards.
"You're making sound, rational arguments," he told Ms. Burkart. "Whereas my experience in a context not as volatile as Yonkers is that rationality is often irrelevant."
At another point, Judge Sand also fretted that the city could imperil the life savings of some families by placing them in financially shaky co-op buildings with desperate landlords.
"The consequences of purchase may be a few thousand dollars, but that may be all that they have," Judge Sand said.
If Judge Sand finds that the effort to scatter mostly black and Hispanic families through existing cooperatives is flawed in conception, he may end up supporting something closer to the N.A.A.C.P.'s proposal to rely on new construction.
That is why Michael H. Sussman, the N.A.A.C.P. lawyer, and Christopher Shaheen, a lawyer for the Justice Department, sought in their cross-examinations to show that Yonkers's once recalcitrant attitude toward integration has changed very little and that 450 adequate apartments will never be found.
 
4 Percent Cap Debated
 Mr. Sussman bore in on statements by Yonkers officials that they would place a cap of 4 percent on the number of subsidized tenants steered to any one building, suggesting that the city was still trying to hold down the number of minority families permitted to participate. He also focused on the city's decision to require approval by co-op boards of tenant purchases even when apartments were held by building landlords and did not typically require such approval.
Mayor Zaleski testified that the 4 percent figure was merely an effort to assure integration by scattering tenants around middle-class areas of Yonkers and that the figure had been recommended by the housing expert appointed by Judge Sand. And Ms. Burkart said the motive behind requiring board approval was to assure that tenants would be welcome.
Under prodding by the city's lawyer, Raymond P. Fitzpatrick Jr., Mr. Zaleski sought to show that despite years of stubborn resistance to housing integration by his predecessors and other officials, he was elected with a pledge to resolve the controversy.
"I stated again and again in public forums that the city needed to respect its constitutional obligations," he said. "I stated that we had an obligation to move the city forward."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 16, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about a housing desegregation case in Yonkers misstated the number of families that have received approval as tenants from cooperative building boards. Only one of the four qualified families needs the approval of a cooperative board, and that family has not yet received such approval.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 14; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1144 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Sic 'Em!

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
BOB DOLE'S TITLE is Senate Republican Leader. The sign over his door used to read, "Minority Leader," a tradition Senator Everett Dirksen preserved, but Senator Hugh Scott changed it in the late 1960's when he was leader because it struck him as down-putting.
The Senate Republican Leader (going against Times style, I capitalize the letter l because it is part of a title) called the other day and, before passing along a hot news tip, observed, "Those guys in the White House just don't know sic 'em." 
 I asked what he meant; Dole seemed taken aback, as if surprised to find that I didn't know sic 'em, either. "It means 'anything,' " he said. He thinks I've been inside the Beltway too long.
A quick call to DARE -- the Dictionary of American Regional English, at the University of Wisconsin in Madison -- turned up the geographic dispersion of the dialect term: a few spottings in the Midwest, explaining Kansan Dole's usage, but heaviest in the Pacific Northwest.
Question JJ156 on the DARE questionnaire, skillfully designed to elicit regionalisms, is "Sayings about a person who seems to you very stupid: 'He doesn't know ----.' " Although some would respond with a brief expletive, DARE's query drew 27 answers of Sic 'em, along with these more detailed responses: " 'Here' from sic 'em," "Sic 'em from 'come here' " and "Sic 'em from 'go get 'em.' "
When American Speech magazine queried readers about sic 'em in 1961, one observed that his mother heard it from Arkansas friends who owned hound dogs. Another reader, the great San Francisco dialexicographer Peter Tamony, replied: "The remark describes an unresponsive, indolent, shiftless person. He is like a dog that shows no courageous and instant reaction to the command 'sic 'em.' " Mr. Tamony gave an etymological insight by adding that sic 'em is "merely a pronunciation modification of seek 'em or seek 'im."
The earliest citations are from Stewart Edward White's 1907 "Arizona Nights": "You see, for all their plumb nerve in comin' so far, the most of them didn't know sic 'em. . . . I didn't know sic 'em about minin'." In Ramon Adams's 1968 "Western Words," the term is defined as "a cowboy's expression meaning 'ignorant.' I have heard many unique references to ignorance, like 'He don't know 'nough to pack guts to a bear,' 'He don't know dung from wild honey' and many others. Ted Logan referred to a man with 'His head's so hollow he's got to talk with his hands to get away from the echo.' "
The key is the unspoken from. Not to know sic 'em (sometimes spelled sickum) means not to distinguish the master's command to his dog to attack from the entirely different command "come here." (This is not a canine slur; either the master or the dog can be the stupid party. Or both can be: when I say sic 'em! to James, my Bernese mountain dog, he snarls ferociously and comes at me.)
Modern dialect users are more familiar with not knowing from beans, which probably originated in "not knowing split beans from coffee beans," or "not knowing beans from barley," "beans from bullfrogs," etc. The key from is found in "not knowing cow chips from kumquats," a fine double alliteration; indeed, alliteration is frequent in this trope of comparison, as the makers of Shinola shoe polish learned to their rue. Today, the from is usually dropped, and "He don't know beans" is all that remains.
I am indebted to Republican Leader Dole for this lead, if that's what he called about.
 
SUMMER READING
 IN AN ERA OF audiobooks and videotapes and CD-ROM's, the printed book remains the single best way to learn and appreciate the language. As long summertime weekends approach (go try to find a book editor in the office on Friday), here are the books I am taking with me to the West Virginia mountains to read:
"When They Took Away the Man in the Moon," a novel by Kate Lehrer, a self-discovery specialist who is getting up into the Anne Tyler league (Harmony, $20).
"Blue Hearts," a spy novel by Jim Lehrer, rapidly becoming known as "Kate Lehrer's husband," a modern spy novel set in the C.I.A.-infested mountains of West Virginia (Random House, $20; dicker with your bookseller to sell you the Lehrer family books in a package for a discount).
"Crossing by Night," a spy novel by David Aaron, Jimmy Carter's deputy national security adviser, based on the life of Elizabeth Pack, the legendary British secret agent (Morrow, $22).
To nonfiction, sticking with spies to start:
"Spy Trader," by Craig R. Whitney, which John Le Carre accurately blurbs as "a revelation"; the fascinating story of the cold war through the ambivalent eyes of the shadowy German who arranged the spook swaps (Times Books, $25).
"The Real Anita Hill," by David Brock, which I'm taking because of the reverse-selling review in The New Yorker by two pro-Hill, anti-Clarence Thomas writers (Free Press, $24.95).
"The Fifties," by David Halberstam, who writes breezily but profoundly about the time that shaped the postwar world (Villard Books, $27.50).
"Touched With Fire: Manic-Depressive Illness and the Artistic Temperament," by Kay Redfield Jamison, showing why Byron, Poe, Melville and other depressives lit up the landscape, by one of the nation's foremost psychiatrists (Free Press, $24.95).
"The Hard Way," by Alexander B. Brook ($19.95). I'll read this memoir by a crusty editor because it's the first book from Warren Phillips's new publishing house, Bridge Works Publishing, Bridgehampton, N.Y.
"Terror in the Night," by Jack Nelson, the gripping history of the Ku Klux Klan's campaign against Southern Jews (Simon & Schuster, $22).
Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, Tenth Edition ($21.95). I get my kicks reading great dictionaries: "Mole . . . 4. a spy (as a double agent) who establishes a cover long before beginning espionage." And if the owner has a specific question about any word that didn't make it or word origins, he or she can write M-W's research service. (How come wimp is "origin unknown"? Isn't it from "whimper," spelling influenced by Popeye's friend Wimpy?)
 
STAND AND DELIVER
 THE MOST ill-considered phrase uttered on the floor of the House of Representatives this year came from the Speaker himself.
Urging his fellow Democrats to support President Clinton's economic proposals, Speaker Tom Foley said, "This is the time to stand and deliver."
Presumably, the Speaker meant that the members must courageously stand up and be counted to deliver their votes. However, the phrase Stand and deliver! is the command of the highwayman holding up a horse-drawn coach. Its meaning was clear to every driver carrying valuable cargo: stand still and deliver up the gold and jewelry.
The phrase today still carries the connotation of mounted theft. It's not a locution a politician wants to apply to a representative's relations with the taxpayers.
