HEADLINE: Labor Draws the Line in Decatur

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: DECATUR, Ill.

 BODY:
UNTIL the resistance began at the Caterpillar plant here, Lance Vaughan first installed a set of small hydraulic hoses on the huge off-highway trucks that he helps to assemble, and then a big outside hose. Now he installs the big one first, and reaches awkwardly around it to attach the others, losing production time in the process.
This is not sabotage. The instructions furnished by Caterpillar's engineers specify the inefficient procedure, Mr. Vaughan says. Normally, he ignores such instructions and makes a note to himself to tell the engineers to fix the mistake. Now, he no longer speaks up. Withholding initiative, he works "to the rules" furnished by the company. 
 "I used to give the engineers ideas," said Mr. Vaughan, who is 38 and has worked at Caterpillar for nearly 20 years. "We showed them how to eliminate some hose clips and save money. And I recommended larger bolts that made assembly easier and faster, and were less likely to come loose."
Mr. Vaughan's behavior is being multiplied hundreds of times in Decatur, interviews with workers show. A slowdown is taking place not only at Caterpillar, but also at the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company, whose corn-processing operation spreads like a refinery over 400 acres near the center of Decatur, turning out soft-drink sweeteners, corn oil and other products.
At both companies, tough new work conditions -- including reduced seniority rights and, at Staley, 12-hour workdays -- were imposed after an impasse in contract negotiations. In response, union workers like Mr. Vaughan at Caterpillar and Patricia Zilz at Staley are trying to slow production and thus force the companies back to the bargaining table. Ms. Zilz works with three other waste-water analysts who now drive a truck around the vast plant collecting water samples at 15 miles per hour, the company speed limit, rather than the 25 miles per hour or more that got the job done faster in the past.
 
'In-Plant' Strategy
 That sort of resistance is making this city, set among fields of corn and soybeans 175 miles south of Chicago, the most significant battleground to date for a novel union tactic: Rather than strike, and risk losing jobs to outsiders hired to replace them, the nearly 2,500 union members at Caterpillar and Staley are staying on the job and trying what they call an "in-plant strategy." They are testing, in effect, the widely held proposition that in today's competitive world, no company saddled with employees who carry out their tasks only routinely, and without initiative, can make money for long.
So far, the battle is inconclusive. What is clear, though, is that a lot is at stake in Decatur. Reflecting the importance of in-plant resistance, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has endorsed the strategy. If the unions win, labor stands to regain some of the bargaining power it lost in 1981, when the nation's air traffic controllers struck and President Reagan replaced them en masse. And the outcome could also have implications for employers and workers across the nation in nonunionized workplaces.
Citing the harsh realities of a weak economy and global competition, employers have been asking more from workers -- who have given in, fearful they might otherwise lose their jobs. But at some point, say labor economists and others who study the workplace, management starts to lose something in worker loyalty, initiative and cooperation for all that it might gain in lower labor costs and more flexible work rules. Getting both sides to agree on where that point is could be the big labor-management challenge of the early 90's -- with a miscalculation likely to be costly.
"Workers almost always see a way to do a job better," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist, "and passing up these opportunities in time becomes damaging for companies and the economy."
In a union setting, like the one here, the resistance to givebacks is organized and the workers have the benefit of union safety nets that protect against job loss. In a nonunion setting, such as an office or college campus, the resistance is amorphous but often just as deeply felt.
"If you have a professor who is asked to handle 400 students instead of 100 -- and that is happening regularly -- she does it, because she knows that if she does not, she can be replaced by any of the several hundred people who have applied for her job," said Katherine Newman, a Columbia University anthropologist.
Unable to openly resist, as the unionized workers at Caterpillar and Staley can, the protest becomes an accommodation, Professor Newman said -- one in which the teacher "creates an inefficiency somewhere else." In this sort of case, she said, a teacher "substitutes multiple-choice tests for essay assignments, although knowing that multiple-choice tests are a terrible way to prepare students to be critical thinkers."
 
Smiles and Hellos
 Even in Decatur, the resistance by Mr. Vaughan and others is virtually invisible. Walking among the huge trucks and partly assembled yellow road graders also made here, Gary Stroup, the plant manager, greets workers with ostentatious warmth, and they respond with smiles and hellos -- as if he and they are friends rather than opponents in a tense and potentially historic battle.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Stroup insists that the battle is not even being fought. "This is Middle America," he said. For a union "to come and ask these people not to do their jobs fully is to go against their work ethic and their moral fiber."
But the union is doing just that, said Larry G. Solomon, president of the United Auto Workers local here that represents Caterpillar employees. "Most of us have been taught the work ethic, but when we must fight, we can put that work ethic in neutral," Mr. Solomon said.
Morris Delbridge, who machines axles at Caterpillar, agrees. When his equipment broke down in the past, he called in the repairman himself and helped diagnose the trouble. Now, he leaves all that to the foreman. And Gregory Peck at Staley says he has considerable control over the speed at which he produces a corn-based ingredient for beer, but only increases the speed now when a foreman specifically tells him to do so.
The resistance appears to be gradually reducing efficiency at both Caterpillar and Staley, although the companies deny union claims that slower production has caused a delay in the filling of customer orders.
"We continue to grind corn and to operate the plant in a normal fashion," said J. Patrick Mohan, an executive vice president at Staley. "What we are losing is moving toward greater productivity, and that is costly."
Without an "engaged" work force, Mr. Mohan adds, Staley will have difficulty getting the return on the investment here to an acceptable annual rate of 15 percent or more from the present 10 percent average.
The resistance getting tested here could be affected by what is happening in Washington. President Clinton is trying to restore some of the power to strike, once again making a strike a viable alternative to a slowdown. A bill that would outlaw the hiring of permanent replacements for strikers has been sent to the floors of the House and Senate, and the House might act this week. The chances of final approval are uncertain, given the fierce opposition of corporate America.
"That bill puts too much power in the hands of the unions and of labor," said Gerald Flaherty, vice president for human resources at Caterpillar.
 
Wages Still High
 For the moment, the power is not there. And Caterpillar and Staley, having failed to win union agreement to their proposals, have imposed them unilaterally, calling their actions "implemented contracts." The companies argue that despite the changes they made, benefits and pay -- averaging $18 an hour at Caterpillar and $13 at Staley -- are still very high for the Midwest, and their workers are fortunate to have these jobs.
Realizing this, the workers will eventually give up their resistance, the companies say, overruling their unions in the process: the U.A.W. at Caterpillar and the Allied Industrial Workers of America at Staley.
Maybe. What the companies overlook, say the unions, is that some of the new rules that were imposed are wreaking havoc on workers' lives. Staley, for example, has moved its production workers to 12-hour shifts, with 3 one week and 4 the next, from 8-hour shifts, 5 days a week.
That has angered many, including Ms. Zilz, the waste-water analyst. "I was asked the other day to stay over an extra four hours and I worked 16 hours and I got no overtime for it because I did not manage to accumulate more than 40 hours in that particular week," she said. But with three children at home, Ms. Zilz, 46, had never sought much overtime. What really angers her, she says, is that she is cut off from her children by the longer shifts. "I cannot be a Girl Scout leader anymore, and I can't participate in a carpool," she said.
The slowdown at Caterpillar began last spring, after the U.A.W. called off a five-month strike, mostly at plants in Illinois, because Caterpillar was lining up replacement workers. Now the in-plant resistance involves nearly 15,000 workers at Caterpillar's various plants, including the 1,700 in Decatur, a city of 86,000 where the company is the largest employer.
Local 837 of the Allied Industrial Workers resorted to the strategy last fall for the 780 Staley employees that it represents here. The resistance began after an old contract expired and the company -- purchased in 1988 by Tate & Lyle P.L.C., a British multinational -- insisted that the plant was too costly and that pay and work rules be brought in line with similar facilities elsewhere. An impasse resulted.
 
Gumming Up the Works
 The worker resistance here is actually an amalgam of two proven labor tactics. One was the sitdown strike, made famous in the Depression; the other was the brief, informal slowdown, used for decades to protest a firing or other specific grievance.
"In the 1930's, when people tried to strike and were fired, there was a huge pool of unemployed people available to replace them," said Harley Shaiken, a labor economist at the University of California at San Diego. "So they did sitdown strikes instead. The U.A.W. even organized the auto industry this way. The in-plant strategy is essentially a walking-around sitdown strike that gums up production without halting it."
But while labor responded enthusiastically to the sitdown strikes of the 30's, the on-the-job resistance today is harder to sustain. For one thing, Caterpillar and Staley, although insisting they have no plans to move their operations to areas of cheaper labor elsewhere, nevertheless hold out that possibility if they fail in the struggle with their unions. For Staley, there is also talk of a shutdown: it recently gave 60 days' notice that it might close the corn oil section of its plant here, eliminating 92 jobs.
But Caterpillar is trying to win over the workers by giving as well as taking. While imposing cutbacks in such things as seniority rights and future staffing levels, it has also promised six years of job security for current workers. That promise, if fulfilled, would give most hourly employees, whose average age is 48, enough years to retire on full pensions. And pensions are also to go up.
"Most of our employees are trying to do a good job," said Mr. Flaherty, the human resources executive, in effect claiming that the resistance is not drawing many adherents.
Mr. Vaughan says that he almost fell into this category. Working as an assembler on the overnight shift, he farms 600 rented acres during the day, providing back-up income during strikes, Mr. Vaughan says, but leaving little time for union activity.
"I never got involved before, but now I have to," he said. "You can't straddle the fence when there isn't a contract that we have signed and they can't change. That is stressful. My kids will be in college in four years and what do I tell them, that I have job security for six? Maybe I do."
 
Bringing In Advisers
 With so much at stake, the Allied Industrial Workers has sought help from Ray Rogers, a New York consultant known for putting labor disputes into the public spotlight and thus increasing the pressure on management to settle. Already, two Midwestern banks have removed Staley executives from their boards after Mr. Rogers campaigned to get unions to withdraw deposits from the banks.
The local has also brought in Jerry Tucker, a former U.A.W. official and an early proponent of the in-plant resistance under way here. At weekly meetings at the local's union hall -- meetings that draw more than 300 Staley workers, nearly half the hourly staff -- Mr. Tucker offers encouragement and listens to testimonials.
The plant is falling behind in filling an order from Miller Beer, one worker reports. And another, Michael Banning, whose operation produces corn-based additives for food products, reads from a notice posted by a supervisor. "I am asking everyone to cooperate and get the production in this building back to what you've demonstrated in the past," it says.
Mr. Tucker asks about grievances. They are an effective way, he says, of keeping managers and workers from their jobs while dealing with complaints. And then, answering questions, he explains ways to file them, particularly by groups of workers.
Over at Caterpillar, Mr. Stroup, the plant manager, shares Mr. Tucker's view that grievances can hurt. He judges the effectiveness of the resistance in part by the number of grievances. They are down at Caterpillar, Mr. Stroup says -- and Mr. Solomon, the U.A.W. local president, does not challenge that assessment.
"We could do a lot better job gathering information about what is working and what isn't," Mr. Solomon said, noting that the U.A.W., unlike Allied, does not schedule weekly rank-and-file meetings.
Whatever the differences in strategy between the two unions, they are certainly in agreement on the goal. Having already called off a strike at Caterpillar, U.A.W. officials say they can't -- and won't -- call off their new form of resistance. "No worker, not even one on layoff, has ever suggested that we accept their contract offer," said Bill Casstevens, the U.A.W.'s secretary-treasurer.
 
Union Foes: Weak Demand, Automation
 THE weak national economy is turning out to be a blessing of sorts for Caterpillar Inc. and the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company. Orders are off; that's not good. But the worker slowdowns at the two companies have to cut more deeply into production if the companies are to feel the pain.
Caterpillar, which makes graders, loaders and off-highway trucks at its Decatur plant, illustrates the problem. High volume in boom times is 22 units a day, versus a current 15 or 16. "We could get to 22 now if we had to," said Gary Stroup, the plant manager, insisting that the slowdown has failed. "But we don't have to."
The Allied Industrial Workers of America, Local 837, has a similar problem at Staley. The company does not have to run its Decatur plant flat-out to fill its orders, said J. Patrick Mohan, an executive vice president. "In a weak economy, it is harder for the union to make an impact on production."
Automation is another obstacle complicating the efforts of the United Auto Workers to slow production sufficiently to force Caterpillar to negotiate. Motor graders made here used to move down assembly lines. To keep the lines moving, even at slow speed, required a full staff.
Now the graders are assembled in niches along an open "highway." After a section is installed in one niche, a robotic cart carries the grader to another niche for further assembly.
"The highway requires fewer people because you don't have to keep the whole line going," Mr. Stroup said, explaining not only why a slowdown is harder to bring off, but also why employment at the plant here has declined to 2,700 people from 4,400 in the late 1980's.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Shopping Lessons From (Gasp!) the Air Force

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
FOR anyone familiar with the horror stories of Air Force procurement -- $500 ashtrays, $700 toilet seats and $1,000 hammers -- it was easy to be apprehensive when the service announced in 1991 that it was letting out a contract covering as many as 300,000 advanced personal computers.
Now, more than two years after the Air Force opened its Desktop IV competition with a vow that the contract would be a model for streamlined high-technology procurement, the first batch of computers is almost ready for delivery. 
 The good news is that the Air Force -- and thus the public -- actually got a good deal on the $724 million, three-year contract, under which the whole Defense Department may buy equipment. This despite all the delays caused by bureaucratic fiat and red tape, repeated protests from losing bidders, and some bombast from pork-barrel politicians. Instead of paying premium prices for outdated technology, the military is getting top-quality commercial systems at bargain prices.
And the Desktop IV experience may even offer some lessons for private-sector businesses.
"Let's face it, if corporations bought computers the same way," said Robert A. Dornan, senior vice president of Federal Sources Inc., "our competitiveness in the world economy would crumble."
"But in the long run," Mr. Dornan hastened to add, "Desktop IV was a significant success. The Air Force tried a lot of new things."
"Instead of demanding detailed, nitpicky stuff, it called for open specifications," continued Mr. Dornan, whose consulting firm, based in McLean, Va., specialized in government technology contracts. "Instead of low price, it looked for best value. It used electronic bulletin boards for bidding. And what it wound up with was not quite state of the art, but pretty darned close."
Two companies, the Zenith Data Systems Corporation of Buffalo Grove, Ill., and Government Technology Services Inc. of Chantilly, Va., will share the contract. What they won, essentially, is a three-year hunting license to sell personal computers, peripherals and software to various Defense Department and civilian agencies, all under the Air Force umbrella contract.
Zenith Data, a subsidiary of Groupe Bull of France, appears to have the best chances for bagging Government sales. Unlike most of the original bidders, it proposed computers based on the Intel Corporation's i486 microprocessors. That was a bold step at the time, in May 1991 when the i486 was relatively new, but it paid off as the contract dragged on.
Government Technology was added to the award after several protesters, including Electronic Data Systems, Apple Computer and the Compuadd Corporation, cried foul over the Air Force's decision to give the contract solely to Zenith Data.
Government Technology originally bid in the summer of 1991, including 386- and i486-based computers made by Everex Systems Inc., which has since filed for bankruptcy protection. And while 386-based PC's were popular in 1991, today they are considered outdated. Last week, in a highly unusual step, Government Technology asked for permission to revamp its bid, even before the first computers were shipped.
"Under the terms of the contract, we are allowed to refresh the technology periodically, and we, as did Zenith, plan to take advantage of that," said Deborah M. Tucker, the company's vice president for corporate communications. She declined to say what changes the company wanted to make, but the newspaper Federal Computer Week reported that Government Technology is scrambling to find a PC maker other than Everex. It is also likely that the 386-based offerings will be abandoned. An Air Force decision on the proposed modifications is expected this month.
Compuadd, along with Sysorex Information Systems Inc. of Falls Church, Va., was the original contract winner. But after protests from losing companies, the Air Force acknowledged that its Standard Systems Center at Gunter Air Force Base, Ala., in its haste to award the contract under a new "fast track" procurement plan, had disqualified all the other bidders on technical grounds -- reportedly for errors as simple as filling out forms incorrectly.
The Air Force was forced to cancel the contract in January 1992 by the the General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals and then reopened the bidding. In September, Zenith Data was notified that it was the sole winner.
Electronic Data Systems, a General Motors subsidiary, led the next round of protests, complaining that Zenith Data's bid had violated the Trade Agreements Act of 1979. That act requires companies to "substantially alter" components purchased from designated foreign countries before they can be sold as finished products to the Government. Although Zenith Data assembled its monitors in the United States, the protestors said, it technically violated the 1979 act. Zenith Data denied the assertion.
E.D.S., of Dallas, and Compuadd, of Austin, enlisted the aid of the formidable Texas congressional delegation, including Representative J. J. Pickle and Senator Lloyd H. Bentsen, now Treasury Secretary. The Texans argued that because Zenith Data had been sold to a French company, and because the computers were to be used by the military, awarding the contract to Zenith Data posed a national security risk.
Zenith responded that it had supplied the military with computers used in the Persian Gulf war and had sold more than 500,000 computers to the Government in previous contracts. It also noted that E.D.S. was selling Taiwanese monitors to the Government under another contract. Even so, an administrative law judge at the G.S.A.'s Board of Contract Appeals upheld the protests.

 Then, last month, E.D.S. and the other protesters dropped their appeals. (Zenith Data acknowledged it had reached a financial agreement with E.D.S., the terms of which were not disclosed.) Government Technology was added as a second supplier.
Zenith Data recently disclosed details of its Desktop IV bid, which show that the military gets to go shopping at bargain prices. The computers involved are virtually the same as those available to anyone else, but the volume discounts are hefty.
For example, one Zenith Data computer, to which the Air Force has given the catchy designation CLIN 0003AB, has these specifications:
An Intel i486DX/33 microprocessor with an upgrade socket for a faster i486 chip, a 400-megabyte hard disk drive, 8 megabytes of system memory, 3.5-inch and 5.25-inch diskette drives, keyboard, mouse, four 16-bit expansion slots, 1 megabyte of video RAM for superior graphics performance, built-in Ethernet networking connectors and a 14-inch multi frequency, non-interlaced color monitor with Super VGA graphics and local-bus video.
It comes with a suite of Microsoft software: DOS, Windows, Word for Windows, Excel and Powerpoint, plus Polaris Packrat (a personal information manager) and software for connecting to Unix systems, plus a promise of free software upgrades for the life of the contract. The computer is backed by three years of free, worldwide, on-site service and round-the-clock toll-free telephone technical support, seven days a week.
Price: $2,330.
According to Zenith Data's Z-Direct sales catalogue, the public can get a Z-Station 433Dh computer for $2,599. It, too, has an i486DX/33 chip and upgrade socket, built-in networking and a Super VGA monitor. But it also has only 4MB of system memory, a 200-MB hard disk drive and a single diskette drive. Forget the $1,000 worth of application software and upgrades offered with CLIN 0003AB, and lop two years off the on-site service contract.
So what are the lessons for businesses?
First, it helps to buy in volume, insisting on discounts. Also, "Insist on transparent upgrade capabilities," suggested Robert B. Costello, a former Under Secretary of Defense for Procurement in the Reagan Administration, now a private consultant.

 Instead of writing 100-page specifications that spell out everything down to the type of processor and the number of screws on the computer case -- as the Air Force used to do -- consider an open search for the best value. Zenith Data's machines cost more than the 386's proposed by others, but they provide more power, a longer life span, extra software and service and support.
In short, don't be fixated on low cost. "Sure, you can choose a computer that costs $100 less, but that $100 can evaporate in one afternoon when a service technician comes to fix something," Mr. Dornan said.

HEADLINE: 'Little Italy' in South America: Colombia's Rising Leather Industry

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
SAY "Colombian exports" and most people will think of cocaine or coffee -- or books, bananas and oil. Lately, though, without fanfare, finely tooled Italian-style leather belts and bags have been added to the list.
In fact, with labor costs one-fifth those in Italy, Colombia is becoming South America's "Little Italy." It is pouring money into machinery and training to offer leather goods on the world market at half the price charged by Italian manufacturers. 
 Even the Italians are giving Colombian leather high marks for quality. After fingering soft purses and portfolios, and inspecting bags and briefcases, an Italian visitor here confessed: "I was quite surprised -- some of the workmanship is at the Italian level."
The visitor was not an idle shopper. He is Arturo Senserini, president of the Italian Association of Leather Manufacturers.
"Colombian handbags are now on the same level as France and Italy," added Giusseppe L. Landi, an Italian industrial economist who is providing technical advice to leather manufacturers here. "With leather garments, they have to improve their style. But in three years, they can reach the level of European industry."
Now, Italian manufacturers are exploring joint production ventures and Italy's export promotion institute is sending a mission of leather machinery manufacturers here in August. It has also agreed to sponsor workshops on improving production quality over the next year.
But some unusual factors are holding back the Colombian leather industry: Cattle ranchers are being kidnapped by guerrillas, who are largely rural forces; ranches themselves are deteriorating and hide quality can be poor. Also, bombings and other violence often scare away foreign buyers.
Still, Colombia's leather exports amount to $200 million a year, with 60 percent going to the United States. American consumers, however, are largely oblivious to the phenomenon. In the United States, Colombian products are usually marketed under brand names, or with the country of origin hidden in fine print.
"Retailers know the Colombian look, but there is no public perception," said Michael Schreiber, vice president of Latico Leathers of East Hanover, N.J. A major importer of Colombian leather bags, Mr. Schreiber estimated that over the last decade, the number of United States importers of Colombian leather goods has increased from two to 15.
Colombian manufacturers, meanwhile, have new reasons to expand the leather industry. Import tariffs on industrial machinery dropped last year to 5 percent from 35 percent, and tariffs on most imported hides fell to 10 percent from 30 percent.
Despite these financial incentives, the Colombian leather industry has hefty competition elsewhere, especially at the low-priced end of the market. India and China have even lower labor costs than Colombia. The answer to this challenge, according to manufacturers here, is to seek a market niche in high-quality garments, bags, shoes and accessories.
"Our niche is going to be the middle and upper quality," said Maria Angela Tavera, executive president of Colombia's Association of Leather Manufacturers, a group that has seen its membership mushroom over the last decade from 35 companies to 247. "Instead of trying to increase in volume, there is a great effort to improve design and quality."
In expanding its leather industry, however, Colombia has been importing cow hides -- an unusual step for a nation with so many cattle ranches. "Looking down the road, two years from now we think we are going to have a thriving market in Colombia," said Bruce Macdonald, the South America sales manager of the Prime Tanning Company of Berwick, Maine, America's largest exporter of finished leather hides.
A decade ago, exporting cow hides to Colombia would have made as much sense as carrying coal to Newcastle. But in 1992, increasing domestic violence forced Colombia to triple its hide imports over 1991 levels.
As foreign aid to Colombia's rural guerrillas dried up, they turned to kidnapping and extortion -- and of 1,136 Colombians kidnapped last year, more than half were ranchers. A large number of other ranchers paid millions of dollars in protection money to "vaccinate" themselves against kidnapping. In one ranching state, Cesar, kidnappings have become such a problem that the annual cattlemen's fair was cancelled last year.
The impact of all the civil unrest has been a dramatic reduction in Colombia's cattle herd, from 25 million cows in 1974 to 16 million last year.
Enrique White Salazar, president of the National Tanning Federation, referring to ranches that suffer from absentee ownership, added that the hides that are produced here tend to have defects. On some ranches, he said, cows' bellies "are scratched by weeds or wire. There are more illnesses because the cattle are not washed."
Another problem for the industry last year was the rationing of electricity -- the combined result of guerrilla violence, poor rainfall in a country dependent on hydroelectric power and poor Government planning. Many of Colombia's small leather workshops, located in residential neighborhoods, had to cut their working hours during the day while electricity was channeled to industrial zones.
In addition, the repatriation of illicit drug profits hurts legitimate Colombian exporters by boosting domestic inflation. Last year, local prices went up 25 percent in peso terms, while the dollars that exporters earned only appreciated against the peso by 14 percent.
Finally, many buyers have been shying away from Colombia because of the nation's reputation for violence. Foreign registrations for a leather-goods fair here in February thinned after a series of car bombs were detonated in this city, violence the Government said was committed by Pablo Escobar, the fugitive cocaine trafficker.
"I had a good Mexican client who cancelled his trip here because of the bombs," complained Gustavo Gonzalez Jinete, whose factory here, Gonari, exports to Latico in New Jersey. Mario Hernandez Zambrano, who has an outlet of his Marroquinera leather goods chain in Trump Plaza in Manhattan, said: "Only half of our American buyers came this year."
But with the leather industry still on an expansion course, foreign pioneers here say potential profits outweigh the risks.
"I was in Bogota when the World Trade Center was bombed in New York," said Mr. Macdonald of Prime Tanning in Maine, "so it's a worldwide problem." He added that his company planned to be represented each year at the fair. Having expanded tenfold over the last decade, the fair is expected to attract 735 stands in August. It's a gathering that now bills itself "Latin America's Most Important Leather Fair."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The China Factor in Asia Funds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
SPURRED on by China's movement farther and farther from a controlled economy, "China funds" have been popping up fast -- so fast that only one among four new China-flavored mutual funds and three new closed-end China funds has celebrated its first birthday.
Their timing seems auspicious. Late last month, the International Monetary Fund reported that, at $1.7 trillion, China's economy is four times larger than previously believed and the third-largest in the world, behind the United States and Japan. 
 But investors who want to tap into China's fast-growing economy should remember that "10 to 12 percent economic growth rates won't translate into big investment returns overnight," said Colin Mathews, a closed-end fund analyst with Morningstar Inc., fund researchers in Chicago. And, like all investments in emerging markets, these funds carry plenty of risks.

 From the time they came to market last summer, the three closed-end funds -- the China Fund, the Greater China Fund and the Jardine-Fleming China Region Fund -- have been volatile. They trade, like common stock, on the New York Stock Exchange, and began selling at premiums of roughly 8 percent over the net asset value of the securities they own. But by October, all three had fallen to discounts approaching 20 percent.
Why? Because the funds are so similar, supply exceeded demand, explained Thomas J. Herzfeld, in Miami, a specialist in closed-end funds. Then there was a buyers' riot on China's stock exchange, followed by a threat in the United States to revoke China's most-favored-nation trade status.
But the funds quickly rallied when China agreed to reduce barriers to imports from the United States, averting a costly trade war. Then in April the Securities and Exchange Commission ruled that the funds were allowed to buy "B" shares -- Chinese company shares created for foreign investors -- clearing the way for direct investment in Chinese issues.
Until the S.E.C. ruling, Chinese investments were nearly impossible. So funds labeled "China" haven't necessarily invested there, or at least not heavily, and that's still true. Direct Chinese investments account for only 16 percent of the Greater China Growth Fund's portfolio, for instance, and just 3 percent of the China Fund's.
Mutual fund investors likewise can only get a taste of China through regional funds. The two granddaddies here are Newport Tiger, started in 1989, and T. Rowe Price's New Asia, the only no-load in the group, set up in 1990. Two more began investing last year: the Merrill Lynch Dragon Fund and the Eaton Vance Greater China Growth Fund, in Boston, the first mutual fund to make China, rather than the Pacific Rim, its investment focus. In April, Van Eck, in New York, set up the Asia Dynasty Fund and Fidelity introduced its Southeast Asia Fund.
None of the China mutual funds, however, are loading up on direct investments in China. Instead, all try to capitalize on China's growth mainly by buying shares in Hong Kong, Korean or other Pacific Rim companies with large sales revenues from China or manufacturing facilities there.
Typical is Eaton Vance, which invests just 4 percent in China -- in Shanghai Refrigeration Compressor, Dazhong Taxi and Shenzhen China Bicycle, among others. Some 45 percent is in Hong Kong, whose exchange is better established and better capitalized, 13 percent in Singapore, roughly 10 percent each in Malaysia and Korea, and the rest in the Philippines, Thailand and Taiwan.
Newport Tiger, with no direct investment in China, has 48 percent of its portfolio in Hong Kong and the rest throughout Asia. "The China story is compelling, but it's going to be some time before the securities markets are settled enough to invest there," said Tim Tuttle, managing director of the fund's sponsor, Newport Pacific Management.
George Murnaghan, vice president of Rowe Price Fleming International, sponsor of the New Asia Fund, said, "We looked at 'B' shares, but there are cheaper ways to get China exposure." New Asia has 31 percent of its portfolio in Hong Kong and the rest in Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Australia and New Zealand.
Most of the funds plan to continue investing outside China despite the S.E.C.'s blessing to plunge in. Valuations are high on the Chinese exchanges, managers say, partly because so few new issues are floated on the exchanges, which are not very liquid anyway.
Managers are enthusiastic about China's prospects, but concede that interim performance will probably be erratic, despite flashy gains this year of 30 to 35 percent (closed-end) and 19 percent and up (mutual) funds.

Mr. Mathews suggests that investors hang onto shares in Pacific Rim funds for at least 10 years to capture the long-term value built into China's economic prospects, and limit their exposure to only a small part of the high-risk portion of their portfolios. As shown by the lukewarm performance of funds that sprang up after Eastern Europe opened for investment, new and uncharted territory isn't easy to till profitably.
As for the closed-end funds, today they again sport hefty premiums and Mr. Herzfeld advises waiting to buy until the funds return to discounts -- which, because the funds react so sharply to political news, he noted, could be any time.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
A Week of Springtime for the Republicans

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
STILL smarting from their loss of the White House, Republicans triumphantly seized on their victories last week in the Texas Senate race and the Los Angeles mayoral race as evidence that their party had hit the comeback trail.
They grandly pronounced that the voters had repudiated President Clinton and that last year's loss was a rejection of George Bush, not the Republican Party. The results even spurred jubilant talk about taking back the Senate in 1994 and making big inroads into the Democratic majority in the House. 
 "It looks to me like it's a bad time to be running with a 'D' beside your name because all that anger and resentment, that anti-Washington feeling, is now aimed at them," said Charles Black, who was a senior adviser to the Bush campaign. "You're seeing a Democratic base being dispirited; they're staying home."
Even David Wilhelm, who as chairman of the Democratic National Committee is charged with putting the positive spin on even the most gloomy news, acknowledged the obvious, albeit with understatement: "We didn't have a great political week."
In Los Angeles, Richard Riordan, a conservative, became the first Republican mayor in a generation, defeating Michael Woo, a liberal City Councilman endorsed by Mr. Clinton, by 54 percent to 46 percent.
In the Texas Senate race, the surprise was not that Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Republican, defeated the Democratic incumbent, Senator Bob Krueger, but that she won by a margin of 2 to 1. Though Mr. Krueger was never endorsed by Mr. Clinton and in fact distanced himself from the President's economic program, Mrs. Hutchison seemed to focus her campaign as much on Bill Clinton as on her opponent in Texas.
There were other danger signs for Democrats. Sam Farr, a Democratic Assemblyman, was elected to the California race for the House seat vacated by Leon E. Panetta, Mr. Clinton's budget director. But in a largely Democratic district along the coast south of San Francisco, Mr. Farr defeated a Republican, Bill McCampbell, with only 52 percent of the vote. Two years ago, Mr. Panetta defeated Mr. McCampbell with 72 percent.
And Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican who won the New Jersey gubernatorial primary, is viewed as a formidable rival for Gov. Jim Florio because of the state's economic woes and tax increases.
While all this evidence has certainly rejuvenated the Republicans' spirits, it does little to mask the party's troubles: It is still struggling to find common ground between moderate factions and the increasingly influential religious conservatives. There is also a leadership void, with polls showing that Ross Perot is more popular and better known than any Republican who might run in 1996.
Mr. Wilhelm dismisses the Republican crowing as premature. "I fundamentally believe that six to nine months from now, the political dynamic is going to be far different," he said. "We will have passed the budget, passed health care reform. If the Republicans believe that gridlock and an excessive display of partisanship is in their interest, that is a fundamental miscalculation of the American people."
But Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, is not looking to six or nine months from now but to 1994 and the chance to end the 56-44 Democratic advantage in the Senate. "Our slogan now," he said, "is seven more in '94."

HEADLINE: LOST IN WASHINGTON;
An Economy Looking for Signals Gets One a Minute

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PERHAPS it was naive, but the hope was once in the air that President Clinton would march into Washington, lift the nation's spirits, get employment up and the deficit down and have the economy gliding along like a high-speed train.
That hasn't exactly happened. Instead Mr. Clinton has gotten bloodied and bruised as he struggles to push his budget package through a Congress with ideas of its own. This has dissipated the burst of confidence that greeted the President, and, to Mr. Clinton's chagrin, the underpowered economy remains on the same unhappy course as when he arrived -- chugging uphill and on the slow track.
Some economic analysts believe that all the inside-the-Beltway mudslinging and mayhem can only cause the economy to lose more steam. Washington has never been like Moscow of old, with heavy-handed bureaucrats pulling the strings of factories and shops thousands of miles away. But Washington does send out countless subtle signals every day that influence myriad economic decisions, and in recent weeks those signals have spelled uncertainty with a capital U.
Businesses abhor uncertainty -- it worries them and often paralyzes them. True, a considerable amount was to be expected, since Mr. Clinton came into office on the promise of change, committed to cutting the deficit and overhauling health care. But he seems to have piled it on with a vengeance -- with the help of Congressional Democrats and Republicans, of course. This uncertainty further clouds an already murky economic picture, with just as many indicators pointing down as up.
Confusion in Washington inarguably hurts the economy to some degree because it has sent corporate executives to the sidelines, anxious for matters to clarify before they get on with the business of expanding, hiring and investing -- paradoxically, the precise economic goals that Mr. Clinton wants to achieve. With the investment tax credit here one day and gone the next, with trial balloons being floated about new consumption and payroll taxes, and with the energy tax seemingly changing every few minutes like a kaleidoscope, many corporate executives say they don't know who's on first.
 
A Tax Free-for-All

 And the uncertainty is likely to continue for months to come, through the Administration's anticipated but much delayed effort to reform health care, which accounts for one of every seven dollars spent in the economy.
In its latest turn last week, the White House abandoned an energy tax on the heat content of fuels, and now appears ready to let a Congressional free-for-all determine what energy tax the country should have. The leader among a raft of unpopular proposals is a transportation tax -- a levy on gasoline, diesel fuel and airline fuel pushed by Senator John Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat.
Seeing all this confusion, many executives are asking how they can decide whether to build a new factory or hire new workers when they don't know which new taxes they will face and how large they will be.
"Many businessmen are deferring decisions on hiring and capital spending -- either they don't know what Washington is going to come up with or they don't like what has already been proposed," said Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm. "They're uncertain or frozen."
In Mr. Brinner's view, such uncertainty hardly hurt the first quarter of this year because most investment and hiring decisions had been locked in when Mr. Clinton took office. But many analysts agree this uncertainty is hurting the economy now.
In the first quarter, the economy inched upward at a miserably slow nine-tenths of 1 percent. The Administration is praying for a robust second quarter, and many economists say that just might happen in spite of Washington's budget turmoil. But if the economic torpor continues, it will hard to push the jobless rate much below 7 percent -- and to fulfill Mr. Clinton's goal of creating 8 million jobs in four years.
 
Vicious Cycle
 Indeed, if growth doesn't get better and soon, the economy's weakness could metastasize into serious political trouble for Mr. Clinton, just as it did for George Bush. That could complicate efforts to push through his economic and health care programs, forming a vicious cycle of uncertainty undercutting the economy and hampering lawmakers, creating more uncertainty, and so on. Americans, Mr. Brinner says, will be less game for sacrifice and grand experiments when the economy and their paychecks are going nowhere. And members of Congress, already in a surly mood, might grow even less loyal to Mr. Clinton as worries fester that he might not turn around the economy before the 1994 elections.
At the moment, the economy seems to be both accelerating and holding back. On one hand, businesses seem discouraged by all the confusion in Washington. But on the other, companies see the economy expanding, although slowly, quarter after quarter, and as orders flow in, they feel obligated to increase hiring.
"Even though companies are worried about new laws or taxes and all the uncertainty, that is very much overridden by the fact that new orders keep coming in," said Mitchell Fromstein, chief executive officer of Manpower Inc., the temporary help company.
For businesses, predicting how the economy will behave in six months is about as difficult as predicting whether Mr. Clinton will stop stumbling by then. On the negative side, consumer and business confidence are dipping, retail sales are weak and factories have scaled back their investment plans. Brighter news, however, comes from the strong pickup in employment in May and surprisingly robust gains in car and housing sales.
What economic strength there is seems concentrated in sectors highly sensitive to interest rates. Mr. Clinton can claim some responsibility for that, since long-term interest rates dropped sharply after he was elected and unveiled his $500 billion deficit reduction package. Since his $19 billion economic stimulus package went down in flames, he is looking to the sharp fall in interest rates as the economy's salvation, saying it will translate into $100 billion in stimulus.
The trouble is, the combination of tax increases and spending cuts in his budget package is bound to have a numbing effect on the economy -- what economists often call "fiscal drag." Companies complain that higher taxes or dropoffs in government contracts cause them to hire fewer people. And corporate worries have been aggravated by reports that Mr. Clinton's health-care package may include hefty payroll taxes of 7 to 10 percent of the wage base.
"We are being more than extremely careful about hiring," said Pepe Piedra, chairman of NeoCAD, a software company in Boulder, Colo. "There could be a double whammy for us between the enormous tax increases in the economic package and the whammy of new taxes to pay for health-care reform."
One company recently finished a study on whether to modernize an existing American factory or replace it by building a new plant in Mexico. The study concluded that it was a tossup, but, a company executive indicated, if the Administration pushes through a 10 percent payroll tax for health care, the investment will go south of the border.
With the recent shake-up in the White House, Administration officials nevertheless exude confidence that they will get their economic package passed this summer, that confidence in the economy will rebound and that Mr. Clinton's popularity will likewise. If only the American people were as confident.

HEADLINE: On These Shores, Immigrants Find a New Wave of Hostility

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TOLERANCE and intolerance toward immigration form a double helix in the American genetic code. The United States, every civics textbook says, is a nation of immigrants, a refuge to the tired, the poor and the tempest-tossed. But nativism, the political reaction against immigration, is a hardy strain. It flourishes in times of economic and political uncertainty. It is flourishing now.
Last week's wreck of the Golden Venture, the smugglers' ship that spilled nearly 300 Chinese immigrants seeking political asylum onto New York's shores, and the abuse of the asylum system by a key suspect in the World Trade Center bombing, have spurred anti-immigration bills in Congress. They have raised fears that a flood of foreigners threatens the political and economic security of the United States. In particular, they have amplified calls for restrictions on the system of political asylum. 
 "The sense of siege has been a very good vehicle for the anti-immigration people," said Demetrios Papademetriou, director of immigration policy at the Labor Department from 1988 to 1992. "Their message resonates around the country: Immigration is out of control; our borders have fallen."
Immigration and Naturalization Service officers now use the language of the war on drugs. They speak of smuggling cartels trafficking in illicit cargo. William S. Slattery, director of the service's New York office, uses the language of war itself. "Who's going to control the borders of the United States?" he said. "The aliens have taken control."
The same message reverberates in Germany, where xenophobic firebombings and Government decisions to restrict immigration have coincided, and in France, whose new interior minister declared last week that the nation cannot absorb more immigrants.
About one million foreigners will ask to immigrate to the United States this year. Roughly 10 to 15 percent will request political asylum. No one knows how many more will slip across the border and into the sprawl of New York or Los Angeles. No one can measure the cost of health services or education for them. The strain on cities is enormous. But it always was, from the first great waves of immigration in the 1840's.
"All the overcrowded school districts today are immigrant school districts," said Frank Vardy, a demographer with New York's Department of City Planning. "That's always been true, ever since immigration started. Today 42 percent of all births in the city are to immigrant mothers. Those children are all American citizens, every one."
In California, "the nativist arguments are economically driven," said Larry Eig, a legislative attorney at the Library of Congress. "People will do anything they can to cut down the costs of immigrants and immigration. They are culturally scared as well as economically scared."
More than a few descendants of immigrants are saying enough is enough. "We cannot accommodate even a fraction of the people who want to move here," said Dan Stein, director of the Federation for American Immigration Reform.
The modern strain of nativism was cross-fertilized by three movements: zero population growth, environmentalism and the English-first movement. Each of their beliefs supported the fundamental nativist credo: this country cannot assimilate more aliens.
If that is true, then a tenet of the Founding Fathers has collapsed.
"What Thomas Jefferson and others did was to create a civic culture which made it possible for the United States to make Americans out of people from vastly different cultural and religious backgrounds," said Lawrence Fuchs, acting chairman of the Federal Commission on Immigration Reform. "No other country does that."
But no other country has the same burden of immigrants, refugees and asylum seekers. None has an agency quite like the I.N.S., simultaneously responsible for throwing aliens out and allowing them in. None has quite the same tradition of embracing and repelling alien cultures.
In 1795, George Washington asked God "to render this country more and more a safe and propitious asylum for the unfortunate of other countries." Three years later, in the Alien and Sedition Acts, Congress gave the Government extraordinary powers to arrest and deport foreigners deemed un-American.
President Jefferson undid the Acts. "Shall we refuse to the unhappy fugitives from distress that hospitality which the savages of the wilderness extended to our fathers arriving in this land?" he asked.
In the 1850's, the nativist Know-Nothing Party elected governors, controlled state legislatures, and commanded scores of seats in Congress with demands for an end to immigration. Its members rioted against Irish and German newcomers, saying they would never fit into the American mosaic.
Five years later, the Government sought immigrants for Civil War soldiers. President Lincoln put this plank in the Republicans' 1864 platform: "Resolved, That foreign immigration . . . to this nation, the asylum of the oppressed of all nations, shall be fostered and encouraged by a liberal and just policy."
That resolution ebbed with world wars. After admitting more than 600,000 Europeans made homeless by World War II, Congress passed the McCarran Act, excluding the ideologically incorrect and fixing quotas based on race and nationality. Each crisis provoked an exception -- Cubans after Castro's rise, Vietnamese after Saigon's fall. The doors of political asylum opened to those fleeing communism and closed for those fleeing the armies of the right. The new flood of illegal Chinese immigration began with the Bush Administration's liberalization of asylum policy after the Tiananmen Square killings.
Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln all used the word "asylum" to mean an America where anyone could come to make a better life, said Mr. Fuchs. Today asylum has a more narrow definition: the refuge offered people with "a well-founded fear of persecution" in their homelands.
"It's now so much easier to get to our doorstep on planes, on ships, on foot," said Mr. Fuchs. "Thousands of people show up and claim political asylum, and because we have a system of due process, it's very hard to administer. How do you ration the tickets to get in?"
Often left out of this life-and-death debate are those seeking asylum.
Min Sun Min is 37 years old and living in Brooklyn, two facts he regards as minor miracles. He grew up in Burma and became a history teacher. The government jailed and tortured him for his political beliefs. Released, he fled through the jungle into Thailand and was granted political asylum by the United States in April. He now works in a movie theater and studies advertising.
"My belief is that everyone has to be free," he said. "I love freedom here. The many Chinese people who came here by boat and the Haitian refugees who came here, their lives are the same situation. I know some Haitian refugees were sent back and the Chinese were put in jail. My feeling is Haitian, Chinese, whatever, people who have political reasons should have equal opportunity to save their lives."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Clinton's Health-Care Plan: It's Still Big, but It's Farther Away

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE shimmering vision of health-care reform, a central promise of President Clinton's campaign, seems to be receding into the distance as Administration officials and members of Congress wrestle with problems like taxes and the Federal budget deficit.
The soaring ambition of Mr. Clinton's health plan has been brought down to earth by certain political laws of gravity, and no one is more worried than the 500 policy analysts who labored for Hillary Rodham Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, dissolved May 30 with no assurance about the use to which their work will be put. 
 "The policy-making process was unusual, exhilarating, disorienting and rather bizarre, but it produced a workable proposal," said Dr. Irwin E. Redlener, a New York City pediatrician who assisted the task force for three months. "I worry that Clinton's proposal will now be dismembered because of political and fiscal pressures as it runs through the gantlet of Congress, with special interests waiting in the wings."
The need for improvements in the health-care system -- to slow the explosive growth of health spending, to guarantee care for the uninsured, to provide security for those who already have some coverage -- is as great as ever.
But the prospects for sweeping changes have dimmed for several reasons: the Administration's own delays; its political naivete; the erosion of the President's political capital; the inherent conflict with his economic plan and deficit-reduction goals, and not least, the power of the "special interests" that Mrs. Clinton often decries.
The Administration seems to have underestimated the magnitude of the task it was undertaking.
Prof. Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, said: "You couldn't find a more enthusiastic supporter of Clinton than I was in January. I was quite sure that he would give us a bold vision for health-care reform by May 1 because Hillary Clinton's personal reputation was riding on that deadline. But if you ask me now, instead of that early vision of an elegant, powerful program announced to the world by an exuberant Clinton, I think you will get a compromise worked out by the White House and Congress. And it may be more incremental than bold."
Referring to the Administration, Mr. Reinhardt said, "Their heart is in the right place, but I'm no longer so sure of their political and technical acumen."
Whereas Mr. Clinton tends to favor mandates and requirements, Congress is more likely to provide encouragement and incentives to control costs and get small employers to buy health insurance for their employees.
 
Fading Commitment
 At her confirmation hearing in January, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said any money saved through cutbacks in Medicare and Medicaid would be used to provide health benefits for the uninsured, not to reduce the Federal budget deficit. But that commitment evaporated in the blistering heat of political reality.
In his budget request in mid-February, Mr. Clinton proposed to cut the projected growth of Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly, by more than $50 billion over five years, and all the savings were earmarked for deficit reduction. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, chairman of the Finance Committee, raised the ante last week when he suggested further Medicare cutbacks of $35 billion over five years.
President Clinton's budget director, Leon E. Panetta, warned that such big reductions in Medicare would be seen as "undercutting health-care reform." Mr. Clinton's health policy advisers expressed despair. For if Congress follows Mr. Moynihan's suggestion, they said, the President may have to scale back his health-care proposals or seek bigger tax increases to pay for them.
Kevin E. Lofton, chief executive officer of Howard Unversity Hospital in Washington, said, "We expected health-care reform to pay for the uninsured." Instead, he said, the hospital may lose some of the money it is receiving for people already insured through Medicare and Medicaid.
Medicare serves more than 35 million people. There are 30 million Medicaid recipients; about half are under 18 years old.
In the political calculus of Washington, the economy takes priority over health care, for this reason: people must have secure jobs before they can get health benefits through those jobs. Mr. Clinton's plan would require all employers to provide health benefits for their workers, either directly or indirectly though regional insurance purchasing groups.
Economists have been involved in the formulation of Mr. Clinton's health-care proposals, but their insights have not always been welcomed or assimilated by his health policy team, and that was probably a mistake. For as C. Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, says: "Government policy toward health care can never be separated from financing or tax issues, or from alternative uses and expenditures to which tax dollars might be devoted. In many discussions, health policy is treated as isolated from tax policy. Inevitably and irreducibly, however, they are two sides of the same accounting ledger."
 
All or Nothing
 In remarks that now look prescient, Mr. Steuerle said in May 1992: "The failure to make headway in health care derives from the attempt to do too much. The drive to 'do it all' has, in many ways, deterred efforts toward incremental improvements that, when combined, could be quite substantial."
One such incremental effort seeks to regulate the health insurance market, to prevent insurers from denying coverage or charging exorbitant premiums for people with a high risk of costly illness. Democrats, Republicans and many big insurance companies now agree that such regulation is needed. But there is little chance that it will be considered except as part of Mr. Clinton's proposal to restructure the entire health-care system. Indeed, some Democrats oppose piecemeal change on the ground that it would undermine political support for comprehensive change.
When people speak of the political naivete of Mr. Clinton's health policy advisers, they are referring to technicians like Ira C. Magaziner and Walter A. Zelman, who have inventive minds but no experience in Washington. Mr. Magaziner, the coordinator of Mrs. Clinton's task force, is the President's senior adviser for policy development; Mr. Zelman, who also works at the White House, is one of the chief architects of the Clinton proposals. The vast apparatus of the task force, with its work groups, policy papers and secretive discussions, sometimes seemed to exist more for the purpose of educating Mr. Magaziner than drafting legislation.
But Mr. Clinton was ultimately responsible for the operation of the task force. Its strengths and weaknesses reflected his style of management. He has wallowed in hours and hours of discussion, and he has impressed his staff with his command of the nuances of health policy. But he has deferred crucial decisions about how to pay for new benefits and whether to regulate the prices of insurance, drugs, doctors and hospitals.
Thus, the sales campaign for the President's health plan appears to be in a more advanced stage of development than the plan itself. The Democratic National Committee will orchestrate a public relations campaign in support of the President's proposal. Mrs. Clinton is already assailing critics of the President's approach. And the White House has distributed "talking points" so members of Congress can answer questions from constituents (Will I still be able to choose my doctor? Won't quality be sacrificed? Won't this plan kill small business?).
President Clinton's approval rating has fallen sharply since February, and Mrs. Clinton's popularity has suffered a more modest decline. If the President cannot persuade Congress to pass a $16 billion jobs bill, can he sell a health-care proposal costing two or three times that? It will be difficult. But polls consistently show a public yearning for major changes. For Mr. Clinton and Congress, the challenge is to shape such sentiment into a consensus for specific legislation that would revolutionize health care in America.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
There's Nothing Like Foreign Policy for Producing Ennui

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SHORTLY after President Clinton took office he held a town meeting in Chillicothe, Ohio, during which an audience chosen by lottery asked him about everything, it seemed, from health care to Hillary. But in 90 minutes he did not get a single question on foreign policy. It was a harbinger of things to come.
In all the town hall meetings the President has held since then, you could count on one hand the number of unprompted foreign policy questions he has received from the public. Clinton aides barely bother anymore to even prepare the President for foreign policy questions, for they know he is much more likely to get asked about the trimmings of Cristophe the barber than the travels of Christopher the diplomat. 
 What happened to American foreign policy? It was here a minute ago. Lately, though, the whole subject seems to excite almost nobody: Iraq attempts to assassinate former President Bush while he is on a visit to Kuwait, and people shrug: "No harm done." Bosnian Serbs continue to thumb their noses at Washington, and people just avert their eyes. President Clinton opts for renewing trade benefits for China, with only the most tentative human rights conditions, and Congress is mute.
"You have to ask yourself," said Robert Tucker, professor emeritus of international relations at Johns Hopkins, "is there anywhere in the world where the American people today would be ready to suffer 5,000 casualties to achieve some foreign policy goal, besides the defense of the United States?"
An interesting question. And while it may not engage many in the wider public, it has sparked something of a new debate among foreign policy experts.
The fuel for this debate, and the underlying cause for the indifference to foreign policy, can be found in two conditions that happened to coincide in the last few years: the nation's thin wallet and its ambivalent will. Without a lot of cash, Americans are choosing foreign policy issues selectively. And without a Soviet Union as a threat, few of these issues really seem worth choosing.
More fuel for the debate was provided by Bosnia. As President Clinton campaigned on the promise of a more aggressive policy there, then tiptoed toward intervention, then suddenly retreated, it raised in the minds of many analysts fundamental questions about the limits of American power today, and the limits of American domestic tolerance for an activist foreign policy.
But the real spark for the debate was provided by Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff, when, at a recent lunch with diplomatic reporters, he said: "Our economic interests are paramount." Given its limited resources, he said, the United States must "define the extent of its commitment commensurate with those realities -- this may on occasion fall short of what some Americans would like and others would hope for." Referring to Bosnia, he added: "Are people dying because the United States could do more if we wanted to? Yes."
Two articles then stoked the discussion by trying to tell Mr. Clinton what choices he should make in a world of scarce resources and ambiguous interests. One was an essay by Michael Mandelbaum, an American foreign policy professor at Johns Hopkins, who had served as a campaign adviser to the President. In an article for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, he argued that the "Tarnoff Doctrine" -- that we simply cannot afford to lead as we once did -- is wrong, because given the central role that America plays in the world, there is no such thing as taking a back seat and still achieving the ends it wants. According to this argument, if Washington does not lead no one will.
Mr. Mandelbaum faults the Clinton team not for acknowledging the limits of American resources to lead, but rather for a failure to set and justify for the American public clear priorities for where America should lead and where it should not. Without such priorities, he argued, America will dissipate its energies on secondary issues, and without good justifications the Administration won't get support for the most important priorities.
A more isolationist perspective is presented in the forthcoming issue of Foreign Affairs, in which Alan Tonelson, research director for the Economic Strategy Institute, argues that "the superpower role that America has played since 1945 is now not only too expensive and risky for the public taste, but is also unnecessary." The United States can protect its global economic and strategic interests, he contends, with a "significantly lower international profile." Mr. Tonelson worries, though, that "an Administration and a loyal opposition still addicted to globalism and leadership on the cheap may yet bloody the country's nose or warp its economy by pursuing world order in Bosnia or elsewhere."
In their defense, Clinton foreign policy aides disavow the Tarnoff Doctrine. They say that where it has counted -- particularly on the pivotal matter of aid to Russia -- they have been ready to lead. And elsewhere, they say, they have articulated clear, sustainable, realistic objectives -- ranging from stemming missile proliferation (a policy pursued with recent initiatives directed at both Iran and Ukraine), to establishing a framework for negotiations with Japan, to completing the world trade talks. There has also been success in turning back authoritarianism in Guatemala. The only area in which the Administration officials acknowledge that the President over-promised and then retreated is Bosnia.
 
When Is Credit Due?
 Nevertheless, Mr. Clinton has not gotten much credit for his foreign policy, and is not likely to. For one thing, it is going to be hard for him to assert the sort of clear-cut leadership that wins plaudits on the world stage. For American cold war Presidents, "multilateralism" -- working in concert with allies -- was really just a cover for the assertion of naked American power. For Mr. Clinton it is a fundamental necessity. This is because the United States believes that it can't afford to go it alone, except in cases of direct threat to its national interests. In addition, without the moral clarity of the Soviet threat, which could always justify action, most Americans seem reluctant to intervene abroad unless assured that the stakes are worth it by seeing allies join in the operation. It is hard to stand above the pack when you need them not for decoration but real support.
In addition, Mr. Clinton will find it difficult to succeed in foreign policy until he redefines for the American public what constitutes success. During the cold war, everyone knew what success was: The Berlin wall was up one day and down the next -- that was success. Russia was Communist one day and a democracy the next -- that was success. You didn't need to explain it to anyone on the street. But what is success in Bosnia? What is success in the helter-skelter march toward democracy in Eastern Europe? What is success in the trade talks with Japan? When everyone has a yardstick, no one has a yardstick -- and that is why, short of another direct threat to American security, Mr. Clinton is going to have to set some clear goals before anyone can measure whether he has met them.

HEADLINE: Europeans Fear Unemployment Will Only Rise

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 12

 BODY:
A new unease has taken hold in Western Europe as the conviction grows that record levels of unemployment may be tied less to the region's economic slump than to fundamental shifts in the work place and in the global economy that will persist beyond the current recession.
Last year, as the number of jobless mounted, the focus was on high German interest rates. By discouraging investment and consumption, the argument went, the high cost of money in Western Europe was delaying recovery and the creation of jobs. But as the rates have fallen this year, without any immediate response, awareness has grown that something deeper may be wrong. 
 Alarm is spreading: 17.4 million people are unemployed in the 12 countries of the European Community, or 10.3 percent of the work force, up from 14.6 million at the start of the year.
Over the next 18 months, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development of 24 countries predicts that unemployment in its 19 European member countries will jump almost 20 percent, to 23 million people or 11.9 percent of the work force. And that prediction is based on the beginning of an economic recovery next year in Western Europe.
"There is a great deal of apprehensiveness because we just don't know the full answers to why unemployment is surging," said one senior official from the economic organization, which is based in Paris. "If we did we could at least lay down some policy guidelines."
 
Whether, Not When, Jobs Return
 The question being asked is no longer when jobs will come back but whether they may have been permanently lost as a result of new technologies, the increased mobility of production, the determination of many large companies to become leaner and more flexible, and the relatively high cost of employing people in Western Europe.
"Now that capital and exchange controls have been largely removed, and communication is more or less instantaneous, investment goes increasingly to countries offering the best combination of labor costs, productivity and growing markets," said J. Paul Horne, the chief economist for Smith, Barney, Upham in Paris. "On all those counts, Europe loses out to Southeast Asia and this is going to weigh on the job market."
Every month, companies in sectors as varied as autos, champagne, tires, electronics, computers and glass announce new layoffs. For every I.B.M. or General Motors in the United States, there is a Philips or an Olivetti in Western Europe, engaged in equally extensive restructuring that eliminates tens of thousands of jobs.
 
Clear Consequences
 Already, the political and social consequences are clear. Turkish immigrants are killed in an arson attack in Germany. The French Interior Minister, Charles Pasqua, tells Le Monde that "our objective, given the gravity of the economic situation, is to move toward zero immigration." Prime Minister Edouard Balladur announces that a priority in long-stalled world trade talks must be the protection of European jobs.
Behind the sometimes vitriolic bluster on foreign goods and people lie fundamental questions about Western European competitiveness and the welfare state. Central elements of postwar Western European society -- like job security and extensive unemployment, social security and medical benefits -- are being re-examined even as the United States weighs an extension of health insurance to all Americans.
The reasons are clear. German wage costs, the highest in Europe, are now about 35 percent higher than in Japan and 50 percent higher than in the United States. This leads BMW to build a production plant in the United States, Mercedes-Benz to consider a similar move, and Audi A.G., a division of Volkswagen, to build an engine plant in Hungary rather than incur German wage costs. Each similar move costs Western Europe jobs.
Economists estimate that the overall burden of tax, social security and medical insurance payments amounts to about 41 percent of the total output of goods and services in Western Europe, compared with about 30 percent in Japan and the United States. This makes corporations think twice about plants in the region.
Recent research by the economic organization has revealed alarming statistics suggesting that unemployment has become endemic in Western Europe and that entrepreneurial activity is being stunted by the heavy costs to employers of the various benefits they must provide to workers.
While the United States has created more than 30 million jobs in the private sector since the mid-1970's, the European Community has created only about 3 million.
 
Job Growth in Public Sector
 Indeed, job growth in Western Europe has mainly come from the public sector, which has provided more than 5 million new jobs over the last two decades. But with most of these nations facing heavy budget deficits and taxation already high, further public-sector job growth appears very unlikely.
The Paris-based economic organization has also found that 45.8 percent of the unemployed in Europe have been out of work for more than a year, while the comparative figure in the United States is a mere 6.3 percent. This figure is viewed as particularly disturbing because technological change is now so rapid that the long-term unemployed quickly become virtually unemployable.
"If Europe is going to get anywhere close even to current U.S. unemployment levels of 6.9 percent, we have to become more flexible," said the director of Britain's employment policy institute, John Philpott. "The fact is that low-wage manufacturing jobs will go increasingly to newly developing countries where wage costs are low," he said. "Where we can compete is with jobs involving skilled labor and a high value-added content. But this means replacing long-term unemployment benefits with training and work programs."
The comparison between unemployment rates is not parallel, however. In Europe, people of working age and without jobs are counted as unemployed for as long as it takes them to find new work. In the United States, by contrast, unemployed people must be seeking work to be counted in unemployment statistics, so those who have stopped looking for work are excluded in calculating the jobless rate.
Alongside more vigorous and ambitious training, many analysts see a need for a rethinking of relations between employers and labor unions in Western Europe. Rigid relationships in which unions negotiate on behalf of tens or hundreds of thousands of workers in entire industrial sectors are increasingly seen as too unwieldy for a global economy in which the premium is increasingly on the speed and flexibility of production methods.
"A lot of the old industrial structures are obsolete," said Robert Skildesky, a professor of political economy at Warwick University in England. "The German model of a small number of big unions bargaining with employers, which is followed to a greater or lesser extent in most European countries, has produced very high wage costs and a lot of inflexibility."
That inflexibility may have been acceptable in a less global economy, but its cost is beginning to look prohibitive. Indeed, many economists believe that the current surge in unemployment has demonstrated that Western Europe stands at a crossroads.
Where the region relied heavily for employment on industries using the methods of Henry Ford -- capital-intensive manufacturing industries using a lot of unskilled labor -- it will now have to adjust because those jobs will increasingly move to places where such labor can be had more cheaply.
Instead, Western Europe must prove that it has the highly skilled and flexible labor force needed to be effective at the so-called lean production processes now being adopted by a range of industries.
 
Premium on Adaptability
 These processes put a premium on adaptability. For example, Japanese auto plants have cut the time for changing presses from weeks to hours. But in Western Europe, such nimbleness tends to be hindered by labor traditions of steady jobs, ponderous employer-employee negotiations and high non-wage costs.
Of course, the recession has taken a heavy toll on jobs. The European auto industry, for example, is in a slump not seen for two decades, with sales expected to fall as much as 15 percent this year over 1992. When a recovery comes, some jobs are certain to return.
But the number of those returning jobs may be more limited than in previous recoveries. At Moet et Chandon, a 25 percent drop in sales since 1989 led to a decision by the champagne manufacturer last month to lay off about 200 of its 1,600 employees. It was the first time since the crisis of the 1930's that Moet had cut jobs.
Philippe des Roys de Roure, the company spokesman, said the cuts were inevitable because champagne drinking slumped with the end of the high-rolling 1980's.
But asked if he expected sales to pick up again and new jobs to return, he said he believed that the next decade would at least be tough.
"People have less confidence in the future," he said. "The last 30 years were glorious for champagne, but I'm afraid that's over."
