HEADLINE: Tight-Money Tactics of Depression Era Return

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Federal Reserve Prepares for a Rate War" (Business Day, June 1) reports that the Federal Open Market Committee on May 18 gave Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Chairman, "leeway to raise short-term interest rates, now 3 percent, by up to one-half of 1 percent before the next meeting in early July."
If this information, leaked from the supposedly secret meeting of the Federal Reserve's main policy-making committee, proves correct, it strongly indicates the Fed's policies of tight money will continue at the peril of the United States economy. 
 While the prospect of higher interest rates is making headlines, an equally important story is being overlooked -- the Federal Reserve's campaign to tighten the money supply. For a year and a half, and especially over the last three months, the Federal Reserve has engineered money growth far below the target ranges that it presented to the House Banking Committee in 1992 (2.5 percent to 6.5 percent) and in 1993 (2 percent to 6 percent).
This year, for the first time since the end of World War II, the basic money supply defined as M2 was negative for an entire quarter of a year. Money growth corrected for inflation and population growth (real per capita money supply) is falling rapidly, just as it has before every recession since 1960. Raising interest rate targets now would mean slowing the money supply even more. And that would severely damage the economy.
The Federal Reserves's campaign of tightening the money supply now is similar to its policies in the Great Depression of the 1930's, which devastated our country for a decade. In September 1932 a majority of Federal Reserve governors explained why they opposed expanding the money supply, stating that they supported the "10th annual report of the Federal Reserve Board (1923) -- 'The Federal Reserve supplies the needed additional credit in times of business expansion and takes up the slack in times of business recession.' "
At the Nov. 15, 1932, Open Market Policy Conference, the Federal Reserve decision makers stated:
"All the members of the conference were of the opinion that there is no occasion to buy more securities at the present time. The question for the decision of the conference, therefore, was whether the system should now sell some of its present holdings or leave the account stationary."
In other words, at the height of the Great Depression, when 24.1 percent of American workers were idled, the central bank pushed for even slower money growth, though the money supply had already fallen. This lack of sensitivity to the plight of the average working man and woman is still difficult to fathom, much less accept.
Again today, the high priests of sacrifice and pain are putting out messages to the public that, regardless of the pain they cause, the Federal Reserve fears the mere possibility of inflation so much that they prefer killing growth to taking any risk that healthy growth might entail. But like their 1932 forebears, they ignore the damage their mistaken policy does to the whole country.
There are positive rates of monetary growth that are consistent with moderate inflation or none at all. It is too bad the Federal Reserve is determined to stop any possibility of inflation through a policy of slow or negative money growth. Let's not repeat the mistakes of the past. Sound money and sound growth are not inconsistent, incompatible or even impossible goals.
 
(Rep.) HENRY B. GONZALEZ
Chairman, Committee on Banking,
Finance and Urban Affairs
Washington, June 4, 1993

HEADLINE: JUNE 6-12: No to Colt;
Connecticut Gives Up Some Guns and Butter

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
A glaring conflict of interest in considering legislation is supposed to prompt lawmakers to excuse themselves from voting, but this one could not be avoided: Was Colt's Manufacturing Company of Hartford, 47 percent owned by the Connecticut state employee pension fund, a maker of assault weapons or not? Should the company's best-selling rifle, the Sporter, be banned in the state where it is made?
Last week, by the barest of majorities and with much angst on the part of some legislators, Connecticut said yes. 
 The new gun law, which was immediately signed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., made Connecticut only the third state in the nation, after New Jersey and California, to impose an absolute ban on the sale of a type of gun that the police say is showing up in greater numbers in the hands of urban drug gangs.
But it is surely the first state where legislating restrictions has required such searing self-examination about how the goals of economic development, urban social policy and law enforcement can fit together. Meanwhile, gun shop owners and distributors say that Sporters and other guns covered by the law, which does not take effect until Oct. 1, are flying off the shelves.

PUB-DATE: June 13, 1993

SECTION: Section 14; Page 3; Column 1; Summer Times Supplement

LENGTH: 1421 words

HEADLINE: CRUISES;
Running Away to Sea: A Brief but Shipshape Trip

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

 BODY:
IT was time for a sea change. Terra firma had grown too familiar. The little ad caught my eye. "Windjammer cruises from Mystic, Conn.," it said. "That's the ticket," I said to myself, and added, "Shiver me timbers." I have no idea what that means. Somehow it sounded right.
I called the number listed and communicated my interest to an answering machine that greeted me by saying, "Ahoy there." Presently a pamphlet arrived offering a variety of accommodations and departure dates on the Mystic Clipper. There were five-day, three-day and two-day voyages to choose from. We signed on for a weekend sail, sending off $518 for two berths. 
 Following instructions that came by mail, we drove up on a Friday evening, arriving after dinner at the pier in downtown Mystic where the Clipper was tied up. She was a 120-foot twin-masted vessel, and even in the dark I liked the cut of her jib, or would have if her sails had not been furled.
We were welcomed aboard by Craig Van dewater, the first mate, who told us we would be heading out for Shelter Island in the morning. It turned out he was also a bassoonist with the Nassau Symphony Orchestra. This happenstance is all the more amazing when you consider that the Oxford English Dictionary defines windjamming as both sailing a vessel and playing a wind instrument. I had left my O.E.D. behind and so did not learn this until I got home. I'm sorry I did not have a chance to talk about it with Mr. Vandewater.
 
Two Bunks and a Skylight
 He showed us to our cabin, one of six that shared a head down a gangway toward the bow. The head had a toilet and a shower with hot and cold water. Our cabin, the cheapest of the private quarters, was neat, cozy and functional. It was also very small, suitable only for two people who were quite fond of each other. There were two bunks, a sink, a skylight and reading lamps. Since my wife was recovering from a broken arm, I did not protest when she took the lower berth, and I set about practicing getting into and out of the upper one, which jutted out just a foot below the ceiling.
Eventually I adapted a version of a high jumper's approach and got to the point where I could almost get into bed without bumping my head or scraping my shins. Then I practiced sleeping.
That proved taxing. The problem was that I was kept awake by my concern about what would happen when I awoke. Would I sit up, as was my custom, and thereby risk a concussion or a bloody nose? The prospect gave me a lot to worry about, but since worrying has been a hobby for a long time, I was quite happy.
My wife said I did sleep, and on Saturday morning, I rose to the sound of ship's bells, the smell of pancakes and bacon, and a glorious sunny Saturday morning. My wife and I met the 12 other passengers and our captain, John Eginton. Like Mr. Vandewater and three of the remaining four crewmen, he had a fine nautical beard. Inspired by it, I vowed not to shave for the length of the voyage.
 
A Pancake Tradition
 By 9 A.M., the Clipper set out under power down the Mystic River. Just ahead lay a drawbridge. The crew gave out cold pancakes, instructing us to throw them at the man who operated the bridge. "It's a tradition," the cook said. I had read enough to know that it is dangerous to ignore tradition at sea, so with the rest of the passengers, I scaled pancakes, missing badly. The man on the bridge threw his own pancakes and came closer.
Once we reached Long Island Sound, Captain Eginton gave orders to hoist the Clipper's 5,000 square feet of sail. The passengers joined in hauling for a minute or two to raise the two larger sails.
It was not quite 10 A.M., and we were left to our own devices. I was eager for distractions. In a pattern that continued throughout the journey, the other passengers were mostly paired off in what appeared to be married couples. They were all friendly enough, but conversations tended to resemble the banter at a table of a wedding reception where no one knew one another: "The ship is very beautiful, isn't she?" or "Did it take you long to get here?"
 
Steerage Class, Too
 I chatted with the captain at the wheel, learning that on our course to Shelter Island we would be bucking tides and head winds. The routes, he said, were determined largely by weather conditions, with possible destinations including Block Island and Newport, R.I., and on the longer sails Martha's Vineyard.
I learned that the ship was nine years old and had been built in Rhode Island on the model of a Baltimore coastal schooner similar to the kind used by Yankee privateers in the Revolutionary War. The design had been adapted especially for passengers and was certified to take as many as 56 overnight passengers.
There were two other kinds of cabins in addition to ours: one a little larger that cost $269 a person for a weekend voyage, and two so-called owners' cabins, which have their own heads and showers, for $289 a person. There is also something like steerage class available in the dining hall, where 14 bunks flop down and can be curtained off to provide privacy. Such accommodations, which went unused on our sail, cost $229 a bunk for the two-day sail.
After chatting, I began scanning the horizon. We passed New London, Conn., and I thought of Eugene O'Neill, who grew up there and wrote of "dat ol' davil, sea." We passed North Dumpling Island, where we saw a lighthouse and a recently built, scaled-down version of Stonehenge. Mr. Vandewater told me the island had been purchased by someone who had playfully seceded from the United States, issuing visas and setting up his own currency, the dumpling.
We passed some cormorants and enough expensive-looking pleasure craft to make me wonder about my standing in the economic pyramid. We passed Fishers Island and in the distance could see Plum Island, where the Army reportedly raises and maintains all kinds of killer bacteria. I tried to hold my breath.
Then I lay down on a mattress on deck intent on reading. I read three pages and fell into a very pleasant sleep, awakening just in time for a lunch of crab salad. Like all the meals aboard, it was quite good and ample.
After lunch, I played Scrabble with my wife. We tried to use only nautical terms, but we failed. Later I read, scanned and slept. In the face of a stiff wind, Captain Eginton tacked along a zigzag course for Shelter Island, arriving to tie up at Dering Harbor. There was just enough time for a brisk walk through the tiny commercial center before all of us, crew and passengers, gathered for a steak dinner in the lounge.
The conversation continued on deck, but the sun and sea and relaxation had taken their toll, so we turned in relatively early. I seemed to be getting the hang of things, and I slept much better.
As Sunday morning broke hazy, I felt myself being drawn into the increasingly familiar rhythms of life afloat: breakfast, hoisting sails, scanning, chatting, reading, napping, eating and waiting to eat.
 
Fellow Travelers in the Mist
 Now the wind was at our backs, and we were on a much more direct course than on the outward passage, in which we were forced to sail 50 miles to cover a point-to-point distance of about 28 miles.
There was one stretch of the Sound where giant tankers kept looming through the mist. As I listened to their pilots give their positions over the radio, I noticed that our captain and crew were not worried. This, I realized, was my moment. I knew just enough about vectors to calculate the chances of collision. There I was along the starboard rail, silently and happily worrying as I mentally plotted converging courses and watched one tanker after another pass us at distances of at least a mile.
And so it went, napping, eating, reading, chatting, hoisting, more waiting to eat, scanning, and anticipating collisions and disasters. But in fact, there were no tragedies or dramas. It made me wonder what would have happened to literature if Conrad, Melville, Stevenson and O'Neill had known only such smooth sailing. No mutinies, no shipwrecks, no tempests, no failures of nerve, no crazed crewmen or breaching whales.
The Clipper returned to its berth on the Mystic River. It was late Sunday afternoon. We shook hands with our fellow passengers and the crew members, thanking them for safe adventure. We drove the 130 miles back to the city, and all along the way we could still feel the gentle pitching of the sea in our legs. After two days before the mast, home were the sailors, home from sea.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: New York Hotels;
New York City Hotels Battling the Blues

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
SEVERAL years ago, when Regent Hotels International decided to put up a 52-story luxury hotel at 57 East 57th Street, it seemed like a great idea. The New York economy was booming, hotels were commanding impressive room rates, and occupancy rates were high.
By last August, when the Four Seasons bought all the Regent properties, New York wasn't such a boom town anymore. The Four Seasons professed to be unworried. After all, the company, whose Pierre Hotel has been astriking success, would have its name emblazoned on a luxury property. 
 "This was an extraordinary opportunity to put our name on a global billboard," said Thomas Gurtner, the new hotel's manager.
Still, the Four Seasons opened this month into a sobering environment. Its 24-hour room service, I.M. Pei design, health club and business center will undoubtedly pique the interest of business travelers. And the remodeled St. Regis Hotel on 55th Street and Fifth Avenue, which many thought would be its biggest competitor, claims to have "exceeded all expectations" since it reopened 21 months ago.
But Stephen Alden, the St. Regis' director of marketing, declines to give occupancy figures. And whether the Four Seasons, at room rates of $295 to $3,000, will draw enough guests to justify the more than $1 million a room the hotel has cost is another question altogether.
"The return on that kind of investment is almost a mathematical impossibility," said Philip G. Georgas, regional vice president of Omni Hotels, which owns the Omni Berkshire on 52d and Madison.
It's probably cold comfort, but the Four Seasons will not be struggling alone. Occupancy in all hotels dropped sharply in recent years, and few guests are paying the full published rates. Hoteliers that want to bail out are finding that buyers willing to pay decent prices are scarcer yet.
The result is that most people who run hotels in the city are hunkering down for the long haul. They are abandoning their scattershot marketing, aiming instead at particular customer groups. They are asking repeat visitors for suggestions on how to improve their service and physical plant -- and, in many cases, spending millions of dollars to follow those suggestions. And they are rebuilding themselves and their sales forces, all in hopes that, when and if business does pick up, they will be in position to shine.
"IN just about every segment, from foreign tours to corporate travel, we have to work twice as hard to generate business," said Sam Haigh, president of Doral Hotels & Resorts, which owns four Manhattan hotels.
The numbers tell a sorry tale. The recession and the Gulf War hurt hotels throughout the country in 1991. But New York had two added things against it. It is overbuilt: more than 6,000 hotel rooms were added in Manhattan in the last five years. And the three-year-old 5 percent state tax on rooms that go for more than $100 a night has brought taxes on most New York City hotel rooms to a staggering 21.25 percent, effectively driving lucrative convention business to Chicago, Las Vegas and other cities. The hotel industry has been lobbying Albany to get the tax repealed, but so far there's no movement.
"Everybody we talk to has said, 'You are absolutely right, this tax has got to go,' " said Joseph E. Spinnato, president of the Hotel Association of New York City. "We're guardedly optimistic, but we've got to continue knocking on doors, seeking legislative help."
For now, occupancy and revenues remain dismal. PKF Consulting, which specializes in hotels, says that the occupancy level in Manhattan for the four months ended April 30 was 62.7 percent, only seven-tenths of a point above the 62 percent for the same four months last year and well below the 72.2 percent of 1990.. Average room rates were down to $135.36, 30 cents below the same period last year and $5.49 below 1990's peak. Although the second half of the year is traditionally stronger for hotels, and both occupancy and room rates will probably end higher (see chart), no one predicts anything approximating a rebound.
Payroll costs, meanwhile, continue to go up, with hotels struggling to meet union contracts they agreed to in more halcyon days.
"PAYROLL costs can kill profitability if a hotel isn't doing great," said Jeffrey S. Wilder, a partner in the Wilder Group, a New York hotel brokerage.
Not surprisingly, a lot of hotel owners would just as soon leave the market. But hotel sales remain few and far between.
The Helmsley Palace, which has been seeking a buyer since Leona Helmsley ran into her legal troubles, is on the auction block and industry insiders expect it to go for as little as $200 million, well below what it could have commanded a few years ago. Other hotels rumored to be on the block, including the Sheraton Russell and the Millenium, are barely getting nibbles.
"Lenders and investors alike are still pretty skittish about real estate in general and hotels in particular," said Sean Hennessey, a senior vice president and national manager of Landauer Associates' hotel division.
The few hotels that are being sold are going for a song. According to John A. Fox, a director at PKF Consulting, four years ago hotels commanded prices as high as $400,000 a room; today's buyers offer less than half that. And many would-be sellers simply do not have the option of selling at a loss.
"Sellers who bought or refinanced in the '80s have big mortgages that they can't cash out unless they cover their debt," Mr. Fox said. "Buyers aren't offering them enough to be able to do so."
Hotel owners readily concede that problem. Doral, for example, is selling "select" properties elsewhere in the country, but in Manhattan it is trying instead to restructure debt at its more-highly-leveraged properties.
"Now is not the time to sell real estate assets in Manhattan if you don't have to," Mr. Haigh said. "You just can't sell today for a price that lets you take positive equity out and still service debt."
Sales are a bit brisker outside Manhattan. For two years the Crowne Plaza in Stamford, Conn., was on the market, with an asking price of nearly $15 million; two months ago New Castle Hotel Corporation, a Shelton, Conn., company that specializes in turning around ailing hotels, bought it for $4 million. Now the company is looking for similar bargains in the New York hotel market.
"New York sellers definitely are getting more flexible," said David J. Buffam, New Castle's president.
Indeed they are. A group of Italian investors bought the Parc Fifty-One, now the Michelangelo, for $42 million last year; just three years ago, Park Lane Hotels paid $71 million for it. The bankrupt Prince George Hotel on East 28th Street sold this year for about $8 million; just two years ago its owners were still asking $20 million.
And a group of European and South American investors just agreed to buy the Collingwood, on 35th Street west of Fifth Avenue. The sale is rumored to be for about $5 million. Bernard Sillins, one of the Collingwood's owners, did not confirm that number, but says ruefully, "We got a lot less than we would have gotten five years ago."
In this troublesome environment, the niche hotels seem to have the best chance of survival. Later this year, when British Airways opens the condominium-turned-hotel that it owns at 127 East 55th Street, it will have a captive audience -- it is using it to house its own flight crews.
The Fitzpatrick on Lexington Avenue, which is owned by Irish investors, is doing well attracting Irish visitors. Similarly, Mr. Wilder and some California partners have been turning the old Latham Hotel on 28th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues into a half-youth hostel, half-budget private rooms for foreign travelers.
About half the hotel's 160 rooms are renovated and rentable, and Mr. Wilder says business is brisk.
But competition for niches is getting fierce. Manhattan East Suite Hotels, which operates nine hotels, has kitchens in most of its rooms, making it attractive for longer-term stays. Its occupancy rates are about 80 percent, well below the better than 90 percent in 1990 but still above industry averages.
PRESSURE on rates has been intense and competition has been heating up. The long-mothballed Sutton Hotel on East 56th Street near First Avenue has reopened as a long-term destination, offering 84 apartments for minimum stays of 30 days. And conventional hotels are modifying some rooms to attract corporate contracts.
So Manhattan East finds itself fighting to guard its turf. The hotel chain has started sending thank-you letters to first-time visitors, complete with questionnaires asking what else they might like to see on their next visit. It is offering corporations that sign contracts for at least 100 room nights a year a guaranteed rate and a guaranteed room at one of the other properties if their first-choice one is booked.
And it has developed a computer data base that will help it promote directly to regular customers. For example, someone who often visits at Christmas might get a letter offering a special holiday rate for next Christmas.
"Sure, we want new customers, but we are really trying to develop programs to retain the customers we have," said Priscilla Hurley, director of advertising.
But perhaps the fiercest competition these days is for the business traveler. Hotels like the St. Moritz and the two Sheratons on Seventh Avenue and 52d Street, which have traditionally catered to the leisure crowd, are now chasing corporate business. Hotels like the Vista International, which had marketed itself more to the domestic business crowd, is now chasing international business travelers.
Many of them have totally rebuilt themselves to go after those new markets. ITT Sheraton, which owns the Sheraton New York and Sheraton Manhattan, has spent close to $200 million to renovate both hotels. Much of the money went into refurbished meeting facilities and amenities like a fitness center. Now the hotel is actively marketing itself to groups like the American Society of Association Executives and Meeting Planners International, groups whose members can influence where their companies hold conventions and seminars.
"We used to be a destination place for people attending functions at the Javits Center," said Stephen D. Powell, director of sales and marketing for both hotels. "Now we want our meeting facilities to be the destination."
SO does the Vista International. The Vista, which once owned the market for Wall street-oriented traffic, has had to contend with fierce competition from the newer Marriott Financial Center and, to a lesser extent, the Millenium. Its occupancy, which used to be well over 70 percent, had been mired in the 60 percent range, as much because of competition as of the recession.
The hotel already had plans to transform its second floor into a high-technology business meeting center when the explosion on Feb. 26 in the World Trade Center garage forced the entire hotel to close for extensive repairs. The hotel is unlikely to reopen before late fall. But it is using its enforced hiatus to reposition itself in its market.
It is redoing its lobby and its ballroom and is carving out a new entrance from the nearby plaza directly to the second floor, which it hopes will increase traffic flow to its restaurants. And it plans to promote its relationship to the World Trade Center.
"That link makes no difference to downtown corporations, but in international markets the World Trade Center is an attraction in itself," said Jean-Claude Noel, senior vice president of the Americas for Hilton International, which manages the Vista.
The hotels that are part of large chains may have an easier time getting the word out. The Hotel Maria, on Lafayette Street near Canal Street, has been doing far better since it became the Holiday Inn Downtown and could hook in to Holiday Inn's worldwide reservation system. The new Four Seasons, too, is part of a chain that has 45 hotels and numerous branch sales offices around the world, all of which are geared up to refer travelers to the new New York location.
Chains with several New York properties, meanwhile, are looking for marketing synergies between them. Each of Doral's four hotels in New York used to have its own sales staff; now the company has combined them into one staff that will market all four properties. "We can't let our own hotels compete with each other any more," Mr. Haigh said.
The independents, or those whose affiliated hotels are widely scattered, are having to work much harder.
"We just don't have the huge advertising budgets that the large chains have," said Mr. Georgas of Omni Hotels. "We have to rely on long-term relationships."
Over the last year, Mr. Georgas has been asking regular visitors to the Omni Berkshire what they would like to see changed. He now plans to revamp the hotel, at a cost of $40 million to $60 million, to yield not only major esthetic changes, like new carpeting and furniture, but faster elevators, better air-conditioning and new room amenities like faxes and extra phone lines.
There are similar goings on at the St. Moritz. For more than a year FAI Insurances Ltd., the Australian company that bought the hotel in 1989 for $175 million, unsuccessfully sought a buyer for the property. About nine months ago it pulled the hotel off the market and began massive renovations and systems overhauls.
It has redone most of its rooms and public spaces. It has also taken a sharp knife to expenses -- for example, it has computerized what had been a very expensive and not very efficient manual telephone system, and reduced labor-intensive paperwork in check-in and check-out systems.
"We've just focused on every aspect of expense and brought the margins down to an acceptable level," said Ralph Stephenson, an FAI managing director who says that last year the hotel reaped an 11 percent increase in revenues and an eightfold increase in gross operating profits over 1991.
LAST fall the St. Moritz invited 20 major corporate clients to a meeting to pick their brains on what services they would like to see. As a result of that meeting, the St. Moritz has simplified what had been a polyglot of rates, so that most rooms can be had at ratesbetween $109 and $149 a night. It has put in a new business center and concierge services. It has strengthened its catering staff to better handle corporate functions.
Now it is trying to get the word out. It has hired people who are experienced in corporate sales and they are using telemarketing companies, direct mail and plain old cold calls to reach travel agents and big corporations in feeder cities like Chicago and Los Angeles, as well as New York.
"Sure we're still interested in weekend sales and big international tours, but for the first time our main focus is on the corporate market," said James Claus, vice president of Tishman Hotel Corporation, which manages the St. Moritz for FAI.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about New York City hotels referred incorrectly to the Latham Hotel. The building's northern half remains a conventional hotel, the Latham, at 4 East 28th Street; the southern half now operates as a youth hostel and budget hotel, the Gershwin, at 7 East 27th Street.

HEADLINE: Northwest Indian Treasures

BYLINE: By SUZIE BOSS; SUZIE BOSS is a freelance journalist who lives in Portland, Ore.

 BODY:
THE Cascade Mountains run like a spine down the backside of the Pacific Northwest, splitting Oregon into two distinct landscapes. The west is wet, a verdant rain forest. The east is dry and sunny, a sagebrush ocean washing across red soil. The difference in terrain seemed as clear to me as a geology exhibit during a recent 100-mile drive from Portland to the Warm Springs Reservation, home to three Indian tribes whose stories are intricately connected to the land east of the mountains. I planned to visit the Museum at Warm Springs, which opened in March to showcase a large collection of tribal art, and spend a weekend at Kah-Nee-Ta, a resort built at a hot springs on the reservation.
As Highway 26 crossed the Blue Box Summit, about an hour's drive from Portland, and began its descent off the eastern face of Mount Hood, the narrow, wooded view opened to frame a broad expanse of high desert. Clouds thinned into threads above red-rock volcanic columns. On this side of the Cascades, the air is drier, the light brighter, the horizon wider. Snow-capped mountains stretch across the horizon. 
 For 8,000 years, ancestors of the Wasco, Warm Springs and Paiute tribes lived here in relative harmony. They fished salmon from the rivers, gathered huckleberries from the foothills, hunted game on the plateaus, and wove native plants into decorative sacks and baskets, usually used for gathering edible plants.
Until white settlers pushed this far west in the 1800's, setting down roots on 160-acre homesteads, the tribes had used some 10 million acres here for fishing, hunting and plant-gathering. The Wasco and Warm Springs tribes gave up claims to those lands in a Government treaty in 1855 and were given the 644,000-acre reservation. The Paiutes, more nomadic than the other two tribes, moved onto the reservation 20 years later, after losing a battle for control of their ancestral lands.
The Museum at Warm Springs draws from a rich collection of native artwork, photographs and stories to tell the long history of the three tribes that compose the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs. The $7.6 million museum, designed to evoke a creekside encampment among a stand of cottonwoods, is the result of a 20-year effort to preserve and showcase culture on the reservation. Since 1974, the tribal council has spent more than $900,000 buying artifacts from families of the Warm Springs community.
As part of the design process, the Portland architects Bryan Burke and Donald Stastny listened to stories, visions and dreams shared by tribal members. The resulting design liberally mixes art with architecture, using a variety of building materials to suggest native symbols and the natural resources of the region. The building's unusual roof line combines elements of a tepee, a longhouse and a travois -- a sled used by nomadic tribes to carry their belongings. The exterior walls are of basalt from nearby cliffs and bricks woven into a basketlike pattern. The roof, of metal and concrete tile, reflects the sky by day, and glows under evening lighting.
At the museum entrance, I passed a quiet pool of water, then learned in self-guided exhibits that Indian ceremonies traditionally begin and end with a cool drink. In the lobby, wooden pillars branch up to the ceiling, mimicking the cottonwoods growing just outside. Art meshes with architecture in small gestures, too, such as the door handles modeled after feather bustles on a dancer's costume.
As I waited in line to pay admission, the woman working the ticket counter noticed that another visitor was wearing a silver frog pendant. The ticket taker launched into a tale about how, as a child on the reservation, she was cautioned by her grandmother not to tease the frogs "or our spring would dry up."
Storytelling, the heart of Indian life, takes place on a grand scale at the museum. In each of several permanent display areas, audiovisual exhibits use similar stories to teach visitors about daily life, traditions, songs, dances, medicines, and rites of passage for each of the three tribes. Artwork featured in the displays includes intricately beaded vests and headdresses, patterned baskets and colorfully decorated cornhusk bags. Exhibits draw from a collection of 2,500 photographs.
The centerpiece of the museum is a trio of traditional dwellings built by tribal members. The tule mat wickiup, or house, of the Paiutes, the Warm Springs summer tepee, and the Wasco wooden plank house are each separate display areas, fully stocked with traditional furnishings. One of the most elaborate presentations is a diorama inside the Wasco house depicting a wedding scene with two families in full ceremonial costume. A taped story describes the customs that accompanied the trading of goods between the bride's and groom's families.
Exhibits about early reservation life make viewers aware that the cultures of these three tribes have survived against great odds. From the 1870's, Indian boarding schools forbade any language but English, nearly silencing the native tongues within one generation. Long hair, considered sacred, was cut short when Indian children arrived at Government-run schools. For people who had built their traditions around fishing, hunting and plant-gathering, Government policies designed to turn Indians into farmers made little sense. In the 1950's, a hydroelectric project along the Columbia River destroyed Celilo Falls, the tribes' most important fishing place.
Today, a total of 3,000 people live on the Warm Springs Reservation; most are members of the three tribes or are related to tribal members. A tribal council includes the chief for each of the tribes. As a result of an aggressive economic development program dating from the 1950's, the reservation employs more than 1,000 people in a variety of industries: lumber, hydroelectric power, fishing, clothing and tourism. In summer, the busiest season for tourism in the area, the payroll can top 2,000.
After visiting the museum, I headed toward Kah-Nee-Ta resort, about 10 miles from the museum along a winding, two-lane road colored red by spring rains. Built in stages since the late 1960's, with a conference-wing added just this year, the resort hotel sits alone on a high bluff. A modern-looking desert oasis made of wood and concrete, the building blends well with its natural setting. Four floors of guest rooms stretch along the bluff in two wide wings. A large, heated pool outside the lodge lobby is a natural gathering place. An even larger natural hot springs pool is located half a mile downhill at a recreational area called Kah-Nee-Ta Village.
Kah-Nee-Ta resort offers guests a variety of well-kept accommodations, including hotel rooms at the main lodge, and cabins, tent sites and cement-floored tepees at the nearby Village. I had a comfortably furnished lodge suite, with a wide balcony overlooking the red-rock landscape and the bright green Kah-Nee-Ta golf course in the foreground.
Indian motifs are used throughout the resort, from the patterned fabrics in the bedrooms to the arrowhead-shaped layout of the hotel itself. The hotel lobby, built around a massive four-sided fireplace, features changing displays of native art by tribal artists such as Lillian Pitt, who makes ceramic masks. On weekends, artists often set up shop in the lobby. The gift shop offers a wide selection of art and jewelry, along with colorfully beaded knit shirts and woolen blanket coats made on the reservation by Warm Springs Clothing.
The Juniper Dining Room, which is just off the hotel lobby and has high wooden ceilings and wide windows, offers native-inspired menu choices. With advance notice, guests can order "bird-in-clay," the house specialty featuring a game hen baked in clay and then cracked open tableside with a wooden mallet, which the diner gets to keep. I didn't order ahead, but wasn't disappointed with the remaining choices: venison, rabbit, buffalo, beef and salmon, all accompanied by crisp Indian fry-bread and blackberry preserves. The menu includes a good selection of Northwest wines, as well as beers from small, local breweries. Because of the resort's isolated location, the large dining room fills quickly. Even with reservations, guests can expect to wait for a table. Service is attentive but unhurried.
Even in early spring, daytime temperatures were warm enough to lure a crowd to the hot-springs pool. By summer, Kah-Nee-Ta Village is packed with families using the pool, miniature golf course, bath house with tubs for mineral soaks, game room and a casual restaurant. Spring is a quieter season, with hikers following trails along the Warm Springs River and kids zooming on Rollerblades and mountain bikes around the Village. Summer brings a fuller menu of activities, including Indian dance demonstrations, river kayaking and weekend salmon bakes. Horseback riding with guides is offered throughout the year, weather permitting.
I divided my time between the Village area and a quieter pool at the main lodge, next to a well-equipped fitness center. After an afternoon hike up and down the nearby hills, where wildflowers were starting to blossom amid the sagebrush, I headed back to the hotel's outdoor whirlpool, the best seat in the house for watching a high-desert sunset.
 
 
 
IF YOU GO
Getting There
 The Museum at Warm Springs is in the town of Warm Springs along Highway 26, a two-hour drive from Portland. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. The mailing address is Post Office Box C, Warm Springs, Ore. 97761; telephone (503) 553-3331 . Admission is $5, $4.50 for senior citizens and and college students and $2.50 for those between ages 5 and 12. Those under 5 are admitted free.
 
Where to Stay
 Kah-Nee-Ta Resort is about 10 miles north of Warm Springs, on a well-marked road. In the lodge, double room rates start at $89.95, suites at $159.95. Post Office Box K, Warm Springs, Ore. 97761; (503) 553-1112.
In Kah-Nee-Ta Village, cottages range from $79.95 to $169.95; tepees are $49.95 for up to 3 people, but will accommodate as many as 10, and tent sites are $15.
 
Places to Eat
 Dining choices range from a casual restaurant and snack bar in the Village area to the more elegant Juniper Dining Room in the lodge, where reservations are a must. Dinner for two with bottle of wine runs around $50.

HEADLINE: U.S. Open: Towns Brace For 30,000

BYLINE: By JOYCE JONES

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD

 BODY:
TOMORROW, the deluge. With the start of practice rounds for the U.S. Open, an estimated 30,000 spectators will descend upon the Baltusrol Golf Club here.
For Springfield (population: 14,000) and its neighbors, Summit and Union, the weeklong championship will present a giant challenge in crowd control and a major economic opportunity. 
 For five years, officials of the club and the towns have been preparing for the event, the first Open here since 1980. "The good side," said Summit Fire Chief John Gerity, "is the large influx of people spending a lot of money in the area. On the other side is the extra workload worrying about those 30,000 people and their safety."
The scope of the event has grown dramatically in 13 years. The number of employees hired this year (2,500) and volunteers recruited (3,000) have both doubled. Some 1,100 telephone lines have been installed, versus 200 in 1980, and the expected press corps representation has soared to 2,100 from 350.
The impact is being felt for miles around. The United States Golf Association has booked the entire Grand Summit Hotel as headquarters for the event. The Hilton in Short Hills has been sold out for a year, as have the Governor Morris Hotel in Morristown and the Murray Hill Inn in New Providence.
The Summit Chamber of Commerce has organized special programs to encourage the Open visitors to spend time downtown. Bagpipers, a jazz band and the Banjo Ragtimers Dixieland Band will perform in the streets. For the first time, local restaurateurs will be allowed to set up sidewalk cafes. And a contest has been organized to urge shop owners to decorate their windows with golf themes; winners will receive day tickets to the championship. (A weekly ticket costs $200.)
Tomorrow will test the plans that Springfield's Chief of Police William Chisholm has been developing for months. "Twenty-two of our 43 officers have been assigned each day to be on traffic control from 5:30 A.M. to 9 P.M.," he said.
"It's a labor of love," said Springfield Mayor Philip Kurnos, referring to the time spent preparing to handle the crowds. "While the police will be working overtime, some of that money will be recovered from the $30,000 fees the U.S.G.A. paid the township in filing for site permits," he said.
Officers from the State Police and the Union County Prosecutor's office will also take part in traffic control, while at Baltusrol itself Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and employees of the Encore Security Group will be on hand.
Some 900 volunteer marshalls, members of area golf clubs, will work the lower course where the matches will be held, controlling the crowds. They all attended a three-day training session provided by the United States Golf Association.
Extra police from neighboring towns will help with traffic control. Some roads will be blocked off. Two main public parking areas have been established, the quarry in Summit and special sites at Newark International Airport. Shuttle buses will take drivers and passengers from the two areas to Baltusrol.
In addition, the Summit Chamber of Commerce and New Jersey Transit are operating a shuttle bus from the Summit train station to the golf club. To use it, a U.S. Open ticket and a train stub will be required.
Both the Summit and Union Fire Departments are supplying backup units for the Springfield department. "It's the most comprehensive plan we have ever put together," said Springfield Fire Chief William Gras. "We'll have men on a fire-safety watch at Baltusrol and we'll maintain a pumper on the scene there."
The Open has engaged the attention of many people in town government here, including Cinthia Weaver, an official of the Board of Health. Some 200 chefs will be preparing food in the so-called Corporate Village, a collection of 46 hospitality tents that companies have rented for $125,000 apiece. Ms. Weaver has been working since October with the Maryland-based caterer for the tents, Ridgewells, checking on plans for food storage and refrigeration; during the tournament, she will be monitoring the cooking temperature and other aspects of food preparation.
At Baltusrol itself, the years of preparation for the championship reached a crescendo of activity last week as the finishing touches were put on the course and convoys of trucks brought materials to the Corporate Village.
The man who has knit the various threads of the event together is Dick Miller, the general chairman and a retired Prudential executive. He oversees 50 committees and finds himself following through on such tasks as finding 900 accommodations for players and their families, golf association officials and the press. "It has grown so fast," he says of his volunteer job.
Another major figure has been Bob Ross, director of golf, a club professional and the manager of the pro shop. In a shop specially stocked with golf art and memorabilia for the Open, Mr. Ross was rapidly fielding telephone calls one recent morning. "Refresh my memory where I met you," he told one of the many callers seeking U.S. Open tickets. Jack Nicklaus, a two-time Open champion who will be one of the 156 players this year, says of Mr. Ross: "Bob insures the success of this championship."
Baltusrol has two championship golf courses supervised by Mr. Ross, the upper and the lower. Since May 3, electric golf carts have been banned from the lower course, where the Open will be played, and only members -- no guests -- have been permitted to use it.
 
Upgrading the Course
 Rees Jones, the golf course architect, was brought in to polish and update the lower course. He follows in the footsteps of his father, Robert Trent Jones, who upgraded the lower course for the 1954 Open.
The changes he has made in the course, Rees Jones said, reflect in part the improvements in recent golf equipment, including clubs and balls. He has lengthened the course in some places, adding six new tees and three new bunkers.
His goal, he said, was to make the course challenging for the best players in the game, but there were limits. Club officials wanted his changes to benefit their members' games, too. "A player like John Daly can drive the ball so far, but you can't design a course only with him in mind," Mr. Jones said. "You don't build a church just for Easter Sunday."
The Corporate Village is situated on the upper course. Some 20,000 pots of annuals will frame the tents; at night, six guards will roam the area to protect the plants from foraging deer.
The tents have 2,400 square feet of air-conditioned space, Palladium windows and landscaped patios. In preparation for the thousands of guests who will be entertained in the tents by brokers, bankers, insurance executives and Donald Trump, the caterers have stocked 11,000 servings of Hawaiian French toast, 18,400 eggs and 50 cases of kiwis.
In nearby Mountainside, the Hospitality Group of America has set up its own corporate tent village in the parking lot of a restaurant, L'Affaire. Sod has been laid on the macadam and flowers planted.
 
A Sense of Pride
 Beyond all the statistics and the elaborate preparations for the Open, those taking part in the event exhibit a strong sense of pride. Baltusrol and the Open are more than just another club, another tournament.
There are, for example, the traditions of the 98-year-old club. By the front door of the golf shop last week, a gray-haired figure was sitting, dressed in red plus fours, an official U.S. Open jacket and a straw hat. Newcomers sometimes greeted him: "How are you today?" They usually did not wait for an answer, which was just as well. Members call him Solly, and he is a most life-like mannequin.
Every time Marc Brody of Westfield drives by Baltusrol Golf Club, he says, he experiences "a feeling of awe" that U.S. Opens have been played there. This week, Mr. Brody will himself be on the course with the golf greats -- as one of the 900 marshalls.
Dressed in a uniform of black slacks, a beige U.S. Open shirt and a straw hat, he will be on duty at the first hole, in company with 30 other members of Shackamaxon Golf Club in Scotch Plains.
At the training session, he said, "The U.S.G.A. was pretty straightforward in telling us, 'You are not here to be in a privileged position to watch, but to make sure that the crowd does not interfere with play.' " Then Mr. Brody took a turn at practicing his job. Pretending to face the crowd, he gestured a stop sign with his hand, and said, "Quiet please."

HEADLINE: Facing the Problem Of County Gangs

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THE jagged scar begins three inches above Luis Cruz's left ear, clearly visible through his closely cropped haircut, and continues down to the middle of his neck. "It's a long story," the 21-year-old said. "We were young and thickheaded then."
It started with a squabble at school over a girl, continued with retaliatory skirmishes between two rival youth groups and exploded one night two years ago on a street corner on this city's west side, a crowded jumble of housing projects, apartment buildings and modest one- and two-family houses. 
 Mr. Cruz -- now a college student majoring in criminal justice -- was walking home with a friend when he was jumped. One of the 15 attackers, wielding a box cutter, ripped open the side of the young man's head and slashed through his back.
 
Time for a Truce
 The story might have been longer, and bloodier because a fellow member of Mr. Cruz's group, the Urban Ricans set out for revenge with a shotgun.
It was at that point, as Mr. Cruz recovered in intensive care under police protection, that members of the Yonkers Police Department's Community Affairs Division called for a truce among warring youth factions and an end to the violence, which has taken the lives of three teen-agers in the city, the most recent last week. The police suspect that that drive-by shooting death of Ticard Miller, 18, was gang related.
While Yonkers and other cities -- like Peekskill, Mount Vernon, White Plains and New Rochelle -- continue to struggle with escalating gang activity and to tally the resulting deaths and injuries, smaller towns and villages have also discovered that they are not immune.
 
70 Groups Identified
 Contrary to commonly held beliefs that gangs are a problem only in the poorer sections of cities, preliminary findings of the Westchester Task Force on Gangs indicate that as many as 70 groups with about 1,500 members are operating throughout the county. The report says that the gangs have been responsible for assaults, robberies, drive-by beatings and shootings in the larger cities and noise complaints, alcohol abuse, property damage and verbal harassment throughout the county. Others studying gangs, however, said that many gangs are organized to distribute and sell drugs.
In response to a task force questionnaire, Yonkers reported 30 gangs, Mount Vernon reported 10 and Peekskill said it had 5 to 10. Other communities said they had one or two problem youth groups, and many said they were worried about teen-age gangs coming into their communities from surrounding cities. The task force report said that drug-franchise gangs from Chicago, Miami and Los Angeles were not active in Westchester.
The task force report also said that the street gangs in Westchester appear to be small, independent and loosely structured groups that are territorial in nature. The average gang has 10 to 12 members who range in age from 12 to 32. The ethnic makeup of the gangs, according to the report, was 75 percent black and Hispanic and 25 percent white.
 
40-Member Council Appointed
 Only Yonkers reported female as well as male gangs, but in separate interviews officials in other communities said that they were aware of female members, usually girlfriends of the male members, in some gangs or youth groups. Some gang members who were interviewed said that girls carried their weapons for them because male police officers couldn't search the girls and lost time having to call in female officers.
The gang members said that when a fight was about to happen, the girls came to school dressed in workout clothes with their faces greased and their hair tied back to prevent scratches on their skin and hair pulling.
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke last month appointed a 40-member Urban Youth Council and charged it with assessing the needs of Westchester's at-risk youths in Greenburgh, Elmsford, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, Ossining, Peekskill, Port Chester, the Tarrytowns, White Plains and Yonkers.
 
More Aggression Observed
 "Every day we see evidence of kids who have lost faith in themselves, their parents, their teachers, their lives," Mr. O'Rourke said, citing the findings of the gang task force.
It is a trend that has left law-enforcement officials, psychologists and others studying gang activity and violence among youths with more questions than answers and with increased anxiety as summer approaches, when gang activity usually peaks.
The experts cannot explain why even in well-to-do communities the level of violence among youths has escalated, although they are quick to say that gangs in Westchester -- even at their toughest -- are not the same as Los Angeles gangs, which are regarded as some of the fiercest in the country.
But even in places like Mamaroneck, an upscale community tucked into the Long Island Sound shoreline, Police Detective Robert J. Reynolds said that he had witnessed "more aggression and more fighting among teens in the last year than in the last 10."
Sometimes, those observing the increased violence say, there are obvious reasons for restlessness and in-fighting among youths. On Yonkers's west side, for example, police officers and other officials cite one-parent minority families that are struggling financially, little supervision of offspring by mothers who must often work two jobs, too few constructive neighborhood activities and even fewer job opportunities for city youths.
Last year the unemployment rate for minority youths aged 16 to 19 was above 40 percent, twice the figure for all youths, reported Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist for the New York State Department of Labor.
Most gang members interviewed said their groups evolved from neighborhood friendships that began during the early years of elementary school. The Urban Ricans, Mr. Cruz said, were "clean-cut, hard workers in school and were never into drugs."
He added: "But other kids called us 'smurfs,' because we were short, and, if they called me that, I showed them I wasn't."
Another west side resident, Harold Morales, a 16-year-old member of the Lawrence Posse, said that most of the time his group "just chills or looks for girls" but members are somewhat confined to the neighborhood where they live, because outside of the area, "we got beef with other kids."
He added, "I gotta keep watching my back."
Two other west side residents, Noel and David Roman, 18-year-old twins and former members of the Lawrence Posse, said they did not look for trouble, but as Noel said, the group sometimes "got into small fights that became big deals."
Nevertheless, officials are hard put to answer why some of the most violent gangs in the city -- among them, the Hell's Kitchen Boys -- come from the well-kept homes that line the tidy streets on the city's east side. The more than 20 members of that group, officials say, are Italian and Irish from middle- and upper-middle-class homes, and some attend expensive prep schools.
Detective Sgt. Lorenzo Paul of the Yonkers Police Department speculated that the east side gangs were formed after the city's public schools were integrated in the late 1980's, disrupting the long-standing social order in the high schools.
"The upper-class white kids felt that they were no longer in control, so they used steroids and bulked up and fought back," he said.
 
Task Force Criticized
 Divisions of race, class and money are less clear in other parts of Westchester, like Mount Kisco, where Lieut. Robert Dagostino described his two-square-mile village as an "upper-middle-class community, with an urban mix in a rural setting." There, too, youths are hanging out on the streets at night, dealing drugs, and some have weapons. Lieutenant Dagostino blamed teen-agers from outside the village, "who take the train up on weekends and mingle with the locals," for most of the problems.
In New Castle, Detective Geoffrey Harisch criticized the county task force for using the term "gangs" too loosely and chose instead to describe the teens-agers in his upper-class community as belonging to "little renegade groups, not tightly knit gangs that kill for each other." He said local youth groups were responsible for graffiti and for petty larcenies that supported their drug use. The groups use marijuana, cocaine, crack heroin and heroin kickers -- "little packages that go for $10 a pop," he said.
Detective Harisch blamed outside groups coming in from White Plains and Mount Kisco for much of the trouble in New Castle.
In Scarsdale, Lieut. Robert F. Nicolais of the village police department said, "Criminal mischief and vandalism occasionally rears its ugly head even in this community." He blamed an influx of teen-agers from Yonkers and New Rochelle, who "get wind of parties in Scarsdale," for some of the problems.
"Kids have always done things," Lieutenant Nicolais said, "but the activity that we're seeing in the 1990's is a heck of a lot more dangerous."
Dr. Toni Collarini, executive director of the County Youth Bureau and chairwoman of the task force, said much of the gang activity appears to be related to the struggles of adolescent boys to define their self-image.
Or as Mr. Cruz said, looking back to his days as a member of the Urban Ricans, "It's about manhood, but finally we agreed not to go out and prove ourselves anymore."
Some experts, like Police Officers Victor Mendez and Joseph LeCoq in Yonkers, who work with youths and gang members, said the gangs -- or crews and posses, as they are also called -- provide members with a sense of family and protection.
But Dr. W. James Cosse, a Hartsdale psychologist and consultant to several police forces, said: "There has been a profound change. Gangs have shifted from banding together to define identity and turf to selling and distributing drugs. Gangs are now about business. There are enormous, mind-boggling amounts of money being made among youths in the sale of drugs and protection. It goes all the way from 'I'll watch your car for $5' to 'I'll watch your store to make sure it's not torched' to 'I'll protect you at school.' The banding together of affinity groups is classic stuff. The new forms are gangs as business enterprises. You'll find them anywhere you want to look."
 
Maintaining Close Relationships
 But if at the core of the gang activity, it is as County Executive O'Rourke said, a matter of youths who have lost faith in themselves and their lives, how can officials address that problem?
In Mount Kisco, Lieutenant Dagostino said youth officers are maintaining a close relationship with teen-agers and telling them that "drugs and violence are not the way to long-term success."
In Yonkers, Officers Mendez and LeCoq said that, with guidance, at least some of the youths outgrew the problems, and many of the younger ones at least had hope.
 
'I'm Too Old for This Stuff'
 Alex Alvarado, for example, a former member of the Urban Ricans who is now 20, has married and is the father of 1-month-old Yessenia.
"I'm too old for this stuff," said Mr. Alvarado, who works as a machine operator for a graphics supply firm. "If I take a bat, or worse, and go after someone, I'll be tried as an adult. I can't do that now, because I have a family."
And Reginald Rivas, 17, a member of the Elliott Troopers in Yonkers -- who recently had 40 stitches in his face to close up a knife wound and who rarely travels outside of his neighborhood for fear of further attacks -- said he dreams about the future.
"I'll probably marry my girlfriend Rosemarie, have two kids and live in the mountains," he said. "Let's see if I get attacked by the Lawrence Posse there." Mr. Rivas said he hopes to study nursing when he graduates from high school.

Both say they want to go to college in the fall. (pg. 4) (Dan Cronin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: United Way Reports 10 Percent Drop

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
CITING an uncertain economy, a smaller pool of donors and questions of staff misconduct, the United Way of Westchester and Putnam reported this month that contributions for the current fiscal year fell 10 percent short of expectations.
As a result, officials of organizations receiving money from United Way, an umbrella group that collects money for various charities, say they may now have to cut staff and possibly programs and turn to other fund-raising efforts to meet their budgets. 
 Ralph A. Gregory, president of the local United Way, reported that his organization fell short of its original $15.7 million goal for 1992-93 by $1.6 million. In mid-March, the organization -- realizing that pledges were down -- revised its projections and set a new target of $14.2 million. As of last week, the organization said it had collected $14.1 but was still hopeful that it would meet the revised goal by June 30, when the campaign officially ends.
During the 1991-92 fund-raising year, the organization collected $15.2 million in donations -- up from $14.9 million the year before.
 
Scandals Have Hurt
 United Way organizations nationwide are reporting that contributions this year are down about 3 percent, Mr. Gregory said.
He acknowledged that the current drive had been hurt by the resignation last year of United Way of America's former president, William Aramony, after disclosures about his $463,000 salary, lavish expense accounts and the financial manipulations that created a series of profit-making spinoffs.
Another blow to the organization's reputation came when Evol Sealy, the local chapter's former director of accounting, admitted last year to stealing $280,000 in charity contributions and was sentenced to a prison term of one to three years at the Bedford Hills Correctional Center. An insurance policy covered the local United Way's losses.
Mr. Gregory called this year's fund-raising campaign drive "challenging," saying that following Mr. Aramony's resignation, his organization, one of 2,000 autonomous United Ways, had demanded better accounting procedures from United Way of America, which is based in Alexandria, Va.
"We had to be able to reassure donors here that our house was in order," he said.
 
Other Factors Cited
 Mr. Gregory said that other factors affecting this year's disappointing results were the sluggish economy and a smaller pool of potential donors, a result of the continuing reduction in personnel by major corporations in the county -- among them, International Business Machines, Pepsico, Texaco, Kraft General Foods and Nynex. The organization solicits donations from employees at those and other companies.
Mr. Gregory, who said that "those who gave, gave more this year," added that even though there were fewer employees making pledges this year, the amount each gave was up by about 3.9 percent, according to the local United Way's statistics.
Each year, the charitable organization supports 127 local agencies on an ongoing basis and gives one-time grants to another 30 to 40. Among the regular recipients of United Way aid in Westchester and Putnam counties are the Red Cross, the American Cancer Society, the Young Men's and Young Women's Christian Associations, the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Associations, the Child Care Council of Westchester, the Volunteers of America, the Senior Personnel Employment Council in White Plains and the Nepperhan Community Center in Yonkers.
At the headquarters of the Red Cross chapter in White Plains, Robert L. Lenseth, the general manager, said: "Unfortunately, this is not the first year that this has happened. We've lost $170,000 over two years from United Way."
The Red Cross received more than $1 million from United Way's 1990-91 drive but only expects $836,800 from the current fund-raising efforts. The Red Cross's total budget for 1992-93 is $2.4 million.
"We're going to have to work smarter with less in the way of resources," Mr. Lenseth said. "Nonprofits are having to follow the lead of corporations and think thin and skinny, lean and mean."
He said the Red Cross chapter was considering closing its office in Yonkers, which was established in the early 1900's, and consolidating its central headquarters. He said that would mean many clients from Yonkers and Mount Vernon -- where the Red Cross serves 260 families, mainly victims of fires -- will have to travel to White Plains.
At the Hawthorne offices of the Mid-Hudson chapter of the Volunteers of America of Greater New York, which received $16,000 last year for its Runaway and Homeless Youth Network, its director, Catherine J. Marsh, said: "We can't afford to lose dollars for this program. It's going to hurt us severely."
The current budget for the Runaway and Homeless Youth Network is $425,000, made up by a "mosaic of funding," Ms. Marsh said, with financing from United Way and the state, county, Federal Government and private foundations.
And at the Nepperhan Community Center, the executive director, Mary A. Gaines, said: "I don't know if agencies like ours can continue to exist. We may have to close."
The center sponsors activities for youngsters, including its Read Now-Latchkey Program for grade-school children and pregnancy-prevention programs for teen-agers.
Mrs. Gaines said that last year the community center, which has an annual budget of $200,000, received $67,049 from the United Way. It also receives state and city funds.

The Economy
If the news tomorrow on May consumer prices is encouraging, as was the Producer Price Index reported on Friday, current inflation worries will presumably be defused. [Page D1.]

[A12.]

Japan's pharmaceutical companies have been living with Government price controls for years. Now, analysts say, the controls will get even stricter. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: State Comptroller Assails Dinkins's Pact on Budget

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall yesterday sharply criticized the $31.2 billion budget agreement reached over the weekend between Mayor David N. Dinkins and leaders of the City Council, saying there were "serious questions about its soundness."
The criticism by Mr. McCall, who has been in the job just six weeks, comes as a rebuke to the Mayor on several levels. Not only is Mr. McCall the state's second highest official and top fiscal monitor, he is also a longtime friend and political ally of Mr. Dinkins. Prior to becoming Comptroller, Mr. McCall was president of the New York City Board of Education, a Dinkins appointee. 
 Since the city's fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's, the state comptroller has frequently issued opinions on New York City's budget. But the comptroller has no authority over the city's budget, which must be approved by the mayor and the City Council.
 
Little Long-Range Relief
 Mr. McCall said that the budget put together by the Mayor and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone did little to provide long-range relief for the city's fiscal woes. Mr. McCall's criticisms echo many of the concerns that the City's Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, and state fiscal monitors had with Mr. Dinkins's initial budget proposal.
Under the plan agreed to by Mr. Dinkins and the Council leadership, spending will increase by $1.8 billion, a rise equal to about twice the rate of inflation, which is now running about 4.3 percent a year. The budget also calls for spending reductions of more than $130 million, which will affect services ranging from school buses to job placement centers.
Mr. McCall said that there were "uncertainties contained in the proposal for next year's budget -- too many for the budget to remain balanced for long." He also criticized the so-called one-shot revenue proposals in the budget, including more than $200 million borrowed against uncollected property-tax payments and the proposed sale of the Off-Track Betting Corporation for $55 million. That, Mr. McCall said, "is unlikely to occur as planned."
 
'Without Fiscal Stability'
 "Without a budget based on recurring revenues that fund recurring expenditures," Mr. McCall said, "and without fiscal stability in the long run, the city will not be able to meet its commitment to social responsibility -- to providing the social services and to fulfilling the needs of its citizens."
Mr. McCall also said that $150 million in Federal assistance included in the budget was not certain and that spending on items like overtime and the operation of the Health and Hospitals Corporation was likely to exceed budget estimates.
Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, said that the budget announced by Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Vallone was "balanced according to the strict standards used by the private sector." He added that the budget included a "significant downsizing of our estimates of the state and Federal aid that we expect in the coming fiscal year."
Mr. Jones said that many of the methods to secure long-term budget stability could be accomplished by state officials and legislators. Policies concerning the costs to the city of pensions, health insurance, workers' compensation and Medicaid are all controlled by the state rather than local governments, Mr. Jones said.
Several Council members and other officials said they interpreted Mr. McCall's criticism as an effort to distance himself from the Mayor, partly because he faces election next year. "He is trying to show that he is independent," said Marc V. Shaw, the Council's budget director. "But it's unfortunate that, rather than work with city officials and the Council, he's chosen to attack them."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Awaits 2d Key Index Of Inflation

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
If the consumer price news for May proves as encouraging tomorrow as the Producer Price Index reported on Friday, the second inflation scare of 1993 will presumably be defused.
The producer index -- what American producers receive for their finished goods -- was unchanged last month, after sizable increases in both March and April. This spurred optimism among many in the credit markets, where inflation is synonymous with danger. 
 Another positive report, from the consumer side, would be sufficient to push bond prices higher and to send yields, which move in the opposite direction, lower. Yet it is not clear if the relief obtained would be strong enough to bring down long-term interest rates to new lows.
 
One Cruel Month
 The first scare of 1993 began with unexpectedly high inflation reports for February, which were released in mid-March. It ended with mild reports for March prices announced a month later.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rallied on the good news, and the yield fell back to match the 16-year low of 6.72 percent for two days early in March. But that was only for two days, and no new mark was established.
For shorter-term rates, the easing of inflation fears -- again, if confirmed by the Consumer Price Index -- means that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise short-term interest rates immediately. This belief is expected to have the further effect of lowering these rates.
Still, yields are not expected to be drawn near the April low of 3.71 percent on two-year Treasury notes, because the specter of action by the Federal Reserve at some point still hangs over the market.
 
Confluence of Good News
 Along with the Producer Price Index, several other positive reports helped the bond market rebound sharply on Friday, and they are expected to help it this week, too. These include:
*A moderate increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in the core inflation rate, which excludes food and energy. Forecasters think that the Consumer Price Index will rise two-tenths of 1 percent, half the increase in April.
*A leveling off in the price of gold, the metal that is a traditional refuge when steeper inflation is expected. On Friday, gold, which had reached a three-and-a-half-year high of $381.40 an ounce in May, was down $3.50 an ounce, to $367.50. Its total decline for the week was $11.
*A drop in the Commodity Research Bureau index to its lowest level in almost four months. Seventeen of the index's 21 components were down Friday. The price of a barrel of crude oil for July delivery fell below $19 and is down more than 6 percent for the month.
*Surprisingly weak retail sales in May, rising one-tenth of 1 percent. This evidence of a still sluggish economy means that there is likely to be little effective pressure for price increases.
And if that holds, there is a better chance that consumer inflation will slow during the rest of the year, to a pace below the brisk 4.3 percent annualized rise of the first four months. Based on recent years, inflation has tended to rise sharply in the first four months and taper off in the remaining eight.
Nonetheless, some analysts and traders said Friday that they did not think the good news would drive long-term interest rates to new lows.
 
'Still Suspicious'
 "I think it keeps us in a trading range," said James S. Fralick, the principal senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. Of inflation, he said: "People are still suspicious and still concerned. These concerns have been dampened, but they will resurface later in the year."
Mr. Fralick, like some other forecasters, expects that the economy will be growing at a moderate pace of about 3 percent for the rest of the year, which will mean that consumer inflation will turn out higher than the 2.9 percent of last year. He said he remained worried about rising medical and education costs and thought that manufacturing capacity use had risen enough "that we are a little close to the level at which we would see some price increases."
The strong jump in employment in May, with nonfarm jobs up 209,000, is a signal that the pace of the economy is moving toward 3 percent annual growth, rather than the nine-tenths of 1 percent annualized growth in the first quarter of the year.
"The employment data point to solid gains in personal income, which you would expect to see echoed in consumer demand in coming months," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
 
Drawing Hope From Change
 Mr. Lipsky also noted that economic growth may not be as slow as suggested by weak retail sales. Sharp upward revisions for April, he noted, had raised sales figures to where he expected them to be for April. There could be another increase for May when those figures are revised.
Jay Goldinger, a trader at Capital Insights in Los Angeles, did not think that long-term bond yields would reach a new low because, he said, investors would sell their holdings on rallies. "I think," he said, that "we are in an environment of when you get a bout of strength you sell, and when you get a panic you buy."
"That, coupled with good inflation news could generate new lows on the long end of the curve, but not on the short end of the curve," he said, comparing credit instruments like 30-year Treasury bonds and two-year Treasury notes. "The residual expectation of a Fed-tightening rules that out."
 
On the Other Hand . . .
 But Mr. Lipsky maintained, "If investors become convinced that prices could be kept at a 3.25 percent rate despite a pickup of growth back to levels of 3 percent, then new yield declines are certainly possible and a testing of recent lows could not be ruled out."
