HEADLINE: Valuable Diploma or Meaningless Piece of Paper?

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
A year ago, Charisse Dangerfield, a cherub-faced 16-year-old from the Bronx, was just another student bored with the rigors of getting a good education. On more days than she can count, she shortened her misery by skipping math and any other classes she found especially dull.
"I was doing badly," she said, her words accented by the rhythmic smacks of her chewing gum. "I just wasn't doing my work." 
 But before Charisse was backed into a seemingly lightless tunnel between dropping out and being pushed out of school, her mother took a well-intentioned gamble. She enrolled her daughter in a program that would essentially allow her to skip high school by taking classes for a General Educational Development diploma, known in shorthand as G.E.D.
"It's easier than high school," Charisse said, adding that she is never given homework after her two-and-a-half-hour school days. "The teachers try to help you more."
 
Value of Diploma Debated
 Whether students like Charisse are making the right decision is a topic of growing debate among educators, as the city expands its G.E.D. capacity while some academicians question the value of its special diploma.
Nationally, the number of people taking the G.E.D. declined slightly last year, primarily because of sharp drops in Florida and New York State. In Florida, the decline is attributed to the disruptions of Hurricane Andrew, while in New York State officials cite a new $25 testing fee. But in New York City, where public school administrators have been aggressively persuading dropouts to resume their educations, as well as helping needy students get fee waivers for the examination, G.E.D. testing continues to increase, said Shelia Evans-Tranumn, director of the city's Auxiliary Services for High Schools.
Some supporters of the G.E.D. say that attaining the diploma -- which requires passing a test that includes sections on English, reading, science, social studies and math and generally takes students months to prepare for -- can greatly improve a student's scholastic skills and pave the way for college. But detractors argue that a G.E.D. diploma is far less valuable than a conventional high school education and that having a back-door route to graduation can distract some students who should be in high school.
"I wouldn't want my child getting a G.E.D.," said Lester Golden, director of high schools for the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, the union for New York school administrators. It is obvious, Mr. Golden said, that a G.E.D. diploma is "not on the same level as a city diploma or state Regents diploma."
 
Age Limit as Deterrent
 For more than 50 years, G.E.D. has represented a second chance at getting a basic education for nearly anyone who was unable to obtain a conventional high school diploma. Introduced in 1942 by the Veterans Testing Service, the program was primarily designed for Americans who interrupted their high school years to serve in World War II.
The G.E.D. Testing Service, which administers the test nationwide, does not allow anyone under the age of 16 to take the test to prevent students from leaving school too early.
But today, nearly one in seven diplomas, both in New York City and nationwide, is a G.E.D. It is increasingly being seen by some -- particularly those who feel trapped in poor, inner-city schools -- as a shortcut out of a troubled high school experience.
In the last four years, the number of students in the New York school system's G.E.D. program rose to 15,000 from 6,000, said officials for the Board of Education's Auxiliary Services for High Schools, which operates the G.E.D. preparation classes.
Susan Porter Robinson, director of outreach for the Center for Adult Learning, said it is "disturbing" if students are indeed leaving schools in favor of G.E.D. diplomas. The center is part of the American Council on Education, a nonprofit group that administers G.E.D. with each state department of education.
 
Not Intended as Lure
 "We don't want G.E.D. ever to be a lure for students who belong in school," she said. "This is an opportunity for adult learners who did not complete school to earn a diploma."
Nonetheless, Raymond Domanico, director of the Manhattan Institute's Center for Educational Innovation, said the potential benefits of earning a G.E.D. diploma are clear for students who have trouble with conventional high school settings.
"Students leaving with a G.E.D. are better having one than not," he said, adding that some go to college.
Mr. Domanico, a former director of data analysis for the New York City Board of Education, said he found that in the mid-1980's about 30 percent of the city's high school students had extreme difficulty handling the demands of traditional classroom instruction. For many of those youths, G.E.D. is a "better option than just dropping out."
But several recent studies suggest that someone with a G.E.D. diploma tends to do no better financially than someone with no diploma at all, and significantly worse than those with high school diplomas.
"It amounts to nothing in labor-market earning," James J. Heckman, a University of Chicago economist who co-wrote a series of research papers on G.E.D.'s last year. Referring to the test itself, he said, "it is not a challenging examination."
And the Army, the last branch of the armed services to accept G.E.D. graduates, last year stopped accepting recruits with G.E.D. diplomas because, it said, they failed basic training at twice the rate as recruits with traditional high school diplomas.
But G.E.D. officials discount the Heckman studies, contending that their sample group of less than 150 all-male G.E.D. graduates was insufficient to properly represent the benefits of the diploma. The value of a G.E.D. should not be "determined solely on a person's income," said Janet Baldwin, director of policy research for the G.E.D. Testing Center in Washington.
 
A Second Chance
 Despite the debate, the program is increasingly being viewed as an attractive alternative to high school in some neighborhoods, like the South Bronx. Many students, like Charisse Dangerfield, who have squandered their chances to graduate with their classmates, view a G.E.D. diploma as a safety net to rebound them into a productive future. And New York school officials count most young G.E.D. graduates as "successful completions," thus lowering the system's drop-out rates.
A student who reads at the eighth-grade level can take three to six months of preparation for the test, G.E.D. officials in New York said.
Ms. Evans-Tranumn attributes the sharp rise in G.E.D. students to several factors. As the number of dropouts has increased, schools have become better at tracking them and helping them find other methods -- like alternative schools and G.E.D. -- of getting diplomas, Ms. Evans-Tranumn said.
In addition, new waves of immigrants settling in New York have helped to create a pool of slightly older high school students with special needs who have turned to the G.E.D., Ms. Evans-Tranumn said.
And there are, she said, students with growing impatience who want "to get in college right away."
 
Largest Single Group
 About half of the city's G.E.D. candidates are 16 to 19 years old, officials said. Every year, more than half a million people take the G.E.D. tests in the United States and its territories. About 33 percent of them are 16 to 19.
It is the largest single group of students taking the test, according to 1992 statistics complied by the American Council on Education.
The city's auxiliary services counsels students on the best method to complete their high school education, its officials said. In many cases, students who had especially poor attendance and few of the required 40 credits to finish high school are encouraged to study for the G.E.D. test, Ms. Evans-Tranumn said.
"We have always gotten students who came from the worst high schools in this city, from the streets, from being homeless, straight out of jails, presently on probation," she said. "But in the midst of that, we've gotten the high achievers, who have come from the top high schools."
Many New York students say that their schools have become too infected with violence and drugs for students to learn, or that their teachers are too frightened or uninterested to teach. So some say they are considering dropping out and opting into G.E.D. classes, which tend to be smaller and more individualized.
"I've seen really sharp, young black men and women who were opting to get G.E.D.'s to leave school early," said Evelyn Reid, a professor at the Department of Curriculum and Instruction for Ohio University in Athens, Ohio. "What's happening in New York is just the tip of the iceberg of what is happening in other parts of the country."
Dr. Baldwin, of the G.E.D. Testing Service, which is also part of the American Council on Education, said a recent survey by her office found that nearly a quarter of students who drop out do so because they feel "disengaged from school." They are bored or unhappy, cannot adjust to school routine or just don't like school, she said.
"This cuts across racial and social lines," Dr. Baldwin added.
Indira Fret of the Bronx said she dropped out of school at 15 because of nothing less than sheer terror.
When she was 14 years old, she said, she was sexually attacked by a group of boys at her school. She was rescued from her attackers but was too terrified to remain in school.
Mrs. Fret, who is now 22, resumed her education years later in a G.E.D. program in the South Bronx.
"I wanted to be a flight attendant," she said, but was disappointed when she was told by a job interviewer that she must at least have some college education. After getting a clerical job in a G.E.D. center in her old Bronx neighborhood, she decided to enroll.
Today, she said, she wants to pursue a "career in computers." A high school or G.E.D. diploma is a requirement for the computer training course she wants to take.
She has been taking G.E.D. preparation courses for several years and has taken the test seven times, she said. But each time Mrs. Fret has failed to achieve the passing grade of 225 out of a possible 385. Undaunted, Mrs. Fret, who has a 5-month-old daughter, is preparing to take the test again.
"I hope to graduate on June 18," she said with a smile brimming with pride and optimism.

GRAPHIC: Photo: General Educational Development diplomas are increasing in New York City where school administrators have successfully persuaded many dropouts to resume their education. Indira Fret, 22, left, has gone back to school in a G.E.D. program in the South Bronx. Charisse Dangerfield, right, said the program is "easier than high school." (Photographs by Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Stock Traders Cautious Ahead of Price Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks turned in a lackluster performance in sharply slower trading yesterday, but key indexes managed to move a little higher.
Trading was cautious ahead of today's release of the Consumer Price Index for May, which may or may not confirm last week's Producer Price Index report that showed a leveling of inflation. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.68 points, to 3,514.69, with volume on the New York Stock Exchange at 216.2 million shares traded, sharply lower than Friday's 256.8 million. The number of Big Board gainers and losers were nearly even.
Other market indicators were narrowly ahead, including the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter issues, which rose 3.22 points, to 696.41.
 
 
Drug Issues Cited
 Anthony Ludovici, senior vice president and senior investment analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc., described the market as leaderless with the exception of drug issues.
Mr. Ludovici said Hillary Rodham Clinton's speech on Sunday before the American Medical Association in Chicago might have been a factor in moving drug stocks higher. Mrs. Clinton offered doctors "a new bargain" in health-care reform, promising to try to include prescription drugs among areas subject to less burdensome supervision if the association would support the Administration's plans.
In trading yesterday, Pfizer rose 1 1/2, to 72 3/8, and Schering-Plough gained 7/8, to 69.
Among issues bouncing back from recent selloffs, Apple Computer gained7/8, to 44 5/8, and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing advanced 1/2, to 109.
Transportation issues, led by airlines and rails, were down and under pressure, with the outcome of the economic package and the energy tax still unresolved. Delta Air Lines slid 7/8, to 52; AMR, American Airlines' parent, fell 7/8, to 68 1/2, and UAL, United Airlines' parent, lost 1 1/2, to 131 7/8.
In other trading, an announcement by U.S. Surgical that it would report a second-quarter loss put pressure on the stock as it tumbled 3 1/8 to finish at 26 5/8. Analysts cut their earnings estimates on the bad news.
Reebok International, which said earnings for the second quarter and the year would be lower than analysts' estimates, fell 4 3/8, to 30. The company said the earnings shortfall came primarily from United States footwear operations, where lack of new products in the basketball category, pricing and repositioning of the casual shoe line resulted in lower revenues.
Atmel, a manufacturer of integrated circuits, announced a technology licensing agreement for I.B.M. to sell a line of ultra-high-speed computer parts from Atmel. Atmel touched a 52-week trading high of 25, before closing at 24 5/8, unchanged.
 
 
Eastman Kodak Gains
 Shares of Eastman Kodak rose 2 5/8, to 53 3/4, in anticipation of a possible restructuring announcement today. The stock accounted for more than half the move on the Dow. Eugene Glazer, a Dean Witter analyst, adjusted his recommendation on Kodak to buy from neutral.
Goody Products, which designs and markets a variety of hair accessories, rose 5 1/8, to 23 1/2, on an agreement in principle with the Newell Company to merge Goody into a subsidiary of Newell.

HEADLINE: Intra-Party Fights Complicate Florio-Whitman Race

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 14

 BODY:
Jim Florio already has his hands full battling the Republicans in his gubernatorial campaign, and Christine Todd Whitman will be under constant fire from the Democrats. That's to be expected.
But just to make things interesting, both candidates also face nagging problems in their own parties that at best are unwelcome distractions, and at worst could undermine efforts to get the vote out in November. 
 Mr. Florio, the Democratic incumbent, has to worry about warring factions in Essex and Hudson Counties, two traditional Democratic strongholds where he must roll up big margins to stay in office. The Florio camp is intent on achieving peace and patching any cracks in party discipline.
The Essex County organization will elect a new chairman on Tuesday. But it is not clear whether that will give Democrats a chance to unite or an excuse to continue the fighting.
 
Leaders May Not Follow
 Mrs. Whitman, the Republican challenger, is in a more delicate situation. Her party controls the Legislature, leaving Mrs. Whitman walking the tightrope of criticizing the state of affairs in Trenton without jabbing her own party's leaders with the barbs. She showed how hard that can be right after she won the primary when she assailed the Governor for "cynically" discussing a tax cut during an election year. Turns out the idea was first aired by Republican leaders in the Legislature.
Moreover, those legislative leaders have been dealing with the Governor on a variety of issues for two years and are not necessarily ready to simply follow Mrs. Whitman's lead during the campaign, when all 120 seats are up for re-election.
This was brought home today when the Joint Appropriations Committee released its version of the state budget for the coming fiscal year.
Instead of a tax cut for the middle class discussed by the Republican leadership and the Governor, the committee's proposal now has a $150 million "taxpayer relief fund surplus." The Republicans say the money would be allocated during the coming year to help offset possible gasoline or other tax increases by the Clinton Administration.
Suddenly left without a tax cut to share credit for, Mr. Florio criticized the lawmakers, and Mrs. Whitman, saying they were setting up a political slush fund.
The problem for Mrs. Whitman is that she had nothing to do with the budget change, according to her staff. She did try to recoup today, however, saying the Republican majority's budget deserved support, and calling Mr. Florio's interest in cutting taxes "a foxhole conversion."
 
Tougher Fight in the Suburbs
 Of the two candidates, Mr. Florio seems to have the tougher road for now with the added burden of infighting in Hudson and Essex Counties. The Governor is hoping that residents' anger at the $2.8 billion in new taxes he pushed through the Legislature in 1990 will not become votes against him. He also has to hope that a Federal inquiry into whether state bond business was improperly steered to certain bond houses uncovers no wrongdoing.
Mr. Florio defeated James A. Courter, a former Republican Congressman, for the governorship four years ago by more than 540,000 votes. But he will find tougher sledding in the suburbs this time, said Neil Upmeyer, the president of the nonprofit, nonpartisan Center for Analysis of Public Issues in Princeton.
"The Governor will be very dependent this time on large turnouts in the Democratic strongholds," Mr. Upmeyer said.
In 1989 Essex County gave Mr. Florio 74,629 more votes than it gave Mr. Courter, and Hudson, Middlesex and Camden counties each added more than 60,000 for the Governor.
In Essex and Hudson counties this year, the Democratic chairmen denied veteran state senators a place on the organizations' endorsed slates of candidates in the primary.
 
Senators vs. County Leaders
 In one of Hudson's three legislative districts, Senator Thomas F. Cowan, a 16-year member of the Legislature, was defeated by Mayor Nicholas Sacco of North Bergen, who was backed by Bruce Walter, the Hudson Democratic Chairman. Mr. Cowan was supported by Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive.
In Essex County, Senator Richard J. Codey, a 20-year legislative veteran, won renomination with 62 percent of the vote, chiefly by campaigning against the man who pushed him off the organization's ballot line, the Essex Democratic Chairman, Thomas J. D'Alessio. Then Mr. Codey campaigned to unseat Mr. D'Alessio as county chairman.
On Saturday Mr. D'Alessio threw in the towel. He announced he would not seek re-election as chairman when the county's Democratic committee meets Tuesday night and said he would support Thomas Giblin, the Essex County Surrogate and former freeholder. Mr. Codey was still mulling whether to run for chairman himself, to back someone else or to agree to support Mr. Giblin.
Mr. D'Alessio, who is also the Essex County Executive, is under indictment on Federal charges of mail fraud and money laundering stemming from a fund-raising dinner.
 
'We Must Be United'
 State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak, the New Jersey Democratic Chairman, says he is worried about the splits in the two counties. "The problems are going to have to be settled, but they are going to have to do it," he said. "Any involvement by me would not be helpful." He said, however, that he would tell the counties "in the strongest way possible" that they had to put aside their differences.
"We must be united in November," he said.
Another possible problem for Mr. Florio is that Bret Schundler, a Republican, recently defeated the Democratic organization in Hudson County to win the mayoralty in Jersey City. He promptly announced that the Democratic Party could no longer take the city for granted.
For her part, Mrs. Whitman has to find a way to plot her own course in the coming months without crossing wires with veteran party members.
"She has a problem with her relationship with the Republican Legislative leadership," said Mr. Upmeyer. "Her initial remarks calling a tax cut a 'cynical' idea was a pie in the face of her own party's leaders."
 
A Matter of Trust
 "The legislative leaders weren't with her when she talked to the press," he added, "and they are not as unified a team as you would expect."
But Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian said he heard a simple, coherent message in what others viewed as a flip-flop on the question of taxes. "What she said was that she wouldn't trust Florio to cut taxes but she would trust us," he said.
Mark Herr, the executive director of the State Republican Committee, said it was important that the Republican Party "speak with one voice." That, he said, will become easier as soon everyone realizes there are only two issues in the coming campaign -- "the economy and integrity."
"The Republican Party is more unified than it has been in years, and we have only one person to thank for it: Jim Florio," Mr. Herr said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Mixed Views on New York City

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Two major credit agencies gave mixed reviews yesterday to the $31.2 billion budget approved by the New York City Council.
Both agencies -- Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service -- are reviewing the details of the budget, which has nearly $1.8 billion more in spending than did the budget adopted last year. But the agencies' initial responses, before a thorough reading of the spending plan, differed. 
 Richard Larkin, the managing director who oversees the S.& P. analysts following New York City's finances, said there were some disturbing elements in the budget, which is for the 1994 fiscal year that begins July 1. He said the agency would comment on its current rating of New York City's debt by the end of the month, but he would not indicate whether a change was afoot. S.& P. now rates the city A- with a negative outlook.
 
Improvement Is Noted
 At Moody's, Michael Johnston, a vice president, and Brad Gewehr, a senior analyst, said the city faced difficult problems in balancing its budget over the long term. But they both said they saw no reason to change the agency's rating because the new budget, despite its faults, was better than those of a couple of years ago. They also said that the end of the recession in New York City was improving the outlook. The Moody's rating is Baa-1, which is lower than the S.& P. rating.
Mr. Larkin said the new level of spending, given the current size of the budget gaps, "is not affordable on an ongoing basis." He said some of the one-time savings and revenue items in the budget were not likely to be there next year to support the higher level of city spending.
He said the S.& P. review would focus on "whether there is any significant risk to some of the projections and assumptions in 1994 and if it makes the future gap in 1995 and beyond any worse."
Mr. Johnston and Mr. Gewehr agreed that there were problems with the assumptions in the budget. But Mr. Johnston said that the economy, which he called "the foundation of the city credit rating," was "in the process of stabilizing." And of the budget itself, he added, "Frankly, when you stack it up with budgets done in recent years, it is not as uncertain."
Mr. Gewehr, noting that there had been sharp criticism of the budget as it went through the drafting and approval process, said that some opponents were saying that the credit agencies would have to take action, possibly by lowering the city's rating. But he said that this budget "represents a budget process consistent with the credit rating we have on the city at this point."
 
Financing Trump
 Donald J. Trump is coming back to the junk-bond market, possibly as soon as today, and selling $375 million of bonds, some of which could earn 15 percent or more for the buyers.
The deal, with Merrill Lynch as the lead underwriter, is in two parts. The largest piece is $315 million in mortgage notes due in 2001 to be issued by Trump Plaza Funding Inc.
The second part, which is expected to yield the 15 percent or more, is $60 million in payment-in-kind notes due in 2003 to be issued by Trump Plaza Holding Associates. Only $35 million of these notes will be offered to the public; the rest is going to creditors of Mr. Trump.
The payment-in-kind notes come with a warrant that allows the holder to get an additional $1,000 in principal for each $5,000 of original payment-in-kind notes.
With a payment-in-kind note, the issuer can make the interest payments by issuing new notes with the face value of the interest owed if the cash is not available. Under this deal, payment in kind can be made until some time in 2001.
According to Merrill Lynch, the price talk on the mortgage notes has them priced to yield 11.25 percent to 11.50 percent if they are sold at par or their face value. The talk on the payment-in-kind notes puts the yield 150 basis points or hundredths of a percentage point over the yield on the mortgage notes, placing them in the range of 12.75 percent to 13 percent. The effective yield rises to 15 percent or more if the value of the warrants is included, analysts say.
The bonds are all rated below investment grade -- the junk-bond category. Standard & Poor's rates the mortgage bonds at B and the payment-in-kind notes at CCC+. Moody's rates the mortgage notes at B-3 and the payment-in-kind notes at Caa.
Kingman Penniman, executive vice president at Duff & Phelps/MCM Investment Research Company, said his firm was recommending the mortgage bonds. But he said that if the demand for the bonds was so great that the yield could be cut below 11 percent, he would have to reconsider the recommendation because such a yield might not be enough to compensate for the risk.
His firm has no recommendation on the payment-in-kind notes, but he said they should be evalulated as an equity investment rather than a fixed-income investment.
 
Treasury Market
 Treasury prices finished slightly lower yesterday after a day in which most traders and investors were biding their time ahead of this morning's release of the Consumer Price Index for May.
With the report Friday that the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods was unchanged in May, much of the inflation scare of the last month has dissipated. If the consumer index comes in at the two-tenths of 1 percent that is expected, then investors will breath easier for the time being.
In late trading, the price of the 30-year bond was down 3/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 6.81 percent from 6.80 percent on Friday.
Following are the results of the yesterday's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: In Serbia, Sanctions Fuel Rage

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia, June 11

 BODY:
Under the green plastic roof of the central market, Desa Kukobat fumbled to make change for a customer, slowly counting out a thick pile of 100,000- and 50,000-dinar notes, once a small fortune in Yugoslavia. The head of lettuce she had just sold cost 50,000 dinars; the man, apologizing, said the smallest bill he had was one million dinars, which is worth only about $1.30 at today's rate.
"The embargo is suffocating us," complained Mrs. Kukobat, 53, a sunburned woman selling cucumbers, lettuce and potatoes. "People can't afford to buy anything, we can't afford to produce very much and the money is worthless paper. Why don't you ease these sanctions? We are not America's enemies." 
Like other people in this graceful Danube River city, 50 miles northwest of Belgrade, that is the capital of Serbia's fertile Vojvodina region, Mrs. Kukobat says she does not care so much about the war in neighboring Bosnia, nor about politicians' visions of a greater Serbia.
 
Harder Each Day
 What matters, she says, is that life for her and for her family becomes harder with each day, a grim reality resulting from the United Nations' economic sanctions enforced a year ago on what remains of Yugoslavia. For this she holds the West -- rather than her own leaders -- accountable.
Mrs. Kukobat's opinion is just the sort the most nationalist and militant political leaders in Serbia like to hear.
"This is what we have argued," said Maja Gojkovic, the 30-year-old vice president of the Serbian Parliament and a lawyer from Novi Sad who is a founding member of the Serbian Radical Party. "Instead of achieving their goal of making Serbia surrender, the West has only provoked the people's spite."
The most jingoistic of the Serbian parties, the Radicals won a third of the votes cast in Novi Sad in last December's national elections and now make up the second-largest block of legislators in the Federal Assembly.
 
Strengthened Hard-Liners
 Western diplomats in Belgrade believe that hyperinflation, currently running at an estimated 300 percent a month, and the continuing decline in production in the rump Yugoslavia have strengthened the hand of hard-liners who favor continued support for the Serbian nationalists in Bosnia.
Those problems may also have been a factor in recent moves by the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, to crack down on internal critics.
Goran Golic, a 31-year-old clerk in a bookshop on a cobblestone square in Novi Sad, said many people are turning to the nationalists for their answers.
"They have nothing else to lose, so why not?" said Mr. Golic, whose shop is filled with fading copies of fashion magazines, dating from the time before the embargo.
His colleague, Milorad Vlaisavljevic, 27, added: "The sanctions have closed the circle around the people, diminishing their energy and limiting their access to information. You must know this: The West is not punishing the politicians, it is punishing ordinary people, and strengthening the hand of those who are the most authoritarian."
 
Powerful Still Live Well
 Bojana Krndija, a 23-year-old university student, said that by imposing sanctions to pressure Serbia into ending its support for the Bosnian Serbs, the West is missing the point.
"I don't know how my mother manages to live," she said. "But I am sure the people in political power here still have a good life."
While the sanctions are the handy explanation for everything that has gone wrong, Western diplomats say they account for only a part of Yugoslavia's difficulties. A more important obstacle, they insist, is Mr. Milosevic's determination to preserve the old socialist command economy.
"For Milosevic, the problem is not the war in Bosnia," said Vladeta Yankovic, an opposition member of Parliament. "His trouble is at home."
 
A Scene of Plenty
 On the surface, life in Novi Sad, a regional market center of 179,000 people, appears untouched. Cafes and restaurants are crowded, the market stalls are filled with eggs and vegetables from the surrounding rural areas, and vendors on the central square sell everything from popcorn and ice cream on sticks to cigarettes.
But there are critical shortages of some goods, including soap powder and milk, and wages are not keeping pace with prices. The government monthly minimum wage for May was six million dinars, which at current prices will buy about six cheese sandwiches.
Last week, a Belgrade magazine calculated that if one were to borrow a million dinars today, it would cost 180 billion dinars to repay in a year's time, if inflation does not worsen.
Still, for many like Radoslav Vasic, a 27-year-old shoemaker and army veteran whose business has dropped off to virtually nothing, the sanctions and the economic decline are something good Serbs must endure.
"The sanctions will change nothing," he said. "No matter if you shoot at us, no matter what injustice you do to us, we know we are right."

HEADLINE: Havana Journal;
43,412 Stricken Cubans, and Not a Single Answer

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, June 12

 BODY:
On the 15th floor of the Hermanos Almeijeiras Hospital, the towering downtown complex that is the pride of Cuba's medical establishment, new patients arrive each day with a mysterious ailment that has left many people sightless and set off a global scramble to determine its cause.
Some patients with the disease, which has been variously described as optic neuropathy and peripheral neuropathy, writhe and grimace as muscles in their legs and arms flicker in and out of spasm. Others lie listlessly, their vision blurred and their other senses confused. Since the disorder of the nervous system first surfaced at the end of 1991, the illness has been diagnosed in 43,412 people, the Cuban authorities say. 
 In a sort of hysteria arising in part from fear and uncertainty about the disease's origins, countless others have shown up in clinics and doctors' offices to report everything from burning and tingling in their hands and feet to difficulty distinguishing ordinary colors, only to find that their symptoms, real or imagined, had nothing to do with the epidemic.
"For Cuban scientists, this disease remains an absolute mystery," said Dr. Raul Gomez Cabrera, director of the Hermanos Almeijeiras Hospital. "The one thing we can say with certainty is that it is very different from the usual patterns of epidemic."
So far scientists from Cuba and the growing number of foreign specialists mobilized to study and help contain the epidemic have focused on two possible causes for the disease: toxic or nutritional factors, or some previously unknown virus.
One baffling factor is that outbreaks within families or households, where people live in close contact and eat similar food, do not appear to be especially common, Cuban experts say.
 
The U.S. Sends Scientists
 In a rare show of American cooperation with Cuba, a team of scientists from the National Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta and experts from the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., visited Cuba recently to examine patients and take samples of bodily fluids back to laboratories in the United States for analysis.
So far the disease is not known to have caused any deaths, and it seems to run its course in four to six weeks, leaving most patients with minor damage to the nerves. Nearly 10 percent of the patients have lost their sight, however, and some suffer from a lingering loss of coordination. Because the disease is relatively new, doctors are not certain that such damage will be permanent.
As another patient in the same hospital room moaned from the painful spasms in her feet, Dianelis Sanchez, an 18-year-old woman from Pinar del Rio in western Cuba, said she had been sent to Almeijeiras Hospital 10 days earlier after her vision deteriorated and she felt tingling in her arms.
"I feel better now, except for the needle I got when they took fluid from my spine this morning," Miss Sanchez said. "I am not in any pain, and my sight seems to have returned to normal."
Unsure of the cause of the disease, Cuban doctors have been injecting patients with high doses of multivitamins and administering ordinary pain killers, both of which seem to provide some relief, even though there is no evidence that the disease is actually caused by nutritional deficiencies.
More exotic treatments have been tried on some patients, including ultrasonic and magnetic therapies and hyperbaric oxygenation, a treatment most often used for victims of severe burns or smoke inhalation.
Hoping to slow the spread of the disease, Cuban public health officials say they are distributing ordinary multivitamins to the entire population at a cost estimated so far at $40 million. The vitamins are not thought to be a cure, but rather seem to improve general health and increase resistance to the disease.
That it would occur to the Cuban authorities here to distribute vitamins so widely is a reflection of the plummeting living standards in what had only recently been one of Latin America's healthiest and most affluent countries. Especially hard hit is the Cuban diet, with is limited by strict rationing.
 
Little Resentment Evident
 Cuba's economic decline has resulted mainly from the collapse of the Soviet bloc and a three-decade American embargo. But the suffering has been aggravated by fierce storms that have destroyed crops and interrupted work on tourist hotels that were a leading economic priority.
Soon after it became apparent that it had a major epidemic on its hands that would require international help, President Fidel Castro's Government seemed worried about the possibility that citizens would blame their leaders for the problem. Initially the Government even hinted that the illness could be the work of foreign sabotage.
But there has been little evidence of strong resentment toward the Government over the outbreak itself. Health care is one of the few areas in which Havana has been able to maintain standards comparable to those that existed before the country's economic crisis began three years ago.
One hypothesis is that substitutes used by individuals or state-owned producers for ordinary food ingredients have had a toxic effect. Because of the shortages, soy products are often substituted for meat, for example, and alcoholic beverages are often brewed at home.
Even more worrying to many medical experts, some of whom who draw comparisons to the sudden appearance of AIDS, is the possibility of a new or recently mutated virus that could conceivably spread to other countries and affect health in ways that are still unknown.
"There is enormous work to be done here before getting to the bottom of this, and the Cubans are in no position to do it all on their own," said Dr. Miguel Marquez, resident director of the Pan American Health Organization. "No one knows where this thing could appear next, or if we will be seeing deaths from it down the road."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Ends Down Slightly; Energy Prices Are Also Off

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices continued their retreat yesterday until a late rally erased most of the loss and left traders uncertain about gold's underlying strengths.
"We're looking to see where this correction will end," said Dinsa Mehta, chief bullion dealer at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. 
 The gold market has been in a general decline since late last month when it reached a 28-month high of $384.50.
When gold trading opened at the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday, there was a renewal of last week's selloff, attributed to the Producer Price Index and other economic measures showing little inflationary pressure.
"But then the market found some new buying and it zoomed up five bucks on the close," Mr. Mehta said. "We're still uncertain what this means, but it looks like $360 is the lower level for this market."
By the end of the day, gold for August delivery, the most actively traded contract, was down 80 cents, settling at $365.30 a troy ounce after being as low as $361.70. Silver, meanwhile, advanced, with July silver rising 2.5 cents, to $4.218 a troy ounce.
Another analyst, William O'Neill of Merrill Lynch Futures in New York, was not much impressed with the late rebound in gold.
"I'd call the recovery today a dead cat bounce," he said. "The short-term trading trend is still negative," he said. "That doesn't mean the market will drop to the March lows of $325, but there is room for further declines."
Gold analysts said they were awaiting the Government report today on consumer prices in May, which is expected to throw some further light on the prospects for inflation and the price of gold.
Separately, most energy futures were lower at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Light sweet crude oil for July delivery lost 9 cents and settled at $18.89 a barrel; July heating oil was 0.56 cent lower at 52.45 cents a gallon; July gasoline was 0.07 cent lower at 54.54 cents a gallon, and July natural gas was 2.2 cents higher at $2.200 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: An Employer Loses Ruling On Pensions

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The Supreme Court unanimously upheld today the constitutionality of the Federal pension law that requires employers to make good on their financial obligations when they withdraw from an industrywide pension plan.
The case was an important test of the law Congress passed 13 years ago to remove employers' incentives to avoid financial liability by pulling out of weak pension plans. 
 The employer in this case, a California-based manufacturer of concrete pipes, told the Court that its withdrawal liability would consume 46 percent of its net worth. It argued that the assessment violated its constitutional right to due process of law and was an unconstitutional taking of its property without compensation.
Writing for the Court today, Justice David H. Souter said that the liability imposed by the law, the Multiemployer Pension Plan Amendments Act of 1980, met the test of due process as a "clearly rational" form of economic regulation. On the property issue, he wrote, "Our cases have long established that mere diminution in the value of property, however serious, is insufficient to demonstrate a taking."
The decision, Concrete Pipe and Products of California v. Construction Laborers Pension Trust, No. 91-904, upheld a 1991 decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco.
The multiemployer pension law was passed as an amendment to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, known as Erisa, the basic Federal law regulating employers' pension obligations. The amendment addressed specific problems facing industrywide pension plans, which are common in industries composed of small employers whose workers move from job to job within the same trade.
While in theory, these pension plans offer stability and risk-sharing for employers and portability for employees, they have been beset by problems of underfinancing. When the law was passed to impose withdrawal liability on employers who leave such plans, the condition of these already weak plans was being weakened further by employer flight.
Under the 1980 law, employers who leave a plan must pay their proportionate share of the plan's unfinanced vested benefits. Calculating that obligation can be highly contentious, and the law created a system requiring deference to the judgments of the plan's trustees, usually a joint labor-management committee.
One of the employer's constitutional arguments in this case was that because trustees are obliged to consider the health of the plan as a whole, the system creates a built-in bias toward imposing the maximum liability on any single employer who withdraws. Justice Souter, however, said that this feature of the law did not make it unconstitutional.
In several earlier cases, the Court had upheld the constitutionality of the multiemployer law as a general matter without examining its operation in the detail provided by this case. One of Concrete Pipe's arguments was that the law was so burdensome as to be unconstitutional in its specific application even if constitutional as an abstract matter.
 
Banks and Insurance
 The Court without comment refused today to hear an appeal from a ruling that the Comptroller of the Currency lacked authority to permit national banks to sell title insurance and other specialized forms of insurance.
The case involved a 77-year-old Federal banking law known as Section 92, which the Court dealt with in a separate case a week ago in ruling that the section remained valid despite having been inadvertently omitted from the compilation of Federal laws more than 45 years ago.
Section 92 permits banks in cities with fewer than 5,000 people to sell insurance. The case before the Court today began as a challenge by the title insurance industry to a 1989 decision by the Comptroller of the Currency permitting the Chase Manhattan Bank to sell title insurance.
Chase Manhattan is obviously in a city of more than 5,000 people; the Comptroller relied for his regulatory decision on another section of the banking law permitting national banks to exercise "all such incidental powers" as are necessary to carry on the business of banking.
Rejecting the Comptroller's regulation, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, had ruled that Section 92 had an implicit bar against broader activities by banks situated in large cities. The Federal Government, as well as Chase, appealed the ruling to the Supreme Court. The Second Circuit's decision "calls into question a variety of activities performed by national banks," the Government's brief said.
The appeals the Justices turned down today were Chase Manhattan Bank v. American Land Title, No. 92-482, and Ludwig v. American Land Title, No. 92-645.

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices to Decide if a Federal Law Protects Abortion Clinics From Protests

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether abortion clinics can invoke a Federal racketeering law to sue anti-abortion groups that organize demonstrations and blockades intended to shut down the clinics.
The Justices accepted an appeal filed by the National Organization for Women, which tried to use the law, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, to sue several anti-abortion groups on behalf of abortion clinics in Delaware and Wisconsin. The organization sought to prove that the groups had formed a nationwide conspiracy to eliminate access to abortion by using extortion and intimidation to drive the clinics out of business. 
 Two lower Federal courts dismissed the lawsuit on the ground that the racketeering law, usually known as RICO, does not apply in the absence of "economic motivation." The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, called the demonstrators' actions "reprehensible" but said that "noneconomic crimes committed in furtherance of noneconomic motives" were not covered by the racketeering law.
The Clinton Administration, asked by the Justices for its views on the case, told the Court that the lower courts had interpreted the law in too "narrow and grudging" a way. In a brief filed last month, the Administration urged the Supreme Court to grant the appeal and to rule that the racketeering law should apply in the abortion clinic context. The case will be argued next fall.
 
Second Case on Clinics
 The case brings the issue of protests at abortion clinics back to the Court only months after the Justices rejected the use of another law, a Reconstruction-era civil rights law known as the Ku Klux Klan Act, which some lower courts had invoked to protect clinics against violent protests. A bill to overturn that ruling has been introduced in Congress.
The Bush Administration had entered the earlier case on behalf of Operation Rescue, one of the main clinic protest groups and a defendant in the new case, along with the Pro-Life Action League, the Pro-Life Direct Action League and leaders of the groups.
Because the racketeering law is such a powerful legal weapon, providing for triple damages and other heavy penalties for running an "enterprise" through a "pattern of racketeering activity," abortion clinics across the country have tried to use it. The lower Federal courts have been split over whether the law is limited to economically motivated conspiracies, like the infiltration of a legitimate business by organized crime.
 
Little Prior Action
 In answering that question, the Supreme Court's decision in this case, NOW v. Scheidler, No. 92-780, could provide an important interpretation of the racketeering law beyond the abortion clinic context. In past decisions interpreting the law, the Court has expressed unease over the expansive use of the law, which has been widely used in ordinary business disputes far removed from its origin as a weapon against organized crime. But the Court has generally taken the position that any limitations should come from Congress and not the courts.
In its brief, the Clinton Administration said that the economic motive requirement adopted by the Court of Appeals posed "serious definitional problems," because the analysis left it "entirely unclear" how to draw the line between an economically motivated conspiracy that would be covered by the law and a politically motivated one that would not be. Political protests can serve incidentally to attract members and contributions, the brief said.
There were also these developments at the Court today:
 
Set-Aside Programs
 The Court ruled that white contractors could sue to challenge Federal programs that set aside a portion of public works contracts for minority-owned businesses.
The decision, written by Justice Clarence Thomas, reinstated a constitutional challenge brought by a group of white contractors to a minority set-aside ordinance in Jacksonville, Fla. The 7-to-2 decision overturned a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, which had held that the white contractors lacked legal standing to sue because they could not demonstrate that they would have been able to bid successfully for the contracts from which the program excluded them.
In their underlying lawsuit, the contractors, members of the Northeastern Florida Chapter of the Associated General Contractors of America, argued that by reserving a portion of public works contracts for minorities, the city was violating the equal protection principle announced by the Supreme Court in a similar case from Richmond. The Court today did not deal with that question, which will be addressed by the lower courts now that the lawsuit has been reinstated.
In his opinion, Northeastern Florida Contractors v. Jacksonville, No. 91-1721, Justice Thomas said the appeals court had misconceived the question of standing by requiring the contractors to show that they would actually have been awarded a contract if permitted to compete. The contractors' injury, he said, "is the inability to compete on an equal footing in the bidding process, not the loss of a contract."
Justice Thomas noted that in the case of Alan Bakke 15 years ago, the Court permitted a lawsuit by Mr. Bakke, a white applicant to a California state medical school, without requiring him to show that he would been admitted had 16 of the 100 places not been reserved for minorities. Mr. Bakke's injury was being denied the chance to compete for all the places, the Justice said.
The two dissenting Justices, Sandra Day O'Connor and Harry A. Blackmun, did not address the merits of the question over standing. Rather, they said the Court should have dismissed the case as moot because Jacksonville modified its ordinance last fall, shortly after the Court agreed to hear the contractors' appeal.
The ruling today is likely to be important beyond the context of challenges to set-aside programs. At issue more generally is an individual's right to sue the government over the administration of a benefit program without being able to show that he or she would have actually obtained the benefit. Several liberal groups including Public Citizen, the American Civil Liberties Union, and the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Educational Fund filed briefs in this case, warning that the lower court's limited view of standing would close the courthouse doors to many lawsuits of this type.
 
Double Jeopardy
 The Court agreed to decide whether the constitutional protection against double jeopardy applies to a proceeding to determine whether a someone convicted of a crime should receive a longer sentence as a persistent offender.
The case, Caspari v. Bohlen, No. 92-1500, is an appeal by the State of Missouri of a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis. The appeals court ruled that a man convicted of robbery, and sentenced as a repeat offender in a faulty sentencing hearing, could not be subjected to a new sentencing hearing without violating his right against double jeopardy.
The appeals court based its ruling on an earlier Supreme Court decision that invoked the double jeopardy clause to bar a second death sentence proceeding in a case in which a death sentence has once been set aside. One question in the new case is whether the Court will limit that principle to death penalty cases.
